    "Accrued benefit" means the monthly normal retirement benefit that a member has accrued as of any given date, based on the normal retirement benefit formula in Section 2.64.120 and the member's average monthly compensation and years of service as of such date. 
    "Actuarial equivalent" means a benefit of equal actuarial amount when adjusted for the form of payment or the timing of payments by the actuary for the plan in accordance with the following actuarial assumptions: 
1.  Interest: six percent per annum, compounded annually; and 
2.  Mortality: the 1984 Unisex Pension Mortality Table. 
    "Actuary" means the actuary who is selected from time to time by the board of trustees. 
    "Anniversary date" means the first day of the fiscal year of the city, which, as of October 1, 1990, is October 1. 
    "Average monthly compensation" means the average of the member's actual monthly base compensation during the member's thirty-six (36) consecutive full months of service that produces the highest average out of the sixty (60) consecutive months of service that precede the member's retirement or other termination of employment. If the member has less than thirty-six (36) months of employment his or her average monthly compensation shall be based on his or her actual months of employment. 
    "Beneficiary" means the person or persons designated by a member to receive any return of employee contributions which may be payable hereunder at the member's death pursuant to Section 2.64.200 and/or to receive payment of a member's DROP account which may be payable hereunder at the member's death pursuant to Section 2.64.330. 
    "Compensation" means regular base salary excluding remuneration for overtime, shift differentials or any other type of special or extraordinary compensation from the city, or effective October 6, 2012, and for a member who is compensated on an hourly rate basis means such member's regular hourly rate of compensation excluding remuneration for overtime, shift differentials and any other type of special or extraordinary compensation from the city. A member's compensation shall be subject, if applicable, to the limitations on the compensation that may be recognized pursuant to Section 401(a)(17) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code and the rulings and regulations thereunder. If a member is in qualified military service, as defined in Section 414(u)(5) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code, the member shall be treated as receiving compensation from the city during such period of qualified military service equal to: 
1.  The compensation the member would have received during such period if the member were not in qualified military service, determined based on the rate of pay the member would have received from the city, but for his or her absence during the period of qualified military service; or 
2.  If the compensation the member would have received during such period was not reasonably certain, the member's average compensation from the city during the twelve-month period immediately preceding commencement of the qualified military service (or, if shorter, the entire period of employment immediately preceding commencement of the member's qualified military service). 
    "Direct rollover" means a payment by the plan to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. 
    "DROP account" means the retirement fund's bookkeeping account for deferred retirement option provision accounts which shall be maintained by the retirement fund pursuant to Section 2.64.330 and included in the annual actuarial valuation and report required by Section 2.64.210. 
    "Eligible retirement plan" means an individual retirement account described in Federal Internal Revenue Code § 408(a), an individual retirement annuity described in Federal Internal Revenue Code § 408(b), an annuity plan described in Code § 403(a), or a qualified trust described in Federal Internal Revenue Code § 401(a), which accepts the Participant's or alternate payee's eligible rollover distribution. However, in the case of eligible rollover distribution to the surviving spouse, an eligible retirement plan is either an individual retirement account or individual retirement annuity. An eligible retirement plan shall also mean an annuity contract described in Section 403(b) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code and an eligible plan under Section 457(b) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or political subdivision of a state and which agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into such plan from this plan. The definition of eligible retirement plan shall also apply in the case of a distribution to a surviving spouse, or to a spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under a qualified domestic relation order, as defined in Section 414(p) of the Code. 
    "Eligible rollover distribution" shall have the meaning set forth in Section 2.64.350. 
    "Full-time police officer or firefighter" means a police officer or firefighter classified by the city as a full-time employee because he is hired to work more than 1500 hours per year. 
    "Mandatory retirement age" means age sixty-five (65), as specified in Section 2.64.080. 
    "Member" means a police officer or firefighter of the city, who is eligible to participate in the retirement fund in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.64.050. 
    "Normal retirement age" means the age specified in Section 2.64.080. 
    "Normal retirement date" means the date specified in Section 2.64.080. 
    "Part-time police officer or firefighter" means a police officer or firefighter classified by the city as a part-time employee because he is hired to work 1500 hours or less per year. 
    "Plan year" shall mean the fiscal year of the city, which, as of October 1, 1990, is October 1st to September 30th. 
    "Retirement fund" means the city, police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund maintained by the city pursuant to this chapter. 
    "Salary" means regular base salary and excludes remuneration for overtime, shift differentials or any other type of special or extraordinary compensation from the city, subject, if applicable to the limitations on the salary that may be recognized pursuant to Section 401 (a)(17) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code and the rulings and regulations thereunder. If a member is in qualified military service, as defined in Section 414(u)(5) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code, he shall be treated as receiving salary from the city during such period of qualified military service equal to: 
1.  The salary the member would have received during such period if the member were not in qualified military service, determined based on the rate of pay the member would have received from the city, but for his absence during the period of qualified military service; or 
2.  If the salary the member would have received during such period was not reasonably certain, the member's average salary from the city during the twelve-month period immediately preceding commencement of the qualified military service (or, if shorter, the entire period of employment immediately preceding commencement of his qualified military service). 
    "Years of service" means the aggregate sum of a member's years of service, computed in accordance with Sections 2.64.060, 2.64.070 and, in the case of a duty caused disability, Section 2.64.150. 
(Ord. 8284 (part), 2007; Ord. 8039 § A, 2005; Ord. 7593 § A, 2002; Ord. 7443 § B, 2001; prior code § 2-122) 
(Ord. No. 8667, § 2, 1-15-2013; Ord. No. 8687, § 2, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.030 - City tax. 
    A tax shall be levied on each dollar of value of all taxable property annually assessed in the city, as the same appears on the tax books, which sum shall be placed in a separate fund and set aside and made a part of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund by the city. Said sum shall not be used for or diverted to any purpose other than herein specified. The retirement fund's trustees shall pursuant to Section 2.64.210 cause the actuary to determine the fund's actuarial present value of accrued and projected retirement fund benefits in an actuarial valuation report as of each anniversary date (which, effective October 1, 1998, shall be based on the fair market value of the retirement fund's assets as of the immediately preceding March 31st, adjusted by the retirement fund's assumed investment return to such anniversary date). The trustees of the retirement fund shall cause such annual actuarial valuation report to be based upon member data (to determine retirement fund liabilities) for the twelve-month period ending on the March 31st immediately preceding each anniversary date, beginning March 31, 1998. As soon as reasonably practicable after this annual actuarial valuation report is provided to the retirement fund's trustees, and before the beginning of the next fiscal year of the city, the retirement fund's trustees, in order to fund the retirement plan's benefits on an actuarially sound basis, may recommend to the city council whether the city tax levy should be changed for the next fiscal year, and, if so, to what amount. Any change in the levy may only be taken, however, by formal action of the city council. The city council, in order to fund the retirement plan's benefits on an actuarially sound basis, may change the city tax levy, regardless of whether the retirement fund's trustees make any recommendation in this regard. 
(Ord. 8039 § B, 2005: Prior code § 2-123) 
2.64.040 - Board of trustees. 
    There is created a board to be known as the board of trustees of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund of the City of North Kansas City, Missouri, all of whom shall serve without compensation. The board of trustees shall consist of the mayor, the city attorney, the city treasurer, the chief of police (or his designated alternate), the fire chief (or his designated alternate), a member from the police department and an alternate member from the police department elected by the contributing police department members and a member from the fire department and an alternate member from the fire department elected by the contributing fire department members. Such police department and fire department elective trustees are to be elected annually on or before the first day of the city's fiscal year and shall serve as trustees for such fiscal year. Elected alternate members from the police department and the fire department and the designated alternate of the police chief and fire chief shall be referred to as an alternate trustee and shall only be entitled to act in the place of the elected member or fire or police chief when such elected member or chief is unable to act for any reason. Additionally, the city administrator shall serve as an ex-officio member of the board of trustees. The city administrator shall have voice, but no vote, at meetings of the trustees and shall not be counted in determining whether there is a quorum for a trustees' meeting. 
    The mayor shall be president of said board of trustees and said trustees shall, by a majority vote, appoint a secretary, who may be, but need not be, a member of said board and employ an actuary. The city treasurer shall be the official treasurer of said board of trustees. In the absence of the mayor, at a meeting at which a quorum is present, the board may elect that any member preside who may be a member, an alternate member or an ex-officio member. The compensation of all persons engaged by the board of trustees and all other expenses of the board of trustees necessary for the operation of the retirement system shall be paid at such rate and in such amounts as the board of trustees shall approve, the said compensation and expense to be paid out of the said police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund. The police officers' and firefighters' fund shall be under the exclusive management and control of said board of trustees, in whose name it shall contract all of its business and hold all of its moneys, securities and other properties. 
    The board of trustees shall keep a record of all its proceedings which shall be open to public inspection. It shall meet whenever necessary and transact all business before it. The board of trustees shall annually report in writing to the city council showing the transactions for the preceding fiscal year and a balance sheet showing the financial condition of said fund by means of an actuarial valuation of said fund and shall furnish such other information from time to time as the city council shall request. 
    The board of trustees shall make rules and regulations for the government of its affairs, the administration of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund and for the limitation of time within which claims may be filed. The board of trustees shall have exclusive jurisdiction to determine retirement pensions, claims or benefits under the fund. It shall hold hearings in connection therewith and take evidence on all said matters, and the evidence record, findings and decisions of the board of trustees shall be final. 
(Ord. 8039 § C, 2005: Ord. 7443 § C, 2001: prior code § 2-124) 
(Ord. No. 8594, § 1, 12-6-2011) 
2.64.050 - Eligibility for participation. 
    All persons who become police officers and firefighters of the city shall become members of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund upon employment as a full-time police officer or firefighter or upon reemployment as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city as defined in Section 2.64.020. Any police officer or firefighter first hired after age fifty-five (55) shall not be entitled to become a member of this pension plan, even if the police officer or firefighter is hired to work full-time, provided the police officer or firefighter is offered other wages or benefits provided by the city. Each police officer or firefighter, at the time Ordinance 2146 became effective, shall be a member of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund on the effective date thereof. 
(Prior code § 2-125) 
(Ord. No. 8687, § 3, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.060 - Year of service. 
A.  A "year of service" shall mean each 12 consecutive month period after a member's employment as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city, as described in Section 2.64.050, or reemployment as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city, as described in Section 2.64.390. Years of service shall also count each consecutive completed month as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city as a one-twelfth fraction of a year (as provided in Section 2.64.120(A)(4)). Absence without pay for any period of more than one month's duration shall not be counted as service, except for (i) a leave of absence approved by the city, or (ii) service in the Armed Forces of the United States during a period of time beginning on or after December 1, 2001 during which the member's reemployment rights were guaranteed by federal law as a result of "qualified military service", as defined by Section 414(u)(5) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code; provided the member is in qualified military service for more than one month and is either (a) reemployed by the city as a police officer or firefighter within the time required by such law or (b) on or after January 1, 2007, dies or becomes totally and permanently disabled while in qualified military service. If a period of qualified military service satisfies all of the above requirements, except that the qualified military service began before December 1, 2001, the period of qualified military service will only be recognized as "years of service" if the reemployed member makes the required employee contributions, with interest, for the period of military service within the lesser of (a) three times the member's period of qualified military service, or (b) five years after his reemployment. 
B.  If a police officer or firefighter leaves the service of the respective department for more than one month for any cause other than (i) a leave of absence approved by the city or (ii) being in the Armed Forces of the United States under the circumstances and subject to the conditions described in subsection (A)(i) above; his prior service shall be void, and on reentering the service of the police department or fire department, he shall not be entitled to credit for any service prior to his reemployment, unless he was vested at the time he left the service of the respective department as described in Section 2.64.130 or is reemployed as a full-time police officer or firefighter who may accrue additional benefits pursuant to subsections B, C or D of Section 2.64.390. 
(Ord. 7471 § A, 2001: Ord. 7443 § D, 2001: prior code § 2-126) 
(Ord. No. 8486, § 1, 8-24-2010; Ord. No. 8687, § 4, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.070 - Certificate of service. 
A.  Under rules of the board of trustees, any person who was a police officer or firefighter at the time Ordinance No. 2146 became effective shall file with the board of trustees a detailed statement of all service prior to July 1, 1972, as a police officer or firefighter of the police or fire department for which he claims credit. Upon verification of such service record, the board of trustees shall issue to each such police officer or firefighter a certificate of service certifying the length of his prior service on the basis of such statement as verified. 
B.  If such a police officer or firefighter leaves the service of the respective department for more than one month for any cause other than (i) being in the Armed Forces of the United States under the circumstances and subject to the conditions described in Section 2.64.060; or (ii) a leave of absence approved by the city, his certificate of prior service shall be void, and on reentering the service of the police department or fire department, he shall not be entitled to credit for any service prior to such date of reentering the service of the police department or fire department, unless he was vested at the time he left the respective department or is reemployed as a full-time police officer or firefighter who may accrue additional benefits pursuant to subsections B, C or D of Section 2.64.390. 
(Prior code § 2-127) 
(Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.080 - Normal retirement. 
A.  The normal retirement age of any member of the police officers' and firefighters' pension plan is age fifty-five (55) and the completion of ten (10) years of service, except that in no event shall it be after the attainment of the plan's mandatory retirement age sixty-five (65) and the completion of ten (10) years of service. A member's normal retirement date shall be the first day of the month coincident with or next following such member's normal retirement age. A retiree's normal retirement benefit shall be calculated as provided in Section 2.64.120 
B.  A retiree under this section shall have the option of electing to defer the commencement of his retirement benefit to the first day of any month after his normal retirement date, but in no event after his mandatory retirement age. If the retiree does not remain employed after his normal retirement date and does not elect a DROP account benefit under Section 2.64.330, then such DROP account benefit shall be the actuarial equivalent of the retirement benefit to which the retiree was entitled on his normal retirement date. If the retiree remains employed after his normal retirement date and also elects a Section 2.64.330 DROP account benefit, he shall be a DROP account retiree and his benefits shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.64.330. 
(Ord. 7593 § B, 2002: prior code § 2-128) 
(Ord. No. 8687, § 5, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.090 - Early retirement. 
A.  Any member of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund with at least twenty-five (25) years of service, regardless of his age, may retire within ten (10) years of his normal retirement date and shall be entitled to a retirement benefit commencing on his normal retirement date. Such benefit shall be equal to the member's accrued benefit as of his early retirement. 
B.  A retiree under this section shall have the option of electing that his retirement benefit commence on the first day of any month coincident with or next following his early retirement date, but in no event after his mandatory retirement age. If the retiree does not remain employed after his early retirement election and does not elect a DROP account benefit under Section 2.64.330, then the amount of such early retirement benefit shall be the actuarial equivalent of the member's accrued benefit as of the commencement of his early retirement benefit. If the retiree remains employed after his early retirement election, and also elects a Section 2.64.330 DROP account benefit, then he shall be a DROP account retiree and his benefits shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.64.330. 
(Ord. 7593 § C, 2002: prior code § 2-129) 
(Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.100 - Late retirement. 
    Any member of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund who has attained his normal retirement age, may defer his retirement date to the first day of any month following his normal retirement date, but not after his mandatory retirement age, at which time, he shall be entitled to a retirement benefit. If the retiree does not remain employed after his normal retirement election and does not elect a DROP account benefit under Section 2.64.330, then such late retirement benefit shall be the greater of (i) the actuarial equivalent of the member's normal retirement benefit, as computed under Section 2.64.120 as of the member's normal retirement date, or (ii) of the benefit otherwise payable under Section 2.64.120, based on the member's average monthly compensation and years of service as of the member's late retirement date. If the retiree remains employed after his late retirement date and elects a Section 2.64.330 DROP account benefit, then he shall be a DROP account retiree and his benefits shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.64.330. 
(Ord. 7593 § D, 2002: prior code § 2-130) 
(Ord. No. 8687, § 6, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.110 - Retirement procedure. 
A.  Any member, no less than ninety (90) days prior to his or her desired retirement date, shall file with the board of trustees an application for retirement setting forth the date on which he or she desires to retire. The board of trustees shall, within thirty (30) days after receipt of such application, determine if such member shall be eligible to retire on the date selected. If the board finds such member eligible to retire on the date selected, he or she shall be retired as of that date. 
B.  Not later than thirty (30) days prior to the attainment of his or her mandatory retirement age (sixty-five (65)), by a member who has not yet retired, the board of trustees shall notify such member that he shall be retired not later than the first day of the month coincident with or next following his or her attainment of his or her mandatory retirement age (sixty-five (65)). 
(Prior code § 2-131) 
2.64.120 - Normal retirement benefit. 
A.  The monthly retirement benefit for a member retiring on or after his or her normal retirement date with thirty (30) or more years of service shall be sixty (60) percent of his or her average monthly compensation. The monthly retirement benefit for a member retiring on or after his or her normal retirement age with less than thirty (30) years of service shall be calculated as follows: 
1.  Two and one-half percent for each of the first twenty (20) years of service; plus: 
2.  One percent for each year of service in excess of twenty (20), multiplied by the member's; 
3.  Average monthly compensation; and 
4.  Counting completed months of service as one-twelfth fraction of a year of service. 
B.  Such retirement pension benefits shall commence as of the date of retirement and the normal benefit form shall be benefit payments at monthly intervals throughout the remaining lifetime of such member. The form of distribution of such retirement benefit, however, shall be determined pursuant to Section 2.64.140. 
C.  Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, in no event shall a member's normal, early, late, disability or deferred vested retirement benefit hereunder exceed the limitation on such benefits as prescribed by Section 415 of the Federal Internal Revenue Code and the rulings and regulations thereunder, taking into consideration in this regard the special provisions in Section 415 of the Federal Internal Revenue Code which apply to governmental retirement plans for policemen and firemen and increases in the dollar limit under Section 415 of the Federal Internal Revenue Code and the regulations thereunder after a member's retirement which may affect the maximum permitted cost of living adjustment under Section 2.64.310 of this code. The "limitation year" for the purposes of Section 415 of the Federal Internal Revenue Code shall be the plan year (i.e., October 1 to September 30). As permitted by Treas. Reg. 1.415(a)-1(d)(3), Code Section 415, the Code Section 415 regulations, and the rulings thereunder, are incorporated herein by reference, including but not limited to: 
1.  Treas. Reg. 1.415(a)-1, Treas. Reg. 1.415(b)-1, Treas. Reg. 1.415(c)-2. 
2.  Treas. Reg. 1.415(c)-2(b)(1), which provides that certain amounts received under Code Section 132(f)(4) are included in compensation in applying the limitations of Section 415 is incorporated by reference. 
3.  The mortality table specified in Revenue Ruling 2001-62 (GAR'94), which shall apply for purposes of the limitations specified under Code Section 415(b)(2)(E). 
4.  Such other provisions in the Section 415 regulations as may be applicable to the plan. 
(Ord. 7593 § E, 2002; prior code § 2-132) 
(Ord. No. 8364, § 1, 12-16-2008; Ord. No. 8667, § 3, 1-15-2013; Ord. No. 8687, § 7, 4-2-2013)) 
2.64.130 - Vesting. 
    Any member who shall terminate his or her employment after ten (10) years of service and who is not entitled to benefits under any other provision of this plan shall be entitled to a retirement benefit commencing on his or her normal retirement date. Such deferred vested retirement benefit shall be equal to the member's accrued benefit as of the date of the member's termination of employment. The value of any forfeitures resulting from this vesting provision shall be applied to reduce city contributions to the retirement fund. 
(Prior code § 2-133) 
2.64.140 - Joint and survivorship benefit. 
A.  An unmarried member shall receive the value of his benefit in the normal benefit form, a single life annuity, as provided in Section 2.64.120 
B.  A member who is married on his retirement date and who does not die before his retirement benefit starting date may elect, in writing, to receive his retirement benefit in the form of a joint and survivorship benefit. Such joint and survivorship benefit, following the member's death, shall continue to the spouse (as hereinafter defined) during the spouse's lifetime in an amount equal to fifty (50) percent of the amount of the retirement benefit which was payable to the member. The joint and survivorship benefit form of benefit payment shall be the actuarial equivalent of the single life annuity normal form of benefit payment otherwise due the member under Section 2.64.090, 2.64.100, 2.64.120 or 2.64.330, whichever is applicable. 
C.  A member who is married on his retirement date and who does not die before his retirement benefit starting date may also elect a "pop-up benefit," in writing, so that, if his spouse dies after the retiree's joint and survivorship form of payment starts and before the retiree's death, then the amount of the retired member's benefit shall be restored to the same single life annuity form and amount of monthly benefit the retired member would have been receiving at such time had he elected this form of payment when the monthly retirement payments started or when DROP account credits started under Section 2.64.330, whichever is applicable. The combined joint and survivorship form of benefit and pop-up form of benefit shall be the actuarial equivalent of the single life normal form of benefit payment otherwise payable to the member under Section 2.64.090, 2.64.100, 2.64.120 or 2.64.330, whichever is applicable. 
D.  For purposes of this section: 
1.  "Retirement benefit starting date" means the first day of the first month for which a retirement benefit is payable or starts being credited to the member's DROP account, whichever is applicable. 
2.  "Spouse" means the surviving spouse who has been married to the member for at least a one-year period ending on or before the earlier of (a) the member's date of death, or (b) the date the member's first retirement benefit is payable or starts being credited to the member's DROP account, whichever is applicable. 
(Ord. 7593 § F, 2002: prior code § 2-134) 
(Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.150 - Duty-caused disability. 
    Any member of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund who, as a natural and proximate result of an accident occurring while in the actual performance of duties or exposure while in the actual performance of duties for the City of North Kansas City, Missouri, has been certified by the board's medical officer to be totally and permanently disabled, as hereinafter defined, and that such member should be retired, shall be retired immediately on a disability pension. Total disability, as used herein, shall mean that the member is mentally and physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty as a natural and proximate result of an accident while in the actual performance of duties or exposure while in the actual performance of duties for the city, as certified by the medical officer designated by the board, provided that the medical officer shall also certify that the mental or physical incapacity is likely to remain permanent and that the member should be retired as a member of the police department or the fire department. For the purpose of determining whether such an accident was the natural and proximate cause of total and permanent disability with respect to any member with at least five actual years of service, any of the following health conditions resulting in total disability to a member who successfully passed a physical examination within five years prior to the time a claim is made for such disability, which examination failed to reveal any evidence of such condition, shall be presumed to have been suffered in line of duty, unless the contrary is shown by competent evidence: any condition of impairment of health caused by any infectious disease, disease of the lungs or respiratory tract, hypertension, disease of the heart or any condition of cancer affecting the skin or the central nervous, lymphatic, digestive, hematological, urinary, skeletal, oral, breast, testicular, genitourinary, liver or prostate systems, as well as any condition of cancer which may result from exposure to heat or radiation or to a known or suspected carcinogen as determined by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, provided that the condition of cancer did not result nor was contributed to by the voluntary use of tobacco. In order to be entitled to the presumption that an infectious disease was contracted in line of duty, the member shall submit to an annual physical examination at which a blood test is administered. As used in this Section 2.64.150, the term "infectious disease" means the human immunodeficiency virus, acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, tuberculosis, hepatitis A, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, hepatitis D, diphtheria, meningococcal meningitis, methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus, hemorrhagic fever, plague, rabies and acute respiratory syndrome. 
A.  Such disability pension benefit for a disabled member shall be paid monthly and shall be the greater of the amount determined in (1) or (2) below or, in the case of a member who was an active city employee on August 22, 1994, the greatest of (1), (2), or (3) below, where: 
1.  Is an amount equal to fifty (50) percent of the member's average monthly compensation for the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the effective date of the member's retirement; and 
2.  Is an amount equal to (a) plus (b) multiplied by (c) where: 
a.  Is two and one-half percent for each of the first twenty (20) years of service (as hereinafter defined); 
b.  Is one percent for each of the next ten (10) years of service (as hereinafter defined) in excess of twenty (20); and 
c.  Is the disabled member's average monthly compensation, determined as of the date of his or her termination of employment due to duty-caused total disability; 
3.  Is an amount equal to sixty (60) percent of the average monthly compensation of such disabled member, calculated as of August 22, 1994. The board of trustees shall cause the actuary for the retirement fund to determine and report to the board of trustees the amount of the minimum duty-caused disability benefit for the members to whom such minimum benefit applies. The trustees shall permanently maintain such report as part of the retirement fund's records. 
B.  The disabled member's years of service under Section 2.64.150 shall be equal to the disabled member's actual years of service when his or her employment is terminated due to a duty-caused total disability, plus his or her imputed years of service from such termination date to the disabled member's normal retirement date. If a disabled member has partial years of service (either partial years of actual service or imputed service or both) each complete month of such partial years of service shall be counted as a one-twelfth fraction of a year of service. 
C.  In either event, credit for years of service toward retirement will be granted during such total and permanent disability and such total and permanent disability shall not count as a break in continuous service. Such disability pension benefit shall terminate upon the earliest of the following: 
1.  Recovery from such total disability; 
2.  Eligibility for normal retirement benefits; or 
3.  The death of the disabled member. 
D.  A member receiving a disability pension under this section shall, upon the attainment of his or her normal retirement age under Section 2.64.080, receive a normal retirement pension equal to the then amount of the disabled member's benefit under this section, in lieu of his normal retirement benefit under Section 2.64.120, taking into consideration any cost of living adjustment under Section 2.64.310 and, if elected by the member, payable in the form of an actuarial equivalent joint and survivorship benefit under Section 2.64.140. 
E.  The provisions of this section do not apply to a Section 2.64.330 DROP account retiree. 
(Ord. 8284 (part), 2007: Ord. 7593 § G, 2002; prior code § 2-135) 
(Ord. No. 8594, § 2, 12-6-2011; Ord. No. 8687, § 8, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.160 - Nonduty caused disability. 
A.  Any member of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund who has become totally and permanently disabled after five years of service, who is employed as a police officer or firefighter of the city (or on an approved leave of absence) and who does not qualify for normal retirement benefits under Section 2.64.120 or a duty caused disability under Section 2.64.150 shall be retired immediately on a disability pension. Total disability, as used herein, shall mean that the member is mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty for the city as certified by the medical officer designated by the board; provided, that the medical officer shall also certify that such mental or physical incapacity shall likely remain permanent and that the member should be retired as a member of the police department or the fire department. 
B.  Disability occurring as a direct and proximate result of employment with an employer other than the city, shall not be cause for a claim under this section. 
C.  Such disability pension benefit shall be paid monthly in an amount equal to the greater of (1) or (2), where: 
1.  Is the member's accrued benefit, calculated as of the date of the member's termination of employment due to total and permanent disability; and 
2.  Is twenty-five (25) percent of the member's average monthly compensation for the twelve-month period immediately preceding the effective date of the member's disability retirement. In addition there shall also be paid a sum equal to five percent of the average monthly compensation for the twelve (12) months immediately preceding disability retirement that the member was receiving at the time of his or her retirement for each unmarried dependent child under the age of eighteen (18), and each unmarried child, regardless of age, who is totally and permanently mentally or physically incapacitated from engaging in gainful employment sufficiently remunerative to support himself or herself. Such additional sum shall not be paid to or for more than three eligible children, and if there are more than three eligible children, then payments shall be made for the three youngest eligible children; and further provided, that no benefits under this section shall be paid to or for any child or children over eighteen (18) years of age who are totally and permanently mentally or physically incapacitated if such child is a patient or ward in a publicly supported institution, and no benefits shall be paid under this section to or for any child born or adopted after the effective date of the member's disability retirement. 
D.  Credit for service during such total and permanent disability shall not be granted; however, disability hereunder shall not count as a break in continuous service. Such disability pension benefits shall terminate upon the earlier of the following: 
1.  Recovery from such disability; 
2.  Eligibility for normal retirement benefits; or 
3.  The death of such disabled member. 
E.  A member receiving a disability pension under this section shall, upon the attainment of his or her normal retirement age under Section 2.64.080, receive a normal retirement pension equal to the then amount of the disabled member's benefit under this section, in lieu of his or her normal retirement benefit under Section 2.64.120, taking into consideration any cost of living adjustment under Section 2.64.310 and, if elected by the member, payable in the form of an actuarial equivalent joint and survivorship benefit under Section 2.64.140. 
F.  The provisions of this section do not apply to a Section 2.64.330 DROP account retiree. 
(Ord. 8284 (part), 2007: Ord. 7593 § H, 2002: prior code § 2-136) 
(Ord. No. 8687, § 9, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.170 - Recovery from disability. 
    The board of trustees may require, at such time as the board may direct, that any member who is receiving a disability pension as provided in Section 2.64.150 or 264.160, submit to a medical examination at a place and time designated by the board. The medical examination shall be performed by the board's medical officer, or, in special cases, by another physician or physicians designated by the board. If the medical officer (or other physician) certifies to the board of trustees that a member is no longer totally and permanently disabled, the board shall discontinue the member's disability pension. Should any member who is receiving a disability pension refuse to submit to such medical examination, the member's disability pension benefits shall be discontinued until the member complies with the requirements set forth in this section. If such member's refusal continues for more than one year, all rights in and to his or her disability pension, including credit for years of service, shall be forfeited. 
(Prior code § 2-137) 
(Ord. No. 8486, § 2, 8-24-2010) 
2.64.180 - Death benefits. 
A.  A death benefit will be paid upon the death of any active member: 
1.  While eligible to retire in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.64.080; or 
2.  After ten (10) years of service if not eligible to retire in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.64.090. 
B.  Such death benefit shall be in the form of a monthly income and shall be an amount equal to the monthly joint and survivorship benefit that would have been payable to a surviving spouse in accordance with Section 2.64.140 as if the member had retired as of the date of his or her death after electing the joint and survivorship option. In determining the amount of monthly death benefit hereunder, the calculation will be predicated upon the deceased member's actual years of service and the assumption that the date of death coincided with his or her normal retirement date. The death benefit shall be payable as follows: 
1.  Such a member, who dies before the first day of the first month for which a retirement benefit is payable and who has a surviving spouse, shall have his or her death benefit paid to his or her surviving spouse in the joint and survivorship benefit form pursuant to Section 2.64.140. The member's spouse may direct that payment of the joint and survivorship benefit commence at the time the member would have attained his or her early retirement date under Section 2.64.090. If the spouse does not so direct, payment of such benefit will commence at the time the member would have attained his or her normal retirement date. 
2.  If there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse dies or remarries, the death benefit shall be divided among any of the deceased member's children under the age of eighteen (18) years in equal shares; provided, that as each child attains the age of eighteen (18) years said benefit shall then be divided among the remaining children under the age of eighteen (18) years until there are no remaining children who so qualify, at which time all benefits hereunder shall cease. For the purposes of this section, the term "children" shall mean only dependent children of the deceased, both natural and adopted. Any such child, eighteen (18) years of age or older, who is physically or mentally incapacitated from entering into gainful employment shall, so long as such incapacity exists as certified by the medical board, such certification to be renewed annually, be considered to be less than eighteen (18) years of age for the purposes of this Section 2.64.180; provided that if any so incapacitated child shall marry, such child shall not thereafter be entitled to any benefit hereunder. 
    If, when death benefits cease to be paid under subsections (B)(1) and (B)(2) of this section, the total death benefits paid under this section is less than the member's employee contributions with interest as provided in Section 2.64.200 to the date of death, the excess of such employee contributions, with interest, over the total death benefits shall be paid to the member's beneficiary or estate if no designated beneficiary survives. 
C.  Upon the death of a member who has retired on a disability pension, a death benefit will be paid: (1) if such death occurs within two years following the effective date of the member's disability retirement; and (2) if such member would have been eligible for a death benefit as provided above if his or her death had occurred on the effective date of his or her disability retirement. The death benefit payable hereunder shall be determined as provided in this section and shall commence with the first monthly payment due next following his or her date of death. The joint and survivorship actuarial equivalent reduction shall be calculated at the date of his or her death. This determination, in the event there is no surviving spouse, shall assume the spouse's attained age is the same as that of the member. 
D.  It is intended that the retirement fund shall comply with a reasonable and good faith interpretation of Internal Revenue Code Section 401(a)(9) and the regulations and rulings which apply to governmental plans pursuant to Section 823 of the Pension Protection Act of 2006. Therefore, death benefits shall begin by no later than the end of the calendar year in which a member, whose benefits are not in pay status and whose survivors are entitled to death benefits hereunder, dies. Except as provided in this subsection as to Code Section 401(a)(9), the provisions of this Section 2.64.180 do not apply to a Section 2.64.330 DROP account retiree. 
E.  If a member dies on or after January 1, 2007, while in "qualified military service", as defined in Section 414(u)(5) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code, the member shall be treated as an "active member" for the purpose of determining the death benefits payable to the member's spouse or children pursuant to this Section 2.64.180. 
(Ord. 7593 § I, 2002 ; Ord. 7443 § E, 2001: prior code § 2-138) 
(Ord. No. 8364, § 2, 12-16-08; Ord. No. 8486, § 3, 8-24-2010; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.190 - Medical officer. 
    The board of trustees shall appoint a physician to be known as the medical officer who shall make all physical examinations required by this chapter. The fees for such examination shall be paid by the board of trustees out of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund and the medical officer shall receive for each examination such fee as the board of trustees shall approve. 
(Prior code § 2-139) 
2.64.200 - Employee contributions and pick-up contributions. 
A.  Each member shall contribute, by means of monthly salary deductions, five percent of his salary through November 30, 2001. Effective from and after December 1, 2001 to April 5, 2013, each member shall contribute, by means of monthly salary deductions, one and one-tenths percent of his salary and the city shall contribute three and nine-tenths of the salary of each member for each month the member makes salary deduction contributions. These city contributions shall be in addition to any other contributions the city may otherwise make to the retirement fund and shall be accounted for by the retirement fund as city contributions, not as employee contributions. Effective from and after October 1, 2002, neither DROP account retirees who elected the DROP account option prior to April 5, 2013, nor the city shall make the employee and city contributions described herein. Pick-up contributions by the city and additional city contributions described in subsection B of this section shall apply to and are required for members who first elect the DROP account option on or after April 6, 2013. A member may not elect to opt-out of the pick-up (or elect to receive the pick-up contributions, rather than have them paid to the retirement fund). 
B.  Effective April 6, 2013, the city, pursuant to Internal Revenue Code Section 414(h)(2), will "pick-up" and pay the contributions that would otherwise be payable by members as prescribed herein. The contributions picked up shall be treated as city contributions for purposes of determining the amounts of federal and state income taxes to withhold from the member's compensation, but shall be included in member compensation, as defined in Section 2.64.020 and for Federal Insurance Contribution Act tax purposes. Pick-up contributions will be paid from reductions to the salary or regular hourly pay of a member in an amount equal to three and one-tenth percent of the member's salary or regular hourly rate of pay. A member may not elect to opt-out of the pick-up (or elect to receive the pick-up contributions, rather than have them paid to the retirement fund). The city shall contribute an additional six and nine-tenths percent of the salary or regular hourly rate of pay for each member for whom pick-up contributions are made by the city. These city contributions shall be in addition to any other contributions the city may otherwise make to the retirement fund. 
C.  Effective from September 1, 2004 to April 5, 2013, employee and city contributions, in the case of a member who completes thirty (30) years of service prior to age fifty-five (55) and continues in active employment for the city, shall cease as of the first day of the month coincident with or immediately following the date the member completes thirty (30) years of service prior to age fifty-five (55). When such a member attains age fifty-five (55) and continues employment for the city as a police officer or firefighter, the then required employee and city contributions shall resume and continue until the member actually retires or elects DROP account status. Furthermore, as soon as practicable after October 1, 2007, the retirement fund shall return employee contributions made by a member during the period of time after such a member has completed thirty (30) years of service and prior to the date such member has attained age fifty-five (55) (including any active employees who elected DROP account status). Such return of employee contributions shall include the portion of the interest credited to such contributions through September 30, 2007, which is attributable to the return of such employee contributions. Such return of employee contributions shall not apply to members whose benefits are in pay status on September 30, 2007, or who are not active employees of the city on September 30, 2007. Effective April 6, 2013, pick-up contributions and other city contributions described in subsection B of this section shall apply to any member who completes thirty (30) years of service prior to age fifty-five (55) and continues in active employment for the city. 
D.  In the event that all pick-up contributions and/or employee contributions should be returned to the member or paid to his beneficiary, employee contributions shall be credited with interest from the end of the plan year in which such employee contributions were made to the first day of the month immediately preceding such return of any employee contributions. The rate at which interest shall be credited during any plan year will be the interest rate used in the actuarial valuation for the previous valuation year through September 30, 1990, and the federal mid-term rate under Section 1274(d) of the Internal Revenue Code or any successor thereto, compounded annually, as of the first day of each plan year thereafter. 
E.  Each member shall designate a beneficiary to receive any benefits due under this section. 
F.  Any member who leaves the service of his or her respective department prior to retirement and who is entitled to no benefit under any other provision of this retirement fund shall have his or her pick-up contributions and/or employee contributions, with interest, paid to him or her. A member who leaves the service of his respective department and is entitled to a deferred vested normal retirement benefit under Section 2.64.130 may elect to have his or her pick-up contributions and/or employee contributions paid to the member, with interest, but such payment of pick-up contributions and/or employee contributions shall prevent the member from receiving any other benefits under the retirement fund. 
G.  If a member who has not elected a joint and survivorship option dies after retirement (normal, early, late or disability) but prior to receiving retirement benefits equal to his or her total employee contributions with interest to the date retirement benefits or DROP account credits started, the excess of such employee contributions with interest over the sum of: (1) the aggregate retirement benefits; and (2) any DROP account credits received by the member, shall be paid to his or her beneficiary. 
(Ord. 8284 (part), 2007: Ord. 7593 § J, 2002: Ord. 7471 § B, 2001: Ord. 7443 § F, 2001: prior code § 2-140) 
(Ord. No. 8687, § 10, 4-2-2013) 
2.64.210 - Annual actuarial valuation and report. 
    The board of trustees shall cause the actuary to make an annual actuarial valuation of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund on the retirement fund's actuarial valuation date ("actuarial valuation date" shall mean the first day of the plan year) and to make an annual report on such valuation and on the actuarial soundness of the fund. This report shall include the balances as of the actuarial valuation date of any DROP accounts. The board of trustees shall keep such records as are necessary for the purpose of this report. 
(Ord. 7593 § K, 2002: prior code § 2-141) 
2.64.220 - Accounts. 
    The city treasurer shall supervise all monies, securities and other assets of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund, subject to the control and direction of the board of trustees. The city treasurer may, if directed by the board of trustees, and if not in conflict with controlling law, delegate this responsibility to any trust company or the trust department of any bank in the United States. Such a bank or trust company may also be a discretionary "investment fiduciary," as defined in Section 2.64.230(B), with respect to the retirement fund. The city treasurer shall keep books and complete accounts of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund and such books and accounts shall always be subject to the inspection of the board of trustees. The city treasurer shall be bonded at the expense of the fund for all of his or her acts concerning the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund. On the expiration of his or her term of office, he or she shall deliver to his or her successor all monies, securities and other assets in his or her possession and all books, records and accounts which have come into his or her possession as treasurer of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund. 
(Ord. 8039 § D, 2005: Prior code § 2-142) 
2.64.230 - Investments. 
A.  Use of Assets. The assets of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund, in excess of a safe operating balance of cash, may be invested and reinvested in any investment permissible under the prudent investor standard governing investments of police officers' and firefighters' retirement systems in the state of Missouri. 
B.  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms are defined as follows: 
    "Equity interests" means limited partnership interests and other interests in which the liability of the investor is limited to the amount of the investment, but does not include general partnership interests or other interests involving general liability of the investor. 
    "Invest" or "investment" means utilization of money in the expectation of future returns in the form of income or capital gain. 
    "Investment fiduciary" means a person who either exercises any discretionary authority or control in the investment of a public employee retirement system's assets or who renders for a fee advice for a public employment retirement system. 
C.  Investment Duties. The trustees and each investment fiduciary of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund shall discharge their duties in the interest of the participants in the retirement fund and their beneficiaries and shall: 
1.  Act with the same care, skill, prudence, and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing that a prudent person acting in a similar capacity and familiar with those matters would use in the conduct of a similar enterprise with similar aims; 
2.  Act with due regard for the management, reputation, and stability of the issuer and the character of the particular investments being considered; 
3.  Make investments for the purposes of providing benefits to participants and participants' beneficiaries, and of defraying reasonable expenses of investing the assets of the retirement fund; 
4.  Give appropriate consideration to those facts and circumstances that the trustees or investment fiduciary knows or should know are relevant to the particular investment or investment course of action involved, including the role the investment or investment course of action plays in that portion of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund's investments for which the trustees and each investment fiduciary have responsibility. For this purpose, "appropriate consideration" shall include, but is not necessarily limited to, a determination by the trustees or an investment fiduciary that a particular investment or investment course of action is reasonably designed, as part of the investments of the retirement fund, to further the purposes of the retirement fund, taking into consideration the risk of loss and the opportunity for gain or other return associated with the investment or investment course of action; and consideration of the following factors as they relate to the investment or investment course of action: 
a.  The diversification of the investments of the retirement fund; 
b.  The liquidity and current return of the investments of the retirement fund relative to the anticipated cash flow requirements of the retirement fund; and 
c.  The projected return of the investments of the retirement fund relative to the funding objectives of the retirement fund; 
5.  Give appropriate consideration to investments which would enhance the general welfare of the state of Missouri and its citizens if those investments offer the safety and rate of return comparable to other investments available to the trustees or an investment fiduciary at the time the investment decision is made. 
D.  Nothing herein shall prevent the trustees or investment fiduciaries from making investments in any company which does business in any country with which the United States maintains diplomatic relations. 
E.  No member of the board of trustees nor member of the police department or fire department or any employee or agent of the retirement fund shall have any interest in the acquisition of disposition of any investment. 
F.  The retirement fund shall hold all its assets from whatever source derived and for whatever purposes, in a single commingled trust fund, including but not limited to, employee contributions and DROP account balances. 
(Ord. 7593 § L, 2002; prior code § 2-143) 
2.64.240 - Nonalienation clause. 
    The benefits payable by the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund, whether before or after ordered paid by the board of trustees, shall not be assignable or subject to counterclaim, recoupment or set off except as provided in this chapter, nor shall they be subject to assessment, garnishment, execution, injunction, writ of sequestration, or any other decree, order, process or proceeding in any court for the payment of any debt of any said disabled or retired member, and the benefit shall be held and distributed for the purpose of this chapter and for no other purpose whatever. 
(Prior code § 2-144) 
2.64.250 - False statements. 
    Any person who shall knowingly or willfully make any false statement in regard to applying for or securing a pension under this police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund or who shall falsify or permit to be falsified any record or records of such policemen's and firemen's retirement fund in any attempt to defraud, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall lose all rights, interest and privileges under this policemen's and firemen's retirement fund. 
(Prior code § 2-145) 
2.64.260 - Amendment. 
A.  Upon the recommendation by the board of trustees of the policemen's and firemen's retirement fund, the mayor and city council of the city may amend this chapter by accepting or rejecting said recommendation as they deem necessary in matters relating to procedure, administration, eligibility for benefits, disability benefits, causes of disability, retirement benefits, and vesting provisions. 
B.  City council may amend this chapter by accepting or rejecting said recommendation as they deem necessary in matters relating to procedure, administration, eligibility for benefits, disability benefits, causes of disability, retirement benefits, and vesting provisions. 
(Prior code § 2-146) 
2.64.270 - Construction of chapter. 
    If any clause, phrase, sentence, section or subsection of this chapter be declared illegal, inoperative or invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such illegal, inoperative or invalid clause, phrase, sentence, section or subsection shall not affect the remainder of this chapter. Where used in this part the masculine pronoun shall be construed also to include the feminine. 
(Prior code § 2-147) 
2.64.280 - Effective date. 
    Upon approval of the provisions of this chapter and the policemen's and firemen's retirement fund contained herein by the city council, the provisions of this chapter shall become effective with respect to the retirement fund on October 1, 1990. 
(Prior code § 2-148) 
2.64.290 - Benefits from previous ordinances. 
    Any person receiving benefits to the provisions of Ordinance No. 2146 or Ordinance No. 3765, or any amendments thereto, as of the effective date of this chapter shall continue to receive benefits at the level and in accordance with the provisions of Ordinance No. 2146 or Ordinance No. 3765, or any amendments thereto, and for such purpose the provisions of these ordinances, or any amendments thereto, shall remain in effect. 
(Prior code § 2-149) 
2.64.300 - One time cost of living adjustment for certain retirement benefits in pay status. 
    The monthly retirement benefit of each retired member who retired and commenced receiving monthly benefits prior to October 1, 1990, shall be increased, effective for monthly benefit payments made on or after October 1, 1992, by an amount equal to three percent of the retired member's monthly retirement benefit as of October 1, 1992, multiplied by the number of complete years that the retired member's monthly retirement benefit has been in pay status. If the retired member's monthly retirement benefit is being paid in the form of a joint and survivorship benefit pursuant to Section 2.64.140, the survivor's benefit shall be equal to fifty (50) percent of the monthly benefit payable to the retired member, as increased by this one-time cost of living adjustment. In the event the foregoing cost-of-living adjustment should be held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be violative of the Missouri Constitution or otherwise violative of Missouri law, then any retired member who retired and commenced receiving monthly benefits prior to October 1, 1990, shall, upon application to the board of trustees be employed by either the city or by the retirement fund, effective as of October 1, 1992, as a special advisor and supervisor. Any such person so employed shall perform such duties as the board of trustees directs and shall receive from the retirement fund in addition to his or her monthly retirement benefit, a salary equal to three percent of the person's monthly retirement benefit as of October 1, 1992, as a retired member, multiplied by the number of complete years that the retired member's monthly retirement benefit has been in pay status. If the person's monthly retirement benefit is being paid in the form of a joint and survivorship benefit pursuant to Section 2.64.140, the survivor's benefit shall be equal to fifty (50) percent of the monthly benefit and salary payable to the retired member, as increased by this monthly salary. 
(Prior code § 2-150) 
2.64.310 - Cost of living adjustment for future benefits for active members. 
    An eligible member for the purposes of this section is a member who was an active city employee on or after August 23, 1994, the date of the passage of Ordinance No. 6501 by the city council. The monthly benefit as set forth in Sections 2.64.090 (early retirement), 2.64.100 (late retirement), 2.64.120 (normal retirement), 2.64.150 (duty-caused disability) or 2.64.160 (nonduty caused disability) hereof, whichever is applicable, payable to an eligible member who first retired or became disabled on or after August 23, 1994, shall be increased as of each January 1 after the commencement of his or her benefits by a cost of living adjustment which shall be equal to the lesser of (a) the cost of living adjustment which was applied to increase Social Security benefits as of the immediately preceding December 1 (as announced in the Federal Register pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 1382f) or (b) four percent. Effective as of January 1, 2014, this cost of living adjustment shall be (a) the cost of living adjustment which was applied to increase Social Security benefits as of the immediately preceding December 1 (as announced in the Federal Register pursuant to 42 USC 1382(f), but (b) not less than one percent, nor (c) more than three percent. If a monthly benefit is payable to a surviving spouse (as defined in Section 2.64.140) or child (as defined in Section 2.64.180) of a deceased eligible member pursuant to Section 2.64.140 (joint and survivorship benefit) or Section 2.64.180 (death benefit), such benefit shall also be increased as of each January 1 after the commencement of such benefit at the same cost of living adjustment rate. If an eligible member, surviving spouse or child's monthly benefit commences as of a January 1, the cost of living adjustment provided for shall first apply as of the immediately following January 1. If an eligible member, surviving spouse or child's monthly benefit commences as of a day other than a January 1, the cost of living adjustment shall also first apply as of the immediately following January 1, but shall be equal to the amount determined by multiplying (1) by (2), where: 
1.  Is the amount of cost of living adjustment otherwise determined pursuant to this section; and 
2.  Is a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of complete months for which the member and/or the surviving spouse and/or surviving child received monthly benefit payments during the calendar year immediately preceding the applicable cost of living adjustment and the denominator of which is twelve (12). 
(Prior code § 2-150.1) 
(Ord. No. 8687, § 11, 4-2-2013)

(Prior code § 2-150.2) 
2.64.330 - Deferred retirement option provision. 
A.  A member who is eligible for early retirement, normal retirement or late retirement under the retirement fund and intends to remain employed for the city as an employee of the police department or the fire department for at least one additional year, but not more than five years, may elect to have his or her early, normal or late retirement benefit payments under the retirement fund start and be credited to his or her DROP account under the retirement fund without any distribution of such benefits from the retirement fund. The member's DROP account shall also be credited with interest pursuant to Section 2.64.200 as hereinafter provided, until his or her actual retirement, which must be on or before the member's mandatory retirement age, or if earlier, five years after such member commences DROP status. The five year maximum limitation period in this paragraph A shall not apply to a member who elected DROP account status prior to October 1, 2007. 
B.  Such a retired member is referred to herein as a DROP account retiree. The early, normal or late retirement benefit of a DROP account retiree shall be calculated in accordance with Section 2.64.090, 2.64.100, or 2.64.120, whichever is applicable, as of the date he or she elects shall be the starting date for the monthly credit of his or her early, normal or late retirement benefit to his or her DROP account in the retirement fund. The starting date of the DROP account credits shall be elected by the member, in writing, and must be as of the first day of a month beginning after the DROP account retiree's election is received by the retirement fund. For elections made on or after October 1, 2007, the maximum period of time that a member may remain in DROP account retiree status is five years from the date that his or her DROP election was first effective but not later than the member's mandatory retirement age. 
C.  The DROP account retiree shall be treated by the retirement fund in the same manner as any other retiree is treated, except that the amount of the retiree's early, normal or late retirement benefit shall be credited each month to his DROP account in the retirement fund and shall not be paid to the DROP account retiree until after his or her actual retirement. Prior to the start of credits to a DROP account, a DROP account retiree must elect a form of benefit payment pursuant to Section 2.64.120 or Section 2.64.140. 
D.  Once monthly credits to the DROP account start, such monthly credits shall be increased for any cost of living adjustments that may be made pursuant to Section 2.64.310 at the same time and at the same rate that applies to similarly situated retirees in pay status. 
E.  Additionally, the DROP account of a DROP account retiree shall be credited with interest as of each anniversary date in the same manner and at the same rate of interest that is credited at such time to employee contribution accounts under Section 2.64.200. 
F.  A DROP account retiree shall not be entitled to duty caused disability benefits under Section 2.64.150 or non-duty caused disability benefits under Section 2.64.160. 
G.  If a DROP account retiree dies before his or her actual retirement, any death benefits that may be payable to his or her beneficiary shall be based solely on the form of benefit payment elected before monthly credits to his or her DROP account started, plus the balance of his or her DROP account, credited with interest pursuant to Section 2.64.200 through the end of the month immediately preceding the payment. 
H.  After the actual retirement of a DROP account retiree, no further amounts shall be credited to his or her DROP account, except for interest credits pursuant to Section 2.64.200 through the end of the month immediately preceding distribution of the DROP account. Monthly benefit payments in the amount then being credited to the DROP account retiree shall be paid directly to the retiree beginning as of the first day of the month immediately following the actual retirement of the retiree. 
I.  Additionally, a DROP account shall, at the written election of a DROP account retiree, be distributed to the retiree or, if the DROP account retiree dies before his or her actual retirement, to his or her beneficiary in one of the following forms: 
1.  In a single sum cash payment; 
2.  In a direct rollover to eligible retirement plan, as defined in Section 2.64.020; 
3.  In a combination of the above described forms of payment. 
J.  If a DROP account retiree is reemployed as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city, the provisions of Section 2.64.390(D) shall apply and the rehired member shall no longer be treated as a DROP account retiree. If the DROP account retiree is reemployed as a part-time police officer or firefighter, the rehired member shall continue to be treated as a DROP account retiree pursuant to the provisions of Section 2.64.390(D). 
(Ord. 8284 (part), 2007; Ord. 8039 § E, 2005; Ord. 7593 § M, 2002; Ord. No. 8803, 2-17-2015) 
2.64.340 - Complete or partial termination. 
    Upon the complete or partial termination of the benefits provided by the retirement fund, the rights of all affected members to benefits accrued to the date of such termination, to the extent funded, shall be nonforfeitable. The term "partial termination" shall have the same meaning as term means to have under Section 411(d)(3) of the Federal Internal Revenue Code. 
    If a surplus exists upon the complete termination of the retirement fund then, after the discharge of the retirement fund's liabilities to its members and the payment of all retirement fund expenses, such surplus shall be distributed in a manner determined by the city council, which may be based on the recommendation of the board of trustees of the retirement fund. 
(Ord. 8039 § F, 2005: Ord. 5794 § N, 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8667, § 4, 1-15-2013) 
2.64.350 - Eligible rollover distribution. 
    An eligible rollover distribution under either Section 2.64.200 (with respect to the return of employee contributions, with interest, before eligibility for retirement benefits) or Section 2.64.330 (with respect to the distribution of DROP accounts) may be paid to an eligible retirement plan in the form of a direct rollover at the written election of the number or, as applicable, the surviving spouse of a deceased member, or a non-spouse beneficiary. 
    Except as provided in this paragraph, an eligible retirement plan is an individual retirement account described in Section 408(a) of the code, an individual retirement annuity described in Section 408(b) of the code, a Roth individual retirement account, an annuity plan described in Section 403(a) of the code, a qualified trust described in section 401(a) of the code, an annuity contract described in Section 403(b) of the code and an eligible plan under Section 457(b) of the code which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or political subdivision of a state. Effective January 1, 2008, an eligible retirement plan shall also include a Roth individual retirement account, as described in Section 408A of the code. A non-spouse beneficiary may only directly rollover an eligible rollover distribution from this plan to either a traditional or Roth inherited individual retirement account. 
    Employee after-tax contributions may only be rolled over to an IRA or to a qualified plan or 403(b) plan that agrees to account separately for amounts so transferred (including investment earnings or losses thereon), including accounting separately for the portion of a distribution from such an IRA, qualified plan or 403(b) plan which is includible in gross income and the portion of the distribution which is not includible in gross income. 
(Ord. 7593 § O, 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8364, § 3, 12-16-08) 
2.64.360 - No mandatory cash-out distributions. 
    Benefit payments from the retirement fund shall only be made on the basis of a written application of: (i) a member, spouse, beneficiary, the legal guardian of a dependent or disabled child or the legal representative of a deceased member's estate, whichever is applicable; and (ii) the written authorization of at least two members of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. 8039 § G, 2005) 
2.64.370 - Plan administration. 
    The city administrator and/or support staff of the city may provide administrative services to the retirement fund including, but not limited to, enrolling eligible members, deducting employee contributions from member payroll checks, forwarding employee contributions to the appropriate accounts for the retirement fund, processing benefits due to retirement, disability, death or termination of employment and taking such other action as may be requested or directed from time to time by the board of trustees of the retirement fund; provided, however, nothing in this Section 2.64.370 shall be construed as abrogating or superseding any authority of either the board of trustees or the city council of the city with respect to their responsibilities to the retirement fund as set forth in this Chapter 2.64. 
(Ord. No. 8594, § 3, 12-6-2011) 
2.64.380 - Fiduciary liability insurance and indemnification of the trustees and employees. 
A.  To the extent deemed appropriate by the board of trustees, the retirement fund may indemnify and protect any trustee, alternate trustee or employee of the city providing services to the retirement fund against any or all claims, costs, damages or liabilities, including the defense thereof, arising out of a trustee, alternate trustee or employee's responsibilities with respect to the retirement fund; provided, however, that no trustee, alternate trustee or employee shall be indemnified for gross negligence, willful misconduct, personal dishonesty, fraud or intentional failure to act prudently, as determined by the board of trustees or, if the issue affects a majority of the board of trustees, the city council. 
B.  The board of trustees is authorized to obtain and maintain fiduciary liability insurance and/or indemnity policies to insure trustees, alternate trustees and employees of the city providing services to the retirement fund against any losses incurred as a result of their responsibilities with respect to the retirement fund. 
C.  No trustee, alternate trustee or employee shall be entitled to indemnification under this section unless within thirty (30) days after receiving written notification of a claim against him/her, the trustee, alternate trustee or employee shall have given notice of such claim to the board of trustees and the city. 
(Ord. No. 8594, § 4, 12-6-2011) 
2.64.390 - Reemployment. 
A.  Rehire of a Nonvested Former Member. If a police officer or firefighter who is a nonvested former member under Section 2.64.130 hereof is reemployed as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city, he shall become a member of the police officers' and firefighters' retirement fund upon his reemployment. Such a member shall be treated the same as any other new member of this plan. 
B.  Rehire of a Deferred Vested Member Whose Benefits Are Not in Pay Status. If a member who terminated his employment with ten (10) or more years of service and whose benefits are not in pay status is reemployed as a full-time police officer or firefighter, then he shall become a member of this plan with his prior years of service and compensation recognized by this plan in the calculation of the benefits to which the reemployed member is entitled upon his later termination of employment, retirement, or disability prior to the commencement of benefit payments hereunder or to which his surviving spouse, children or beneficiary is entitled upon his later death prior to the commencement of benefit payments hereunder. 
C.  Reemployment of a Retiree Whose Benefits Are in Pay Status. If a retiree whose benefits are in pay status is reemployed as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city, his retirement benefit payments shall cease immediately. Such rehired member shall, upon his later retirement, have any additional years of service and compensation earned after his reemployment taken into consideration in the determination and resumption of early, normal or late retirement benefits which were in pay status at the time of his reemployment in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.64.080, 2.64.090 or 2.64.100, whichever is applicable. 
    If a retiree whose benefits are in pay status is reemployed as a part-time police officer or firefighter for the city, his retirement benefit payments shall continue uninterrupted, and the reemployed member shall not accrue any additional benefits for the period of his reemployment as a part-time employee. 
D.  Reemployment of a DROP Account Retiree Whose Benefits Are in Pay Status. If a DROP account retiree whose benefits are in pay status is reemployed as a full-time police officer or firefighter for the city, his retirement benefit payments shall cease immediately.
