    Before issuing a permit for a carnival, the city council shall cause an investigation to be made of the size and equipment of the carnival and shall require a written agreement from the carnival as to the time of day when it intends to operate. Based upon such investigation, the city council shall not issue such permit if it determines that such carnival will result in substantial danger to the peace, health or safety of the area in which such carnival is proposed to be located. 
(Prior code § 4-43) 
5.16.070 - Previous revocation sufficient cause for refusal. 
    A permit for the conduct of a carnival may be refused to any person who has in his or her previous operation of any carnival, in any other city or this city, violated the ordinances and requirements of the other city or this city so as to have caused such city to have revoked any permit or permission to operate such carnival and the city council has cause to believe similar conduct may occur again in its operations under such proposed plans of operation. 
(Prior code § 4-44) 
5.16.080 - Insurance. 
    Before any permit shall be issued, the applicant shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy, to be approved by the city council, providing insurance coverage for such carnival and all operations thereof for injury to or death of persons and against damage to the property of another, including personal property, in sums of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for any one person, two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for any one occurrence, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage in any one occurrence. 
(Prior code § 4-45) 
5.16.090 - Noncompliance prohibited-Revocation. 
    Every person obtaining a permit to operate, carry on or conduct a carnival in the city shall agree as a condition thereto to fully and completely comply with the provisions of this chapter and all other applicable ordinances of this city and in accordance with the stated plans of the carnival or the operations thereof. In the event such person or anyone employed thereby or operating with permission thereof shall violate the provisions of any such laws, or operate such carnival contrary to the expressly stated plans of the carnival, the permit for such carnival may be revoked and cancelled upon submission to the city council of competent evidence that there has been such a violation. 
(Prior code § 4-46) 
Chapter 5.20 - CHARITABLE AND RELIGIOUS SOLICITATIONS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Generally 

5.20.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms used in this chapter are defined as follows: 
    "Charitable" means any activity represented as carried on from unselfish, civic, or humanitarian motives for the benefit of others, and not for private gain, and includes without limitation appeals to fund patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal, cultural, eleemosynary, scientific, historical, athletic, medical, or religious activities, either actual or implied. 
    "Clerk" means the city clerk or his or her designee. 
    "Contributions" means donations in any form and, without limitation, include food, clothing, money, pledges, subscriptions, property, donations including loans of money or of property, and the amounts solicited in payment for anything of value if such solicitation is founded in whole or in part upon a charitable or religious appeal. 
    "Cost of solicitation" means any money or thing of value given or expended by or on behalf of a soliciting person for the purpose of promoting or administering a campaign of solicitation and includes, among other things, expenditures: 
1.  For solicitation publicity, including advertising material, appeal correspondence, envelopes, enclosures, brochures, postage, posters, programs, tickets, decals, printed or otherwise reproduced materials and all cost of such reproduction and expenditures for the purchase of space or time from any communications media; and 
2.  For rental or purchase of space, facilities, or equipment used in connection with a solicitation, for all utility and maintenance expenses, and for all licenses or privilege fees; and 
3.  For transportation of any kind used in the conduct of the solicitation; and 
4.  For compensation of any kind paid to paid promoters or solicitors or paid to any person for aid, assistance, material, or facilities for use in the conduct of a solicitation; and 
5.  For secretarial, clerical, executive, and administrative services; and 
6.  For merchandise, prizes, emblems, tags, gifts, awards, or other things given or sold to others; and 
7.  For obtaining or presenting any program of entertainment or instruction in connection with a solicitation, including expenses or compensation paid to entertainers or performers and the cost of housing, maintaining, or providing facilities for the presentation of such program, and all incident expenses. 
    "Paid fund-raising counsel" means a person who for a fixed fee advises or acts as a consultant, whether directly or indirectly, in connection with soliciting contributions for a charitable organization, but who does not actually solicit contributions as a part of his or her services. 
    "Paid promoter or solicitor" means a person who as a business: 
1.  For a financial consideration solicits contributions for, or on behalf of, a charitable organization, either personally or through agents or employees specifically employed for that purpose; or 
2.  Who plans, conducts or manages in addition to acting as a consultant to a charitable organization in connection with the solicitation of contributions. 
    "Religious" and "religion" mean any activity directly involving the promulgation or observance of any system of worship or to the building or maintenance of places of worship. 
    "Solicit" and "solicitation" mean the request, directly or indirectly, for money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the representation that such request or a part thereof will be used for a charitable or religious purpose. These words shall include the following methods of making solicitation: 
1.  Any oral or written request; 
2.  The distribution, mailing, or publishing of any handbill or other publication; 
3.  The making of any announcement by mail, newspaper, radio, television, telephone, telegraph, or other means of communication, concerning an appeal, assemblage, athletic or sports event, bazaar, benefit, card party, campaign, carnival, circus, contest, dance, drive, entertainment, exhibition, exposition, lecture, party, performance, picnic, sale, social gathering, which the public is requested to patronize, or to which the public is requested to make a contribution by reason of any charitable or religious purpose connected therewith; 
4.  The sale of, or attempt to sell, any advertisement, advertising space, book, card, coupon, device, magazine membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable or religious purpose; 
5.  A "solicitation" shall be deemed completed when made, whether or not the person making the same receives any contribution or makes any sale referred to in this section. 
(Prior code § 21-56) 
5.20.020 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person soliciting contributions for any charitable or religious purpose, as included within the terms of this chapter, without fully complying with its terms, or any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, or any person soliciting for any such purpose by means of any false or fraudulent statement of fact, or filing or causing to be filed, an application for a permit under this chapter containing any false or fraudulent statement, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred ($500.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than one hundred eighty (180) days, or may be punished by both fine and imprisonment. 
(Prior code § 21-57) 
Article II. - Charitable or Religious Solicitations 

5.20.030 - Solicitor's credentials. 
A.  Content. All persons to whom permits have been issued shall furnish a copy of the permit or other credentials approved by the clerk to each of their solicitors, and such credentials shall include the name of the permittee, the permittee's address, a telephone number at which information about the permittee and its charitable purpose can be obtained, the expiration date of the permit and the solicitor's name and photograph. 
B.  Use-Display. No person shall solicit under any permit granted under this article without the credentials required by this section. Such credentials must be shown upon request to all persons solicited and to any police officer of the city. 
(Prior code § 21-66) 
5.20.040 - Receipts for contributions. 
    Any person receiving money in excess of one dollar ($1.00) or anything having a value in excess of one dollar ($1.00) from any contributor under a solicitation permit shall give to the contributor on request a written receipt signed by the solicitor showing plainly the name and permit number of the person under whose permit the solicitation is being conducted, the date, and the amount received; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any contributions collected by means of a closed box or receptacle. 
(Prior code § 21-67) 
5.20.050 - Financial report from holders of permits. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons issued permits under this division to furnish the clerk within sixty (60) days after the solicitation has been completed, a detailed report and financial statement showing the amount raised by the solicitation, the amount expended in collecting such funds, including a detailed report of wages, fees, commissions, and expenses paid to any person in connection with such solicitation and the disposition of the balance of the funds collected by the solicitation. For good cause shown, the clerk may extend for an additional period of up to ninety (90) days the time for filing the report. 
(Prior code § 21-68) 
5.20.060 - Books and records to be available for inspection. 
    Upon request by the clerk any person to whom a permit has been granted under this article, and any applicant for such a permit, shall make available for inspection by the clerk or any person designated as his or her representative for such purpose, all their related books, records and papers at any reasonable time, while the application is being considered, during the time a permit is in effect, or for up to one year after a permit has expired. No person shall solicit contributions for any charitable or religious purpose without maintaining a full and accurate system of books and accounts consonant with the Audit Guides (published by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants), or in accordance with the generally accepted standards of financial accounting and reporting for the organization's particular field. 
(Prior code § 21-69) 
5.20.070 - Hours of solicitation. 
    No person shall solicit from door to door within the city before the hour of nine a.m. or one-half hour after sunset of any day. 
(Prior code § 21-70) 
5.20.080 - Misrepresentation. 
    No solicitor shall register a false or fictitious name or address, or shall represent by words or action that he or she is the employee, agent, partner or representative of any person or organization when in fact he or she is not the employee, agent, partner or representative of such person or organization. 
(Prior code § 21-71) 
5.20.090 - Posted premises. 
    No person, while engaged in soliciting regulated by this article, shall knock at the door or ring the doorbell of any home, apartment, or other dwelling unit in the city upon which is clearly displayed at the entrance a notice which reads "No solicitors," or which otherwise clearly purports to prohibit peddlers, solicitors, or vendors on the premises, unless such person is or has been invited upon the premises by the occupant thereof. 
(Prior code § 21-72) 
5.20.100 - Permit required-Exceptions. 
    No person shall solicit contributions for any charitable or religious purpose within the city, without a permit from the clerk authorizing such solicitation; provided, however, that the provisions of this article shall not be applicable to any solicitations made upon premises owned or occupied by any association or church on whose behalf such solicitation is made or where solicitation is for a benefit to be held on the premises of the beneficiary; nor shall they be applicable to any association or church soliciting contributions from persons who are members thereof at the time of such solicitation; nor to any solicitation for the relief of any individual specified by name at the time of the solicitation where the solicitor represents in each case that the entire amount collected, without any deduction whatever, shall be turned over to the named beneficiary, nor shall they be applicable where anticipated contributions amount to less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Prior code § 21-81) 
5.20.110 - Application-Filing, contents, cannisters. 
A.  Filing. An application for a permit to make charitable or religious solicitations shall be made to the clerk. Such application shall be filed with the clerk at least ten (10) working days prior to the time the solicitation is to begin. 
B.  Contents. The application shall contain the following information or, in lieu thereof, a detailed statement of the reasons why such information cannot be furnished: 
1.  The name, address or headquarters of the person applying for the permit; 
2.  If the applicant is not an individual, the names and addresses of the applicant's principal officers and managers, and a copy of the formal authority, if any, authorizing such solicitation; 
3.  The purpose for which such solicitations is to be made, the total amount of funds proposed to be raised thereby, and the use to be made of any receipts therefrom; 
4.  A specific statement, supported by reasons and, if available, figures, showing the need for the contributions to be solicited; 
5.  The name and address of the person by whom the receipts of such solicitation shall be disbursed; 
6.  The name and address of the person who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitation, and the names of all professional fund raising counsel and professional promoters to be connected with the proposed solicitation; 
7.  An outline of the methods to be used in conducting the solicitation; 
8.  The entire time, giving preferred dates, during which such solicitation shall be made; 
9.  The estimated cost of solicitation; 
10.  If any person intends to solicit by means of coin or currency boxes, receptacles or cannisters, their application for a solicitation permit shall so state, the number of boxes, receptacles or cannisters to be used, the dates they will be used, and the method to be employed in distributing and picking them up. All cannisters shall be picked up promptly after the end of the authorized period. Each cannister must be identified by placing on each one, the name, local address and local phone number of the person or organization conducting the solicitation and effective dates of the cannister solicitation. An accounting shall be maintained of each cannister distribution; 
11.  The amount of all salaries, wages, fees and commissions, expenses and costs to be expended, and the maximum percentages of funds to be collected which are to be used to pay cost of solicitation and cost of promotion; 
12.  If a paid promoter is used by the organization, and the paid promoter is to receive payment of benefit for such services out of the funds collected, then such facts must be stated in the application, and there must be a written agreement between the organization and the promoter which contains all the terms and conditions of the arrangement and expressly sets out any payment or benefit to be paid to the promoter, and a copy of such agreement must be filed with the application; 
13.  A statement to the effect, that if a permit is granted, it will not be used in any way as an endorsement by the city; 
14.  The percentages of funds to be collected which are to be retained locally and used for the benefit of residents in the city; 
15.  Two photographs of each person who is to solicit funds. Such photographs shall be of appropriate size (approximately two inches by two inches), one of which shall be attached at all times to the permit, and the other shall be maintained in the records of the city. 
C.  If, while any application is pending, or during the term of any permit, there is any change in fact, policy, or method altering the information given in the application, the applicant shall so notify the clerk in writing within forty-eight (48) hours. 
(Prior code § 21-82) 
5.20.120 - Information to be public. 
    Any information contained in the application shall be considered public property and may be reproduced in any local medium to inform the citizens of the community. 
(Prior code § 21-83) 
5.20.130 - Investigation of application. 
    The clerk shall examine all applications filed for the permit required by Section 5.20.100 of this chapter and shall make or cause to be made, such further investigation of the application and the applicant, as well as any claim of exemption from the requirement of a permit under Section 5.20.100 as he or she shall deem necessary in order for him or her to perform his or her duties under this chapter. Upon request by the clerk, the applicant shall make available for inspection, all the applicant's books and records at any reasonable time before the application is granted, during the pendency of the application, during the time the permit is in effect, or after a permit has expired. 
(Prior code § 21-84) 
5.20.140 - Permit-Standards for granting, revoking or denying. 
    A charitable solicitation permit as provided for in Section 5.20.100 shall be issued by the clerk whenever the clerk finds that the following facts exist; and the clerk shall revoke or deny renewal of a permit when any of the following facts cease or fail to exist; provided, however, that whenever the clerk revokes or denies a permit the applicant or permittee shall be furnished with the clerk's findings of fact which are the basis for such revocation or denial. 
A.  That all the statements made in the application are true; 
B.  That the applicant has a good character for honesty and integrity or, if applicant is not an individual person, that every official and managing agent of the applicant has a good character and reputation for honesty and integrity; 
C.  That the solicitation will not mislead or defraud the public and, further, the solicitation material and the general promotional plan are neither false, misleading, nor deceptive, and that they afford full disclosure, and comply with any rules and regulations established pursuant to this article; 
D.  That the method or methods for solicitation outlined in the application do not include any of the following methods of solicitation: 
1.  Charitable or religious solicitation by children under fourteen (14) years of age where the child will be paid for such solicitation, 
2.  Delivery by mail or otherwise of any unordered merchandise, tickets or coupons, 
3.  That no part of the solicitation is conducted by any lottery or other device prohibited by law; 
E.  That the solicitation is promoted solely by a desire, the charitable cause described in the application, and will not be conducted primarily for private profit; 
F.  That upon request the solicitor will afford full disclosure to each person solicited, at the time of the solicitation, of the portion of each contribution which will be given the charitable organization; 
G.  That the methods of solicitation will not obstruct traffic or interfere with public safety; 
H.  That the solicitation is in compliance with all the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Prior code § 21-85) 
5.20.150 - Fee for filing application. 
    The clerk shall not consider any application unless a fee of five dollars ($5.00) is paid to the clerk. 
(Prior code § 21-86) 
5.20.160 - Permit contents-Duration. 
A.  Contents of Permit. Permits issued under this article shall be signed by the clerk and shall bear the name of the permittee, the permit number, the permittee's address, a telephone number at which information about the permittee and its charitable purpose can be obtained at least during the normal business hours, the expiration date of the permit, and a statement that the permit does not constitute an endorsement by the city. 
B.  Duration of Permit. The clerk shall determine from the application and from such facts as may be developed in connection with the application, the period for which the permit shall be approved provided that the period shall not exceed one year from its date and shall be limited to the duration of the particular program of charitable or religious solicitation with a separate permit being required for each such program. 
(Prior code § 21-87) 
5.20.170 - Permit transfer. 
    Any permit issued under this article shall be nontransferable. 
(Prior code § 21-88) 
5.20.180 - Appeals. 
A.  Request for Hearing. Within five days after receiving written notification in person or by mail, that application for a permit to solicit has been denied by the clerk, or that a permit after issuance, has been suspended by the clerk, such applicant or permittee may file with the clerk a written request for a public hearing to review the action of the clerk before the city council together with written exceptions to the findings of fact upon which the clerk bases his decision. The clerk shall refer said request with all files, records, and other data thereto pertaining to the city council. 
B.  Notice of Hearing. Upon the filing of such request and exceptions the clerk shall fix a time and place for the hearing before the city council, but not later than ten (10) days after the filing of the request, and shall notify the applicant for review of the time and place at least five days prior thereto. 
C.  Conduct of Hearing. At the hearing, the applicant for review may present evidence in support of such request and state exceptions to the findings and decision of the clerk. Any interested persons may, at the discretion of the city council, be allowed to participate in the hearing and present evidence in favor of or in opposition to the request or exceptions. 
D.  Decision. Within ten (10) days following the conclusion of the hearing, the city council shall render a written report, either sustaining, modifying or rejecting the original decision of the clerk. This report shall be filed in the clerk's office for public inspection, and a copy shall be served forthwith, in person, or by mail, upon the applicant for review and all parties to the hearing. 
(Prior code § 21-89) 
Article III. - Paid Promoters and Solicitors 

5.20.190 - Financial reports required. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons issued a paid promoter or solicitor's license to furnish the clerk within thirty (30) days after the solicitation has been completed, a detailed financial statement showing the amount raised by the solicitation, the amount expended in collecting such funds, including wages, fees, commissions, and expenses paid to any person in connection with the solicitation and the amount of funds dispersed to the charitable organization for which the solicitation was held. 
(Prior code § 21-101) 
5.20.200 - Segregation of funds. 
    No paid promoter or solicitor shall commingle any contributions with the paid promoter or solicitor's funds or property. 
(Prior code § 21-102) 
5.20.210 - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any paid promoter or solicitor to solicit, within the city, any contribution for any actual or purported charitable or religious purpose, unless said promoter or solicitor shall have first obtained a license from the clerk, covering each program of charitable or religious solicitation undertaken by said promoter or solicitor. 
(Prior code § 21-116) 
5.20.220 - License application. 
A.  Filing To obtain a paid promoter's or solicitor's license, the promoter or solicitor shall make and file, at least seven working days before the commencement of any solicitation, an application with the clerk for a license. 
B.  Contents. In such application, the applicant shall set forth, in addition to such other information as may be required by the clerk on an individual basis: 
1.  The name and address of the applicant; if such applicant is a corporation, the name and address of each of its managing officers and agents; and if it is an unincorporated association, firm or partnership, the name and address of each member of such unincorporated association, firm or partnership. 
2.  A statement of fact listing the past five charitable or religious organizations the applicant has solicited for, and the city where the solicitation took place. 
3.  The general plan or method by which the applicant proposes to conduct his or her business as a paid promoter or solicitor, a copy of any and all agreements or understandings made or had with any person or association in whose behalf such solicitation is being conducted, together with at least one copy of each of any such agreement or understanding which shall be in writing, and specifically the total compensation the promoter or solicitor is to receive for the promotion and solicitation. 
(Prior code § 21-117) 
5.20.230 - Investigation of applicant-License issuance. 
    The clerk shall examine each application for a certificate of approval, and shall make such further investigation of the applicant as the clerk shall deem necessary. The clerk shall issue to the applicant a license to solicit as a paid promoter or solicitor if from such investigation, the clerk shall be satisfied: 
A.  That all of the statements made in the application are true; 
B.  That the applicant has not in the past ten (10) years: 
1.  Been convicted of a crime involving solicitations for or on behalf of any charitable or religious organization, or 
2.  Been convicted of any crime involving misrepresentation, deceit or fraud, or 
3.  Been found in any civil or administrative proceedings to have committed any act of misrepresentation, deceit, or fraud; 
C.  That in any telephone appeal in conjunction with a charitable or religious solicitation each telephone solicitor shall: 
1.  Clearly and accurately disclose at the onset of the solicitation the name of the paid promoter or solicitor, the name on whose behalf the solicitation is being made, and the purpose of the telephone call, 
2.  Be provided a copy of the solicitation permit and upon request must furnish information from this to individuals being solicited by telephone for a contribution, 
3.  Shall furnish to each purchaser or contributor an invoice, receipt or statement containing the name of the paid promoter, the address and telephone number from which the solicitation was made, and the name of the charitable organization on whose behalf the solicitation was made; 
D.  That the general plant of the proposed solicitation conforms to Missouri and federal laws and the ordinances of the city. 
(Prior code § 21-118) 
5.20.240 - Notice of denial of license application. 
    In the event the clerk denies the application for a license, the clerk shall notify the applicant, in person or by mail, of the clerk's decision, giving the applicant a written statement of his or her reasons for such denial. 
(Prior code § 21-119) 
5.20.250 - License term. 
    Every paid promoter or solicitor's license issued under this article shall expire at the end of the program of charitable or religious solicitation for which it was issued, and in no case shall it extend beyond one year. 
(Prior code § 21-120) 
5.20.260 - License suspension and revocation. 
    Upon complaint being filed and verified by the clerk, or upon the clerk's own initiative and investigation, if it is found that any person to whom a license has been issued under this article has violated any of the requirements of this article, or that the licensee, his or her agent or solicitor, or other employees have made untrue statements or misrepresented the purpose of the solicitation, or has failed to fully account for contributions coming into the promoter or solicitor's hands, the clerk may suspend such license. The licensee may then have the same recourse from the clerk's decision as is provided in Section 5.20.180 for persons whose permits have been revoked or suspended. 
(Prior code § 21-121) 
Chapter 5.24 - GARAGE SALES 
Sections: 

5.24.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section. 
    "Garage sale" means and includes all general sales, open to the public, conducted from or on a residential premises in any residential zone, as defined by the zoning ordinance, for the purpose of disposing of personal property, including, but not limited to, all sales entitled "garage," "lawn," "yard," "attic," "porch," "room," "backyard," "patio," "flea market," "rummage," or "moving sale." 
    "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association, organization or corporation of any kind. 
    "Personal property" means property which is owned, utilized and maintained by any individual or members of his or her residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence, but not including motor vehicles. It does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment, or food items not grown on the premises. 
    "Residential premises" means a building or portion thereof designed exclusively for residential occupancy, including one-family, two-family and multiple dwellings. 
(Prior code § 13-190) 
5.24.020 - Permit required. 
    No garage sale shall be conducted unless and until the person desiring to conduct such sales shall obtain a permit therefor from the public works department. Members of more than one residence may join in obtaining a permit for a garage sale to be conducted at the residence of one of them; however, individuals of more than one residence joining together to conduct concurrent garage sales must obtain a garage sale permit for each residence. 
(Prior code § 13-191) 
5.24.030 - Written application required. 
    Prior to the issuance of any garage sale permit, the person conducting such sale shall file a written application which may be obtained from the public works department during regular business hours. The written application shall set forth the following information: 
A.  Full name and address of each applicant or applicants if multiple residence; 
B.  The location at which the proposed garage sale is to be held; 
C.  The date or dates upon which the sale shall be held; 
D.  The date or dates of any other garage sales within the current calendar year; 
E.  An affirmative statement that the property to be sold was owned by the applicant as his or her own personal property and was neither acquired or consigned for the purposes of resale; 
F.  An affirmative statement that the applicant agrees to abide by all North Kansas City ordinances in conjunction with the operation of the garage sale. 
(Prior code § 13-192) 
5.24.040 - Fee. 
    There shall be an administrative processing fee of three dollars ($3.00) for each permit. 
(Prior code § 13-193) 
5.24.050 - Number of sales allowed and permit conditions. 
    The permit shall set forth and restrict the time and location of such garage sale. No more than two such permits may be issued to one residential premise during any calendar year. If members of more than one residence join in requesting the permit, then the permit shall be considered as having been issued for each and all residences. 
(Prior code § 13-194) 
5.24.060 - Hours of operation. 
    Each garage sale shall be limited to no more than the daylight hours of three consecutive days. 
(Prior code § 13-195) 
5.24.070 - Exceptions. 
A.  A Sale Not Held Because of Inclement Weather. If a garage sale is not held on the day for which the permit is issued or is terminated during the first day of the sale because of inclimate weather conditions, and an affidavit by the permit holder to this effect is submitted, the public works department may issue another permit to the applicant for a garage sale to be conducted at the same location within thirty (30) days from the date when the first sale was to be held. No additional permit fee is required. 
B.  Third Sale Permitted. A third garage sale shall be permitted in a calendar year if satisfactory proof of a bona fide change in ownership of the real property is first presented to public works. 
(Prior code § 13-196) 
5.24.080 - Investigation. 
    The department of public works may conduct an investigation as may reasonably be necessary to determine if there is compliance with this chapter. 
(Prior code § 13-197) 
5.24.090 - Display of sale property. 
    Personal property offered for sale may be displayed within the residence, in a garage, carport, and/or yard, but only such areas. No personal property offered for sale at a garage sale shall be displayed in any public street or right-of-way. 
(Prior code § 13-198) 
5.24.100 - Display of permit. 
    Any permit in possession of the holder of a garage sale shall be posted on the premises during the time the sale is conducted in a conspicuous place visible to the public. 
(Prior code § 13-199) 
5.24.110 - Property permitted to be sold. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell goods at a garage sale that have been purchased for resale; or to sell goods accepted or taken in for sale from any commercial business or enterprise on a consignment basis, or to sell goods that accumulated in ordinary dwelling usage. 
(Prior code § 13-200) 
5.24.120 - Advertising. 
A.  Signs Permitted. Only the following specified signs may be displayed in relation to a pending garage sale: 
1.  On-site Signs Permitted. Two signs of not more than four square feet each shall be permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence where the garage sale is being conducted. 
2.  Off-site Signs Permitted. Two signs of not more than four square feet each are permitted; provided, that permission to erect such signs is received from the property owners upon whose property such signs are to be placed. 
3.  Prohibited Signs. No signs shall be erected, placed, posted or otherwise displayed on any public property, including street signs and posts, traffic signs and posts, or upon public utility pole or street light standard. 
B.  Time Limitations. Such signs shall not be erected sooner than twelve (12) hours prior to the time and date of sale. Signs must be removed at the close of the garage sale activities. 
C.  Removal of Signs. The person responsible for conducting such garage sale shall be responsible for removing any such sign. 
D.  Violation. Persons responsible for nonconforming signs or signs not placed in accordance with this chapter may be subject to penalties pursuant to Section 5.24.170. Nonconforming signs or signs not placed in accordance with this chapter shall be removed by city employees. 
(Prior code § 13-201) 
5.24.130 - Public nuisance. 
    The person to whom such permit is issued and the owner or tenant of the premises upon which such sale or activity is conducted shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of good order and decorum on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity. No such person shall permit any loud boisterous conduct on said premises nor permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the area of such premises. All such individuals shall obey the reasonable orders of any member of the police, fire, or public works departments of the city in order to maintain the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Prior code § 13-202) 
5.24.140 - Inspection. 
    A police officer, code enforcement officer or any other official designated by any city ordinance to make inspections pursuant to a licensing or regulating ordinance or to enforce the same, shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a garage sale for the purpose of enforcement or inspection and may close the premises from such a sale or cite any individual who violates the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 13-203) 
5.24.150 - Parking. 
    All parking of vehicles shall be conducted in compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances. Further, the police department may enforce such temporary controls to alleviate any special hazards and/or congestion created by any garage sale. 
(Prior code § 13-204) 
5.24.160 - Revocation and refusal of permit. 
A.  False Information. Any permit issued under this chapter may be revoked or any application for issuance of a permit may be refused by the public works department if the application submitted by the applicant or permit holder contains any false, fraudulent or misleading statement. 
B.  Conviction of Violation. If any person is convicted of an offense under this chapter, the department of public works is instructed to cancel any existing garage sale permit held by the person convicted and not to issue such person another garage sale permit for a period of one year from the time of conviction. 
(Prior code § 13-205) 
5.24.170 - Penalty. 
    It is unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. Upon conviction thereof, such person shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or be punished by incarceration for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and incarceration. Each day's violation of, or failure, refusal or neglect to comply with, any provisions of this chapter shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Prior code § 13-206) 
5.24.180 - Persons exempted from chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to affect the following: 
A.  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
B.  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; 
C.  Any bona fide charitable, eleemosynary, educational, cultural or governmental institution or organization when the proceeds from the sale are used directly for the institution or organization's charitable purposes and the goods or articles are not sold on a consignment basis. 
(Prior code § 13-207) 
Chapter 5.28 - HANDBILLS AND BILLPOSTERS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Handbills 

5.28.010 - Intent and purpose. 
    The city council finds and declares that to protect the people against the nuisance of and incident to the promiscuous distribution of handbills and circulars, with the resulting detriment and danger to public health and safety, the public interest, convenience and necessity requires the regulation thereof and to that end the purposes of the ordinance codified in this article are specifically declared to be as follows: 
A.  To protect local residents against trespassing by solicitors, canvassers or handbill distributors upon the private property of such residents if they have given reasonable notice that they do not wish to be solicited by such persons or do not desire to receive handbills or advertising matter; 
B.  To protect the people against the health and safety menace and the expense incident to the littering of the streets and public places by the promiscuous and uncontrolled distribution of advertising matter and commercial and noncommercial handbills; and 
C.  To preserve the people's constitutional right to receive and disseminate information. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-1) 
5.28.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Commercial handbill" means and includes any printed or written matter, any sample or device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature: 
1.  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing; 
2.  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interests thereof by sales; 
3.  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; but the terms of this clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, when either of the same is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided, that nothing contained in this clause shall be derived to authorize the holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of this state, or under any ordinance of this city; or 
4.  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    "Newspaper" means and includes any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the United States Postal Service, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and, in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    "Noncommercial handbill" means and includes any printed or written matter, any sample or device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a commercial handbill or a newspaper. 
    "Obscene" means material which depicts or describes sexual conduct that is objectionable or offensive to accepted standards of decency which the average person, applying contemporary community standards would find, taken as a whole, appeals to prurient interests or material which depicts or describes, in a patently offensive way, sexual conduct specifically defined by the applicable state law, which, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
    "Person" means and includes any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    "Private premises" means and includes any dwelling, house, building, or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited, uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, or other structure. 
    "Public place" means and includes any and all streets, boulevards, avenues, lanes, alleys, or other public ways, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, plazas, grounds and buildings. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-2) 
5.28.030 - Posting notice, placard, bill etc., prohibited. 
    No person shall post, stick, stamp, paint or otherwise affix, or cause the same to be done by any person, any notice, placard, bill, card, poster, advertisement or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public, to or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or curbstone, flagstone, or any other portion or part of any public way or public place, or any lamp post, electric light, telegraph, telephone or trolley line pole, or railway structure, hydrant, shade tree or tree-box, or upon the piers, columns, trusses, girders, railings, gates or other parts of any public bridge or viaduct, or other public structure or building, or upon any pole, box or fixture of the fire alarm except such as may be authorized or required by the laws of the United States, or the state of Missouri, and the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-3) 
5.28.040 - Throwing handbills in public places prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any public place within the city. Provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any commercial or noncommercial handbill in any public place to any person willing to accept such handbill. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-4) 
5.28.050 - Placing handbills in or upon vehicles prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any automobile or other vehicle. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the handing, transmitting or distributing of any commercial or noncommercial handbill to the owner or other occupant of any automobile or other vehicle, who is willing to accept the same. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-5) 
5.28.060 - Distribution of handbills on uninhabited or vacant private premises prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are uninhabited or vacant. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-6) 
5.28.070 - Distribution of handbills where prohibition property posted. 
    It is unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on such premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisements," or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of such premises do not desire to be molested or to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any such commercial or noncommercial handbills left upon such premises. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-7) 
5.28.080 - Distributing handbills at private premises-Exceptions. 
A.  No person shall throw, deposit, or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or other person then present in or upon such private premises; provided, that, except where the premises are posted as provided in this article or where anyone upon the premises requests otherwise, a person may place or deposit any such commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon such private premises, if such handbill is contained in a plastic bag ventilated with air holes throughout the surface of the bag, or unventilated plastic bag no greater than six inches in width, or if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks, streets, or other public places. Mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
B.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States or to newspapers; except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place or upon private property. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-8) 
5.28.090 - Handbills depicting certain matter prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to post, handout, distribute or transmit any sign, or any handbill: 
A.  Which is reasonably likely to incite or to produce imminent lawless action; or 
B.  Which is obscene or unlawful. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-9) 
5.28.100 - Existing ordinances not affected. 
    The ordinance codified in this article shall not be deemed to repeal, amend or modify any ordinance ever ordained, either prohibiting, regulating or licensing canvassers, hawkers, peddlers, transient merchants, or any person using the public streets or places for any private business or enterprise, or for commercial sales, not covered herein. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-10) 
5.28.110 - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine or penalty of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than three months, or both. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-11) 
5.28.120 - Severability. 
    If any provision, or portion of a provision, of this chapter, or its application to any person or circumstances, shall be held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter, or the application of the provision to other persons or circumstances, shall not be affected. 
(Ord. 7272 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-12) 
Article II. - Distributor's License 

5.28.130 - Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a billposter for hire or as a handbill distributor for hire, or for any person to distribute commercial handbills, without first complying with the terms of this chapter and all other relevant laws and regulations; provided, that nothing contained herein shall apply to any person advertising his or her business or activity upon his or her own premises, if such business or activity is regularly established at a definite location in such city; and, also if a license has been obtained therefor, if such license be required under the terms of any applicable law, provision of this code or other ordinance of the city. 
(Prior code § 12-31) 
5.28.140 - Application. 
    Any person desiring to engage, as principal, either in the business of a billposter for hire or in the business of distributing commercial handbills for hire shall make application to and receive from the city clerk, or other officer empowered to issue the same, who shall act whenever the city clerk is herein referred to, a license in the manner and for the period prescribed by the terms of this chapter and by all relevant provisions of this code. Such applicant shall make written application to the city clerk upon a form provided for such purpose by the city clerk. Such form shall contain, among other things that may be required, the name, the business address and a brief description of the nature of the business to be conducted by the applicant, the probable number of agents and employees so to be engaged, together with a request for a license for the period for which the applicant seeks to engage in such business. 
(Prior code § 12-32) 
5.28.150 - Fee. 
    License fees under the terms of this chapter, and for any such purpose, shall be as follows: 
For a period of one year $50.00 For a period of three months 25.00 For a period of one week $10.00 For a period of one day 5.00  
Provided, that persons acting for licensees, as agents or employees, in the posting or distributing of any such signs or handbills, shall not be required to obtain a license or pay a fee, but each such person shall comply with each of the other provisions of this chapter and be subject thereto. 
(Prior code § 12-33) 
5.28.160 - Revocation-Transferability-Refund of fee. 
    Without excluding other just grounds for revocation, the city council, or official so empowered by law, may revoke any license obtained under an application containing a false or fraudulent statement knowingly made by the applicant with intent to obtain a license by means of false or fraudulent representations, or for violation of this chapter, or any other grounds specified by law. Such application shall be accompanied by the fee provided for in this chapter. No license issued under this chapter shall be transferable and if any such license shall be surrendered by the licensee therein named, or shall be revoked for cause, neither the licensee named in such license, nor any other person, shall be entitled to any refund of any part of such fee. 
(Prior code § 12-34) 
Chapter 5.32 - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8895, § 1, adopted Mar. 15, 2016, repealed former Ch. 5.32, §§ 5.32.010-5.32.210, and enacted a new chapter as set out herein. The former chapter pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

5.32.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Adult-oriented merchandise" means any sexually-oriented implements, paraphernalia, or novelty items, including, but not limited to, condoms and sexually-oriented items that are designed or marketed primarily for the stimulation of human genital organs. 
    "Applicant" means an individual, or if not an individual, the general partner, chief executive officer, manager, or other person responsible for the ownership and operation of the massage establishment, who applies to obtain a massage establishment permit under this chapter. In the case of an employee permit, "applicant" means an individual who applies for a permit under this chapter. 
    "Employee" means any person who renders any service on the premises of a massage establishment, whether part-time, full-time, temporary, permanent, or independent contractor, regardless of whether such services are provided for compensation. 
    "Massage" means health care or health maintenance techniques or procedures carried out by a massage therapist involving pressure on or friction against, or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of a person's skin, muscles, and tissues or the stretching of body limbs with the hands or with the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance with or without such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powder, creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations commonly used in this practice. 
    "Massage establishment" means a fixed location used as a place of business where any person engages in or carries on or permits to be engaged in or carried on any form of massage. 
    "Massage therapist" means any person who, for any consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage as defined in this section. For the purposes of this ordinance, "massage therapist," "masseuse," "masseur," and "massage technician" shall have the same meaning. 
    "On-site massage therapy" means any massage therapy performed or administered for compensation by a licensed massage therapist at a location other than a licensed massage establishment. 
    "Patron" means any person who utilizes or receives the benefit of services of any establishment or occupation provided for in this chapter under such circumstances that he or she will pay money or give any other consideration therefor. 
    "Permittee" means any person possessing a permit required and issued under this chapter, or any owner or operator of the permitted massage establishment. 
    "Sexual or genital area" means the genitals, pubic area, buttocks (except in massage), anus or perineum of any person, and the breasts of a female. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.020 - Permits required. 
A.  Massage Establishment Permit. No person shall operate a massage establishment as defined in Section 5.32.010 without first having obtained a massage establishment permit pursuant to the requirements of this chapter. A separate permit shall be required for each and every separate massage establishment and at any change in ownership of any establishment. 
B.  Employee Permit. No person shall be employed as a massage therapist, whether a part-time, full-time, permanent or temporary employee or independent contractor, in any establishment subject to the provisions of this chapter unless he or she has a valid employee permit issued by the city pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
C.  Permits Nontransferable. No permit, whether for a massage establishment or an employee, shall be sold, transferred, or assigned by the permittee or by operation of law to any other person. Any such sale, transfer, or assignment, or attempt to do same, shall constitute an immediate revocation of the permit and the permit shall thereafter be null and void. A new owner of a massage therapy establishment must submit a new application for a massage establishment permit in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.030 - Exemptions. 
    The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to the following while engaged in the performance of the duties of their respective professions: 
A.  Physicians, surgeons, osteopaths, chiropractors, nurses, or physical therapists who are licensed by the state; 
B.  Hospitals, clinics and other health facilities licensed by the state; 
C.  Barbers and beauticians who are licensed by this state, except that this exemption shall apply solely to massaging the neck, face, scalp, and hair of the patron for cosmetic or beautifying purposes; 
D.  Athletic trainers for amateur, semi-professional, or professional athletic organizations; 
E.  State licensed massage therapists providing services under the supervision of a licensed medical professional or on the premises of a health facility licensed by the state; and 
F.  State licensed massage therapists providing massage services at special events such as conventions, sporting events, conferences, exhibitions, or workplace health events for no more than ten days cumulatively in one calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.040 - Where permitted. 
    Massage services shall be provided only at massage establishments holding a valid massage establishment permit or at facilities exempt from the permit requirement pursuant to Section 5.32.030. Except when provided under the direction or supervision of a state licensed medical professional, on-site massage therapy is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.100 - Massage establishment permit application requirements. 
A.  Each applicant for a massage establishment permit shall file a written application with the chief of police on a form provided by the police department. The filing of an application does not authorize the applicant to provide massage therapy services. 
B.  Applications will be considered complete when all items required by these regulations and the application fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) have been submitted to the chief of police. Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with a written explanation of deficiencies. The city shall take no further action on incomplete applications. 
C.  Each applicant shall submit the following information in the application: 
1.  The full, true name under which the business will be conducted. 
2.  The address where the business is to be conducted. 
3.  The applicant's full, true name, including all other names used presently or in the past, date of birth, state or federal identification number from a valid government issued document, Social Security number, present residence address and telephone number, gender, weight, height, and hair and eye color. 
4.  The names and addresses of all persons financially interested in the business. 
5.  The applicant's two most recent street addresses and the dates of residence at each address. 
6.  Document to prove that the applicant has a lawful right to work in the United States. 
7.  The name, street address, and telephone number of other businesses in which the applicant has owned or been employed within the past seven years. This shall include the dates of employment, positions held by the applicant, and a contact person for each. Applicant shall disclose or declare that within the seven years preceding submission of the application, the owner, operator, manager, and/or responsible managing officer/employee has not: 
a.  Had a massage establishment, massage therapist, or other similar permit of license denied, suspended, or revoked by the city or any other federal, state, or local agency; 
b.  Engaged in conduct or operated a massage therapy or similar establishment in a manner that would be grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of a permit under this chapter; or 
c.  Owned or managed a massage establishment or similar establishment where persons required to be licensed were allowed to work without the required license or permit. 
8.  A statement of the permit history of the applicant which identified whether or not such person has ever held a professional or vocational license or permit, other than as required under this chapter, issued by any agency, board, city, county, or state; the date of issuance of such permit or license; whether or not the permit or license is still in effect; if the permit of license is no longer in effect, whether or not it was revoked or suspended, and if so, the reasons therefor; and the name and location of the jurisdiction or agency that suspended or revoked such license or permit. 
9.  Applicant's criminal convictions in Missouri or any other jurisdiction for offenses other than traffic violations within ten years of the date of application. For the purposes of this subsection, the term applicant shall apply to: 
a.  An individual if the applicant is an individual; 
b.  Any officers, directors, stockholders holding more than five percent of the stock of the corporation, and the managing responsible officer, if the applicant is a corporation; and 
c.  Any partners and the managing responsible officer, if the applicant is a partnership. 
10.  The name, address, and telephone number of any massage business or other similar establishment owned or operated by any person whose name is required to be given pursuant to this section. 
11.  If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the state and date of incorporation and the name, residential address, and telephone number of each of its current officers and directors, along with the amount of stock held. The applicant shall designate one of its officers to act as its responsible managing officer. 
12.  If the applicant is a partnership, the application shall set forth the name, residential address, and telephone number of each of the partners. If the applicant is a limited partnership, it shall furnish a copy of its certificate of limited partnership. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporate applicants shall apply to the corporate partner. The applicant shall designate one of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. 
13.  A statement regarding whether the applicant intends to personally provide massage therapy services at the business and if so, proof of a state issued massage therapy license. 
14.  Proof of state issued licenses for any employees or independent contractors who will perform massage services at the massage establishment. 
15.  The name, address, telephone number, and date of birth of each massage therapist or employee who is or will be employed at the massage establishment, regardless of the nature of the employment. 
16.  Two recent, identical, passport-size, color photographs of the applicant and any employees or independent contractors who will be performing massage services at the applicant's massage establishment. 
17.  Fingerprints taken by a representative of the police department and submitted to the criminal justice information system for processing pursuant to this chapter. 
18.  Written authorization for the city, its agents, and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and into the background of the applicant and the responsible managing officer of the massage establishment, including a waiver authorizing a criminal history records check for the applicant and all owners. 
19.  Such other identification and information shall be provided as required by the chief of police, necessary to discover the truth of the matters specified and required in the application. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.110 - Other licenses and permits required. 
    Any applications made, fees paid and permits obtained under the provisions of this chapter shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other fees, permits or licenses required to be paid or obtained under any ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.120 - Application review. 
    The complete application and any supplementary materials shall be reviewed by the chief of police or his designee. The chief of police may verify the information submitted by the applicant and further investigate the qualifications of the applicant as follows: 
A.  The police department shall take a full set of the applicant's fingerprints and shall submit the fingerprints to the criminal justice information system for evaluation. Upon receipt of the report from the criminal justice information system, the chief of police shall review the criminal history of the applicant; 
B.  The chief of police may conduct additional investigations in a manner authorized by law when necessary to determine if the applicant meets the qualification for a permit pursuant to this chapter; and 
C.  The chief of police shall refer the application to other city departments, as appropriate, to ensure compliance with applicable local, state, and federal laws and regulations, including, but not limited to, building, zoning, health, and fire safety regulations. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.130 - Permit issuance or denial. 
A.  The chief of police shall issue or deny the application for a massage establishment permit within sixty (60) calendar days of the submission of a complete application. When necessary, the chief of police may extend the time to issue or deny the permit by providing notice to the applicant. 
B.  The chief of police shall deny a permit if any of the following circumstances exists: 
1.  The application is incomplete or required supplementary material is not submitted within thirty (30) calendar days of the date the material is requested; 
2.  The applicant fails to provide proof of a valid massage business license issued by the State of Missouri; 
3.  The operation as proposed by the applicant would not comply with all applicable ordinances and laws, including, but not limited to, the city's building, health, and fire safety codes and the zoning ordinance; 
4.  The applicant has previously had a massage establishment permit, massage employee permit, or any similar license, certificate, or permit revoked by the city or any public agency; 
5.  The applicant is found to have made a material misstatement or omission in the application; or 
6.  The applicant has been convicted of any of the following offenses during the seven years preceding the date of the application: any felony or any offense involving sexual misconduct, obscenity, solicitation of a lewd or unlawful act, prostitution, or pandering. 
C.  If prosecution is pending against the applicant for any conduct listed above or for conduct violating this chapter's provisions, the chief of police may postpone decision on the application until the final resolution of the prosecution. As used in this subsection, prosecution means charges filed by the district attorney, administrative proceedings brought by a local government or agency, or a civil or administrative action maintained by any city, county, or state. 
D.  Notice of Postponement or Denial Required. The chief of police shall give written notice of a postponement in reviewing an application or of an application denial. Notice of denial shall include the grounds for the denial and advise the applicant of the right to appeal the denial. Notice shall be provided to the applicant personally or by first class mail to the address provided in the application. 
E.  Permit Duration and Renewal. A permit shall be valid from January 1 to December 31 of the calendar year unless revoked or suspended. 
1.  A permittee may apply for a renewal of a permit thirty calendar days prior to the expiration of the permit. If a permit expires before a permittee applies for a renewal, a new application shall be filed. No privilege to provide massage therapy services shall exist until a renewal application has been approved. 
2.  Permits may be renewed by filing an application for renewal updating information in the original application provided to the chief of police. 
3.  Proof of state issued massage therapy licenses for all massage therapists employed in any capacity by the massage establishment shall accompany the application for renewal. Proof of state licenses for all new massage therapists hired by a massage establishment shall be submitted to the chief of police within thirty (30) days of hiring a new massage therapist. 
4.  After investigating the application for renewal, the chief of police shall renew the permit if the permittee continues to meet the requirements for issuance of a permit and none of the grounds for denial of a permit set forth in the chapter are found. The chief of police shall renew the permit within thirty (30) calendar days of such request if the information upon which the original application was granted remains unchanged and no violations of this chapter have been committed. 
5.  The permittee must update the chief of police of any violation of this chapter or any change in the state of the state issued massage therapy license of any employee or independent contractor within thirty (30) calendar days of the violation of change in licensure. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.140 - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
A.  The chief of police may revoke or suspend any permit granted under this chapter if any of the following are found: 
1.  The permittee does not possess the qualifications for the permit as required by this article; 
2.  The permittee has been found to be in violation of any provision of this chapter; 
3.  The permittee has engaged in conduct or operated a massage establishment or has engaged in conduct as a massage therapist in a manner that violates this chapter or any of the laws that would have been grounds for denial of the permit; 
4.  There is fraud, material misrepresentation, false statement, or omission of a material fact in any application for a permit or in any supplementary material; 
5.  An activity authorized in the permit has been conducted in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public; 
6.  The permittee is providing on-site massage therapy services in violation of Section 5.32.040; 
7.  The permittee or employee fails to grant immediate access to a massage establishment for an inspection conducted pursuant to Section 5.32.310 or hinders an officer's inspection efforts; or 
8.  Any prohibited activity or violation of any relevant state or federal statute, including, but not limited to, any felony or any offense involving sexual misconduct, obscenity, solicitation of a lewd or unlawful act, prostitution, or pandering. 
B.  Duties of Responsible Managing Officer. The responsible managing officer of the massage establishment shall, at all times, meet all of the requirements set for permittees by this chapter or the permit shall be suspended until a responsible managing officer who meets such requirements is designated. If no such person is found within ninety (90) calendar days after the permit's suspension, the corporation or partnership's permit is deemed revoked. If the corporation or partnership wishes to reapply for a permit, a new application shall be filed. 
C.  Procedure. If a permit for a massage establishment is revoked or suspended, the permittee may make an appeal to the city council to determine whether or not such permit shall be suspended or revoked or whether the permit may be retained. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.150 - Appeals. 
A.  If a permit for a massage establishment is denied or revoked, an applicant may, within seven calendar days after such action is taken, request a hearing before the city council. 
B.  Burden of Proof. Unless otherwise specifically prohibited by law, the burden of proof is on the applicant or permittee in any hearing or other matter under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.200 - Employee permit application. 
A.  Any person employed to perform massage therapy services in a massage establishment shall file a written application to the chief of police for a massage establishment employee permit. 
B.  The application for an employee permit shall contain the following: 
1.  Legal name, address, and contact information; 
2.  Two portrait photographs at least two inches by two inches; 
3.  Applicant's weight, height, eye and hair color; 
4.  Written evidence that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
5.  Business, occupation, or employment of the applicant for the three years immediately preceding the date of application; 
6.  Whether such person has ever been convicted of any crime except minor traffic violations. If any applicant has been so convicted, a statement must be made giving the place and court in which the conviction was obtained and the sentence imposed as a result; 
7.  Proof of State of Missouri massage therapist license; 
8.  Fingerprints taken by a representative of the police department and submitted to the criminal justice information system for processing; 
9.  Authorization for the city to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the permit; and 
10.  An application fee in the amount of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
C.  The chief of police shall issue an employee permit within twenty-one (21) calendar days following the receipt of a complete application, unless: 
1.  The applicant is under the age of eighteen (18); 
2.  The applicant has been convicted of any felony or any offense involving sexual misconduct, obscenity, solicitation of a lewd or unlawful act, prostitution, or pandering; 
3.  The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or fraudulent statement of fact in the permit application or in any document required by the city in conjunction therewith. 
D.  Revocation or Suspension. 
1.  An employee permit may be revoked or suspended when the employee is found to be in violation of the requirements of this chapter or when the employee has been convicted of any offense listed in Section 5.32.200(C)(2). 
2.  Before revoking or suspending any employee permit, the chief of police or his designee shall give the employee at least ten (10) days' written notice of the pending revocation or suspension and the opportunity for a public hearing, at which hearing the relevant facts regarding the suspension or revocation shall be determined. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.210 - Employee permit card. 
    Massage therapists shall, at all times when working in a massage establishment, have in their possession a valid permit identification card issued by the city and keep their permit card available for inspection upon request of any person who by law may inspect same. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.300 - Facilities and operating requirements. 
    Every massage establishment and massage therapist shall comply with standards established by the State of Missouri for such businesses and practitioners and the following facilities and operations requirements: 
A.  Applicable Code Requirements. The massage establishment's premises and facilities shall meet all applicable code requirements of the city, county, and state, including but not limited to those related to the safety of structures, adequacy of plumbing, lighting, heating, ventilation, waterproofing, and the health and cleanliness of the facility and shall be maintained in the appropriate condition. 
B.  Permits Displayed. The massage establishment permit and a copy of the State of Missouri massage therapist license of each and every massage therapist providing services on the premises shall be displayed in an open and conspicuous place on the premises. 
C.  Provision of Towels. Massage establishments and massage therapists shall at all times have an adequate supply of clean and sanitary towels, coverings, and linens. Towels, non-disposable coverings, and linens shall not be used on more than one client, unless they have first been laundered and disinfected. Disposable towels and disposable coverings shall not be used on more than one client. Soiled linens and paper towels shall be deposited in separate receptacles. 
D.  Cleanliness of Premises. All rooms, steam or vapor rooms or cabinets, shower and bathrooms, tanning booths, baths, and pools shall be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected as needed, but no less than once each day when the premises are open. Bathtubs shall be thoroughly cleaned with a disinfectant after each use. All walls, ceilings, floors, and other physical facilities for the establishment shall be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
E.  Cleanliness of Equipment. All equipment used in the massage therapy shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Instruments used in providing massage therapy shall not be used on more than one client unless they have been sterilized, using standard sterilization methods. 
F.  Dressing Rooms. If separate dressing rooms are offered, they may be occupied by no more than one person at a time. Dressing rooms need not be separate from the room in which the massage therapy is being performed. 
G.  Toilets. Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations within the massage establishment and shall consist of at least one unisex toilet with lavatories or wash basins provided with soap and both hot and cold running water either in the toilet room or vestibule.
