H.  Employee Wash Basins. A minimum of one wash basin for employees shall be provided at all times. The wash basin shall be located within or as close as practicable to the area devoted to performing massage therapy services. Soap and sanitary towels shall be provided at each basin. 
I.  Operating Hours. No massage establishment shall be open and no persons shall be on the premises of the establishment between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
J.  Alcoholic Beverages Prohibited. No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served, furnished, kept, consumed, or possessed on the premises of any massage establishment. 
K.  Controlled Substances. No controlled substances shall be consumed, kept, or possessed on the premises of any massage establishment unless the person has a prescription for the substance. 
L.  List of Services Provided. A list of all available services and the name of the on-site operator shall be posted in public view on the wall closest to the main entrance of the massage establishment. No owner, manager, operator, or permit shall permit, and no employee shall offer or perform any service other than those permitted under this article and listed on the posted list of available services. 
M.  Sexual Activity Prohibited. No permittee or employee of a massage establishment shall: 
1.  Expose the sexual or genital area of the permittee or employee in the course of a massage; 
2.  Touch or expose the sexual or genital area of any other person in the course of a massage; or 
3.  Perform massage therapy on a patron with the intent or purpose of arousing, appealing to, or gratifying the sexual desires of said patron. 
N.  Employee Attire. All employees must be modestly and professionally attired. No permittee or employee of a massage establishment shall perform any task or service associated with the massage establishment while nude, semi-nude, or dressed in lingerie, see-through, or transparent attire. 
O.  Advertising. No permittee or employee of a massage establishment shall place, publish, or distribute, or cause to be placed, published, or distributed any advertising matter that depicts any portion of the human body that would reasonably suggest to prospective patrons that any service is available that is prohibited under this chapter, or that employees are dressed in any manner other than described in Section 5.32.110(M), nor shall any massage establishment employ language in any advertising text or business name that would reasonably suggest to a prospective patron that any services is available that is prohibited under this chapter. 
P.  Adult-Oriented Merchandise Prohibited. The use or possession of adult-oriented merchandise in or on any part of a massage establishment is expressly prohibited. Condoms shall not be kept or used for any purpose in the massage establishment. 
Q.  Recordings. No electrical, mechanical, or artificial device shall be used by the owner, operator, permittee, manager, massage therapist, or any employee of the massage establishment for audio and/or video recording or still photography or for monitoring the performance of a massage, or the conversation or other sounds in the massage rooms without the knowledge and written consent of the patron. 
R.  Certain Doors Remain Unlocked. 
1.  A cubicle, room, booth, or treatment room on the premises of a massage establishment shall remain unlocked when in use to provide massage services. 
2.  All entrance and exit doors on the premises of a massage establishment shall remain unlocked during business hours unless only one employee is on the premises of the establishment. Locked doors shall be promptly opened when requested by inspection officers. 
S.  Residential Use Prohibited. A massage establishment shall not be used for residential or sleeping purposes. 
T.  Privacy. 
1.  No person other than the patron and the patron's immediate family or guardian is allowed in the massage room while the patron is dressing or undressing. 
2.  No person other than the patron, the massage therapist assigned to the patron, and the patron's immediate family or guardian is allowed in the massage room if any door into the massage room is closed. Others may be in the massage room so long as all doors to the room are fully open. 
U.  Massage establishment employees may not inquire as to whether any patron is a peace officer. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.310 - Inspections. 
    The chief of police or his designated representatives may from time to time make an inspection of any massage establishment in the city for the purposes of determining compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Such inspections shall be made at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner. It is unlawful for any permittee to fail to allow such inspection officers immediate access to the premises or to hinder such officer in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.320 - Responsibility of permittee. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the massage establishment permittee to ensure that any employee complies with the requirements of this chapter and all laws. The massage establishment permittee shall be held responsible for the conduct of all employees on the premises. Any act or omission of any person providing massage therapy shall be deemed the act or omission of the permittee for the purposes of determining whether a permit may be revoked, suspended, or denied. Proof of knowledge of any violation of this chapter shall not be required for purposes of suspension, revocation, or denial of a massage establishment permit. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
5.32.330 - Applicability to existing businesses. 
A.  All persons holding a valid city business license on December 31, 2015 for related services shall have six months following the enactment of this chapter in which to comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
B.  The chief of police may issue a provisional permit to any massage establishment for a period not to exceed six months, if the applicant is able to show substantial compliance with the requirements of this chapter and that remaining compliance can be achieved within the period of the provisional permit. This provisional permit shall not be renewed. 
(Ord. No. 8895, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Chapter 5.36 - POWER COMPANIES 
Sections: 

5.36.010 - License fee. 
A.  Every person now or hereafter engaged in the power and light business in the city shall pay to the city as a license fee, in lieu of any other rental, occupation, license or merchandising tax (but not in lieu of any ad valorem tax) a sum equal to five percent of gross receipts from the sale of electrical energy for domestic, commercial and industrial consumption within the present or any future boundaries of the city. 
B.  The term "sale of electrical energy for domestic, commercial and industrial consumption," as used in this section, shall not include any sale: 
1.  To the United States, the state, or any agency or political subdivision thereof, or to any municipality or any agency thereof; 
2.  For uses which cannot be classified as domestic, commercial or industrial, such as sales to public utilities, telephone, telegraph, radio communication or television companies, railroads, pipe line companies, educational institutions, churches or charitable institutions; or 
3.  For resale. 
C.  Each such person shall, on or before the last day of each calendar month, commencing with July, 1982, in which it makes taxable sales in the city, pay or issue a credit in the sum then due on account of receipts for the preceding calendar month (ending at the last meter reading preceding the last day of said month). 
D.  If such person shall willfully fail or willfully refuse to pay or issue a credit for the license tax herein provided, when due, said person shall, for the first ninety (90) days or any part thereof, pay in addition to such tax a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax due and unpaid, and, for each succeeding month (or any part thereof), pay, as an additional penalty, one percent of such tax due and unpaid as long as the same shall remain unpaid. 
(Prior code § 13-181) 
Chapter 5.40 - PRIVATE SECURITY COMPANIES AND OFFICERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8936, § 1, adopted Aug. 16, 2016, repealed former Ch. 5.40, §§ 5.40.010-5.40.130, and enacted a new Ch. 5.40 as set out herein. Former Ch. 5.40 pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

5.40.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    "Armed private security officer" means any private security officer who carries a firearm in the performance of his or her duties. 
    "Certified firearms instructor" means a firearms safety instructor that is currently certified by the National Rifle Association as a certified personal protection instructor or a certified pistol instructor. 
    "Peace officer" means a person whose primary occupation is a police officer commissioned or authorized by the United States Government, the state or any governmental subdivision thereof to generally enforce the criminal statutes or ordinances of such governmental units. 
    "Private security officer" means an individual who is not a peace officer as defined in this section and who primarily performs the services of a watchman, guard, patrolman or similar on-site services for the purpose of protecting persons or property, or preventing theft, loss, embezzlement, misappropriation or concealment of goods, wares, merchandise, money, bonds, stocks, notes, documents, papers or property of any kind. 
    "Private security company" means any sole proprietorship, firm, company, partnership, or corporation that employs personnel to act as private security officers, whether they are armed or unarmed. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.020 - Permit required. 
    No private security company shall provide private security officers to perform services within the city unless it has been issued a permit pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.030 - Exemptions. 
    Private security officers that are employed by companies that are licensed by the Missouri Gaming Commission are exempt from the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.040 - Enforcement authority. 
    The chief of police, or his or her designee, shall be responsible for the issuance of permits for any private security company desiring to provide private security services within the city. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.050 - Private security company permit. 
A.  The chief of police shall provide a permit application to companies that desire to provide private security services within the city. The permit application will include all of the information that is required to show compliance with the provisions of this chapter including, but not limited to, the following: Company identification information, the names and addresses of the principal owners of the company, locations where private security officers will be working, firearms training and qualification certificates for armed private security officers, and photographs of the uniforms worn by the company's private security officers. 
B.  The chief of police shall issue a permit to a private security company that has successfully completed a permit application. 
C.  The private security company permit will be valid from the date of issuance until the end of the calendar year in which it was issued. 
D.  There is no fee associated with the issuance of a private security company permit. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.060 - Employment restrictions. 
    A private security company shall not employ private security officers, whether armed or unarmed, within the city if: 
A.  The private security officer is not proficient in English. 
B.  The private security officer has a felony conviction for any crime, a conviction for domestic violence or any crime involving assault, or who is subject to an order of protection issued by any court. 
C.  The private security officer is on probation as a result of any federal, state, or municipal law, except for traffic related offenses. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.070 - Complaints and withdrawal or suspension of permit. 
    The chief of police, or his or her designee, may investigate any complaint made against a private security officer. The chief of police shall have the authority to suspend or withdraw any private security company permit when the investigation shows that the provisions of this chapter have been violated. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.080 - Firearms qualification. 
    An armed private security officer must have, within the preceding twelve (12) months, completed eight hours of firearms training taught by a certified firearms instructor. The training must include achieving a passing score after completion of a firearms qualification course with the same firearm that will be carried while performing private security duties. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.090 - Discharge of firearm. 
    A private security company shall immediately notify the North Kansas City Police Department if one of its employees discharges a firearm within the city. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
5.40.100 - Private security officer uniforms. 
    Private security officer uniforms, if worn, shall not bear any resemblance to any uniform worn by members of the North Kansas City Police Department, nor shall the word "Police" be displayed on any badge, uniform, or vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 8936, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
Chapter 5.44 - TAXICABS 
Sections: 
Article I. - In General 

5.44.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    "Enforcement agency" means the department of public works. 
    "Motorbuses" means motor vehicles designed and constructed for the general transportation of passengers for hire and possessing a manufacturer's rated seating capacity of ten (10) or more passengers. 
    "Streets" means the streets, avenues, boulevards, parkways, highways and other thoroughfares and public places of the city. 
    Taxicab. Wherever the term "taxicab" is used in this chapter, it shall include, in addition to such motor vehicles as are commonly known as taxicabs, all motor vehicles of every kind, character and description which are used as taxicabs, cabs for hire or livery cars and engaged as such in the carriage of passengers, for hire; provided, that nothing in this chapter shall be construed to apply to motor vehicles owned by undertakers and used exclusively for funeral services nor to motor vehicles for hire while being used for service at funerals or weddings, nor to motorbuses as defined in this section. 
(Prior code § 28-1) 
5.44.020 - Exemption. 
    This chapter shall not apply to motor vehicles engaged exclusively in the transportation of pupils to and from schools commonly known as school buses, nor to motor vehicles owned by any person and used exclusively to transport his or her bona fide employees to and from the office or plant of such person; nor shall this chapter apply to motorbuses engaged exclusively in interstate or interurban service under a certificate of convenience and necessity issued by the public service commission of the state where less than one-third of the mileage of the route is within the city; nor shall this chapter apply to motorbuses or trolley buses operated as a part of the street railway system. 
(Prior code § 28-2) 
5.44.030 - Maintenance of taxicabs-Equipment generally. 
    Every taxicab operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in clean and serviceable condition and in adequate repair. Each taxicab shall be equipped with brakes capable of stopping and holding the same under all reasonable conditions. Each taxicab shall have two doors affording direct entrance and exit to and from the passenger compartment. The passenger compartment of each taxicab shall have an adequate light therein controlled by a switch control in the passenger compartment. 
(Prior code § 28-3) 
5.44.040 - Rate card and identification card. 
    For every taxicab for which a permit shall be granted, the cab shall contain a rate card stating the fares. Such rate card shall at all times be displayed in a card frame within the taxicab, so placed as to be in full view of any passenger; and every person driving a taxicab in the city shall have posted in the cab in plain view of the passengers an identification card, approved by the city council, showing the driver's face, height, weight, color of eyes and hair, his or her signature and photograph. The current rates shall be prominently displayed on the side of such taxicab. 
(Prior code § 28-5) 
5.44.050 - Meters generally. 
A.  Every taxicab shall be equipped with a single tariff taximeter of a type approved by the enforcement agency. 
B.  Taximeters shall be connected to the transmission or main drive shaft of the taxicab and shall be placed in the driver's compartment on the right-hand side of the vehicle with the face of such taximeter upon which the fare is recorded directed toward the passenger compartment, and so positioned as to be wholly visible to, and clearly discernible by, a passenger sitting in any of the rear seats. 
C.  No person shall operate or permit to be operated or drive, for hire, any taxicab unless the taximeter shall have been sealed by the owner or his or her representative, or by the enforcement agency. 
D.  The meter mechanism shall be sealed within its case. Meter shall be sealed to meter bracket. Driving equipment shall be sealed at upper end of meter bracket. 
E.  The face or dial of every taximeter shall be illuminated by a suitable light arranged so that the figures may be read by any passenger. 
F.  The height of the numerals indicating the fare charged shall be not less than one-half inch. 
G.  Taxicab owners shall be held responsible for the accuracy of taximeters installed on their taxicabs within the tolerance allowed by this section. Inspection and test shall be made regularly by the owner at least once every six months, and more often if necessary to insure continued accuracy of the taximeter. A record shall be kept by the owner of each test of a taximeter, which record shall be available for inspection by the enforcement agency at any time. 
H.  On mileage bench tests, errors in registration, either to the prejudice of the passenger or the owner, shall not exceed two percent of the interval under test, with an added tolerance of one hundred (100) feet whenever the initial interval is included in the interval under test. On mileage road tests, errors in registration shall not exceed four percent of the interval under test with an added tolerance of one hundred (100) feet whenever the initial interval is included in the interval under test; provided, that on a road test, if the vehicle tires are obviously worn, an additional tolerance of one percent to the prejudice of the passenger shall be allowed. 
I.  On time tests on individual time intervals, errors in registration shall not exceed five percent to the prejudice of the owner nor more than ten (10) percent to the prejudice of the passenger; provided, that on the initial time interval the tolerance to the prejudice of the passenger shall not be in excess of fifteen (15) percent. On time tests on average time intervals (computed after excluding the initial interval) errors in registration shall not exceed five percent either to the prejudice of the passenger or the owner. 
J.  Any person operating a taxicab within the city may make a request to the enforcement agency to operate such taxicab on a flat rate basis without the taximeter required and specified by this section. 
(Prior code § 28-6) 
5.44.060 - Proper display of flag when vehicle engaged. 
    No driver shall, while carrying any passenger, display the flag of the taximeter in such position as to denote that such taxicab is not engaged. 
(Prior code § 28-7) 
5.44.070 - Receipt for fare. 
    Every driver, when requested by the passenger, shall give a numbered receipt showing the owner's name, date and the amount of fare charged. 
(Prior code § 28-8) 
5.44.080 - Identification of taxicabs. 
    Each taxicab shall bear on the side of such taxicab, in painted letters not less than two inches nor more than six inches in height, the name of the owner and, in addition, may bear an identifying design and the business telephone number of the owner. No other legend than the name of the owner, the design and the telephone number may be used on the side of such taxicab. 
(Prior code § 28-9) 
5.44.090 - Acceptance of additional passengers prohibited without permission of original passenger. 
    Whenever any taxicab is occupied by a passenger the driver shall not permit any other person to occupy a ride in such taxicab, except by permission of the original passenger. The use of a city taxicab program ticket to obtain the use of a taxicab shall be permission for use of cab by another person. 
(Prior code § 28-10) 
5.44.100 - Number of passengers restricted to seating capacity of taxicab. 
    No driver shall permit more persons to be carried in a taxicab than the seating capacity of the cab, which in no case shall exceed six persons, including the driver. 
(Prior code § 28-11) 
Article II. - Permit to Operate Taxicab 

5.44.110 - Required. 
    No taxicab shall be operated upon the streets of the city until a permit therefor has been obtained from the city clerk as provided in this article. 
(Prior code § 28-36) 
5.44.120 - Liability insurance. 
A.  It is unlawful to operate a taxicab, as defined in this chapter, or permit the same to be operated, nor shall any permit be issued under the provisions of this article, unless the applicant for such permit, in addition to all other requirements in this chapter, shall file and maintain with the city clerk for each taxicab operated a policy of liability insurance issued by a company authorized and licensed to do an insurance business in the state, for each taxicab for which a license is sought, acceptable to and approved by the city clerk and approved as to form by the city, and indemnifying the applicant in the sum of at least twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for injury to or death of one person by reason of the carelessness or negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injury to or death of more than one person resulting from a single accident by reason of the carelessness or negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab, and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for damage to property, including baggage or other property of a passenger carried in or on such taxicab, resulting from any single accident by reason of the carelessness or negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab. The policy shall further contain a clause obligating the insurance company to give twenty (20) days' written notice to the city before cancellation of the policy, the permit to expire upon the lapse of such policy or certificate, or termination of the same by cancellation; unless within twenty (20) days, in case of notice by cancellation by the insurance company, the holder of a permit shall furnish another policy acceptable to the city. 
B.  The policy of insurance required by this section shall contain a provision for continuing liability thereunder to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon. If, at any time in the judgment of the enforcement agency, such policy of insurance is deemed insufficient for any cause, the enforcement agency may require the owner of the taxicab to replace such insurance policy with another to be approved by the enforcement agency. 
(Prior code § 28-41) 
5.44.130 - Revocation-Generally-Hearing. 
    The city council shall have the power to revoke any permit after ten (10) days' notice to the person holding such permit, and after a hearing, if a hearing is requested in writing by the person holding such permits: 
A.  For the violation of any provision of this article; 
B.  When it has been proven to their satisfaction that the holder of such permit has discontinued taxicab operation; 
C.  When it has been proven that such person has wilfully and persistently violated any ordinance of the city, or the laws of the United States, or the state. 
(Prior code § 28-43) 
5.44.140 - Same-For fraud in obtaining permit or license. 
    Whenever it shall appear upon investigation and hearing by the city council that a permit or license issued under the provisions of this article has been obtained by misrepresentation or fraud, the permit shall be revoked. 
(Prior code § 28-44) 
Article III. - Taxicab Driver's Permit 

5.44.150 - Definitions. 
    The term "permit" or "driver's permit" when used in this article means a taxicab driver's permit; the term "applicant" when used in this article means a person making application for a taxicab driver's permit; the term "permittee" when used in this article means a person to whom a taxicab driver's permit has been issued. 
(Prior code § 28-56) 
5.44.160 - Required. 
    Every person desiring to drive a taxicab on the streets of the city, whether as an owner or as an employee of the owner of such taxicab, shall file with the police department a written application for a license to be known as a taxicab driver's permit. 
(Prior code § 28-57) 
5.44.170 - Persons eligible. 
    Every applicant for a taxicab driver's permit shall: 
A.  Be of the age of eighteen (18) years or over; 
B.  Be of sound physique, have good eyesight and hearing, and not subject to epilepsy, vertigo, heart trouble or any other infirmity of body or mind which might render him or her unfit to safely drive and operate a taxicab on the public streets of the city; 
C.  Be able to read and write the English language. 
(Prior code § 28-58) 
5.44.180 - Application-Generally. 
    The application shall be made upon a printed form to be provided by the police department and shall have printed thereon such questions as will, in addition to the requirements enumerated in the preceding section, elicit from the applicant his or her name, age, residence, color, height, color of eyes and hair, nationality, place of birth, length of time he or she has resided in the city; whether a citizen of the United States, married or single; whether he or she has ever been convicted of a crime, including the violation of any city ordinance; whether he or she has previously been granted a permit or license in any city or state as a taxicab driver, and if so, whether such permit or license was ever revoked; and if revoked, the cause thereof, and such other information as may be deemed proper. 
(Prior code § 28-59) 
5.44.190 - Same-Approval by city council-Signature and fingerprints of applicant. 
    The form of the printed application blank referred to in Section 5.44.180 shall be approved by the city council. The application shall be signed by the applicant, and shall bear, in an appropriate place thereon, the fingerprints of each applicant. 
(Prior code § 28-60) 
5.44.200 - Same-Photograph-Photograph to be affixed to permit. 
    Each applicant shall file with his application three recent photographs of himself or herself, of such size as may be required by the police department. If a permit is granted, one of such photographs shall be attached thereto by the police department in such manner as will prevent its removal and the substitution of another without detection. 
(Prior code § 28-61) 
5.44.210 - Same-To be filed as a permanent record. 
    All applications for a taxicab driver's permit shall be kept on file in the police department as a permanent record, and the name and address of all persons to whom a taxicab driver's permit may be issued shall be kept by the police department in an appropriate book, to be maintained as a permanent record. Any suspension or revocation of a taxicab driver's permit or other pertinent information shall be noted on such record. 
(Prior code § 28-62) 
5.44.220 - Chauffeur's permit prerequisite-Permit fee. 
    The permit provided for in this article shall not be issued to any person who is not at such time a registered chauffeur under the laws of the state. The number of such chauffeur's permit shall be noted on the application for a permit under this article. A fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall accompany each application. If a permit is not granted, such fee shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Prior code § 28-63) 
(Ord. No. 8570, § 1, 8-16-2011) 
5.44.230 - Issuance-Form-Defacing entries. 
    Upon satisfactory compliance with the requirements of this article there shall be issued to each applicant by the chief of police a taxicab driver's permit. Such permit shall bear the genuine signature of the permittee and appropriate space shall be provided thereon upon which a record may be made of any conviction of the permittee of any violations of the traffic code or any provisions of this chapter. Any permittee who removes, obliterates or defaces any official entry made upon his or her permit shall, in addition to any other punishment provided by this code, have his or her permit revoked. 
(Prior code § 28-64) 
5.44.240 - Identification card. 
    An appropriate identification card shall be furnished to each taxicab driver to whom a permit has been issued pursuant to this article by the police department, showing his or her permit number and the two-year period for which the same is issued. Such changes in the size, shape or general appearance of the card shall be made from time to time as will make it easy to distinguish the card adopted for any two-year period from those in use during the immediately preceding two-year period. Every taxicab driver while on duty shall display his or her identification card in a card frame within the taxicab, so placed as to be in full view of any passenger. 
(Prior code § 28-65) 
(Ord. No. 8570, § 1, 8-16-2011) 
5.44.250 - Renewal-Fee. 
    A taxicab driver's permit may be renewed for two years by the police department on the written application of any permittee by an appropriate endorsement upon the application for renewal. Such application for a renewal shall show thereon the date upon which his or her original permit was granted and the number thereof. The fee for such renewal shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) and shall be transmitted to the city. 
(Ord. No. 9111, § 25, 9-4-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9111, § 25, adopted Sept. 4, 2018, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code § 28-66; Ord. No. 8570, § 1, 8-16-2011. 
5.44.260 - Suspension and revocation generally. 
    Any person holding a permit, if found guilty of a violation of this chapter, may, in the discretion of the court, in addition to the other punishment provided in this article, have his or her permit suspended or revoked. If such person is found guilty of violation of any law of the state or of the United States, the city council may thereon suspend or revoke his or her permit. 
(Prior code § 28-67) 
5.44.270 - Refusal or revocation for false statement or misrepresentation of a material fact. 
    Any false statement or misrepresentation of a material fact made by an applicant for the purpose of securing a taxicab driver's permit shall be deemed good and sufficient cause for the refusal or revocation of such permit. 
(Prior code § 28-68) 
5.44.280 - Surrender of permit and identification card upon suspension or revocation of permit. 
    In case of suspension or revocation of a taxicab driver's permit, the permit, together with the identification card of the permittee shall be surrendered to the police department, and a statement of such suspension or revocation and the reason therefor shall be noted on the permit. 
(Prior code § 28-69) 
5.44.290 - Return of permit and identification card to permittee after suspension or revocation. 
    In case of suspension, the taxicab driver's identification card and permit shall be returned to the permittee at the expiration of the period for which his or her permit was suspended. In case of the revocation of a permit held by any taxicab driver, he or she shall not again be issued a permit. 
(Prior code § 28-70) 
Chapter 5.48 - TELEPHONE COMPANIES 
Sections: 
Article I. - Generally 

5.48.010 - Exclusive privileges not granted by chapter. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as giving to the person licensed under this chapter any exclusive privileges. 
(Prior code § 13-151) 
Article II. - License Tax 

5.48.020 - Required-Period for which required. 
    Every person, their lessees, trustees or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, owning, operating, controlling, leasing or managing any telephone service or system in the city shall, in addition to all other taxes, payments or requirements required by law or city ordinance, pay to the city a quarter-annual license tax to be due and payable to the city treasurer on or before the thirtieth day of January, April, July and October, respectively, of each year, based upon the business done during the preceding period of three calendar months ending, respectively, on the last days of December, March, June and September. 
(Prior code § 13-161) 
5.48.030 - Computation. 
    The amount of the quarter-annual license tax required by Section 5.48.020 shall be a sum equal to five percent of the gross receipts derived from the sale of telephone and communications service within the present or future boundaries of the city during the preceding period of three months. In the event that it becomes impossible and impracticable for the licensee to include in any quarter annual payment of tax, all of such gross receipts for such three-month period, such licensee shall pay the estimated amount of the tax and include the correct amount by adjusting the next succeeding quarter annual tax payment to the city without penalty. 
(Prior code § 13-162) 
5.48.040 - Reports required-Collectability. 
    The person licensed under this chapter shall make true and faithful reports, under oath, to the city clerk, in such form as may be prescribed by the city council, and containing such information as may be necessary to determine the amounts to which the license tax shall apply, on or before the thirtieth day of January, April, July and October of each year, for all gross receipts for the three calendar months ending, respectively on the last days of December, March, June and September. Each tax so paid shall constitute payment for the three months beginning on the first day of the months of January, April, July and October, respectively, during which months such payments shall be due and payable as herein prescribed; provided, however, that the acceptance of such tax shall not prejudice the right of the city to collect any additional taxes hereafter found to be due. 
(Ord. No. 9111, § 26, 9-4-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9111, § 26, adopted Sept. 4, 2018, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code § 13-163. 
5.48.050 - Penalty for delinquency-Action at law required to recover tax due. 
    For each and every month or part thereof any license tax required by this chapter remains unpaid after the same becomes due and payable, there shall be added to such license tax as a penalty for such delayed payment, ten (10) percent of the amount of such license tax for the first month, or part thereof, the same is unpaid, and for each and every month thereafter, two percent of the amount of such license tax until the same is fully paid. An action at law shall constitute the city's only means of collecting any tax due and unpaid, and failure to pay such tax shall not constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 13-164) 
5.48.060 - Examination of books and records. 
    The city administrator or his designee and any public accountants selected by the city council shall have the right at all reasonable times during business hours to make such examination and inspections of the books of the persons licensed under this chapter as may be necessary to determine the correctness of such reports. The city shall have the right, at its own expense, to employ the same accountants who make the annual audit of the books, records and accounts of the business of the licensee to audit, at the same time, its accounts and records and certify as to the correctness of any payment due and payable by the licensee to the city. 
(Ord. No. 9111, § 27, 9-4-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9111, § 27, adopted Sept. 4, 2018, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code § 13-165. 
Chapter 5.52 - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND VENDORS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Generally 

5.52.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, a "transient merchant," "itinerant merchant" or "itinerant vendor" is defined as any person whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within such city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car or boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops or any street, alley or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction; provided, that such definition shall not be construed to include any person who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery. The person so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this chapter merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(Prior code § 21-16) 
5.52.020 - Loud noises and speaking devices prohibited. 
    No licensee under this chapter, nor anyone in his or her behalf, shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other sound device including any loud speaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys or parks or other public places, for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which such licensee proposes to sell. 
(Prior code § 21-17) 
5.52.030 - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to examine all places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the provisions of this chapter, to determine if this chapter has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Prior code § 21-18) 
5.52.040 - Debris and traffic interference. 
A.  Interference With Traffic. No licensee under this chapter, or any other provisions of this code, nor anyone in his or her behalf shall park or stand his or her vehicle from which merchandise is being sold, for a period in excess of five minutes, in any manner which will interfere with the free flow of motor vehicle traffic on any public street, alley or thoroughfare within the city, nor shall said licensee cause or contribute to cause pedestrians to gather in any manner on any public street, alley or thoroughfare so as to interfere with the free flow of motor vehicle traffic along said public street, alley or thoroughfare within the city. 
B.  Accumulation of Debris. No licensee under this chapter nor anyone in his or her behalf shall contribute to or cause the accumulation of paper, cardboard boxes or other packaging debris in and about said licensee's vending vehicle or stand. 
(Prior code § 21-19) 
Article II. - License 

5.52.050 - Required. 
    It is unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined in Section 5.52.010 to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 21-31) 
5.52.060 - Application. 
    Applicants for license under this chapter shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all parties if a partnership and by the president if a corporation, with the city clerk, showing: 
A.  The name of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the city; the local address of such person while engaged in such business; the permanent address of such person; the capacity in which such person will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
B.  The fingerprints of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business or in lieu thereof, at least three letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county, certifying as to applicant's good character and business responsibility or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the mayor the good character and business responsibility of such person or persons; 
C.  The place in the city where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business shall be conducted; 
D.  The place, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where applicant within the six months next preceding the date of such application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
E.  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by applicant in the city, the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise, whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by sample, at auction, by direct sale or by direct sale and by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods or products are located at the time such application is filed; 
F.  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the city clerk, copies of all such advertising whether by handbill, circular, newspaper advertising, or otherwise, shall be attached to such application as exhibits thereto; 
G.  Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
H.  Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; and 
I.  Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the city clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good. 
(Prior code § 21-32) 
5.52.070 - Investigation of applicant-Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of such application, the city clerk shall cause such investigation of such person's business responsibility or moral character to be made as he or she deems necessary to the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, the city clerk shall so certify in writing, and a license shall be issued by the city clerk. The city clerk shall keep a full record in his or her office of all licenses issued. Such license shall contain the number of the license, the date the same is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of such license, the place where such business may be carried on under such license, and the name of the person authorized to carry on the same. 
(Prior code § 21-33) 
5.52.080 - Bond. 
    Before any license, as provided by this chapter, shall be issued for engaging in a transient or itinerant business as defined in Section 5.52.010 in the city, such applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) executed by the applicant, as principal, and two sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state; such bond to be approved by the city, conditioned that such applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against such applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him or her by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether such misrepresentation or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the city, both as to form and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
(Prior code § 21-34) 
5.52.090 - Applicant required to file service of process. 
    Before any license as herein provided shall be issued for engaging in business as an itinerant merchant, as herein defined, in the city, such applicant shall file with the city clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the city clerk, or the person performing the duties of such position, his or her true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of such applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under such license and the bond given as required in Section 5.28.080 of this chapter, or for the performance of the conditions of such bond or for any breach thereof, which such instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that such applicant for such license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon such agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person applying for such license under this chapter, according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgement of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the city clerk, as herein provided, the city clerk shall send to the licensee at his or her last known address, by registered mail, a copy of such process. 
(Prior code § 21-35) 
5.52.100 - Fees. 
A.  Licensees under this chapter shall pay a fee at the rate of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per annum. 
B.  Every person conducting business licensed under this chapter shall, on the first business day of each week, and upon discontinuance of business in the city present a verified statement showing the total sales made during the preceding week and shall pay to the city the amount of license fee herein before provided, for sales made during the previous week. The city administrator or his designee shall have power and authority to enter any store, building or any other place in which such temporary business may be conducted at any time during business hours for ascertaining the amount of sales made and shall at all times have access to the books of such business. 
(Ord. No. 9111, § 28, 9-4-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9111, § 28, adopted Sept. 4, 2018, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code § 21-36. 
5.52.110 - Display. 
    The license issued under this chapter shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person applying for such license shall desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Prior code § 21-37) 
5.52.120 - Term. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire ninety (90) days after the date of issuance thereof unless a prior date is fixed therein. 
(Prior code § 21-38) 
5.52.130 - Transfer. 
    No license shall be transferred without written consent from the mayor as evidenced by an endorsement on the face of the license by the city clerk showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. 
(Prior code § 21-39) 
5.52.140 - Revocation. 
A.  The licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the mayor after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
1.  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
2.  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares and merchandise; 
3.  Any violation of this chapter; 
4.  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
5.  Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
B.  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his or her last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Prior code § 21-40) 
5.52.150 - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city clerk in regard to the denial of application for license as provided for in Section 5.52.070 or in connection with the revocation of the license as provided for in Section 5.52.140, shall have the right to appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the council within fourteen (14) days after notice of the decision by the city clerk has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth grounds for the appeal. The council shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to such person in the same manner as provided in Section 5.52.140 for notice of hearing on revocation. The order of this council on such appeal shall be final. 
(Prior code § 21-41) 
5.52.160 - Records. 
    The city clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of licensee, together with a license number, with the chief of police; the chief of police shall report to the clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this chapter and any conviction for violation of this chapter, the city clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses and of such complaints and violations. 
(Prior code § 21-42) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 6.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS, ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

6.04.010 - Definitions. 
    Whenever in this title the following terms are used, each shall have the meaning respectively ascribed in this section: 
    "Animal" means any live, vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, other than a human. 
    Animal Control Officer. The use of this term throughout this title shall be a reference to the animal control officer and staff assigned to work under the direct control of the animal control officer, who may act through staff to perform any duty under this title unless otherwise specifically stated. 
    "Animal shelter" means the facility or facilities operated by the city, or its authorized agents for the purpose of impounding or caring for animals held under the authority of this title or state law. 
    "Commercial animal establishment" means any pet shop, grooming shop, auction, riding school, stable, kennel, guard dog service, dog trainer, business keeping animals in stock for retail or wholesale trade or exhibition, or any establishment performing one or more of the principal activities of the aforementioned establishments. 
    "Domestic animal avocation" means the care, breeding, showing or sale of dogs or cats by an adult natural person who maintains a hobby-kennel or hobby-cattery containing more than four but not more than twenty-five (25) animals over the age of six months on the lot on which he or she is resident or on a contiguous lot, which lot or lots are not zoned for business. 
    "Fowl" means any and all fowl, domesticated and wild, male and female, singular and plural. 
    "Harboring" means any person who offers asylum, refuge or sanctuary on any animal on a basis so temporary as to not be deemed to be owning or keeping. 
    "Individual" means one adult and competent human. 
    "Large animal" means any swine, bovine, goat, sheep, beast of burden or any other domestic or wild animal of similar or larger size. 
    "License tag" means any system or systems of animal identification approved by the city which do not involve alteration or permanent marking of an animal. 
    "Owning" or "keeping" means any person who feeds or shelters any animal for three or more consecutive days or who professes ownership of such animal. 
    "Public nuisance" means any animal (or group of animals which contains any animal) which: 
1.  Molests any passerby or chases passing vehicles including bicycles; 
2.  Attacks any other animal; 
3.  Is in season and not properly confined as provided in Section 6.12.100; 
4.  Damages public or private property; 
5.  Barks, whines or howls in an excessive fashion, which is defined as continuous or untimely so as to disturb an individual who is a neighbor (a neighbor for this purpose is defined as an individual residing in a residence structure which is within one hundred (100) yards of the property on which the animal is kept or harbored) and who does in writing state that he or she will so testify if called upon to testify about such matter under oath; 
6.  Is ridden on public property without a permit or which obstructs or interferes with vehicular or pedestrian traffic; 
7.  Causes injury to people; 
8.  Threatens or causes a condition which endangers public health; 
9.  Impedes refuse collection by ripping any bag or tipping any container of such. 
    "Small animal" means any animal not within the definition of large animal, but including all dogs without reference to size. 
    "Veterinary medical care facility" means a facility which has the primary function of providing medical care for animals and is operated by a currently licensed veterinarian. 
    "Wild animal" means any animal which is predominantly free-roaming, as opposed to domesticated. 
(Prior code § 5-1) 
6.04.020 - Administration and enforcement-Generally. 
    Except where otherwise provided, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer under the direction of the police department to administer and enforce the provisions of this title directly or through staff assigned to be supervised by the animal control officer. 
(Prior code § 5-2) 
(Ord. No. 8703, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
6.04.030 - Same-Records. 
    The animal control officer shall keep a record in which he or she shall enter all his or her official transactions. Such record shall be open to the inspection of any person as authorized or limited by the Revised Statutes of Missouri, particularly Chapter 610 and such other enactments as may be or become applicable. 
(Prior code § 5-3) 
6.04.040 - Powers of health official. 
A.  In the event that the health official determines that a rabies or other zoonotic disease control emergency exists, he or she shall so declare and shall issue emergency regulations and take all steps necessary within the provisions of this title and state law to abate the threat. Such emergency steps and regulations shall be in effect only during the period of the declared emergency. 
B.  The health official is also empowered to issue standing regulations for rabies and zoonosis control that he or she finds necessary to protect the public health, which standing regulations shall be filed with the city clerk. Such regulations shall be in keeping with the United States Public Health Service guidelines and Missouri state law. 
(Prior code § 5-4) 
6.04.050 - Impoundment-Authorized. 
A.  By the authority of this section, any animal that is deemed by the animal control officer to be cruelly mistreated in violation of this title or suffering may be seized from the property of its owner or keeper to abate the mistreatment or the suffering of that animal, and it may be confined at the municipal animal shelter for disposition under the terms of this title. 
B.  Any animal that has possibly exposed a person to rabies through a bite wound or other tissue invasion and that is found on the property of the owner or keeper may be removed from that property by the animal control officer if such owner or keeper is not available, willing and able to surrender the animal for the observation required by Section 6.16.020 or 6.16.030. 
C.  Any female dog in season and not confined in a building or solid enclosure as required by Section 6.12.100 may be removed from the property of the owner or keeper to abate such nuisance. 
D.  Any animal delivered to the shelter by the owner and declared by the owner to be unwanted shall be impounded and disposed of under the terms of this title, and the owner shall be assessed a lump sum fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each such unwanted animal delivered to the shelter. The shelter shall only accept unwanted animals under this paragraph from owners who are residents of the city. 
(Prior code § 5-5) 
(Ord. No. 8703, § 2, 8-20-2013) 
6.04.060 - Same-Notice, redemption, etc. 
A.  Notice to Owner. After the impoundment of any animal where a general ordinance summons has not been issued to the owner or keeper, the animal control officer shall promptly notify the owner of such animal of its impoundment if the owner can be determined and located by reasonable investigation; however, no liability shall attach to the city or to the animal control officer or his or her staff for failure to give such notice. The owner of an impounded animal who does not redeem his or her animal may still be proceeded against for violation of any applicable section or sections of this title or any other applicable ordinance. 
B.  Keeping Impounded Animals. Impounded animals shall be kept for not less than five days except: 
1.  When given to be disposed of by an owner, keeper or harborer, in which case the animal shall be held until the next calendar day before making a disposition; 
2.  When an animal arrives at the shelter in so sick or injured a condition that in the judgment of the animal control officer or a licensed veterinarian human compassion requires that the suffering be promptly ended. In such instance said time period shall not apply, and the animal will be humanely killed to prevent needless suffering. 
C.  Animal Adoption. The animal control officer may, in lieu of having an unclaimed animal killed as provided herein, give such animal into the custody of any adult requesting custody (animal adoption) of such specific animal as a pet after viewing it; provided, that in the judgment of the animal control officer such person will humanely care for such animal and will not permit its use for laboratory or experimental purposes. The animal will be awarded to the first qualified applicant. 
D.  Restrictions on Adoption. No animal will be given to the custody of a person who, in the judgment of the animal control officer, is requesting the animal with the intent to sell it. No more than two animals may be given into the custody of any individual or family per year. 
E.  Temporary Permit. After selection of a dog or cat, but prior to the delivery of custody of the animal, the animal control officer shall issue a temporary permit to keep the animal without license or tag for ten (10) days if it is over ninety (90) days old or for ten (10) days after the animal becomes ninety (90) days old, which date shall be entered on the receipt based on the animal's age as estimated by the animal control officer and such age shall be conclusively presumed correct for the purposes of the enforcement of this chapter. 
F.  Seizing Dogs at Large. Any dog owned, kept or harbored in the city and found running at large as defined shall immediately be apprehended and impounded by the animal control officer or other employee or officer of the city with police powers and directed by the city council or the mayor to so act. If the owner or keeper fails to secure the release of such animal as aforesaid, the animal will be evaluated and a determination will be made on the animal's suitability for adoption. 
G.  Impounded Animal Fees. A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged when any animal is picked up for a second time, or for any successive impoundment thereafter by the animal control officer, and transported to the animal shelter or other city-designated place of impoundment. The fee for the care of an animal during the period of impoundment shall be at a rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for each day or portion of a day that said animal is impounded; provided, however, that such fee shall be increased by the actual amount of any unusual expenses incurred whether in the impoundment or the care of said animal. An owner or keeper must pay these fees in full to obtain custody of his or her animal, but this payment is not required for animal adoption. 
(Prior code § 5-6) 
(Ord. No. 8703, §§ 3, 4, 8-20-2013) 
6.04.070 - Penalties. 
A.  Any person violating any provision of this title shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction of any such violation shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifteen dollars ($15.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the city jail for a term not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
B.  Each day's violation of, or failure, refusal or neglect to comply with, any provision of this title shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Prior code § 5-20) 
Chapter 6.08 - ANIMALS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

6.08.010 - Abandonment of domestic animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to abandon any domestic animal within the city. 
(Prior code § 5-7) 
6.08.020 - Permits for elimination of pest animals. 
    The health official is authorized to issue a permit for the elimination of squirrels, starlings or wild pigeons to any other or owner's authorized agent, lessee or tenant of real estate in the city frequented by squirrels, starlings or wild pigeons in numbers the health official believes to be sufficient to create a public nuisance on such real estate; or in cases where such public nuisance exists in a district of the city, such permit may be issued to a duly licensed pest control or exterminating company for such district, which shall be defined on such permit. No permit shall be issued for a longer period than thirty (30) days. Retention of any such permit shall be conditioned upon continuing compliance with advisory instructions issued and regulations adopted by the health official dealing with such activity, which regulations the health official is authorized and directed to promulgate and to adopt by filing them with the city clerk, and which regulations shall govern the trapping and disposal of squirrels, starlings and wild pigeons and shall be designed to ensure humane and sanitary methods for such and for the protection of public health. 
(Prior code § 5-8) 
6.08.030 - Dangerous animals prohibited. 
A.  The keeping or harboring of dangerous animals other than dogs within the city is prohibited. Other than as to dogs which are regulated by Section 6.12.090, a dangerous animal is deemed to be any animal that constitutes a physical threat to human beings or to other animals, or has a disposition or propensity to attack or bite any person or other animal without provocation, or which is wild by nature and of a species which, due to size, vicious nature, or other characteristics, constitutes a danger to human life, physical well-being, or property; or any animal which has been known to bite or attack a human being or other domestic animals without provocation. 
    The duly appointed animal control officer, without complaint, shall have the authority to declare an animal dangerous because of past behavior, violations or the inherently dangerous nature of the animal as to persons. Such a declaration shall be grounds for the impoundment and destruction of the animal unless, without danger to the public, it can be and is removed from the city within forty-eight (48) hours. 
B.  The keeping or harboring of any warm-blooded carnivorous or omnivorous animal (including but not limited to nonhuman primates, raccoons, skunks, foxes, leopards, panthers, tigers, lions, and any member of the canine species other than domestic dog (canis familiaris), but excluding fowl, domestic dogs, house cats and small rodents of varieties used for laboratory purposes) and animals having poisonous bites is prohibited, if not elsewhere prohibited in this title. 
C.  The keeping or harboring of any wolf/dog hybrid with any percentage of wolf parentage is prohibited. 
(Prior code § 5-9) 
6.08.040 - Keeping of livestock and wild beasts prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to keep within the city any livestock (as used herein livestock includes but is not limited to the following animals: horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats and swine) or wild animals of similar or larger size. 
B.  Wild animals not prohibited from being kept as pets shall also be so kept in compliance with the statutes, regulations and treaties of the State of Missouri and the federal government. 
(Prior code § 5-10) 
6.08.050 - Small animals and fowl in pens. 
A.  Location. It is unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any chicken coop, dove cote, rabbit hutch or other yard establishment for the housing of fowl or small animals, except dogs, cats and pigeons, closer than seventy-five (75) feet to the nearest portion of any building occupied by or in anywise used by human beings, other than the dwelling occupied by the owner or keeper of the animals or fowl, or closer than twenty-five (25) feet to the property line of the lot on which such fowl or animals are kept for sale within a bona fide produce market, commission house or store for purposes of trade and while so kept are confined in small coops, boxes or cages, or where such animals or fowl are kept for purposes of research in a laboratory. 
B.  Odors. Every coop, dove cote, rabbit hutch or other yard establishment shall be kept so that no offensive, disagreeable or noxious smell or odor shall arise therefrom to the injury, annoyance or inconvenience of the inhabitants of the neighborhood. 
C.  Disposal of Manure. Every coop, dove cote, rabbit hutch or other yard establishment shall be provided with a watertight and flytight receptacle for manure of such dimension as to contain all accumulations thereof, which receptacle shall be emptied sufficiently often and in such manner as to prevent its becoming a nuisance. Such receptacle shall be securely covered at all times except when open during the deposit or removal of manure or refuse therefrom. No manure shall be allowed to accumulate except in such receptacle. All such manure, when removed from the receptacle, shall be buried with covering of not less than six inches of earth or, if used as fertilizer, thoroughly spaded into the ground, or shall be removed from the property. 
D.  Maintenance of Fowl Enclosures. All earthen guards or runways wherein fowl are kept or permitted to be shall be spaded and then limed once every three months from the month of April through the month of December. For the purpose of killing flies and other insects, all structures, pens or coops wherein fowl are kept or permitted to be shall be sprayed with such substances as will eliminate such insects. 
E.  Maintenance of Enclosures. Any structure, pen, coop or yard wherein animals or fowl are kept or permitted to be shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, devoid of all rodents and vermin, and free from objectionable odors. The enclosed area of all such structures shall be constructed in such a way as to be dry at all times on the inside. The person maintaining any aforementioned structures, pen, coop or yard in the city does by such act of maintenance authorize the director of health to at any time inspect any such structure or premises and issue any such order as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this section. 
F.  Number of Animals, Fowl. Except where fowl, rabbits or other small animals are kept for sale within a bona fide produce market, commission house or store for the purpose of trade and while so kept are confined in small coops, boxes or cages, or where such animals or fowl are kept for purposes of research in a laboratory, it is unlawful for any person to keep or maintain, within two hundred (200) feet of the nearest portion of any dwelling or other building occupied by or in anywise used by human beings, except for a dwelling occupied by the owner or keeper of such animals, more than three chickens or other domestic fowl four months or more of age or ten (10) chicks or other domestic fowl under four months of age, or more than two rabbits or other small animals over the age of four months, or more than five rabbits or other small animals under the age of four months, or more than twenty (20) pigeons. 
G.  Regulations for Keeping Chickens and Other Domestic Fowl. As to the keeping and harboring of chickens or other domestic fowl for whatever purpose maintained, the health officer shall have authority to promulgate regulations to provide that such shall be kept in such a manner as to prevent a nuisance or health hazard. 
(Prior code § 5-11) 
6.08.060 - Pigeons. 
A.  Definitions. "Pigeon" shall include any and all varieties and breeds of Antwerp, racing or homing pigeons accepted by the American Racing Pigeon Union, Inc., as racing or homing pigeons, and other performing breeds of fancy pigeons. "Loft" shall mean a constructed building for the housing of pigeons exclusively. 
B.  Keeping of Pigeons Subject to Permit-Conditions. The keeping and raising of pigeons may be allowed in conjunction with any single-family residence within the city subject to a permit approved by the animal control officer. Conditions for the permit shall include but not be limited to the following: 
1.  No person shall keep, maintain or harbor pigeons unless pigeons are kept or maintained in an approved pigeon loft as is defined in this section. 
2.  Such pigeon loft shall contain no more than fifty (50) pigeons, including squab. Each pigeon shall wear a metal or plastic leg band to identify the owner or keeper thereof. The owner shall maintain a record of the age and date of acquisition of such pigeons, and such record shall be open for an inspection by the animal control officer. 
3.  The pigeons kept in the pigeon loft shall not be allowed by the owner or keeper to perch or linger on the buildings or property of others in the vicinity of such pigeon loft. The pigeon loft shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary and wholesome manner at all times and shall be subject to periodic inspection by the animal control officer. 
4.  Pigeon lofts shall be of a size sufficient to house the number of pigeons contemplated. In no case shall there be more than one pair of pigeons per two and one-quarter square feet of loft space. Lofts shall not be located any closer to any residence than twenty-five (25) feet, except for the property of the owner thereof, nor within fifty (50) feet of the front of the property line of said owner, nor within five feet of any side or the rear of the property line. 
5.  All premises on which the pigeons are kept and maintained shall at all times be kept clean and free from filth, garbage and such other substances that attract rodents. 
6.  All pigeons shall be fed within the confines of the loft or premises in which such pigeons are housed and contained. 
7.  Pigeons shall be permitted to exercise and fly only twice a day under control of the owner or representative of the owner. 
8.  All pigeon lofts shall be so enclosed as to prevent the pigeons from escaping from the confines of said loft. 
9.  Housing of pigeons shall not be permitted in a dwelling house. 
10.  All grains and food stored for the use and feeding of such pigeons shall be kept in a rodent-proof container. 
11.  In the event the animal control officer shall determine that a violation of this provision exists, notification shall be given to the owner of such pigeon or pigeons; and if the violation is not remedied within ten (10) days, the permit of the pigeon owner may be suspended immediately. 
12.  Pigeon owners, hereinafter referred to as "permittees," shall notify the animal control officer of any proposed change in location or physical setup of the premises. 
13.  Any owner whose permit has been suspended shall be notified in writing of the reason for such action. Upon making a written request within ten (10) days after receipt thereof, he or she shall have the right to a prompt hearing by the animal control officer relative to the charges proferred against him or her. He or she may be represented at such hearing by counsel. 
C.  Permit Fee. The permit fee or license for harboring pigeons within the city is established at fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year per owner location. No more than one permit shall be issued to any permittee under the terms of this section. 
D.  Summary Abatement of Pigeon Nuisance. The city finds and declares that the keeping, raising, maintaining or harboring of pigeons in any manner inconsistent with this section is a nuisance and authorizes the summary abatement of such by the animal control officer as if charged with enforcement of this section. 
(Prior code § 5-12) 
6.08.070 - Cruelty to animals. 
A.  Neglect of Animal Care. No owner or keeper of an animal shall fail to provide the animal with sufficient good and wholesome food and water; proper shelter for the species, with insulation if necessary for protection from the weather; adequate bedding; and the opportunity for adequate daily exercise. An owner or keeper shall provide veterinary care when needed to treat injury or illness unless the animal is instead promptly destroyed in a humane manner. Any owner, keeper or harborer of an animal in this city, by the act of owning, keeping or harboring such animal, does authorize the animal control officer to enter the yard where such animal is kept if the animal control officer reasonably believes that the animal is kept in an unlawful, cruel or inhumane manner, and to examine such animal and to seize and impound such animal at the municipal animal shelter when, in the examiner's opinion, it is being kept in an unlawful cruel or inhumane manner. 
B.  Mistreatment-Instigating or Attending Animal Fights. No person shall beat, cruelly ill treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse an animal, or cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, cockfight or other combat between animals or between animals and humans, and any animal so used shall be seized, impounded and promptly humanely destroyed, nor shall any person attend such unlawful exhibition or be umpire or judge at such. 
C.  Report of Animal Struck by Motor Vehicle. The operator of a motor vehicle which strikes any animal shall as soon as possible report the accident to the police department. 
D.  Offering Animal as Prize. No person shall offer to give or give a live animal as a prize or as a business inducement. 
E.  Selling Young Fowl as Novelties. No person shall advertise, display, sell or offer for sale, barter or otherwise deliver to the public as pets or novelties any live chicks, ducklings, goslings, poults or other fowl under two months of age. This subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the advertising, display or sale of any such chicks, ducklings, goslings, poults, or other fowl for commercial purposes; provided, that sales as pets or novelties shall not be considered a commercial purpose under this subsection. 
(Prior code § 5-13) 
6.08.075 - Unattended animals left in vehicles; rescue by animal control personnel or police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful to confine any animal in a motor vehicle or trailer, under weather or other conditions that endanger its life. Whenever an animal is found in such circumstances that an animal control officer or a police officer determines to be endangering to the animal's life, an animal control officer, with the assistance of a police officer, is authorized to enter such vehicle or trailer and rescue the animal, and to impound the animal under the provisions of Sections 6.04.050 and 6.04.060. In making such rescue, and after making a reasonable effort to locate the owner of the motor vehicle or trailer, the police officer assisting in the rescue may take such steps as are reasonable to obtain entry to the vehicle or trailer, including the release or breaking of locks or windows. A written notice of the impoundment of the animal shall be left with the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 8876, § 1, 11-17-2015) 
6.08.080 - Injuring and capturing animals unlawful.
