If the concrete removed was reinforced, then the patch shall also be reinforced in such a way as to tie the new reinforcing into the existing. All concrete shall be three thousand (3,000) pounds with six by six to ten (10) by ten (10) mesh and all surfaces shall have a groom finish and be protected from the elements until properly set. 
c.  In replacing asphalt material, the fill shall be brought to a minimum of ten (10) inches to the finished surface, then apply seven inches of asphaltic concrete base, then one and one-half inches of asphaltic concrete binder and one and one-half inches of asphaltic concrete surface. The finished surface shall be rolled with a smooth-wheeled roller weighting not less than five tons. 
d.  In replacing soil, eight inches of clean, unfrozen earth shall be placed and compacted. 
e.  The enforcement agency may require each excavation to be sealed with a slurry seal or an approved equal, or in the case of extensive excavations, may require any portion of the affected street to be selected. 
3.  In the event of failure to refill said excavation, the director shall have the right to make any and all refills and to require reimbursement of the cost thereof from the person making the excavation, with payment for such cost to be made in the manner prescribed in Section 12.08.260(G) for payment of charges for repaving and resurfacing. However, the person making the excavation has the sole responsibility to see that the excavation is properly barricaded with barricades and/or lights as required by Section 12.08.250(A). 
4.  The person making such refill shall be required to clean up and haul away all surplus earth, rock or rubbish immediately after such refill is completed, unless special permission has been granted in writing by the director or his or her representative. The person making the backfill shall give the enforcement agency a minimum four hours' notice prior to beginning backfill. In case of default thereof, the enforcement agency shall have the right to remove such earth, rock or rubbish and charge the cost of such removal against the deposit of the person to whom the permit was issued. 
5.  In the event of settlement due to defective refill, occurring within a two-year period after the completion of repaving, the enforcement agency shall have the right to make whatever repairs are required to restore the excavation and repaving to a proper condition and to charge the cost thereof against the deposit of the person to whom the permit was issued. 
6.  All moneys collected in accordance with this section shall be remitted to the city treasurer to be placed to the credit of the general fund. 
C.  As-Built Drawings. Within sixty (60) days after completion unless such time is extended or modified by the director, the permittee shall furnish the city with one complete set of plans, drawn to scale and certified to the city as accurately depicting the location of all utility facilities constructed pursuant to the permit. This requirement may be waived by the director. 
D.  Restoration of Structures and Facilities. Upon completion of any excavation work, the permittee shall promptly repair any and all public and private property improvements, fixtures, structures, and facilities in the rights-of-way or otherwise damaged during the course of construction, restoring the same as practicable to its condition before the start of construction. 
E.  Landscape Restoration. 
1.  All trees, landscaping and grounds removed, damaged or disturbed as a result of the excavation, construction, installation, maintenance, repair or replacement of utility facilities, whether such work is done pursuant to a franchise, license, right-of-way use agreement and/or permit; must be replaced or restored as nearly as may be practicable to the condition existing prior to performance of work; 
2.  All restoration work within the rights-of-way shall be done in accordance with landscape plans approved by the director. 
F.  Failure to Restore. If the permittee fails to restore the right-of-way in the manner and to the condition required by this chapter, or fails to satisfactorily and timely complete all restoration required by the city, the city at its option may do such work. In that event the permittee shall pay to the city, within thirty (30) days of billing, the cost of restoring the right-of-way. If permittee fails to pay as required, the city may exercise its rights under the performance bond. (See Section 12.08.210, Surety bond.) 
G.  Payment of Charges for Repaving and Resurfacing. 
1.  If any charge so made by the city remains unpaid after the tenth day of the following month, no further permits for any excavation shall be issued to any such person until such charge has been paid, and provided further that if any such charges so made are not paid within the time above-mentioned, the amount due to the city therefor shall be taken out of the deposit provided for in Section 12.08.210(A) and no further permits shall be issued to any such person until such deposit shall again be brought up to one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
2.  All payments of charges provided for in this section shall be remitted to the city treasurer to be placed to the credit of the general fund. 
(Ord. 7296 § 8, 2000; prior code § 27-62) 
12.08.265 - Revocation of permit. 
    The director may, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to cure, revoke a permit without fee refund until the breach is cured, but only in the event of a substantial breach of the terms and material conditions of the permit. A substantial breach by a permittee includes but is not limited to: 
(1)  A material violation of a provision of the permit; 
(2)  An evasion or attempt to evade any material provision of the permit, or the perpetration or attempt to perpetrate any fraud or deceit upon the city or its citizens; 
(3)  A material misrepresentation of fact in the permit application; 
(4)  A failure to complete work by the date specified in the permit, unless a permit extension is obtained or unless the failure to complete the work is due to reasons beyond the permittee's control; 
(5)  A failure to correct, within the time specified by the city, work that does not conform to applicable national safety codes, industry construction standards, or local safety codes that are no more stringent than national safety codes, upon inspection and notification by the city of the faulty condition; and 
(6)  Such other lawful reasons. 
(Ord. No. 8940, § 8, 9-6-2016) 
12.08.270 - Application of chapter to park department. 
    This chapter shall apply with equal force and effect to excavations in, through and under boulevards, parks or other property under the jurisdiction of the city, except, however, that the park department shall not be required to give any bond, maintain any cash deposit or pay for any permit as in this chapter provided. 
(Prior code § 27-63) 
12.08.280 - Application of chapter to water department. 
    This chapter shall apply with equal force and effect to the water department of the city in all cases where the water department makes or seeks to make any cuts, openings or excavations in, through or under any street, sidewalk, alley or public place, except, however, that the water department shall not be required to give any bond, maintain any cash deposit or pay for any permit as in this chapter provided. 
(Prior code § 27-64) 
Chapter 12.12 - DRIVEWAYS CONSTRUCTION PERMITS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Generally 

12.12.010 - Purpose of chapter. 
    The city council finds and determines that in order to control and regulate the movement and density of traffic on the public streets in the city it is necessary and beneficial for the general welfare and safety of the citizens and inhabitants of the city that openings into public streets for usage of driveways and private streets from within the city be controlled and regulated. 
(Prior code § 27-86) 
12.12.020 - Penalty. 
    Any person constructing or maintaining any connection, intersection or opening from private property to and with a public street right-of-way in the city in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 27-87) 
Article II. - Construction Permit 

12.12.030 - Required. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any opening, connection, intersection or passageway for use as a driveway or private street into the right-of-way of any public street within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city council; such permit shall not be issued until the applicant has complied with the provisions of this chapter and the city council shall have made the determinations and findings required by this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-101) 
12.12.040 - Application. 
    All applications for a permit shall be signed by the owner of the land or his or her duly authorized agent to which such opening, connection or intersection to a public street right-of-way is sought. The application shall state the location of such connection, intersection or opening with a public street right-of-way and a description of the property from which such opening, connection or intersection is sought and the dimensions and character, including construction specifications, of the proposed opening, connection or intersection. Such application shall be accompanied by a map or diagram drawn to scale showing the location of such proposed connection or opening with a public street right-of-way and the dimensions of the proposed opening, connection or intersection and the area or areas for which access is sought. The sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged for each permit issued under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-102) 
12.12.050 - Standards for issuance. 
    No permit shall be issued for any opening, connection or intersection with a public street right-of-way from private property by means of a private street or roadway unless the plans and specifications for the construction of such private street or roadway and the construction of such private street or roadway are in accordance and conformance with the minimum requirements established by this title for the construction of public streets. 
(Prior code § 27-103) 
12.12.060 - Criteria for council approval. 
    Such application shall be submitted to the city council for approval. In considering the approval or rejection of such application, the city council shall give consideration to the following factors: 
A.  The location of such opening, connection or intersection with the right-of-way of a public street; 
B.  The volume and type of traffic that shall be entering upon the public street at proposed opening, connection or intersection with the right-of-way of the public street; 
C.  Other available points of access to public street from such private property; 
D.  Conformity of the plans and specifications of all applicable city ordinances; 
E.  The character of the area and streets at and near the proposed opening, connection or intersection and the effect, if any, the use of such opening, connection or intersection shall have on the movement and control of traffic in such area; 
F.  If the location of such proposed opening, connection or intersection shall cause an undue burden on the movement of traffic or traffic patterns at the point of such opening, connection or intersection or in the immediate vicinity of such opening, connection or intersection; 
G.  If the proposed location of such opening, connection or intersection shall create or constitute a hazard to traffic or the efficient public use of such public street; 
H.  In the event the city council shall determine that a private street or roadway shall be used primarily for local and accessory traffic by the occupants of the property abutting such private street or roadway, the council may waive the requirement that such street or roadway be constructed in accordance with minimum standards established by this chapter for the construction of public streets and permit the construction of such street or roadway in accordance with the following standards: 
1.  All private streets approved pursuant to this subsection and not used for commercial truck traffic shall be improved with a compacted crushed rock base or equal not less than six inches thick and surfaced with asphaltic concrete or comparable hard-surfaced, all-weather dustless material as approved by the enforcement agency of the city, 
2.  All private streets approved pursuant to this subsection used for commercial truck traffic shall be improved with a compacted crushed rock base not less than seven inches thick or equal and surfaced with not less than two inches of asphaltic concrete or comparable all-weather dustless material as approved by the enforcement agency. 
(Prior code § 27-104) 
12.12.070 - Issuance-Council may alter plans. 
    In the event the city council finds and determines that such proposed opening, connection or intersection shall not be detrimental to public use of the public streets in accordance with the standards of this chapter, such application shall be approved and the permit issued; provided, however, that in the event the city council finds and determines that the proposed opening, connection or intersection shall, in accordance with the standards set forth in this chapter, constitute a hazard to traffic or be detrimental to the public use and character of the public street with which such opening or connection intersects, such application shall be denied; provided further, that the city council may in approving such application require a different or additional opening, connection or intersection with the right-of-way of public streets in order to preserve the public character of the public streets affected and in order to effectively and efficiently provide for the movement of traffic on such public street or streets. 
(Prior code § 27-105) 
Chapter 12.16 - RAILROAD CROSSING CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Construction and maintenance of railroad crossings. 
A.  Every railroad corporation shall construct and maintain good and sufficient crossings where its railroad crosses public roads now or hereafter to be opened for public use, which crossing shall be constructed of material and in the manner following: 
1.  Every crossing shall be constructed of materials that will provide a ride quality compatible with that of adjacent roadway surfaces; except that crossings of unconsolidated or asphalt material shall have installed headers of equal height to the top of rails installed on both sides of both rails. 
2.  The crossing on paved roads shall be the same width as the approaching roadway, including drivable shoulders plus two feet on each side. On gravel roads, the crossing shall be the same width as the traveled way, but not less than sixteen (16) feet. 
3.  The railroad corporation shall maintain the road surface from end of ties to end of ties and between tracks where adjacent track centers are less than fifteen (15) feet. 
4.  When a railroad corporation makes a track raise within a grade crossing, the runoff along the roadway shall be maintained at not more than two inches in the first ten (10) feet outside the end of ties, not more than six inches in the next ten (10) feet, and the remaining runoff shall be brought to the same level as the existing grade within an additional ten (10) feet along the roadway. 
5.  The railroad shall maintain a crosswalk of equal width as the approaching sidewalk from the end of ties to the end of ties and between tracks where adjacent track centers are less than fifteen (15) feet apart. The railroad shall use a durable contrasting material between the ends of ties when the approaching sidewalk is constructed of a hard surface material. Any durable material compatible with the material used on the sidewalk may be used on the crosswalk between the adjacent tracks. 
6.  The roadway surface shall be in the same plane as the top of rails for a distance of two feet outside of rails for either multiple or single track crossings. The top of the rail plane shall be connected with the grade line of the roadway each way by vertical curves of the length required to provide riding conditions and sight distances normally applied to the roadway. The roadway surface shall not be more than three inches higher nor six inches lower than the top of the nearest rail at a point thirty (30) feet from the rail, measured at a right angle, unless track super-elevation dictates otherwise. Where crossings involve two or more tracks, the top of rails for all tracks shall be brought to the same plane where practicable. 
7.  Width of roadway at a street-railway grade crossing should correspond to that of the adjoining street and have the same number and width of traffic lanes as the adjoining street, without extra lanes and with center turn lanes at the crossing delineated. At all paved approaches to the street-railway grade crossing, the street traffic lanes in the vicinity of the crossing shall be distinctly marked in accordance with the recommendations of the "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways." 
8.  The crossing surface for all new or reconstructed track where the railroad crosses public roads shall be molded rubber panels with steel re-enforcement and a patterned surface. 
9.  Where the grade of the street approach descends toward the crossing, provisions shall be made to intercept surface and subsurface drainage and discharge it laterally so that it will not be discharged on the track area. 
10.  The ballast and subballast shall be dug out a minimum of ten (10) inches below the bottoms of the ties, one foot minimum beyond the ends of the ties and beyond the end of the crossing a minimum of twenty (20) feet, and reballasted with ballast to conform with American Railway Engineering Association specifications. A minimum of at least ten (10) inches of clean ballast should be placed between bottom of tie and the subballast or subgrade. 
11.  Treated No. 5 hardwood or concrete ties shall be used through the limits of the crossing and beyond the crossing a minimum of twenty (20) feet. Length and spacing of ties should conform to the type of grade crossing surface materials being used. 
12.  The rails throughout the crossing shall be so laid to eliminate joints within the crossing. The nearest joint shall not be less than twenty (20) feet from the end of the crossing. Where necessary, long rails shall be used or the rail ends shall be welded to form continuous rail through the crossing. Rails shall be spiked to line, and the track shall be thoroughly and solidly tamped to uniform surface. Rails shall be protected with rust inhibitor. The rail section should, at a minimum, be one hundred fifteen (115) pound welded rail throughout the crossing to at least twenty (20) feet beyond each end of crossing. 
13.  Flangeways not less than two and one-half or more than three inches width shall be provided. Flangeways shall be at least two inches in depth unless approved by the operating railroad. 
14.  An agreed upon profile, and highway, shall be established between the operating railroad and the public works department. 
15.  Subgrade shall be cleaned of all old contaminated ballast and bladed to a level surface a minimum of ten (10) inches below bottom of tie and at least twenty (20) feet beyond each end of the crossing. 
16.  All drainage areas should be cleaned and sloped away from the crossing both directions along the track and the roadway. 
17.  When practical, a geotextile fabric should be used between the subgrade and the ballast section and at least twenty (20) feet beyond each end of the crossing, and if a rail joint falls within these limits at least five feet beyond the rail joint. If practical, the geotextile fabric should extend under the roadway surface, traveled way, fifteen (15) feet each way from center line of track. 
18.  All ties through the crossing area and at least twenty (20) feet beyond each end of the crossing should be fully tie plated with four spikes per tie plate, and fully box anchored. Optional placement of the tie pads is acceptable. 
19.  Rails should be spiked to line, and the track machined or mechanically tamped and surfaced to grade and alignment of the existing track and roadway. 
B.  When existing crossings have deteriorated to a level of service requiring reconstruction, the reconstruction shall be accomplished in accordance with the requirements for new construction. 
C.  If such corporation fails to construct or maintain such crossings as above provided, then the city shall notify such corporation of the necessity of the construction thereof, which notice or petition shall be in writing and shall be served by delivering a copy of the notice or petition to the agent of the corporation most convenient to the crossing. Upon the service of such notice or petition, if such corporation fails to construct such crossing within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice or petition, the city may proceed to construct and open the crossing as herein provided, and shall be entitled to recover double the amount expended, together with all costs, in the name of the city, in any court of competent jurisdiction, from such corporation refusing to construct the same. Such corporation shall also be liable for all damages resulting from such neglect to construct such crossing; said damages to be recovered in the name of the party injured, in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Prior code § 27-5) 
12.16.020 - Railroads required to pave right-of-way at street crossings. 
    Whenever the city shall, by ordinance duly enacted order any street, alley, avenue, public highway or sidewalk now existing therein or which may hereafter be created and opened for public use, or any part or parts thereof, to be graded, constructed, reconstructed, paved, guttered, curbed or otherwise improved or repaired, it shall be the duty of every railroad corporation owning, operating or leasing any railroad which crosses, abuts or adjoins any such street, alley, avenue, public highway or sidewalk, to grade, construct, reconstruct, pave, gutter, curb or otherwise improve and repair the part or parts of the street, alley, avenue, public highway or sidewalk upon which the right-of-way of the railroad so crosses, abuts or adjoins, to the same extent, of like materials and of as good quality, as the city has required, or shall in such ordinance require, of the other property owners abutting upon the street, alley, avenue, public highway or sidewalk in the grading, constructing, reconstructing or otherwise improving or repairing of the street, alley, avenue, public highway or sidewalk. 
(Prior code § 27-6) 
Chapter 12.20 - VACATIONS AND PUBLIC WAYS 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Initiation of proceedings-Methods to be used. 
    A proceeding for any proposed vacation or termination may be begun by either of the following methods: 
A.  By resolution of the city council upon its own motion duly passed at any regular or special meeting thereof; 
B.  By written petition of any person or corporation owning property fronting or abutting any land included in or subject to use by such public square, park, street, avenue, alley, highway, roadway, pedestrianway, easement, right-of-way or other public way or use, in the city proposed to be vacated or terminated, addressed to the city council, and verified by affidavit of petitioner, if an individual, or an officer thereof, if petitioner is a corporation, which petition shall be filed with the city clerk prior to any action thereon by the city council. 
(Prior code § 27-66) 
12.20.020 - Same-To include description of land involved. 
    Every resolution or petition provided for in the preceding section shall accurately describe the land as to which such vacation or termination is sought. 
(Prior code § 27-67) 
12.20.030 - Notice of adoption or filing of resolutions and petitions. 
    Promptly upon the adoption of any resolution or filing or any petition pursuant to this chapter, the city clerk, over his or her hand, shall give notice of the adoption of such resolution or the filing of such petition, by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, such publication to be at least twenty (20) days prior to the date and time to be stated therein upon which resolution or petition shall be considered by the city council, and which notice shall contain a description of the land as to which the vacation or termination is sought, and shall state the time and place of the meeting of the city council at which the council shall consider such action. 
(Ord. No. 8775, § 1, 10-7-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8775, § 1, adopted Oct. 7, 2014, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code § 27-68. 
12.20.040 - Declaration by city council-Generally. 
    If, upon the consideration of any resolution or petition as described in this chapter, and after proper notice, the city council shall deem it necessary to vacate or terminate any public square, park, street, avenue, alley, highway, roadway, pedestrianway, easement, right-of-way or other public way or use or any part thereof, the council may, by ordinance, duly introduced, read and passed according to law, declare the same to be duly vacated or terminated. 
(Prior code § 27-69) 
12.20.050 - Same-Recordation of documents. 
    Upon the final passage according to law of any ordinance vacating or terminating any public square, park, street, avenue, alley, highway, roadway, pedestrianway, easement, right-of-way or other public way or use, pursuant to such resolution or petition and notice, the city clerk shall file for record in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county, a certified copy of the resolution or petition; the affidavit of publication of notice and a certified copy of the ordinance, the recording fees to be paid by him or her as part of the expenses of such proceeding. 
(Prior code § 27-70) 
12.20.060 - Payment of expenses incurred in proceeding. 
    If proceedings pursuant to this chapter be begun by petition of a person the petitioner shall deposit with the city clerk the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) as a deposit for the payment of costs and expenses which may be incurred by the city by reason of such proceeding and shall further pay any other costs or expenses incident to the filing of the petition and giving of such notice and the filing for record of a certified copy of any ordinance which may be passed in pursuance of such vacation. If the deposit shall not be consumed for such purposes the balance remaining, after the completion of such procedure, shall be returned to the petitioner. The petitioner shall pay any expenses not covered by this deposit. 
(Prior code § 27-71) 
12.20.070 - Reversion of title to land affected. 
    Whenever any vacation or termination as provided by this chapter shall be made the title to any land affected thereby shall pass or revert according to law. 
(Prior code § 27-72) 
Chapter 12.24 - PARADES 
Sections: 
Article I. - Generally 

12.24.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    "Parade" means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, sidewalk, park or other public place in the city. 
    "Parade permit" means a permit as required by this chapter. 
    "Police chief" means the police chief, or his or her authorized subordinate, of the city. 
(Prior code § 27-121) 
12.24.020 - Public conduct during parades. 
A.  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
B.  Driving Through Parades. No driver of a vehicle, street car or trackless trolley shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
C.  Parking on Parade Route. The police chief shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The police chief shall post signs to such effect, and it is unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-122) 
12.24.030 - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
A.  Funeral processions; 
B.  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, provided that such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
C.  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Prior code § 27-123) 
Article II. - Permit 

12.24.040 - Required. 
    No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the city council. 
(Prior code § 27-136) 
12.24.050 - Application. 
A.  Generally. A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the city clerk on forms provided by such officer. 
B.  Filing Period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed not less than fifteen (15) days prior to city council action on the same. 
C.  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade; 
2.  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; 
3.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
4.  The date when the parade is to be conducted; 
5.  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; 
6.  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which will constitute such parade, the type of animals and description of the vehicles; 
7.  The hours when such parade will start and terminate; 
8.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
9.  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade; 
10.  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas; 
11.  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; 
12.  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the city clerk a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his or her behalf; 
13.  Any additional information which the city council shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue; 
14.  The applicant shall provide with the application to the city clerk a certificate of liability insurance indicating that the applicant has in force general liability and automobile liability insurance with the city, named as an additional insured, for at least five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) combined single limit. 
D.  Transmittal to City Council. Such applications shall be transmitted by the city clerk to the city council for consideration in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-137) 
12.24.060 - Standards for issuance. 
    The city council shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, it finds that: 
A.  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
B.  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; 
C.  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
D.  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment enroute to a fire; 
E.  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
F.  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays enroute; 
G.  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(Prior code § 27-138) 
12.24.070 - Alternative permit. 
    The city council, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within three days after notice of the city council, file a written notice of acceptance with the city clerk. An alternative parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-139) 
12.24.080 - Notice of issuance. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the mayor or city clerk shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
A.  The police chief; and 
B.  Such other persons as shall be designated by the mayor. 
(Prior code § 27-140) 
12.24.090 - Contents. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
A.  Starting time; 
B.  Minimum speed; 
C.  Maximum speed; 
D.  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 
E.  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
F.  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; 
G.  Such other information as the city council shall find necessary to the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-141) 
12.24.100 - Revocation. 
    The mayor or police chief shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this chapter upon a violation of the conditions of such permit. 
(Prior code § 27-142) 
12.24.110 - Duties of permittee. 
A.  A permittee under this chapter shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
B.  The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his or her person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Prior code § 27-143) 
Chapter 12.28 - NEWSPAPER VENDING DEVICES 
Sections: 

12.28.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain words and phrases shall be construed herein as set forth in this section, unless it is apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended: 
    "Newspaper vending device" means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used or maintained for the display and sale of newspapers, news periodicals, books, magazines or other printed material. 
    "Public sidewalk" means that portion of the public right-of-way designed or ordinarily used for pedestrian travel. 
    "Public street" means that portion of the public right-of-way designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
(Prior code § 27-161) 
12.28.020 - Prohibited. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it is unlawful for any person or other entity to install, place or maintain any newspaper vending device which projects onto, into or over any part of a public street, or which rests, wholly or in part, upon, along or over any portion of any public street or public sidewalk. 
(Prior code § 27-162) 
12.28.030 - Interference with use of streets and sidewalks. 
    It is unlawful for any person or other entity to install, place or maintain any newspaper vending device which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any public street or any public sidewalk when such installation, placement or maintenance endangers the safety of persons or property, or when the site or location is used for public utility purposes, public transportation purposes or other governmental use, or when such newspaper vending device unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including any legally parked or stopped vehicle, the ingress or egress of any residence or place of business, the use of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes or other objects permitted at or near said location. 
(Prior code § 27-163) 
12.28.040 - Identification. 
    Every person or other entity which installs, places or maintains a newspaper vending device on a public sidewalk of the city shall have affixed thereto, in a place easily seen, the name, address and telephone number of such person or entity. 
(Prior code § 27-164) 
12.28.050 - Size. 
    No single newspaper vending machine shall exceed five feet in height, thirty (30) inches in width or two feet in thickness. 
(Prior code § 27-165) 
12.28.060 - Unlawful installation, placement and maintenance. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person or other entity to install, place or maintain a newspaper vending device upon a public sidewalk in the following locations and in the following manner: 
1.  Within five feet of any marked or unmarked crosswalk or projection thereof, unless specifically approved; 
2.  Within five feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call box or other emergency facility; 
3.  Within five feet of any driveway; 
4.  Within fifteen (15) feet of any designated bus stop sign or post; 
5.  Newspaper vending devices shall be located as follows: only one such device per publication shall be permitted per block, and all publication vending devices shall be collected at one location in said block, designated at the discretion of the code enforcement officer; 
6.  At any location whereby the clear space for the passage of pedestrians is reduced to less than six feet. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person or other entity to chain a newspaper vending device to any property not owned by the owner of the newspaper vending device or to any permanently fixed object. However, newspaper vending devices, when placed side-by-side, may be chained or otherwise attached to one another. 
C.  Newspaper vending devices may be placed next to each other; provided, that no group of newspaper vending devices shall extend more than six feet along a curb or wall. 
(Prior code § 27-166) 
12.28.070 - Abandonment. 
    Any newspaper vending device placed upon the public sidewalk which appears not to have been in continuous use for a period exceeding sixty (60) days shall be considered abandoned and thus constituting a public nuisance subject to removal by the city or its agents, servants or employees. 
(Prior code § 27-167) 
12.28.080 - Hold-harmless agreement. 
    Every person or other entity which installs, places or maintains a newspaper vending device on a public sidewalk in the city shall file a written statement with the clerk of council satisfactory to the city council whereby said person or entity agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the city, its officers, directors and employees from any loss or liability or damage, including expenses and costs, for bodily or personal injury and for property damage sustained by any person as a result of the installation, placement or maintenance of a newspaper vending device within the city. 
(Prior code § 27-168) 
12.28.090 - Permit. 
A.  Required. It is unlawful for any person or other entity to place, locate, operate or maintain any newspaper vending device in or on any part of the public sidewalks of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city council. 
B.  Fee. No fee shall be required for the issuance of a newspaper vending device permit. 
C.  Issuance. Upon proper application on forms provided by the enforcement agency and upon certification of compliance with the provisions of this chapter and approval by the city council, the enforcement agency shall issue to the applicant a newspaper vending device permit. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the enforcement agency may not refuse to issue a permit where the application is otherwise proper. Only one permit shall be required for the placement and maintenance of any number of newspaper vending devices on the public sidewalks by any one vendor. 
D.  Contents. All permits issued hereunder shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant; 
2.  The total number of newspaper vending devices which are to be placed upon the public sidewalks of the city and the specific location of each; 
3.  A certification of compliance with the provisions of this chapter by the enforcement agency. 
E.  Additional Permits. Each additional vending device not listed in the original application shall require additional permits. 
F.  Revocation. If at any time it is determined by the city council that any newspaper vending device for which a permit has been issued is not in compliance with the requirements of this chapter, a "notice of intent to revoke" the permit shall be issued, in writing, to the permittee. Said notice shall set forth the violation or violations which constitute the basis of the proposed revocation. Said notice shall contain the date and time that such revocation shall be in effect and, upon permittee's failure to correct said violation, the permit shall be revoked and the device shall be removed as in Section 12.28.070 made and provided. 
G.  Removal of Unpermitted Devices. Any device installed without a permit may be removed by the city or its agents. 
(Prior code § 27-169) 
12.28.100 - Removal of devices not in compliance. 
    It shall be the duty of the enforcement agency to enforce the provisions of this chapter by removing all such devices not in compliance therewith. 
(Prior code § 27-170) 
Chapter 12.32 - PARKS[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8766, § 1, adopted Aug. 5, 2014, amended Ch. 12.32 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 12.32, §§ 12.32.010-12.32.030, pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

12.32.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain words and phrases shall be construed herein as set forth in this section, unless it is apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Alcoholic beverage" means intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or non-intoxicating beer. 
    "Athletic field" means designated areas for organized athletic league play such as softball diamonds, football fields, and soccer fields. 
    "Athletic shoe" means a smooth soled, no heeled, sport shoe. 
    "Director of parks and recreation" means the individual appointed from time to time by the parks and recreation board to carry out the provisions of this chapter, or the parks and recreation board's designee. 
    "Domestic animals" means animals which are habituated to live in or about the habitations of people or such as to contribute to the support of a family or the wealth of the community. 
    "Litter" means to throw or place, or cause to be thrown or placed, any glass, glass bottles, wire, nails, tacks, hedge, cans, garbage, trash, refuse or rubbish of any kind, nature or description in the parks or recreation areas. 
    "Motorized vehicle" means any self-propelled vehicle, excepting devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    "Permit" means any written license issued by the city or the parks and recreation director or designee permitting a special event or activity on or in a park or building facility. 
    "Special event" means an event which in effect removes public property from public use for a period of time, excluding athletic fields, shelter houses and special events sponsored by the city. 
    "Trail" means any walking trail, exercise path, or path maintained for pedestrians within a city park or recreation area. 
    "Vehicle" means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.015 - Park hours. 
    Except for unusual or unforeseen events, city parks shall be open to the public every day of the year from 5:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. All city parks shall be closed to the public between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., except for authorized sporting events, in which case the public may remain in the park until fifteen (15) minutes after the end of such authorized events. Except for such approved extended organized sporting events, it is unlawful for any person to use such facilities or be present therein during such hours. It is unlawful for any person to camp in or sleep in a city park after the closing hours of such park. The off-leash dog park shall be open daily from 6:00 a.m. to sunset or 9:00 p.m., whichever shall first occur. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.020 - Temporary shelters prohibited. 
    No person shall set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelters in a public park within the city for the purpose of overnight camping; nor shall any person leave in a park after closing hours any movable structure or special vehicle to be used or that could be used for such purpose, such as a house trailer, camp trailer, camp wagon or the like. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.025 - Selling in parks restricted. 
    It is unlawful for any person to expose or offer for sale any article or thing, nor shall he or she station or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing in any public park within the city; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person authorized by the directors of the park board to operate as a concessionaire to sell or vend merchandise; provided, that such person so acts in accordance with the regulations and directions of the park board. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.030 - Use of park facilities. 
A.  All public fountains located in the public park system of the city are decorative in nature and are located therein to enhance the aesthetic appearance of the parks and as memorials. 
B.  All fountains or pools constructed as a decorative structure or memorial structure are to be protected from any damage thereto by climbing or walking on parapets, walls or fountain structures, and all such activities are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.035 - Vehicular use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to: 
A.  Drive any vehicle on an area except the paved park roads or parking areas, or such areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary areas. 
B.  Park a vehicle anywhere except in a designated area. 
C.  Leave a vehicle standing or parked in established parking areas or elsewhere in the park and recreation areas during hours when the park and recreation area is closed with the exception of vehicles parked in connection with a program or event sponsored by the city. 
D.  Ride a bicycle without reasonable regard to the safety to others. 
E.  Use the parks, park drives, parking places or parkways for the purpose of demonstrating any vehicles, or for the purpose of instructing another to drive or operate any vehicle nor shall any person use any park area, including parking places, for the repairing or cleaning of any vehicle, except in an emergency. 
F.  Cause or permit a vehicle in tow of another vehicle to enter the parks or proceed therein, except that in case of a breakdown a disabled vehicle may be towed to the nearest exit; or operate or drive a vehicle containing any person or object projecting or hanging outside of or beyond the side or the rear thereof. 
G.  Operate, ride, push, carry or park bicycles, skateboards and motorized vehicles on the trails, except at Wheel Park. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.040 - Park closings. 
    Any city park or portion of any city park may be closed to the public entirely or closed for certain uses for a period of time as determined by the director of parks and recreation, simply by the posting of signs to that effect or by other means which make it obvious that any city park or portion thereof is closed to the public entirely or closed for certain uses. During the periods of time when any city park is closed, no person shall enter or occupy any such park or portion of such park contrary to the posted regulations. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.045 - Sales and concessions. 
    Sales or advertisement of merchandise or other goods for sale or hire, in any city park or recreation facilities, is prohibited, except by written permission of the director of parks and recreation and upon obtaining a license or contract as a concessionaire as otherwise provided in this chapter; however, no permit shall be required for a city-sponsored event. 
A.  Display of Written Permits. Written permits issued by the city pursuant to this section for the sale or advertisement of merchandise or other goods for sale or hire in any city park or facilities must be conspicuously displayed at all times. 
B.  Temporary Concessions. Temporary concessions may be given for special events to any person, firm or corporation, or to any civic group upon such terms and conditions as set forth by the director of parks and recreation from time to time. 
C.  Concessionaire Contract. In the event concessions at a city park are provided by any party other than the city, the city shall enter into a contract and issue a license for the provision of such concessions. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.050 - Damage to city property. 
    No person shall deface, damage, injure or destroy any city building, bridge, fence or other city enclosure, gate, gate post, grounds, lamp, lamppost, fireplug, hydrant, railing, sign, tree, tree box or any other city property or property not belonging to that person by breaking, cutting, hacking, pulling down, tearing, marking, daubing with paint, or other substance, or in any other way or manner defacing, damaging, injuring or destroying such property. It shall be unlawful for any person to climb any tree or walk; climb, stand or sit upon monuments, vases, planters, fountains, railings, fences or upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purpose. No person shall practice golf techniques such as driving chipping or putting on city park property. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.055 - Wildlife. 
    No person shall pursue, catch, kill, molest, or take in any manner or any quantity any wildlife on parkland except as otherwise permitted by this chapter, or by the express permission of the director of parks and recreation when necessary to control animal damage. 
A.  Domestic Animals. Except in the city's dog park or where may otherwise be posted by the parks and recreation board, while in city parks, domestic animals shall be effectively leashed at all times by a handheld leash by a responsible person physically capable of controlling such animal. Domestic animals shall not be left unattended. Further, the owner or person having custody of such domestic animal shall be responsible for removal of any animal solid waste or feces. 
B.  Horseback Riding. No person shall engage in horseback riding in city parks. 
C.  Trapping. No person shall set or possess any steel, plastic or wooden trap for catching, pursuing or killing wildlife in any city park. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.060 - Plants and other natural materials. 
    All trees, plants, vegetation, soil, rock, sand, stones, wood or other natural materials on city park land are protected. No person shall collect, destroy, damage, cut, carve, mark, transplant, remove, dig in or otherwise disturb any tree, plant, grass, flowers, other vegetation, soil, rock, sand, stones, wood or other natural materials from park lands or in any other way injure the natural beauty or usefulness of any area except by permission of the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.065 - Fires. 
    No person shall ignite or maintain any fire on parkland except in devices designed as grills or other fireplaces provided for that purpose by the city. No person shall leave a fire unattended, and all fires must be extinguished after use. 
A.  Fire Danger. The director of parks and recreation may prohibit all fires on all city parkland by the posting of signs to that effect during designated periods of drought. 
B.  Ignitable and Combustible Materials. No person shall throw away or discard any lighted match, cigar, cigarette, tobacco, paper or other material within or against any building, vehicle, or under any tree or in underbrush. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.070 - Littering. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to litter on city park property. Only litter or trash generated from recreational activities in city parks shall be disposed of in appropriate containers provided by the department of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.075 - Disorderly conduct. 
A.  Generally. No person shall engage in disorderly conduct or any conduct tending toward a breach of the peace or engage in any violent, tumultuous, offensive and disorderly conduct by threatening, quarrelling, challenging to fight or fighting, or by using obscene, offensive, profane or unseemly language to the annoyance, disturbance or vexation of another. 
B.  When Noises Constitute Disorderly Conduct. The causing or making of any unnecessary loud noise by the use of amplified speakers or sound systems shall be considered disorderly conduct (excepted herefrom is the use of city sound equipment utilized at the athletic fields and city-sponsored special events). 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.080 - Alcoholic beverages and glass beverage containers. 
A.  Possession and Consumption Generally. Except as authorized in Section 9.24.010, the possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited in city parks. 
B.  Intoxication. Any person in a state of intoxication or under the influence of a controlled dangerous substance on any city park property or city recreation area may be removed from park property or the recreation area. 
C.  Glass Beverage Containers. The possession of glass beverage containers on city park property is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 8969, § 4, 2-21-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8969, § 4, adopted Feb. 21, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
12.32.085 - Reservations. 
    Any group may reserve any park shelter or athletic field for a specific time and date in accordance with the terms of this section: 
A.  Shelter Houses and Athletic Fields. Shelter houses and athletic fields may be reserved by obtaining a permit from the director of parks and recreation or any employee designated by the director of parks and recreation. Reservations may only be made by a person twenty-one (21) years of age or older. The person making the reservation shall be held accountable for the condition of the shelter house or athletic field at the end of such person's use. The person reserving the shelter house or athletic field shall also be responsible for the actions of those in such person's party. Use of a shelter house or athletic field by anyone other than the party in whom the reservation is made and to whom the permit is issued is prohibited. 
B.  Procedure. The director of parks and recreation or any employee designated by the director of parks and recreation shall record all reservations and record all payments and deposits. Reservations shall be made by the director of parks and recreation or any employee designated by the director of parks and recreation on a first come first served basis upon payment of the fee required by the schedule of fees and charges as amended by the parks and recreation board from time to time. 
C.  Other Use Allowed. Nothing in this section shall prohibit any organized or informal group from using park facilities not otherwise closed to the public without a reservation. Such use shall not interfere with use of facilities by a group having a reservation. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.090 - Tennis courts. 
    Tennis courts may be reserved for events sponsored by the city or programs approved by the director of parks and recreation. It shall be unlawful for any person using a tennis court located on city park property to wear nonathletic footwear on the tennis court surface, use a metal tennis racket on the tennis court without a court guard protector, operate or ride a bicycle, roller skates, rollerblades or skateboard on a tennis court. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.095 - Miscellaneous prohibitions. 
A.  Solicitation. No person shall solicit alms or contributions for any purpose, whether public or private on city park property, unless the solicitation is in connection with a city-sponsored event and approved by the city. 
B.  Gambling. It shall be unlawful for any person in a park or recreation area to play, engage or take part in any game or competitive sport for money, or other valuable thing, without a written permit. 
C.  Firearms and Other Weapons. Other than as provided by federal or state law, no person other than police officers or others authorized by law shall use, carry or possess any long bow, cross bow or slingshot, pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, air gun, spring gun, BB gun or any other weapon in which the force used to propel projectiles is gun powder, air, compressed air or springs, or any instrument that can be loaded with and fire blank cartridges, on any city park system property except as otherwise permitted by this chapter. Further, no person shall discharge a firearm or other weapon into park areas from beyond the park boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.100 - Issuance of permit required. 
    No person shall do any of the following without a permit, provided that no permit shall be required for any action or event sponsored by the city: 
A.  Display an advertising sign or other advertising matter, provided that a sign attached to a vehicle to identify the vehicle, or a sign lawfully on a taxi or bus, is not prohibited; 
B.  Operate for advertising purposes any musical instrument, soundtrack or drum; 
C.  Conduct exhibitions; 
D.  Hold a parade; 
E.  Conduct concerts. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.105 - Cooperative use of city park facilities with schools. 
    The city will make city park facilities available for the use of school classes and other school activities for any public or private school within the boundaries of the North Kansas City School District. Such activities may be scheduled during hours that school is in session or after school. The school shall give at least thirty (30) days' notice to the parks and recreation director of its need to utilize any park area for such school purposes and a permit shall be issued for such school use in the event the park scheduling permits. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.110 - Authority to enact additional rules. 
    The parks and recreation board has the authority to enact any rules not inconsistent with the rules provided by this chapter controlling the general conduct of park patrons which are necessary to ensure the well-being of all park users. Such rules established by the parks and recreation board shall be posted at any such facility to which the rule applies and may be enforced by the director of parks and recreation or any employee designated by the director of parks and recreation and by the police department as if completely set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.115 - Review by parks and recreation board. 
    All decisions of the director of parks and recreation made hereunder are subject to review by the parks and recreation board. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the director of parks and recreation may appeal such decision in writing to the parks and recreation board for final review. The decision of the parks and recreation board in such instance is final with the exception of provisions hereof which specifically requires city council action. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
12.32.120 - Enforcement. 
    The police department and the director of parks and recreation or any employee designated by the director of parks and recreation shall, in connection with their duties imposed by law, enforce the provisions of this chapter. The police department and the director of parks and recreation or any employee designated by the director of parks and recreation shall have the authority to order any person or persons acting in violation of this chapter to leave the park or recreation area. 
(Ord. No. 8766, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
Chapter 12.34 - TOWN SQUARE AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
Sections: 

12.34.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter only: 
    "Public place" means a place to which the public or a substantial group of persons has access during the hours of five a.m. to midnight each day, and includes, but is not limited to, the areas surrounding various city buildings owned by the city. For the purposes of this chapter, public place shall not include: (1) the North Kansas City Hospital and its facilities; (2) the vestibule entry to the city police building; (3) the parking area immediately in front of the police building; or (4) the North Kansas City Community Center and its facilities when a special event has been scheduled with and approved by the director of the community center or his or her designee that authorizes use of the community center between at any time between 12:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
    "Town square" means that area owned by the city immediately south of Armour Road and east of Swift Avenue known as and named the Robert E. Bledsoe Town Square, which serves as a public place and is used for various public activities and events. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.34.020 - Town square hours-Tents, etc., in town square. 
    Town square shall be closed to the public between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m., and it is unlawful for any person to use or occupy town square or be present therein during such hours. It is unlawful for any person to camp in or sleep in town square after the closing hours of such square. No person shall set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelter in town square for the purpose of overnight camping; nor shall any person leave in town square after closing hours any movable structure or special vehicle to be used or that could be used for such purpose, such as a house trailer, camp trailer, camp wagon or the like. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.34.030 - Hours for other public places-Tents, etc., in public places. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, every public place within the city shall be closed to the public between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m., and it is unlawful for any person to use or occupy any such public place or be present therein during such hours. It is unlawful for any person to camp in or sleep in any such public place after the closing hours of such public place. No person shall set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelter in any public place for the purpose of overnight camping; nor shall any person leave in any public place after closing hours any movable structure or special vehicle to be used or that could be used for such purpose, such as a house trailer, camp trailer, camp wagon or the like. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.34.040 - Selling in town square restricted. 
    It is unlawful for any person to expose or offer for sale any article or thing, nor shall he or she station or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing in the town square within the city; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person authorized by the city council to sell or vend merchandise; provided, that such person so acts in accordance with the regulations and directions of the city council. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.34.050 - Use of town square facilities. 
A.  The public fountain located in the town square of the city is decorative in nature and is located therein to enhance the aesthetic appearance of the town square. 
B.  Such fountain or pool constructed as a decorative structure is to be protected from any damage thereto by climbing or walking on parapets, walls or fountain structures, and all such activities are prohibited. 
C.  It is unlawful to wade or bathe in such fountain or pool located in town square. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.34.060 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than five dollars or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.34.070 - Severability. 
    The provisions of this chapter are declared to be separate and severable. The invalidity of any clause, sentence, paragraph, subdivision, section or portion of this chapter, or the invalidity of the application thereof to any person or circumstance shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this chapter, or the validity of its application to other persons or circumstances. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.34.080 - Nonexclusivity. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall limit or preclude the enforcement of other applicable laws. 
(Ord. 8276 § 1 (part), 2008) 
Chapter 12.36 - MUNICIPAL SWIMMING POOL AND TENNIS COURTS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Tennis Courts 

12.36.010 - Compliance generally. 
    All rules regulating the use of the tennis courts are to be strictly obeyed, and the conduct of players and bystanders shall at all times be orderly and decent. 
(Prior code § 20-16) 
Article II. - Swimming Facilities 

12.36.020 - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to the municipal swimming pool. 
(Prior code § 20-31) 
12.36.030 - Rules and regulations generally. 
    No person with oil on the body shall be allowed to enter the pool until the same is removed. No crowding on diving boards shall be permitted. All profane and indecent language is prohibited in the pool and in the dressing rooms. All persons are prohibited from walking on edge of pool or on scum gutter, from running around the pool, and from spitting in the pool. The throwing of paper, confetti or trash of any kind into the pool is also prohibited. 
(Prior code § 20-32) 
12.36.040 - Persons suffering from disease, etc., prohibited. 
    No person suffering from any disease, sore or wound of any kind shall be admitted to the pool. 
(Prior code § 20-33) 
12.36.050 - Shower and foot bath required. 
    All persons desiring to use the pool must first have a shower bath and use the foot bath required by the city before entering the pool. 
(Prior code § 20-34) 
12.36.060 - Smoking prohibited. 
A.  The possession of lighted smoking materials in any form, including, but not limited to, the possession of lighted cigarettes, cigars, pipes or other tobacco products, is prohibited in, on or about the North Kansas City swimming pool facility or on the surrounding swimming pool premises. 
B.  The director of public works of the city shall prominently post "No Smoking" signs with letters not less than one inch in height, or the international "No Smoking" symbol consisting of pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a bar across it, at various locations at the swimming pool facility in the city and on the swimming pool premises surrounding the pool. 
C.  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section is deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished pursuant to the provisions of Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 20-35) 
Chapter 12.40 - STREET TREES AND PARK TREES 
Sections: 

12.40.010 - Definitions. 
    "Park trees" are defined as trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation having individual names; and parks are defined as all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
    "Street trees" are defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
(Prior code § 27-180) 
12.40.020 - Creation and establishment of a city tree board. 
    There is established a city tree board for the city, which shall consist of the director of public works, superintendent of buildings and grounds, and the director of parks and recreation of this city. 
(Prior code § 27-181) 
12.40.030 - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the city council and upon their acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. The board, when requested by the city council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Prior code § 27-182) 
12.40.040 - Operation. 
    The board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Prior code § 27-183) 
12.40.050 - Tree species to be planted. 
    The tree board shall maintain the official list of recommended trees for planting in public areas. The purpose of this listing will be to maintain the diversity in the total tree population. This list shall be available upon request to aid in the selection of trees for private and public properties. The list of recommended trees may be updated periodically by the tree board to reflect new developments or species that will affect the population of the community forest. No species other than those included in this list may be without written permission of the tree board. 
(Prior code § 27-184) 
12.40.060 - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in the official list of recommended trees, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: small trees, thirty (30) feet; medium trees, forty (40) feet; and large trees, fifty (50) feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. 
(Prior code § 27-185) 
12.40.070 - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
    The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in the official list of recommended trees, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: small trees, two feet; medium trees, three feet; and large trees, four feet. 
(Prior code § 27-186) 
12.40.080 - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
    No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five (35) feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet of any fireplug. 
(Prior code § 27-187) 
12.40.090 - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed as small trees on the official list of recommended trees may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Prior code § 27-188) 
12.40.100 - Public tree care. 
A.  The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
B.  The city tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
C.  Any utility with overhead facilities, must have on file a set of tree trimming standards. Utilities will be allowed to trim trees and shrubbery upon and overhanging streets and other public property so as to prevent the branches and foliage from coming in contact with the wires, cables, and other facilities of the utility based upon the preapproved set of standards. Care will be exercised to prevent unnecessary trimming so as to protect any aesthetic benefits of the presence of certain trees and shrubbery. 
D.  This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with Sections 12.40.050 through 12.40.090. 
(Prior code § 27-189) 
12.40.110 - Tree topping. 
    It is unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property. "Topping" is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the city tree board. 
(Prior code § 27-190) 
12.40.120 - Pruning, corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic-control device or sign. 
(Prior code § 27-191) 
12.40.130 - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city tree board will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by such owners at their own expense within sixty (60) days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal on the owners property tax notice. 
(Prior code § 27-192) 
12.40.140 - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Prior code § 27-193) 
12.40.150 - Interference with city tree board. 
    It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 27-194) 
12.40.160 - Authorization for work and bond. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street trees within the city without first receiving authorization from the director of public works or his or her designee. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing park trees within the city without first receiving authorization from the director of parks and recreation or his or her designee. 
C.  Each person shall first file evidence of possession of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage indemnifying the city or any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. 
(Prior code § 27-195) 
12.40.170 - Review by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree board to the city council who may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
(Prior code § 27-196) 
12.40.180 - Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined in accordance with Section 1.16.010 of this code for each offense. A separate and distinct offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 27-197) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Sections: 

13.04.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
    "Customer" means a firm, corporation, legal entity or governmental unit furnished water by the department. 
    "Department" means the city of North Kansas city public works department. 
    "Division" means the water division of the public works department.
