    "Inspection" means an investigation and review by the water division of work performed by others under a permit issued by the public works department. 
    "Lead based materials," when used with respect to solder and flux, means solders and flux containing more than 0.2 percent lead; when used with respect to pipes and pipe fittings, means pipes and pipe fittings containing more than eight percent lead. 
    "Master meter" means one meter measuring the water furnished to serve two or more premises. 
    "Meter" means a mechanical device that measures and records the quantity of water furnished to a customer. 
    "Meter setting" means a box, vault or tile, with covering, containing a meter, meter yoke and connecting appurtenances. 
    "Permit" means a written document issued by the public works department authorizing work to be performed. 
    "Public drinking water system" means any publicly or privately owned water system supplying water to the general public which is satisfactory for drinking, culinary, and domestic purposes and meets the requirements of the Missouri Department of Natural Resources. 
    "Water main" means the water pipe, fittings valves, boxes and manholes installed as an integral part of the distribution system, but not including hydrant units and water service piping. 
    "Water service" means the piping installed from the water main to that portion of the interior piping regulated by the building code. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.020 - Permits. 
A.  Applications for water service shall be made at city hall by or on behalf of the customer requesting water service. The application shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the department. Every customer using water from the waterworks system shall be deemed to have consented and agreed to the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Permits are of three kinds, defined as follows: 
1.  Service permits are required where taps are to be made and new services are to be installed; 
2.  Extension permits are required where an existing service, whether on public or private property, is to be altered, extended, repaired or renewed from the main to the building, or fixtures or appurtenances added thereto or detached from, and when service is disconnected and abandoned at the mains; 
3.  Renewal permits are required where an existing service or services are to be abandoned and replaced with a single larger service that requires a larger tap, or the relocation of any existing service that requires a new tap. 
C.  No work in connection with the tappings of any main or the introduction of water into any premises (public or private) shall be done, nor shall any water service be altered, repaired or extended without prior issuance of a permit authorizing the performance of such work. When the plumber must perform emergency work during other than normal working hours, the water division shall be notified by telephone prior to the starting of such work, and the plumber shall secure the permit on the next regular working day. See Section 13.04.070(C) for inspection to be performed during other than normal working hours. 
D.  A master plumber's or journeyman plumber's license is not transferable. Any master plumber shall subject himself or herself to suspension if he or she attempts to, or procures a water permit for the benefit of anyone other than himself or herself. 
E.  Permits are not transferable and are only valid for the applicant to whom issued and for the job described thereon. 
F.  Permits are valid for ninety (90) consecutive days from the date of issuance. If the permit expires before the completion of the project, it must be renewed. Request for renewal must be made to the city public works department either by telephone, in writing or in person. Reasons for such renewal and a report of the work to date shall accompany each request. An extension of time for an additional thirty (30) days will be granted in all proper cases and noted on the permit. There will be no charge for renewal; however, all outstanding permits that have exceeded the time limit and are not properly renewed, will be classified as delinquent. 
G.  All permit fees and charges shall be paid by the applicant at the time of procuring the permit. 
1.  Permit fees shall not be refundable; 
2.  All charges shall be in accordance with the schedules of prices specified herein. In the event that the permit is not used, these charges shall be refunded. 
H.  No permits will be issued to anyone who is delinquent in payments for water services. 
I.  Permits shall be issued by the public works department to qualified applicants only after all requirements are satisfied. A permit for fire protection service will not be issued without evidence of a water service line for domestic use. Permits are issued subject to a city water main being in front of the property to be served. If the property is large enough to permit a subdividing at a later date, it will be necessary for the water main to front the subdivided property on which the facility to be served is constructed. Failure of the applicant to pay a bill for service rendered by the water division shall be a basis for denial of further permits until such bill or bills be paid. Persistent violation of this provision may be considered cause for revoking the master plumber's license held by the offender. 
J.  Applicants shall be prepared to show proof of qualification at the time of application and shall procure permits for themselves and no other. Permits shall be issued only to the following: 
1.  A plumber who may apply as an individual, firm, partnership or corporation; 
2.  Licensed automatic sprinkler system contractors who are to install fire protection systems only as described in the building code; 
3.  Other utilities or municipalities that purchase water from the city; 
4.  Contractors, who are performing work under city contract which requires them to modify existing water facilities, may be issued permits for the work defined in the contract. 
K.  Prior to receiving the permit, the applicant must submit the following documents for examination at the permit desk: 
1.  Notification from the city that all fees have been paid; 
2.  Where excavation on public property is necessary, the applicant must exhibit an excavation permit issued by the public works department, city hall. 
L.  Each application for a permit shall be made in writing and shall be signed by the applicant, as defined in Section 13.04.020(J), or his or her duly authorized agent. The application shall state in precise terms the work to be done under the permit. In addition, each application shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name of the person for whom the work is to be performed or the owner of the property served; 
2.  The correct address and other legal description where work is to be performed. House numbers must be assigned by the public works department. 
M.  Each permit must be returned to the public works department permit desk by the person to whom it is issued within forty-eight (48) hours after the authorized work has been completed and within ninety (90) days from the date of issuance of such permit. Returned permits must contain a complete report of all work done, and such a report shall be of form and content as prescribed on the permit. 
N.  Reports must be signed by the applicant. Each report must state the date on which the work was completed and must be accompanied by a certificate of inspection signed by the inspector. For service lines connected to the city's water mains and serving premises outside the city limits, an inspection slip must be provided by the plumbing inspection section of the buildings inspection division, certifying that no cross connections are present in the plumbing system of the building served. 
O.  A permit which fails to show clearly and accurately all of the required information shall be rejected, and the applicant shall make corrections immediately. Permits returned without a certificate of inspection signed by the inspector will be rejected. Laxity in making reports or corrections shall be cause for classifying permits as delinquent. 
P.  A plumber or sprinkler system contractor shall be responsible for any defective workmanship performed or material furnished on public property for a period of one year from the date of final inspection by the water division of the public works department. 
Q.  The public works department shall be authorized to cancel for any cause any permit issued. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.030 - Water mains. 
A.  Water mains are classified functionally as feeder mains, distribution mains, and service mains. A further classification into city mains and private mains is also made. These mains are further described as follows: 
1.  A feeder main is a water conduit that is used for transportation of water from one part of the water system to a more remote part or reservoir and coming from pump stations. These mains are usually sixteen (16) inches in diameter and smaller; 
2.  A distribution main is a water conduit that is connected between and from feeder mains and is the principal means of supply for localities. These mains are usually eight to twelve (12) inches in diameter and no less than eight inches in diameter for all pipe laid after January 1, 1978; 
3.  A service main is a conduit that supplies water directly to a customer through a service connection. These shall be mains smaller than twelve (12) inches in diameter. Twelve (12) inch mains may be classed either service mains or distribution mains as deemed appropriate by the water division of the public works department. 
B.  Private water mains will not be allowed connection to the city's system except as a provision between the water division and applicant. Those private mains presently connected to the water division system and in contract with water division mains shall be subject to the regulations hereinafter set forth. 
C.  Connections to water mains shall be made as provided in these rules and regulations. The owner of private water mains, where that owner is not a public utility, must allow new customers to make a service connection to or extend from it for their own purposes. The owner is permitted to charge a fee for this connection, and in the event of disagreement as to the amount of the fee, the public works department shall act as arbiter and will fix a price that will be binding on both parties. All applications for permits to connect to a private water main must be accompanied by a letter from the owner which states specifically that the owner approves the connection. 
D.  When a new water division main is laid paralleling an obsolete existing main, connection between the water division's new main and existing individual tap services will be made at the city's expense, and the obsolete main will be abandoned. Where such obsolete main is a private main, the cost of transferring services will be charged as ordered by the public works department. 
E.  Operation of mains shall be performed only by the water division personnel. Requests by the plumbers for the shutting down of mains shall be made a reasonable time in advance, and shutdown will be performed during regular working hours unless request stipulates otherwise. When shutdowns are made for the benefit of the person making the request, he or she will be charged for this service on the basis of prevailing labor and equipment rates. 
F.  The responsibility for maintenance of mains shall be with the owner of the main. In event of failure of a private main where such failure constitutes a menace to public health and safety or excessive loss of water, the water division of the public works department will repair the main and the owner shall bear the cost. Otherwise, the owner will be notified, and he or she may elect to have either the water division or his or her contractor repair the main at his or her own expense. 
G.  All service mains serving residential homes (single dwelling) will be maintained as stated. A service line from distribution main to meter pit including lid, cover, meter, yoke, ell, valve, meter pit, service line tap, piping and fittings will be maintained, serviced, repaired, replaced, removed and relocated at the sole expense of the water division of the public works department. All other piping, fitting and valves will be the responsibility of the property owner, from the house side of the meter pit to the house. 
H.  All service mains serving commercial, factory or industrial areas shall be maintained, repaired and replaced, removed, resized and kept up to the division's standards at all times by the property owner or building owner. Service mains serving commercial, factory or industrial services are as follows: 
1.  Everything connected from distribution mains including corporation cocks or sleeves, valves, piping, meter, meter pits, meter settings and bypass lines, and piping in meter pits and entire service into the building or property; 
2.  The water division of the public works department will at no time be held responsible to maintain commercial, factory or industrial service main except as stated in Section 13.04.030(F); 
3.  The water division of the public works department reserves the right to do the work or reject the work upon the request of such work. The public works department will act as arbiter in cases of question as to what is termed residential, commercial, factory and industrial. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.040 - Water services. 
A.  Water service piping is classified into two categories: Tap service piping and branch service piping. The components of tap service piping are a corporation stop, copper pipe, a curb stop and box, meter yoke and meter stop valve. The components of a branch service piping are a tapping sleeve and valve, a valve box, pipe, meter stop valves and bypass piping. Branch service piping may be for domestic water service or private fire protection service. When branch service piping is used for private fire protection, the service size must be designed by an engineer. It may not be tapped for domestic service unless otherwise approved by the water division. 
B.  All service lines shall conform to the following requirements: 
1.  Service connections are to be made in front of the property to be served unless otherwise approved by the water division; 
2.  Service lines are to be run perpendicular to the main from the main to the curb box or, in the absence of a curb box, to the property line; 
3.  Service lines shall be laid at least ten feet horizontally from any existing or proposed drain or sewer line. Should local conditions prevent a lateral separation of ten (10) feet, a water service line may be laid closer than ten (10) feet to a storm or sanitary sewer line, provided that the service line is laid in a separate trench or on an undisturbed earth shelf located on one side of the sewer line and at such an elevation that the bottom of the service line is at least eighteen (18) inches above the top of the sewer line. When it is impossible to obtain vertical or horizontal separation, the sewer line must be re-laid and constructed with ductile iron or copper with flare or mechanical compression fittings, and shall be pressure-tested to assure water tightness before backfilling unless otherwise approved by the water division; 
4.  Where service lines must cross over sewers, storm drains, or sanitary sewers, the service line must be laid at such an elevation that the bottom of the service line is at least eighteen (18) inches above the top of the sewer. This vertical separation must be maintained for that portion of the service line located within ten (10) feet horizontally of any sewer or sewer line that it crosses. Said ten (10) feet to be measured as the normal distance from the service line to the sewer unless otherwise approved by the water division; 
5.  Service lines shall have a cover of not less than four feet nor more than five feet, unless obstructions require deeper excavation for clearance; 
6.  No service line shall be less than three-quarter inches in diameter; 
7.  A backflow preventor valve is required on all irrigation systems or other lines constituting a cross connection to the public water supply in buildings already built and not disconnected. Cross connections are not allowed in any building being built or repaired, and must be removed, and building piping worked to specifications. (See Ordinance 5840) 
C.  All tap service lines shall conform to the following requirements: 
1.  All tap service piping shall conform to the latest American Public Works Association (APWA) specifications for type K flexible copper tubing or to the latest American Water Works Association (AWWA) specification C901 for high-density polyethylene (HDPE). HDPE service lines shall be a minimum of SIDR9 with a pressure rating of one hundred sixty (160) psi. 
2.  The connection of the tap service line to the corporation shall be by means of a flared fitting, or approved compression fitting; 
3.  The line shall be laid with an expansion loop located as near to the corporation stop as possible. This loop shall be in the form of a half S bend and be at least six inches of the centerline of the run; 
4.  No union shall be permitted between the corporation stop and the meter pit and meter pit to house or building where the distance is less than one hundred (100) feet. Where distance is greater than one hundred (100) feet, flared unions or approved compression fittings only shall be used; 
5.  No sweat joints will be permitted on any portion of the service line; 
6.  Each curb stop must be fitted with a curb box. Curb boxes shall be cast iron metal material five and one-quarter inch when in street, or parking lot or roadway, and shall be made in two sections that will permit an adjustment of not less than one foot in length so that the overall length can be varied from four to five feet. The lower section of the box shall have a minimum internal diameter of six inches; 
7.  Where meters are set indoors, the service line must enter the building not higher than four feet to center above the floor on which the meter is set; 
8.  Each tap service line shall fitted with a stop valve immediately on entering a building. Where the meter is already indoors an existing building, this valve may be part of the meter set. The stop valve shall be in accordance with current water division specifications; 
9.  Three-quarter inch and one inch K copper services do not require curb stop at the water supply main. Three-quarter inch and one inch services will have two meter valves in meter pit for commercial and factory. Existing meters located inside buildings may remain so until such a time that they are preferred outside by the building owner, the building is altered or changed, or major repair work is to be done on building or service. At this time, the meter will be moved outside, or service will be discontinued until specifications set forth in this chapter are met; 
10.  All services two inches and smaller shall be K copper or HDPE. HDPE service lines shall be colored blue and shall use #12 AWG Copperhead reinforced trace wire (blue in color). Stiffeners shall be used in the ends of the HDPE. All services greater than two inches shall be ductile pipe Class 52 or better. 
D.  All branch services shall conform to the following requirements: 
1.  Branch services two inches and smaller in diameter shall conform to the latest APWA specifications for type K flexible copper tubing. Branch service lines larger than two inches shall be cement lined ductile iron Class 52 or better and conform to the water division standards and specifications for water main extensions. Only flared or approved compression connections shall be permitted on copper branch service lines, and soil flux or silver soldier to be used only in meter pits unless otherwise approved by the water division; 
2.  Branch service lines shall be connected to the main with a tapping sleeve and valve or a tee and gate valve. Valves shall turn counter clockwise, or left to open, and shall be in accordance with APWA specifications; 
3.  The tapping valve or gate valve on branch service connections shall be fitted with a valve box that conforms to APWA specifications. Valve boxes shall also be fitted with a five and one-quarter inch valve box base where necessary; 
4.  All branch service lines shall be fitted with a stop valve immediately on entering a building. 
E.  A service line to supply domestic water may be connected to a branch service line used for fire protection only under the following conditions if approved by the public works department: 
1.  Connection shall be made in a location having the prior approval of the water division; 
2.  Service line for domestic water shall be considered either tap service piping or branch service piping and shall be subject to the provisions of Sections 13.04.040(B), (C) or (D), whichever governs; 
3.  The combination service lines shall be installed as specified by the water division. 
4.  Domestic service lines must have a backflow preventer or check valve in line according to North Kansas City backflow ordinance and be valved before and after all connection fittings according to APWA specifications. 
F.  Temporary service will be permitted only by written request to the public works department and subject to their approval. 
1.  A permit is required for temporary service and is valid for thirty (30) days only and, to be kept in force, must be renewed at the end of each thirty (30) day period; 
2.  Disconnection and abandonment of temporary services shall be in accordance with the rules herein set forth. 
G.  When a service pipe is installed for future use, the pipe shall be installed as far as the curb stop, and the curb stop plugged. An extension permit will be required to complete the service. 
H.  A multiple domestic service is a service having one connection to the main and branching on public property before entrance to a single building. Multiple domestic service piping must meet the following requirements: 
1.  The single building to be served shall be either a store room, a duplex, an apartment, or separately leased property; 
2.  Each shall require a permit; 
3.  Each branch shall have a separate curb stop; 
4.  Distances between branch services shall be a minimum of five feet; 
5.  Each branch shall have a separate meter; 
I.  The water division shall maintain residential service lines from the main to and including the meters. The owner shall maintain the service line after the house side of the meter and assure a safe, potable water supply and in a structural condition that will permit water division employees to perform normally assigned duties. Maintenance of meter tiles, pits, and service lines in residential areas shall be in accordance with APWA specifications. Repairs to any section of the service line shall be performed in an approved manner using approved materials. An insulating bushing shall be used when a new copper service line is connected to an existing service line other than copper. 
J.  Service lines must be disconnected at the main in the event of building demolition or alteration. Abandonment of services shall be performed under an extension permit in the following manner: 
1.  On tap service connections, the corporation stop shall be uncovered, the corporation stop turned off, the service line disconnected, and corporation stop capped off. Two feet of the service line must be cut off. All curb boxes and meter tiles, whether on public or private property, shall have all rings, covers, and lids removed, wall casings removed or broken down to a minimum of one foot below grade, and backfilled to grade; 
2.  On branch service connections, the abandonment shall be performed in a manner specified by the water division. 
K.  When a building is to be razed or moved, all unnecessary services to the premises shall be abandoned in accordance with the following: 
1.  A master plumber shall procure an extension permit for each service to be abandoned and shall perform all work necessary to abandon tap services; 
2.  The master plumber shall be responsible for the excavating and backfilling of all holes and repair of street cuts; 
3.  On tap services, the master plumber shall perform the work of disconnecting line from corporation cock and plug and cut two feet off line, abandonment of the curb box and of meter tile and lid. Inspection shall be made before backfilling; 
4.  When branch services are to be abandoned, the master plumber will be informed at the time of application for permit the manner in which the service is to be abandoned and the disposition of the meter pit. If the water division chooses to salvage the tapping valve, the operation of mains, and the disconnecting and plugging shall be performed by the water division at its own expense, and the plumber shall perform all other work the same as in abandonment of tap service. 
L.  When a building is to be altered, any service abandonment shall be the same as the abandonment for building demolition and all provisions stated herein are applied. All meters at this time will be moved outside with a new meter setting and pit. 
M.  When a plumber is required to repair services that have been disconnected or turned off at the corporation stop by the water division, he or she shall apply for and obtain an extension permit. A new service line, renewal permit and tap will be required. Street repair is the responsibility of the plumber. 
N.  Relocation and replacement of water service lines between the main and the meter tile shall be in accordance with these regulations. Residential, commercial, factory and industrial are used when it apples. The water division reserves the right to specify or determine one from the other when repairs, removals, replacements, relocations of service valves, meter pits, piping and fitting when and where it applies. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
(Ord. No. 8783, § 1, 11-4-2014) 
13.04.050 - Service taps. 
A.  Taps are classified as corporation taps or branch taps. 
1.  A corporation tap is the cutting of threads directly on the wall of the water main and the insertion of a corporation stop; 
2.  A branch tap is a connection to the main made by employing a tapping valve and sleeve or saddle. A tee and valve shall also be considered a branch service tap. 
B.  All taps shall be subject to the following requirements: 
1.  Tapping shall be performed only by the water division; 
2.  Taps shall be located within the property lines of the property to be served unless otherwise approved by the water division; 
3.  Taps shall be made on the side of the main nearest the premises to be served; 
4.  Responsibility for excavation, protection of excavation and backfilling shall rest on the master plumber named in the permit; 
5.  Excavations must be free of water and debris so that the tapper and inspector can perform their tasks without delay. Should the work be in such a condition as to necessitate an additional trip by the tapper or inspector, the master plumber shall be charged for such additional trips at the prevailing rate. All tap holes over four feet deep must be shored or trench jack to hold sides of trench up. Safety rules and regulations will be observed and maintained at all times. 
C.  Corporation taps shall be subject to the following requirements and made only by the water division personnel: 
1.  No corporation tap shall be larger than one inch in diameter; 
2.  Corporation taps shall be made so that the corporation stop is inserted at approximately forty-five (45) degrees on the top quadrant of the main; 
3.  If corporation taps cannot be made in accordance with subsection (C)(2) of this section because of obstructions or conditions that cannot be changed, the water division will determine how the tap is to be done; 
4.  Non-corrosive tapping saddles will be used on all one and one-half-inch services and two-inch services, and run in K copper with flare fittings or approved compression fittings or HDPE DR9 CTS (blue). Stiffeners must be used in the ends of HDPE with #12 AWG Copperhead reinforced trace wire (blue in color); 
5.  A corporation tap shall not be closer than three feet to a bell, spigot, valve or blow off; 
6.  Excavation shall be a minimum four feet by four feet at the surface and shall be four feet by four feet at the main. The main must be entirely uncovered. Tunneling to provide access for tap is not acceptable in most cases. 
D.  Branch taps shall be subject to the following requirements: 
1.  On all service piping larger than two inches, a branch tap shall be made; 
2.  Branch taps shall be made so that the tapping valve is horizontal to insure a vertical valve box over the tapping valve; 
3.  Branch taps shall not be made closer than eighteen (18) inches from the bell end of the pipe or three feet from the spigot end. The minimum distance between taps from face to face of sleeve shall be six feet; 
4.  The excavation for a branch tap shall extend seven feet from the face of the main, and the main shall have eighteen (18) inches of clearance all around, and tap holes or trench must be five feet wide. Safety rules will apply here as in general requirements for taps; 
5.  All branches taps four inches and larger shall be provided with backing blocks or otherwise restrained in a manner approved by the water division; 
6.  The tapping valve on each branch tap shall be provided with a hardwood block support, at least ten (10) inches square and two inches thick, placed on a center line with the valve stem. Supporting blocks are to have good bearing on undisturbed soil. The cost of repairing failures of tapping sleeves and valves found without supporting blocks shall be charged to the plumber under whose permit the subject work was done. 
E.  The plumber shall notify the water division in sufficient time to schedule his or her tap. When taps are desired before noon, the request must be received before ten a.m. two days prior to tap. When taps are desired in the afternoon, the request must be received before twelve noon two days prior to tap. 
F.  Tapping charges shall be in accordance with the price schedule specified in Section 13.04.140(B)(8) of this chapter. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
(Ord. No. 8783, § 2, 11-4-2014) 
13.04.060 - Meter sets. 
A.  Meter sets are classified by location into two categories; indoor meter sets that are already inside an existing building and meter sets to buildings that are being built or will be built in the future. 
B.  All meter sets shall conform to the following requirements: 
1.  All meters shall be in an approved non-hazardous place and accessibility shall be maintained at all times; 
2.  All meters shall be set in a horizontal position; 
3.  The size of a meter shall never be larger than the service line in which it is installed; 
4.  All meter sets for meters one and one-half inches and larger will require a sealed bypass valve, Oraseal or equal; 
5.  Meter sets for meters one and one-half inches and larger will require brass flanges on both sides of meter. Brass flanges shall be in accordance with water division specifications; 
6.  The master plumber shall furnish and install all pipe, fittings and valves necessary for the meter set in accordance with the appropriate specifications of the water division. 
C.  In existing buildings, all indoor meter sets for meters less than one and one-half inches shall conform to the following requirements unless otherwise approved by the water division: 
1.  No meter set shall be permitted left inside a building unless a floor drain is provided within twenty (20) feet of the meter; 
2.  Meters shall not be set higher than four feet to the center of connection above the floor; 
3.  Meters shall not be installed in recreation rooms, rest rooms, or utility rooms, nor be concealed and obstructed by items, cabinets, benches or other built-in fixtures; 
4.  Indoor meter sets shall be made as near as possible to the point where the service line enters the building; 
5.  An indoor meter set for meters three-quarters inch shall be installed with a meter yoke as required by the water division; 
6.  Meters shall not be re-installed in a place of business without the written permission of the water division. The procedure for requesting permission is stated herein under Section 13.04.060(G). 
D.  In existing buildings, meters one and one-half inches and larger shall conform to the following requirements and conditions: 
1.  Where large meters are indoors, written permission must be obtained from the water division. Procedure for requesting permission is stated herein under Sections 13.04.060(C) and (G) will apply here also; 
2.  A lifting ring or hook to accommodate a hoist shall be firmly affixed to the building by casting in concrete or welding to steel. This device shall be installed directly over the meter. This is applicable to meters weighting over sixty (60) pounds; 
3.  A clear access way to the meter shall be maintained at all times. The access way shall be large enough to accommodate an industrial truck; 
4.  Where the meter set is on a lower floor, an elevator or hoist well shall be available to permit transportation of the meter to the street level without negotiating a stairway. This is applicable to meters weighing over sixty (60) pounds; 
5.  The building must be equipped with a loading dock or driveway and water division vehicles shall be permitted access to these areas; 
6.  Meter set shall be made in such a locality that reading and changing of meter shall in no way interfere with the customer's normal course of business; 
7.  Customers shall furnish and allow the use of lifting tackle and industrial trucks for the changing and transporting of meters on the premises. Motorized equipment furnished by the customer shall be operated only by the customer's employees; 
8.  Meter sets, valves and piping shall be made for pit installations or as proposed by the applicant and approved by the water division. 
E.  All outdoor meter sets for meters one inch and smaller shall conform to the following requirements: 
1.  When meters are placed on private property, written permission must be obtained from the water division. Procedure for requesting permission is stated herein under Section 13.04.060(G); 
2.  When outdoor meters are placed on private property, they must be in a location near a driveway or turnout and be accessible to water division vehicles. Location of meter shall be such that water division personnel cannot damage lawns, shrubs, or other property nor interfere with the consumer's normal course of business, nor be a hazard to consumer's and department's personnel; 
3.  Meters shall be in an approved pit and in the arrangement as specified by the city water division; 
4.  Maintenance and testing of meters will be performed by the water division. All meter tiles and pits are the property of the owner and shall be maintained by same. 
F.  All outdoor meter sets for meters one and one-half inches and larger shall conform to the following requirements: 
1.  Meter sets may be placed on public or private property; 
2.  When meters are placed on private property, written permission must be obtained from the public works department. Procedure for requesting permission is stated herein under Section 13.04.060(G); 
3.  When outdoor meters are placed on private property, they must be in a location near a driveway or turnout and be accessible to water division vehicles. Location of meter shall be such that water division personnel cannot damage lawns, shrubs, or other property, not interfere with the consumer's normal course of business, nor be a hazard to consumer's and division's personnel; 
4.  Meters one and one-half inches and larger in size shall be provided with a by-pass connection with a sealed valve and set in a pit. Pit and materials for meter sets shall be as specified by the public works department; 
5.  Maintenance and testing of meters will be performed by the water division. Meter pits are the property of the owner and shall be maintained by same. 
G.  Where these regulations state that written permission for setting meters must be obtained from the public works department, requests for this permission are to be made in the following manner: 
1.  Requests shall be made by submittal of a letter from the owner of the property where the meter is to be set. This letter shall state that the owner is familiar with the requirements of Section 13.04.060(D) and (F), whichever applies, and that the owner and his or her tenants shall observe these regulations; 
2.  Each letter of request shall be accompanied by two prints of an architectural drawing, which show the meter locations, the details of the meter set, and any other information that is necessary to determine the acceptability of the meter set; 
3.  After review and acceptance of the technical provisions of the meter set, the applicant will be provided with an agreement form that he or she must sign and return before meter will be allowed to remain inside of existing buildings. 
H.  Factory, commercial and industrial meters five-eighths by three-quarters inch and larger are available for sale by the water division upon request. Meter price quotes will be given at that time. Customer may furnish their own meter provided they comply with water division specifications and they are tested by the water division before being placed in service. The cost of testing a customer-furnished meter shall be borne by the customer. 
1.  Meters will be pulled and tested for accuracy and repaired or rebuilt if necessary and reinstalled in line every ten (10) years or sooner if meter shows signs of deterioration. Cost will be borne by the customer for labor and material to complete overhaul. Customers may request a new meter at this time. If so, the cost of the new meter plus installation shall be borne by the person or persons making the request. Failure to permit meter testing or repair will result in the service being shut off after notification in writing by the public works department to the customer. 
I.  When meters are set for serving other water utilities, they shall conform to all requirements herein set forth, and in addition they shall include an approved backflow preventer installed on the consumer side of the meter. 
J.  The changing out of meters shall occur during normal working hours of the water division. In the event that this procedure inconveniences a customer, he or she may request that his or her meter be changed after normal working hours; however, he or she will be required to bear the cost of this service and to pay all overtime costs. 
K.  In existing buildings already built, where by-pass was not installed at that time and where a customer on a commercial rate desires a valved by-pass around an existing meter, they may request permission for a by-pass from the water division. Request shall be made in writing and shall clearly state the need for such a connection. If permission for the by-pass is granted, it must: 
1.  Be installed at the expense of the customer under an extension permit; 
2.  Be installed in accordance with the appropriate specifications of the water division. 
L.  Whenever it is necessary to exchange an existing meter for one of a different size, the written authorization shall be given by the water division. All cost shall be borne by the party making the request. 
M.  The relocation of meter tiles and pits shall be performed in accordance with Section 13.04.090(A). 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.070 - Inspections. 
A.  Inspections are required on all work performed under a public works department permit. 
B.  The entire work as described on each permit shall be subject to inspection. If the work is to be performed in phases, an inspection shall be required for each phase. 
C.  Inspections will be performed during normal working hours. When it is required that inspections be performed at times other than normal working hours, the plumber making the request will be charged for the direct cost of such inspection. 
D.  Plumbers shall make request for inspections to the public works department. Request for inspections will be disregarded and the inspection not made if a permit for the work has not been issued. 
E.  Service line excavations and trenches presented for inspection shall be free of water, debris, earth, and other matter that would hinder the inspector. Service lines shall be inspected under line pressure during the inspection. 
1.  Where a copper service line is laid in a trench, the trench shall be left open for its entire length and the entire length of service line exposed to view; 
2.  Where a cast iron service line is installed in a trench, it may be backfilled before inspection, except that all joints and fittings shall not be backfilled, but left exposed; 
3.  Where a service line is bored, the excavations required for boring shall be left open and the portion of service line in these excavations shall be exposed to view. 
F.  Fire protection and domestic services four inches and larger must be hydrostatically tested in accordance with APWA specifications. All inspections of this type shall be by prior approval and arrangement by the water division. All extraordinary expenses for this inspection and test shall be borne by the applicant requesting same. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.080 - Damage to the water system. 
A.  Plumbers engaged in repairing services are cautioned to exercise care to that portion of the service over which the water division has jurisdiction as herein set forth. Whenever the aforementioned section of the water service lines is damaged by a plumber so that it is necessary for the water division to make repairs, the plumber shall be held liable for the cost of such repair and permits shall be denied to him or her until such costs are paid. The plumber shall be held responsible under the following circumstances: 
1.  On all main to curb service lines, where it can be shown that the damage is caused by carelessness, neglect, improper use of tools or any practice not in accordance with the standards of the trades, or any practice in violation of public works department regulations; 
2.  On all copper main to curb service lines, if damage is caused by carelessness or neglect in the opinion of the water division; 
3.  On all main to curb service lines, where the water division employees must work on an overtime basis to repair the line. 
B.  Those plumbers who have a consistent record of breakage shall be deemed careless and therefore made subject to the aforementioned penalties. 
C.  Whenever a main to curb service becomes broken or damaged to the extent that it needs repair, the plumber is instructed to call the water division and inform the water division of this need. The plumber should clearly state that repairs can be performed during normal working hours or that they must be performed on an overtime basis. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.090 - Relocation of water facilities. 
    Factory and commerce requiring relocation of water service lines, curb boxes, meter tiles or pits shall have such relocations accomplished in the following manner: 
A.  On service lines that are all copper pipe, that portion of the service line from the main to the existing meter tile shall be, if required, relocated at the property owner's expense, and that portion from the existing meter pit to the building shall be relocated by the plumber under contract for same or by owner. 
B.  If the service line is copper from the main to the meter pit, the property owner will, if required, relocate this portion at its own expense; the galvanized portion from the meter pit to house shall be replaced and relocated by the plumber under contract or by owner. All galvanized piping, whether on public or private property, requiring relocation shall be replaced with copper in accordance with these regulations. 
C.  On service lines that are galvanized from the main to the building and require relocation, the property owner at its expense will relocate and replace that portion of the service line from the main to the proposed relocation of the building meter pit. On service lines that have meter pits, the property owner will renew service to meter pits. Piping on the building side of the meter pit requiring relocation shall be relocated and replaced with copper by the plumber under contract for same or by owner; 
D.  All residential meter pits shall be relocated on public property if possible. Meter pits for larger meter installations shall be relocated as directed by the public works department. Undamaged meter tiles, pits, rings, covers and lids, curb boxes, curb stops and meter sets may be reused by the water division. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.100 - Sprinkler systems. 
A.  Sprinkler service line size shall be designed by an engineer to determine the proper sizes in all cases from the city main connection into the building it is to serve. 
B.  No sprinkler service line can be extended from one building to another unless the buildings are attached and extended out. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.110 - Water line locates. 
A.  The water division will dispense information pertinent to the location of water mains and services in accordance with its records. This is a public service, and the water division will not honor any claims for damage sustained by the recipient of such information. 
B.  The plumber shall immediately notify the water division of any discrepancies discovered in water division records, drawings, leak investigations, water main or service line locations. The water division will promptly investigate reported discrepancies, reporting the findings to the plumber or agent affected. The water division will not give favorable consideration to additional expense by the plumber or agent due to discrepancies not reported immediately to the water division for investigation. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.120 - Extensions, water mains and appurtenances to water works system. 
A.  The department of public works is authorized to formulate, adopt and enforce rules and regulations providing for the extensions, water mains and appurtenances to the existing system of the city. 
B.  The rules and regulations authorized by the preceding section shall provide that if funds are not available to pay the cost of the extension, or if the revenue from the proposed extension will not result in a sufficient return to repay the cost of such extension within ten (10) years, then the original cost of such water main extensions and appurtenances shall be paid for by funds advanced by those requesting such service, and for the repayment, in whole or in part, of such costs only out of the earnings derived from the income received from the users of water and service along such extensions. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.130 - Lead banned from drinking water plumbing. 
A.  No water service connection to the public drinking water system shall be installed or maintained to any premises where lead-based materials were used in new construction or modification of the drinking water plumbing after January 1, 1989. 
B.  Should any premises be found to be in violation of subsection A of this section, water service shall be discontinued until such time that the drinking water plumbing is in compliance with this article. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004)

For residential customers the deposit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). For business, commercial and industrial customers, the deposit shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).

Volume charges shall not apply to flat rate services that have been properly established with the water and sewer department.

6.  Termination and Reinstatement Charges. When termination of water service has been ordered by the department for any cause, the customer shall be charged the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to cover costs of arranging such termination during regular business hours. In instances where the service is actually terminated and later reinstated, the customer shall be charged an additional fifteen dollars ($15.00) to cover costs of reinstating the service during regular business hours. The fee for reinstatement of water services when performed on weekends, holidays, or after regular business hours is fifty dollars ($50.00).

13.04.150 - Commercial and industrial water accounts with diverted water use. 
A.  Commercial and industrial water accounts are all water service accounts other than one and two family dwellings. Diverted water uses are those where a significant portion of the water purchased is used in manufactured products such as ice, canned goods or beverages and the product is transported in containers away from the premises, or where the water purchased is lost by evaporation or irrigation. 
B.  Where the water user of the premises proves this fact by installation of a meter or other approved method of determining the amount of water so diverted, or has made an estimate of the amount of water so diverted, or has made an estimate of the amount of water so diverted that is acceptable to the city, no sewage service charge shall be levied on such diverted water. 
C.  The director of the public works, or his or her designee, shall make this determination of fact, and shall have authority to adjust the sewer use volume billed on the basis of the facts ascertained. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.160 - Unmetered connections. 
A.  The city is authorized and directed to charge and collect such rates as are fixed and established by this section for water service and water furnished through unmetered connections to customers which are as follows: 
    For unmetered connections, fire suppression systems and other unmetered connections:

C.  There shall be a charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each hydrant flow test. 
(Ord. 8127 § 1, 2006) 
(Ord. No. 8668, § 2, 2-5-2013) 
13.04.170 - Authority to change rates, charges and regulations. 
    The city council retains continuing jurisdiction and authority to change from time to time the schedules of rates and charges and the regulations provided in this chapter as such changes shall be determined expedient and necessary. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.180 - Rendering and payment of bills-Delinquent accounts. 
A.  All water bills shall be paid at city hall. Bills shall include a charge for the period in which the premises were connected to the water system without regard to whether the premises were occupied or unoccupied during all or part of the billing period. All water bills rendered in accordance with the regular schedule of meter rates and flat rates are due and payable when rendered and shall be deemed delinquent if not paid on or before twenty (20) days thereafter. 
B.  A delinquency and termination notice shall be issued twenty (20) days after a bill is delinquent. The delinquency and termination notice shall provide the customer of record with the following information: 
1.  The amount due on the unpaid balance plus penalty; 
2.  Notice that service will be terminated in ten (10) days if the bill remains unpaid. 
C.  The department is authorized to discontinue and disconnect water service for any customer who is delinquent in the payment of bills. Customers are responsible for furnishing the department with their correct addresses for billing purposes. 
D.  Water services shall be deemed to be furnished to both the owner and occupant of the property receiving such service. Any delinquent charges incurred by the occupant, if not the landowner, shall be chargeable against any deposit held by the city for services of such property. 
E.  Delinquent charges shall be a lien upon the property so charged for such services, upon the filing of a notice of delinquency with the Clay County recorder of deeds. The lien hereby created, may be enforced by suit or foreclosure. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.190 - Tampering with, damaging, or removing meters prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to open, interfere with, injure, deface or in any way impair the working of any water meter. It is also unlawful for any person, other than a duly authorized representative of the water division, to remove any meter from its setting. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.200 - Testing of meters. 
A.  The water division shall have the right at anytime to test meters. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.210 - Access to meters required. 
A.  Property owners are responsible for allowing free and non-hazardous access to the meter for reading, removal, inspection or replacement. The city and any representative of the division are hereby authorized to shut off the meter at any location, without notice, where such access to the meter is denied. If division representatives are unable to shut off water because the meter is inaccessible, the property owner shall be in violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter, and will be subject to penalties as set forth in Section 13.04.310 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.220 - Adjustment of charges when meter found to be measuring inaccurately. 
A.  Whenever the department shall find a meter not measuring accurately according to standards of the American Water Works Association, an adjustment of charges for the preceding billing period shall be made by averaging the water used for the corresponding billing period of the past twelve (12) months or if such records are not existent, from the best other method practicable. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.230 - Private service line leaks. 
A.  Water leaks in private water service lines are declared to be a public nuisance that must be repaired according to the terms of this section. It is unlawful for any water customer and/or occupant of private property to fail to repair a service line leak upon proper notice to do so. 
B.  Upon discovery of a leak in a private water service line, the public works department shall serve a notice to repair the leak within seven days of the date on the notice. Such notice shall be served upon the water customer or occupant personally or by registered mail. Failure to repair the leak within seven days as directed will result in the disconnection of water service. Service shall not be reconnected until the leak is repaired and a disconnect/reconnect fee has been paid. 
C.  The public works department has the right to disconnect water service without notice if a leak has been discovered. 
D.  If the water is flowing beyond the private property line in such a way that hazard to public safety exists or a water emergency has been declared, a notice of disconnection shall be left at the property. In addition, a notice of repair shall be given. Service shall not be reconnected until the leak has been repaired. However, no disconnect/reconnect fee will be charged for disconnection pursuant to this subsection. 
E.  Failure to repair a water leak in a private water service line as required herein shall not be a criminal violation of the city code. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.240 - When water service may be shut off without notice. 
    Water service may be shut off to any consumer by the public works department without notice if such consumer shall tamper or in any way interfere with any meter, connections, service pipes, valves or other appurtenances belonging to the city or for any violation by a consumer of the terms of this chapter or any other applicable ordinances of the city or of the statutes of the state. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.250 - City not liable for necessary interruptions of service. 
    In instances where the public health, safety or welfare so requires, the public works department shall have the right to shut off the flow of water in its mains without notice, but will endeavor, insofar as possible, to notify consumers affected of the intention to so interrupt the service. Interruption of service under such conditions shall not give rise to any claim on the part of any consumer against the public works department or the city. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.260 - City not liable for failure to maintain specific water pressure. 
    The public works department does not guarantee to maintain any specific water pressure for its service, and no complaint concerning the pressure shall give any right of claim against the city or the public works department. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.270 - Use of water without permission unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use water from any part of the waterworks system of the city without proper permit or other authority. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.280 - Only authorized persons permitted to shut off or turn on city water. 
    It is unlawful for any person, other than an authorized representative of the public works department or of the fire department of the city to shut off or turn on water from any part of the city's waterworks system, including fire hydrants; provided however, that nothing in this section contained shall be construed as prohibiting master plumbers, duly licensed under this code or other ordinance of the city, from turning on or shutting off water service if such is necessary in the course of the work in which they are engaged. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.290 - Authority to refuse service when contamination may result. 
    The public works department may refuse to deliver water to any premises whereon any condition exists which might lead to the contamination of the public water supply and may continue to refuse such delivery of water to any such premises until such condition is remedied. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.300 - Title to mains vested in city. 
    The full title, ownership and right of exclusive possession to all mains installed upon city right-of-way shall be vested in the city through its public works department. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
13.04.310 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person violating the provisions of Sections 13.04.190, 13.04.210, 13.04.260, 13.04.270, 13.04.280 or any other provisions set forth in this chapter shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined in a sum of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
13.04.320 - Promulgation and interpretation of rules and regulations. 
A.  The city administrator is authorized to promulgate such rules and regulations as shall be reasonably necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter according to its terms and intent. 
B.  The public works department will be the sole interpreter of these rules and regulations. Questions of interpretation shall be submitted to the public works department. 
(Ord. 7913 § 1 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 13.08 - SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Sections: 
Article I. - In General 

13.08.010 - Prohibited deposits. 
    No person shall deposit or throw, or cause to be thrown or deposited, into any sewer, sewer inlet or manhole, any animal or vegetable substance or any hay, straw, ashes, cinders, sticks, shavings, trash, soot, oyster shells, cans, rubbish, broken ware, rags, pieces of iron or other metal or old wearing apparel, or any other article or thing whatever that is liable to cause the sewer to choke up or otherwise obstruct the free flow of water therein. 
(Ord. 7153 § 1 (part), 1999: prior code § 25-1) 
13.08.020 - Sewer charges. 
A.  There are levied charges against every person, firm, partnership, corporation, association and legal entity of any kind occupying property with the city limits having a sewer connection with, having sewers available for connection with, or otherwise discharging sewage, industrial waste, water, or other liquid into the city's sewer system. Such charges are to be the sum of charges based on volume (commodity charge), and base charge (cost of services) to be levied in accordance with the rates set forth in Sections (B)1 and (B)2. 
B.  As set forth in the tables below in subparagraph 1 and 2 hereof, sewer rates shall increase effective January 1, 2019, for the year 2019.

13.08.030 - Payment of sewer charges. 
    All bills for the services furnished by the city's sewage treatment plant and system shall become due and payable within five days from and after the date of rendering such bill and if not paid within twenty (20) days after such date of rendering, such bill shall be considered delinquent, and an additional charge of five percent shall be made on the gross amount of the billing. Notification by mail shall be given to the person, and such five percent delinquency charge shall be paid within ten (10) days or water service to the property shall be disconnected and a ten dollar ($10.00) disconnection charge shall be assessed. Water service shall remain disconnected until such person pays the full amount of all sewer bills, including delinquency charges, such disconnection charge, together with a reconnection charge in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) in addition, sewer service to the property may be disconnected and a fifty dollar ($50.00) disconnection charge may be assessed. 
(Ord. 7153 § 1 (part), 1999: prior code § 25-3) 
13.08.040 - Appeals. 
    In the event that any particular property owner who is legally liable for the payment of the charges imposed under this article, disagrees with, or is aggrieved by, any determination, decision, order, or notice of any kind which is made rendered, issued or given under the provisions of this chapter, such property owner, within twenty (20) days after notice of any such determination, decision, order or notice has been given to, or mailed to, such property owner, shall have the right to take such action as may be necessary or proper to bring the matter in dispute before the director for review by him or her. If such matter of dispute cannot be mutually agreed upon, then upon reasonable notice in accordance with its rules and the provisions of this code the mayor and city council shall make the final determination when necessary as to whether or not the determination, decision, order, nor notice which is the subject of review is proper or correct. The mayor and city council, by a majority vote thereof, shall have the power and authority to reverse or affirm, wholly, or partly, or may modify the determination, decision, order or notice appealed from, and may give or make such determination decision, order, requirement or notice as ought to be made; provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be taken or construed as authorizing the mayor and city council to waive, set aside or in any manner change any specific provision or provisions of this article. 
(Ord. 7153 § 1 (part), 1999: prior code § 25-4) 
13.08.050 - Measurement of water use when water not supplied by city. 
    If an occupant of property discharging sewage, industrial waste, water or other liquids into the city sewerage system is not a user of water supplied by the water department of the city, then such occupant, at his or her own expense, shall install a meter or other measuring device acceptable to the director of the water department for the purpose of measuring water used. Should the occupant fail to install such meter or measuring device, then the director shall compute the amount of water used and such computation shall be the basis of the sanitary sewer service charge. Access to such meter or other measuring device as may be installed shall be given to the water pollution control department employees for the purpose of reading, inspecting, testing or repair of such meter or other measuring device at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. 7153 § 1 (part), 1999: prior code § 25-5) 
Article II. - Sewer, Drain and Culvert Construction and Connection 

13.08.060 - Connecting building sewers and other private drains to public sewer. 
A.  After first obtaining a permit for connection from the public works department, the actual connection of any building sewer or other private drain to a city sewer shall be inspected by a pollution control department inspector. 
B.  The director is authorized to adopt regulations governing the methods of connecting to a public sewer, the pollution control department may be requested to make a connection at the applicant's expense when the plumber or resident homeowner does not have the proper tapping machine. 
C.  The director is authorized to establish inspection and tapping fees, and to adjust such fees from time to time as necessary to reflect costs to the pollution control department for rendering such services. 
(Ord. 7153 § 1 (part), 1999: prior code § 25-31) 
Article III. - Commercial and Industrial Waste. 
Division 1. - General Provisions 

13.08.070 - Purpose and policy. 
A.  This article sets forth requirements for discharge of commercial and industrial wastes to the sewer system of the city. The objectives of this article are: 
1.  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the sewer system that will interfere with the operation of the sewer system or wastewater treatment facilities or damage the infrastructure or equipment; 
2.  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the sewer system which will pass through the city's wastewater treatment facilities into receiving waters without adequate treatment or otherwise be incompatible with the sewer system and treatment works; 
3.  To ensure that the quality of the city's wastewater sludge is maintained at a level which allows its use and disposal in compliance with applicable statutes and regulations; 
4.  To protect city personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and to protect the general public; 
5.  To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge from the city's wastewater treatment facilities; 
6.  To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of operation, maintenance and improvement of the city's sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities; 
7.  To enable the city to comply with NPDES permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements and any other federal, state or local statutes or regulations laws to which the city is subject; 
8.  To establish the responsibilities and duties of the users of the sewer system; and 
9.  To established the authority of the city to enforce the provisions of this article and to enable the city to assess penalties if these provisions are not met. 
B.  Notwithstanding any other pretreatment provisions to the contrary, nothing contained in this article or elsewhere in the city's pretreatment program shall be deemed to be a legally binding commitment under the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. Section 1251 et seq., the Missouri Clean Water Law, RSMo. Sections 644.006 et seq., and applicable regulations (40 CFR Part 403, 10 CSR 20-6.100) for the city to undertake pretreatment implementation or enforcement activities beyond the minimum requirements of said statutes and regulations. Nevertheless, the city maintains its discretionary authority to undertake pretreatment activities beyond the minimum required by said statutes and regulations. 
(Ord. 7153 § 1 (part), 1999: prior code § 25-71) 
13.08.080 - Definitions and rules of construction. 
A.  Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    "Act" means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. 
    Authorized Representative of an Industrial User. 
1.  If the industrial user is a corporation, "authorized representative" means the president, secretary, treasurer or a vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs policy or decision-making functions for the corporation. 
2.  If the industrial user is a partnership or sole proprietorship, "authorized representative" means a general partner or proprietor, respectively. 
3.  If the industrial user is a federal, state or local governmental facility, "authorized representative" means a director or the highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the governmental facility, or his or her designee. 
4.  The individuals described in paragraphs 1 through 3 of this definition may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is submitted in writing to the director and the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or who has overall responsibility for environmental matters for the industrial user. 
    "Batch" means a quantity of wastewater, physically separated from all other quantities of wastewater for the purpose of treatment and/or discharge. 
    "Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of matter under standard laboratory conditions in five days at twenty (20) degrees Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    "Building Drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, water, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the city sewer or other place of disposal. 
    "Categorical pretreatment standard" or "categorical standard" means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by EPA in accordance with Sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act which apply to a specific category of Industrial Users and which appear in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405-471. 
    "Chemical oxygen demand (COD)" means a measure of the oxygen-consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in water or wastewater. It is expressed as the amount of oxygen consumed by a chemical oxidant in a specified test. It does not differentiate between stable and unstable organic matter and thus does not necessarily correlate with biochemical oxygen demand (BOD). 
    "City" means the city of North Kansas City, Missouri. 
    "City sewer" means a sewer owned or controlled by the city. 
    "Code of Federal Regulations (CFR)" means regulations as issued by the United States Government. References to sections of CFR shall be in accordance with the latest revisions unless specifically stated otherwise. 
    "Code of State Regulations (CSR)" means regulations as issued by the Missouri State Government. References to sections of CSR shall be in accordance with the latest revisions unless specifically stated otherwise. 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and wastewater. 
    "Combined wastestream formula" means a method defined in 40 CFR 403.6(e) to derive alternative discharge limits. Such alternative discharge limits may apply where process effluent regulated by any categorical pretreatment standard is mixed prior to treatment with wastewater other than those generated by the regulated process. 
    "Commercial or industrial wastes" means the waterborne wastes from commercial and/or industrial establishments as distinct from sanitary wastewater. This shall include any discharge to the POTW through an interconnection pursuant to an interjurisdictional agreement. 
    "Commercial user" means industrial user. 
    "Composite sample" means a sample resulting from the combination of individual wastewater samples taken at selected intervals based on an increment of either flow or time. 
    "Cooling water" means the water discharged from any use such as air-conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    "Daily maximum" means the maximum flow rate or maximum average concentration of a particular pollutant, which may be discharged in a day. 
    "Day" means a period of normal operation not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours. 
    "Department" means the public works department of North Kansas City, Missouri. 
    "Director" means the director of the public works department of the city, or his or her authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    "Discharge" means material directly or indirectly released to the POTW; or the act of releasing material directly or indirectly to the POTW. 
    "Effluent" means the "end of process" liquid wastes from an industrial process which ultimately are discharged. 
    "Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)" means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    "Garbage" means solid food wastes from the preparation, cooking and disposing of food, together with incidental admixtures, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    "Grab sample" means a sample which is taken on a one-time basis without regard to the flow rate of the sampled stream and without consideration of time. 
    "Groundwater" means water within the earth. 
    "Hazardous waste" means any material, regardless of amount, which would be defined as a hazardous waste under 40 CFR Part 261 or 10 CSR 25 if it were not discharged to the POTW. 
    "Industrial user" means any person discharging commercial, industrial wastes or industrial wastewater. 
    "Industrial wastewater" means all water-carried solid, liquid or gaseous wastes or a combination thereof resulting from any process of industry, manufacturing, trade or business or from the development or recovery of any natural resource. 
    "Instantaneous maximum allowable discharge limit" means the maximum concentration of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any item, independent of the discharge rate and duration of the discharge rate and duration of the sampling event. 
    "Interference" means inhibition or disruption of the POTW, its treatment processes or operations, or its sludge processes, use or disposal which results in violation (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation) of the city's NPDES permit or prevents wastewater sludge use or disposal in compliance with any federal, state or local law, regulation or permit. 
    "Medical waste" means isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood byproducts, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, fomites, etiologic agents, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis waste or any other materials or items commonly used or associated with medical care. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or ground water. 
    "New source" means: 
1.  Any building, structure, facility, or installation from which there is (or may by) a discharge or pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility, or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; or 
b.  The building, structure, facility, or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing sources; or 
c.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility, or installation are substantially independent of an existing sources at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should be considered. 
2.  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility, or installation meeting the criteria of subsection (1)(b) or (1)(c) of this definition but otherwise alters, places, or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
3.  Construction of a new source as defined under this definition has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous onsite construction program: 
i.  Any placement, assembly or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
ii.  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, or design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this paragraph. 
    "Nonresidential contributor" means any contributor to or user of the system whose lot, parcel of real estate or building is served by a water meter larger than three-fourths inch. 
    "Normal sewage" means wastewater which contains not over two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter (mg/l) of suspended solids, not over two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter (mg/l) of biochemical oxygen demand and which does not contain any of the materials or substances listed in Section 13.08.160 in excess of allowable amounts specified in said section. 
    "NPDES permit" means the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit issued by the Missouri Department of Natural Resources or RPA. 
    "Oil and grease" means any material recovered as a substance soluble in an organic extracting solvent as specified by Standard Method 5520 of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," 18th Edition, 1992, or the latest revision thereto. Oil and grease is composed primarily of fatty matter from animal and vegetable sources and from hydrocarbons of petroleum origin. The concentration of oil and grease of petroleum hydrocarbon origin can be determined using Standard Method 5520F. The concentration of oil and grease of animal and vegetable origin is defined as the difference between the total and the petroleum hydrocarbon oil and grease concentrations. 
    "pH" means a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a substance, expressed in standard units. 
    "Pass through" means a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation, caused by a discharge or combination of discharges. 
    "Person" means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns.
