Section 307.4.3 is amended to read as follows: 
Portable outdoor fireplaces . Portable outdoor fireplaces may be permitted in approved, non-combustible commercially built containers including chimineas, fire pits, fireplace operated according to manufacturer's instructions. Measuring no more than 3 feet in diameter and 3 feet tall, raised at least 6 inches off the ground with non-combustible legs and having a non-combustible spark arrester screen with holes no larger than 1/4 inch. The ground beneath this container shall be clear of combustible material for 15 feet in diameter, and 15 feet away from combustible construction. The material being burned shall be natural wood only, and shall not include pressure treated lumber, pallets, scrap wood, tree trimmings, leaves, yard waste, paper, cardboard, garbage and similar items. A pre-connected garden hose shall be accessible.

Sky Lanterns. The lighting of Sky Lanterns is prohibited within the boundary of the City of North Kansas City.

Incinerators . Incinerators shall not be allowed within the boundaries of the City of North Kansas City. 
Exception: When the purpose for the incinerator is only for the cremation of human bodies, incinerators are allowed when the City Council has approved a conditional use permit for a crematorium and are in compliance with all other code requirements. 
Section 5604.1 is amended to read as follows: 
General . Storage of explosives and explosive materials, small arms ammunition. small arms primers, propellant-actuated cartridges and smokeless propellants in magazines, shall comply with provisions of this section.

Section 5704.2.9.6.1 is amended to read as follows: 
Locations where above-ground tanks are prohibited. The storage of flammable or combustible liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings, with a capacity of more than one thousand (1,000) gallons, is prohibited within the boundaries of the City of North Kansas City. 
Section 5706.2.4.4 is amended to read as follows: 
Locations where above-ground tanks are prohibited. The storage of liquefied petroleum gas in a stationary storage tank with water capacity of more than five hundred (500) gallons is prohibited within the boundaries of the City of North Kansas City. 
(Ord. No. 8754, § 1 (Exh. A), 5-20-2014) 
Chapter 15.36 - ELEVATOR CODE 
Sections: 

15.36.010 - Adopted. 
    The Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators, ASME A17-1993 and the Safety Code for Existing Elevators and Escalators, ASME A17.3-1993, including amendments through A17.1b-1995 and A17.3b-1995, respectively, as heretofore read, adopted and amended by the city are adopted as if set out at length in this code. 
(Prior code § 6-150) 
15.36.020 - Inspections required. 
    All buildings or structures having an elevator, wheelchair lift, stairway chairlift, escalator, moving walk, or dumbwaiter, as defined in the Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators, ASME A17.1-1993 and the Safety Code for Existing Elevators and Escalators, ASME A17.3-1993, including amendments through A17.1b-1995 and A17.3b-1995, respectively, shall provide to the public works director a certification that the elevator, wheelchair lift, stairway chairlift, escalator, moving walk, or dumbwaiter has been inspected and complies with all requirements of the safety code. The inspection shall be the responsibility of the building owner or tenant and shall be conducted by a company or individual normally involved in the inspection, construction, or installation, of equipment covered by this section. Inspections shall be conducted on an annual basis and required certifications shall be provided no later than September first of any calendar year. 
(Prior code § 6-151) 
15.36.030 - Filing fee required. 
    An elevator inspection filing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be included with each annual certification provided. 
(Prior code § 6-152) 
Chapter 15.40 - FENCES 
Sections: 

15.40.010 - Permit required-Fee. 
    No person shall erect or construct, or cause to be erected or constructed, any fence within the city without having been issued a permit by the public works department prior to such erection of construction. If the fence is constructed by a contractor, the permit may be issued in his name; however, nothing herein shall relieve the person hiring the contractor of the obligation to ascertain that a permit has been issued prior to construction. The permit fee for construction of a fence shall be determined using the fee schedule utilized for building permits. 
(Prior code § 6-160) 
15.40.020 - Application and issuance of permit. 
    Application for a fence permit, accompanied by the permit fee set forth above, shall be made to the public works department and the public works department shall review and issue or deny such permit. If the application is approved, the public works department shall issue a permit. The application shall consist of two copies of the site plan containing the following information: 
A.  Names, addresses and telephone numbers of the property owner and fence contractor; 
B.  Address and legal description of the project site; 
C.  Statement of materials to be used; 
D.  Diagram showing: 
1.  Property lines and dimensions of the project site, 
2.  Proposed location of fencing, length of fence lines, height of each section of the fencing, and location of materials used if materials differ from section to section. 
(Prior code § 6-161) 
15.40.030 - Regulations. 
    The following regulations shall apply to fences constructed within North Kansas City: 
A.  No fence shall exceed eight feet in height in any industrial zoning district, and no fence shall exceed seven feet in height in any other zoning district, except as may be further specified in this chapter. 
B.  No fence shall be electrified. 
C.  All fencing shall be maintained in good condition. Fencing that is not properly maintained and falls into disrepair may be determined to be a public nuisance and be cause for removal by the property owner or the city per public nuisance procedures. 
D.  The use of razor or similar wire fencing materials is prohibited. 
E.  Barb wire fencing is prohibited in all zoning districts with the exception of zoning districts M-1 and M-2, provided that any strand of barb wire is a minimum of six feet above the adjacent ground. 
F.  No fence, hedge or wall shall be erected or located in such a manner as to obstruct or hinder traffic flow on streets, alleys or driveways in the vicinity of the property upon which it is located. 
G.  No fence, hedge, or walled enclosure greater than three feet in height may be constructed within the area designated for a front setback by the zoning ordinance adopted by the city or through the subdivision platting process. Such fencing shall not be within twenty-four (24) inches of any driveway nor within twelve (12) inches of any public right-of-way. 
H.  If the rear lot line of a corner lot abuts a side property line of a lot facing the side street, no fence, hedge or walled enclosure greater than four feet in height may be constructed within the area designated for a side setback. 
I.  No fence, hedge, or walled enclosure greater than three feet in height shall be constructed within the sight triangle formed from the corner of a right-of-way intersection in each direction for a distance of thirty (30) feet. 
J.  No fence, hedge, or walled enclosure greater than three feet in height shall be constructed within the sight triangle formed from the corner of the intersection with an alley a distance of ten (10) feet in each direction. 
K.  The diagrams below depict additional regulations that specifically apply to corner lots and lots bordering alleys. 
1.  Figure 1 depicts permitted fence locations (for fences greater than three feet but not exceeding seven feet in height) on residential corner lots that are back to back with neither building fronting on the side street. 
2.  Figure 2 depicts permitted fence locations (for fences greater than three feet but not exceeding seven feet in height) on corner lots where the rear lot line of the corner lot borders a lot on which a building faces the side street. 
3.  Figure 3 depicts permitted fence locations (for fences greater than three feet but not exceeding seven feet in height) on a corner lot where the rear lot line borders an alley right-of-way and neither building faces the side street. 
4.  Figure 4 depicts permitted fence locations (for fences greater than three feet but not exceeding seven feet in height) on a corner lot where the rear lot line borders an alley right-of-way and a building faces the side street. 


L.  The following additional requirements shall specifically apply to fences located within North Kansas City: 
1.  All fencing materials shall be architecturally compatible with the neighborhood or other areas in which they are erected. The following materials are generally acceptable: 
a.  Chain link (prohibited in frontyards and in the C-2 zoning district); 
b.  Split rail; 
c.  Wood (fabricated primarily as fencing material); 
d.  Vegetation/hedges; 
e.  Masonry brick, or cinder block; 
f.  Ornamental iron. 
2.  Materials not primarily designed for fencing or materials not listed above shall not be permitted in residential or commercial zones unless approved through the minor exception procedure set forth below. 
3.  Fences already existing within the city shall, for the purposes of this chapter, be considered as "grandfathered," but subject to maintenance requirements. Proposed changes to the fence either by way of repair, extension or replacement is subject to this chapter. 
(Prior code § 6-162) 
(Ord. No. 8420, § 1, 8-25-2009) 
15.40.040 - Exceptions. 
A.  Minor exceptions to these requirements may be considered by the board of zoning adjustment if the applicant submits written consent from all adjacent property owners. The following are defined as minor exceptions: 
1.  The use of other fencing materials not listed as permitted; 
2.  The construction of fences that exceed the height limitations in commercial and manufacturing zones if the proposed fence is to be used for screening or security purposes. 
B.  Other exceptions to these regulations may be considered by the board of zoning adjustment and city council. Approval may be obtained upon a showing that the proposed fence will not create traffic problems for the general public or any neighboring property owner and will not be architecturally incompatible with the neighborhood or other area where erected. 
(Prior code § 6-163) 
Chapter 15.44 - SIGNS, BILLBOARDS, AWNINGS AND STREET CLOCKS[11] 
Sections: 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8603, § 2, adopted Feb. 7, 2012, repealed former Ch. 15.44, §§ 15.44.010-15.44.750, and enacted a new chapter as set out herein. The former chapter pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code §§ 26-1-26-9, 26-11-26-13, 26-31, 26-32, 26-46-26-53, 26-71, 26-74, 26-97, 26-104, 26-116-26-119, 26-131-26-137, 26-151-26-153, 26-166-26-170, 26-181-26-186, 26-191, 26-192, 26-201-26-206, 26-221-26-226; Ord. No. 7793, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 8006, §§ 1-4, 6, 2005; Ord. No. 8181, §§ 1, 3, 4, 2006; Ord. No. 8592, §§ 1-4, 11-15-2011. 

Article I. - In General 

15.44.010 - Purposes. 
    The purposes of this chapter are to: 
A.  Preserve the unique character of the city, and the distinct areas and districts within the city. 
B.  Enhance the visual quality of the community reflected in the visual priority of buildings, open spaces, streetscapes and landscape. 
C.  Ensure safety of pedestrians, motorists or other users of the public rights-of-way and open spaces. 
D.  Promote economic viability by assuring that the city will be a visually pleasant place to visit, conduct business, and live. 
E.  Provide effective and efficient identification and communication for businesses. 
F.  Protect property values by minimizing adverse effects of signs on adjacent property. 
G.  Promote the civic beauty of the community and protect public investments in rights of way and open spaces by limiting the impact of sign clutter on business and community interests. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.020 - Definitions. 
    The following terms shall have the meaning given in this section. All other words and phrases shall have the meaning given by common usage and which best achieves the purposes of this chapter, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. Where a term is not defined and common usage results in a dispute or multiple interpretations, the Code Official may reference the most recent version of Harvey S. Moskowitz and Carl G. Lindbloom, The New Illustrated Book of Development Definitions (Center for Urban Policy Research, Rutgers, and the State University of New Jersey). 
    Awnings and Canopies. An "awning" shall include any structure made of cloth or metal with a metal frame attached to a building and projecting over a thoroughfare, when the same is so erected as to permit its being raised to a position first against the building when not in use. A "canopy" shall include any structure, other than an awning, made of cloth or metal with metal frames attached to a building, projecting over a thoroughfare, and carried by a frame supported by the ground or sidewalk. 
    "Code official" means the city official appointed by the council or city administrator as the head of the enforcement agency, and his or her designees through the administration of that agency. 
    "Development sign" means a free-standing sign identifying an entrance to a development district or area containing a mixture of residential and commercial uses. 
    "Enforcement agency" means the codes division. 
    "Erect" means to build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend or affix, and shall also include the painting of wall signs. 
    "Facing surface" means the surface of the sign upon, against, or through which the message is displayed or illustrated on the sign. 
    "Flag" means a sign made of fabric or other non-rigid material with no enclosing framework containing distinctive colors, patterns, symbols or other heraldic devices used as identification or symbols for national, state, municipal, corporate, or other institutional representation, and affixed to a permanent pole or structure in a manner that allows regular and periodic removal and replacement. 
    "Freeway" means a multiple lane divided highway with fully controlled access, as by cloverleafs for intersecting roads. 
    "Frontage, building" means the linear distance of the building facade that is oriented towards and most paralleled to a public street, excluding the distances caused by any off-sets in the facade. Buildings on corner lots may count each street facing facade for the purposes of measuring building frontage. 
    "Frontage, lot" means the linear distance of a lot measured along the public right-of-way towards which the lot is oriented. Corner lots may count each public street frontage for the purposes of measuring lot frontage. 
    "Highway" means a main public road or thoroughfare other than, or in combination with, a city street, road, avenue or boulevard, i.e., Missouri Highway 1 (Vernon Street). 
    "Iconic display" means a free-standing or wall sign of greater than one thousand (1,000) square feet. 
    "Illuminated sign" means any sign lighted by or exposed to artificial lighting either by lights on or in the sign, or directed toward the sign. 
    "Incidental sign" means a minor sign that is customarily associated with the use of a lot or building, incidental to the function or operation and not primarily aimed at drawing attention to specific activities or business related to the premises. 
    "Incombustible material" means any material which will not ignite at or below a temperature of one thousand two hundred (1,200) degrees Fahrenheit and will not continue to burn or glow at that temperature. 
    "Institutions" means a nonprofit group or organization. 
    "Mobile sign" means a sign designed to be movable from one location to another and not permanently attached to the ground or to any immobile structure. Such sign may consist of a mobile structure such as a semitrailer, carriage, trailer, van, sled or other device in a manner such that the purpose during a specific time it is immobile is to serve as a sign. This definition excludes permitted pedestrian or temporary signs which are otherwise moveable. 
    "Nonprofit" means such groups, agencies or individuals who have received a nonprofit designation from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). 
    "Sign" means any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display illustration or insignia, or other identification, that is visible from any public place or is located on private property and exposed to the public and that directs attention to a product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business or solicitation, including structures that exist to support or enhance the sign. 
    "Street clocks" means any time or temperature device erected upon a freestanding standard or attached on the extension of any building or structure for the convenience of the public and placed and maintained by some person for the purpose of advertising their place of business. 
    "Temporary sign" means a sign that is not permanent both in terms of its duration of display and in the manner of construction, which allows easy removal of the sign. Examples include banners, posters, yard signs, and other similar signs. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012; Ord. No. 8656, §§ 1, 2, 11-20-2012; Ord. No. 9034, § 1, 10-3-2017) 
15.44.030 - Sign categories and types. 
    The following sign types are distinguished for the purposes of the sign allowances in this chapter. Where any particular sign application involves a sign type that does not clearly fall within any single category, or could fall within more than one category, the code official shall interpret the particular application based on the most similar sign type, with consideration given to the purposes of this chapter. 
TABLE 15-1: SIGN TYPES TYPE DESCRIPTION Wall Sign A sign painted, printed or attached to the exterior surface of a building, awning, canopy or other fixed surface in a permanent manner with a scale and design legible to vehicles in the roadway or pedestrians at a distance from the building. Window Sign A sign hanging in, painted on, or otherwise affixed on a window in a permanent manner with messages visible from the outside of the building but designed and located in a manner that permits views through the window to the interior of the building. Roof Signs Any sign mounted or extending above the cornice line of a flat roof building, or above the eave of any pitched roof building, with a scale and design legible to vehicles in the roadway or pedestrians at a distance from the building. Ground Signs Any sign that is mounted to the ground independent from any building with a scale and design legible to vehicles in the roadway or pedestrians at a distance from the building or site. Free-standing signs encompass two specific sign types:   Monument Sign: A type of free-standing sign where the entire bottom of the sign is mounted on the ground or ornamental surface structure, and where the surface area of the structure does not exceed fifty (50) percent of the sign area of the sign mounted upon it.   Pole Sign: A type of free-standing sign constructed on one or more columns, poles or similar structures so the bottom edge of the sign surface is elevated above the ground. Reader Board/Drive-through A sign designed in conjunction with drive-in services to give information relative to the business where it is located, and which information may change frequently. Pedestrian Signs A sign with a design and scale to be legible to pedestrians in front of or immediately adjacent to the building or site or to be legible to individuals internal to a site. Pedestrian signs may be located in a permanent manner on the valance of awnings, hanging below a canopy or awning, projecting from a wall, mounted on a wall or window, or free-standing. Directional Sign A sign aimed at communicating messages to vehicles entering a site, or internal to a site. Off-Premise Commercial Sign A sign or sign structure with a commercial message for an establishment, merchandise, service, or entertainment which is not located, sold, produced, manufactured or furnished at the location on which the sign is located. Person Sign A temporary sign held by or attached to a person. Portable Reader Board A freestanding sign secured to a portable base or frame, designed to be legible to pedestrians.  
Figure 15-1: Sign Types 

(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012; Ord. No. 8935, § 1, 8-16-2016) 
15.44.040 - Interpretation of dimensional standards. 
    The following shall be used in interpreting dimensional standards in this chapter for signs: 
A.  General Area Calculation. Signs mounted on a standard geometric shape, such as a triangle, circle, or rectangle, shall be measured by the standard mathematical formula for that shape. Signs mounted on an irregular shape shall be measured by the smallest area of a collection of standard geometric shapes (circle, triangle or rectangle) that can encompass the entire area of the irregular shape. No more than three geometric shapes may be used. (See Figure 15-2.) 
Figure 15-2: Standard sign measurements and measurements of signs mounted on irregular shapes. 

B.  Free-Standing Signs. The area of the free-standing or other ground-mounted signs shall be computed by the entire area of the face of the structure, cabinet or module enclosed by the border of the frame. 
C.  Wall or Window Signs. The area of wall, window or other building-mounted signs shall be computed by means of the smallest continuous perimeter figure which encloses the outer limits of the writing, emblem or other display, using no more than three standard geometric shapes. Gaps in writing, emblems or other display which are more than two times the width of the tallest element of the sign area, and which do not otherwise alter the surface upon which the sign is mounted, may be subtracted from the calculation of the sign area. Where these gaps are excluded from the sign area, each area shall be interpreted as a separate sign for the purpose of any sign quantity limitations. (See Figure 15-3.) 
Figure 15-3: Where the gap in portions of the sign is larger than two (2) times the height, it shall be counted as two (2) separate signs for any sign quantity limitations that may apply. 

D.  Decorative Elements. Decorative embellishments such as pole covers, supporting framework, roofing and support structures which are included to enhance the aesthetics and improve the architectural compatibility of the sign with the site and building may be excluded from the area calculation if they contain no writing, emblem or other display. 
E.  Double-Faced Signs. In computing area of a double-faced sign, the area of the largest side shall be considered the total area of the sign. However, if any interior angle formed by the faces of the multi-faced sign, or other volume of the sign structure results in any portion of the sign faces being separated by more than three feet, then all sides of the sign shall be considered in calculating the sign area. (See Figure 15-4.) 
Figure 15-4: When the opposite faces or any portion of a sign is separated by less than three feet, it is considered one sign and only the area of one sign face is counted towards the total area. When that separation is more than three feet, each sign face shall count towards the area. 

F.  Height. Sign height is measured from the lowest point of the ground directly below the sign to the highest point on the sign or sign structure. 
G.  3-Dimensional Signs. 3-dimensional sign area is measured as the profile of the object using the formula in subsection A times the depth using the rule in subsection E that each three feet of depth constitutes a new sign face with the area of the profile. For example, a 3-dimensional sign with a profile area of A and a depth of eight feet would have a total sign area of 3 × A. 
Figure 15-5: 3-D signs are measured by using the area formula for a profile of the object and then multiplying it by one for each three-foot increment of depth for the object. 

(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.050-15.44.199 - Reserved. 
Article II. - Sign Districts and Allowances 

15.44.200 - Generally. 
    Sign allowances on individual sites in the city are established by sign districts. Each site in the sign districts identified below shall have the sign allowance given. Additional standards in other sections of this chapter can limit the quantity, size, amount, design, application or location of specific sign types on a specific property. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.210 - Armour Road District. 
TABLE 15-2: ARMOUR ROAD DISTRICT SIGN ALLOWANCES District Boundaries An area 200' on each side of the center line of Armour Road commencing at the intersection of Armour Road and Howell Street and extending east along Armour Road to the intersection of Armour Road and Interstate 35, and an area extending 200' north of the center line of Armour Road commencing at the intersection of Armour Road and Interstate 35 and extending east along Armour Road to the intersection of Armour Road and Vernon Street.  
TABLE 15-2: ARMOUR ROAD DISTRICT SIGN ALLOWANCES Sign Type Allowance Wall Signs Each building shall have a total wall sign allowance of 10% of the wall area, per wall. Each building may have up to 3 wall signs per wall. Or, buildings with multiple tenants occupying individual units with separate entrances may have 1 wall sign per tenant space, provided the sign is located on the individual unit space. No sign shall be more than 150 square feet. Each sign shall be at least 20' from another sign. Wall signs shall be no higher than 30'. Any wall sign projecting more than 12? from the wall shall be limited to no more than 100 square feet. The area for a projecting sign shall count towards the total wall sign area allowance at a rate of 1.5 times that actual area of the projecting sign. Projecting wall signs shall not extend more than 8' from the wall and shall maintain at least 10' clear area above the ground. Window Signs Each building may have window signs on all first-story windows. Window signs shall not exceed more than 20% of the first-story window area. Any window signs on upper stories shall count towards the area requirement for wall signs, but may be in addition to the quantity limit. Upper story window signs shall not exceed more than 15% of the window area. Roof Signs Prohibited Ground Signs Each lot may have a total ground sign allowance of 100 square feet, plus 1 square foot for each linear foot of lot frontage on a public street above 50'. Corner lots may count only 1 frontage, but may use the longest frontage. Each lot may have 1 ground sign per acre, plus 1 additional ground sign for each increment of an acre above 1 acre. No single ground sign shall exceed 250 square feet. Ground signs shall be separated by a minimum of 35', including signs on adjacent property. Pole signs shall be no higher than 30', but must have a minimum clear area of 12' for the lowest edge of the sign. Monument signs shall be no higher than 6'. Reader Board No more than 2 reader board signs may be erected at each drive-in service location. Sign area shall not exceed more than 32 square feet per sign. The sign area of each reader board sign may be 100 percent digital. Digital reader boards signs shall comply with all other requirements of Section 15.44.300.D. No sign shall be more than 7 feet high. Free-standing reader board signs shall be set back at least 20 feet from any property line. Reader board signs mounted on a building shall follow any applicable building setback. Pedestrian Signs Each lot shall be allowed 1 pedestrian sign for each primary building entrance, and 1 pedestrian sign per each 30' of linear building frontage. No single pedestrian sign shall exceed 8 square feet. Any pedestrian sign hanging above a pedestrian walkway, such as signs affixed to awnings or canopies, shall maintain at least 7' clear area from the walkway. Directional Signs Each lot shall be allowed 1 directional sign for each lot entrance. No single directional sign shall exceed 6 square feet. Off-Premise Commercial Signs Prohibited  
(Ord. No. 8656, § 7, 11-20-2012; Ord. No. 8807, § 1, 3-3-2015; Ord. No. 9034, § 2, 10-3-2017; Ord. No. 9158, § 1, 1-2-2019)

The top of such signs shall not extend more than 30' above the adjacent highway grade. For those portions of the manufacturing district that are adjacent to and abutting the Broadway Extension, no off-site signs shall be permitted. For all other portions of the manufacturing district, off-site signs shall be permitted: provided that: 1. 750 s.f. max. 2. 30' height limit from the closest adjacent street grade.

TABLE 15-8: REDEVELOPMENT AREA DISTRICT SIGN ALLOWANCES District Boundaries All that area lying south of Armour Road, east of Interstate 35, north of 16th Avenue, and west of the Chicago, Quincy, and Burlington Railroad right-of-way.  
TABLE 15-8: REDEVELOPMENT AREA DISTRICT SIGN ALLOWANCES Sign Type Allowances Wall Signs Each building shall have a total wall sign allowance of 25% of the wall area, per wall. Each building may have up to 3 wall signs per wall. Buildings with multiple tenants occupying individual units with separate entrances may have 1 wall sign per tenant space. No sign shall be more than 175 square feet in area. No wall signs or any portion of a wall sign may extend above the roof of the building. Any wall sign projecting more than 12" from the wall shall be limited to no more than 100 square feet. The area for a projecting sign shall count towards the total wall sign area allowance at a rate of 1.5 times that actual area of the projecting sign. Projecting wall signs shall not extend more than 8' from the wall and shall maintain at least 10' clear area above the ground. Window Signs Window signs shall not exceed more than 20 percent of total first-story window area. Window signs on upper stories shall count towards the area requirement for wall signs but may be in addition to the quantity limit. Upper story window signs shall not exceed more than 15 percent of the total upper story window area. Roof Signs Prohibited Ground Signs Each lot may have a total ground sign allowance of 100 square feet, plus 1 square foot for each linear foot of lot frontage on a public street above 50'. Corner lots may count only 1 frontage, but may use the longest frontage. Each lot may have 1 ground sign per acre, plus 1 additional ground sign for each increment of an acre above 1 acre. No single ground sign shall exceed 100 square feet. Ground signs shall be separated by a minimum of 35', including signs on adjacent property. No ground sign may be taller than 8 feet in height. The base of the sign shall be a maximum of 12 inches above the surrounding grade. The width of the top of the sign shall be no more than 120 percent of the width of the base. Reader Board No more than 2 reader board signs may be erected at each drive-in service location. Sign area shall not exceed more than 32 square feet per sign. The sign area of each reader board sign may be 100 percent digital. Digital reader boards signs shall comply with all other requirements of Section 15.44.300.D. No sign shall be more than 7 feet high. Free-standing reader board signs shall be set back at least 20 feet from any property line. Reader board signs mounted on a building shall follow any applicable building setback. Pedestrian Signs Each lot shall be allowed 1 pedestrian sign for each primary building entrance and 1 pedestrian sign per each 50 feet of linear building frontage. No single pedestrian sign shall exceed 8 square feet. Any pedestrian sign hanging above a pedestrian walkway, such as signs affixed to awnings or canopies, shall maintain at least 7 feet clear area from the walkway. Directional Signs Each lot shall be allowed up to 2 directional signs for each lot entrance. Directional sign area shall be limited to 12 square feet cumulative per entrance (e.g., 2 @ 6 s.f. or 1 @ 12 s.f.). Off-Premise Commercial Signs In those portions of the Redevelopment Area District that abut Interstate 35, Highway M-210 or streets intersecting Highway M-210, off-premise commercial signs shall be permitted, provided that such signs meet the following requirements: 1. There shall be no more than 1 such sign structure abutting Interstate 35 and no more than 1 such sign abutting M-210 or intersecting streets. 2. Any sign abutting Interstate 35 shall not exceed 800 square feet in area. Any sign abutting Highway M-210 or intersecting streets shall not exceed 100 square feet in area. 3. The top of such signs shall not extend more than 30 feet above the adjacent highway grade. Development Signs Lots abutting an intersection of two or more public streets may have one development sign. Such signs are permitted in addition to any other permitted ground signs. No development sign shall exceed 100 square feet. Development signs shall be separated from all other ground signs by a minimum of 35', including signs on adjacent property. No development sign may be taller than eight feet in height. Development signs may include identification of off-premise businesses or establishments, provided that such businesses or establishments are located within the Redevelopment Area. Iconic Display Each lot may have no more than one iconic display. May be approved through a Conditional Use Permit pursuant to the procedural requirements of Section 17.96.020 of the Zoning Ordinance.  
(Ord. No. 9034, § 3, 10-3-2017; Ord. No. 9158, § 6, 1-2-2019) 
15.44.260 - Residential District. 
    The Residential District is all of the area zoned for residential uses by the provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city, except such areas as are included in any other sign district as defined in this chapter. No signs shall be permitted in the Residential District except by the exemptions provided in Section 15.44.280. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012; Ord. No. 8813, § 2, 3-17-2015) 
15.44.270 - PUD District. 
    Signage shall be governed according to the uses designated on the approved sketch plan, and shall comply with the most applicable underlying sign district based on uses within sections of the PUD. Deviations from the most applicable underlying sign district may be approved through the PUD process. Further, an applicant proposing deviations from the most applicable sign district shall demonstrate that the deviation is: 
A.  The minimum deviation necessary to promote the interest of the PUD district; 
B.  Is consistent with the overall design and planning standards for the PUD district; 
C.  Results in an equal or lesser impact on adjacent property, nearby neighborhoods, and public streetscape; 
D.  Promotes a unique identity for the PUD district in a way that cannot be accomplished by the standards of the most applicable underlying sign district; and 
E.  Furthers the purposes of the city's PUD ordinance in a way that cannot be accomplished under the standards for the most applicable underlying sign district. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.280 - Exemptions. 
    The following specific signs are exempt from the permit process and allowed in addition to any signs included in the sign allowance for each sign district within the limitations described below. 
A.  Address Signs. One per address up to two square feet. Address signs on buildings shall be between four feet and nine feet high. Ground-mounted address signs shall be no more than three and one-half feet high. 
B.  Building Name Plate. Each building may have one name plate sign up to three square feet, except that a name plate sign integrated into the architecture, such as a stone, engraved plate or other substantial theme associated with the permanence of the building may be up to twenty-four (24) square feet. 
C.  Flags. The following signs are allowed and exempt from permits: 
1.  Residential Sign District. Flags up to forty (40) square feet and mounted on a building by a removable pole and mounting system, or mounted on a permanent, free-standing pole not to exceed thirty (30) feet high. 
2.  All Other Sign Districts. Flags up to ninety-six (96) square feet and mounted on a building by a removable pole and mounting system, or mounted on a permanent, freestanding pole not to exceed thirty (30) feet high. For lots with more than one acre, one flag may be up to two hundred sixteen (216) square feet. 
3.  American flags shall not be subject to the size limits in subsections 1 and 2 to be eligible for exemption. 
4.  Any other flag exceeding this exemption shall require a sign permit within the allowances for a temporary or permanent sign. 
D.  Institutional Signs. Any institutional use that is otherwise permitted in the residential sign district may be allowed signs subject to the following: 
1.  One monument sign per street frontage limited to forty (40) square feet maximum and four feet high. 
2.  One wall sign per street-facing facade limited to thirty (30) square feet. 
3.  Illumination and digital signs in the residential sign district are limited according to the standards in Section 15.44.300(C) and (D). 
4.  Applicants shall submit drawings and specifications to the city to demonstrate compliance with this exemption. 
    Any institutional uses in other sign districts shall have signs permitted according to the standards of that sign district. 
E.  Bicycle Sharing Facilities. Where bicycle sharing facilities are located in accordance with a valid operating agreement with the City of North Kansas City, signs on facilities and bicycles shall be allowed pursuant to the approved operating agreement. Signs located on bicycle sharing facilities shall not be illuminated and shall not include any flashing, moving, digital, or electronic changeable copy features. 
(F)-(G)  Reserved. 
H.  Incidental Signs-Nonresidential. The following signs are allowed without limitation as to quantity and exempt from permits in the Armour, General Business, Downtown, Manufacturing and South Burlington Sign Districts, for incidental signs, such as those identifying hours of operation, public announcements, warnings, hazards or other notice on private property, provided: 
1.  Incidental signs shall not exceed three square feet. 
2.  Any incidental signs beyond the above exemptions shall require a permit and be within the applicable allowance for permitted signs in each sign district. 
I.  Incidental Signs-Residential. Each lot shall be permitted up to three incidental signs, such as those identifying a warning, hazard or other notice on private property provided no sign exceeds two square feet. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012; Ord. No. 8656, §§ 3-6, 11-20-2012; Ord. No. 8935, § 3, 8-16-2016; Ord. No. 8992, § 1, 6-6-2017) 
15.44.290 - Temporary signs. 
    Temporary signs may be erected and maintained in accordance with the standards of this section. 
A.  Temporary Signs-Nonresidential Sign Districts. 
1.  Signs Exempt from Permits. All lots in a nonresidential sign district shall be allowed up to two temporary signs not requiring the issuance of a temporary sign permit, subject to the following standards: 
a.  Exempt temporary signs shall not exceed twenty-four (24) square feet in sign area. Any lot with over one hundred fifty (150) feet of frontage on a public street may have one of the exempt temporary signs up to forty-eight (48) square feet. 
b.  Exempt temporary signs that are ground mounted shall be no greater than six feet in height. Exempt temporary signs that are affixed to a building shall be no higher than thirty (30) feet. Temporary signs displayed in a window shall not cover more than forty (40) percent of any window, inclusive of all signs displayed in the window. 
2.  Signs Requiring a Permit. In addition to temporary signs that are exempt from the issuance of a temporary sign permit, all lots in a nonresidential sign district may erect or display additional temporary signs subject to the standards of this subsection. Such signs shall not be erected or displayed without first obtaining a temporary sign permit in accordance with Section 15.44.530 and shall meet the following standards: 
a.  Temporary signs shall not exceed sixty-four (64) feet in sign area and shall not weigh more than fifty (50) pounds. 
b.  Temporary signs that are ground mounted shall be no greater than six feet in height. Temporary signs that are affixed to a building shall be no higher than thirty (30) feet. Temporary signs displayed in a window shall not cover more than forty (40) percent of any window, inclusive of all signs displayed in the window. 
c.  Person signs shall require a temporary sign permit. Sign area of person signs shall include only the area of the sign held by or attached to the person. Person signs shall not obstruct sidewalks or enter the public right-of-way. Person signs shall not use any type of lighting, bullhorns, or amplified sound. No more than one person sign shall be permitted per lot at any one time. 
d.  Temporary signs shall not extend over or into any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public thoroughfare without a short term conditional use permit issued by the city council. 
e.  Each lot in a nonresidential sign district shall be issued no more than three temporary sign permits per year. Each temporary sign permit shall be valid for no more than thirty (30) calendar days each. At the expiration of each permit, the permit holder shall immediately remove the temporary sign. 
B.  Temporary Signs-Downtown Sign District. In addition to the temporary signs allowed pursuant to the provisions of Section 15.44.290(A), one portable reader board sign per occupational license is allowed in the Downtown Sign District subject to the following standards: 
1.  The sign shall consist of non-illuminated chalkboards or similar type devices mounted on tripods, easels, or pedestals. 
2.  The sign shall not exceed twelve (12) square feet in area and four feet in height. 
3.  The sign may be located on a sidewalk, provided at least six feet of clear area exists for pedestrians in all directions around the sign. The sign shall comply with all other standards contained in Section 15.44.300. 
4.  The sign shall be located no further than twenty-five (25) feet from the principal entrance of the business, shall remain only during daylight hours, and be removed from the premises daily. 
C.  Temporary Signs-Residential Sign Districts. 
1.  Signs Exempt from Permits. All lots in a residential sign district shall be allowed up to three temporary signs not requiring the issuance of a temporary sign permit, subject to the following standards: 
a.  Exempt temporary signs shall not exceed eight square feet in sign area. 
b.  Exempt temporary signs that are ground mounted shall be no greater than four feet in height. Exempt temporary signs that are affixed to a building shall be no higher than thirty (30) feet. 
2.  Signs Requiring a Permit. In addition to temporary signs that are exempt from the issuance of a temporary sign permit, all lots in a residential sign district may erect additional temporary signs subject to the standards of this subsection. Such signs shall not be erected without first obtaining a temporary sign permit in accordance with Section 15.44.530(C) and shall meet the following standards: 
a.  Temporary signs shall not exceed fifty (50) feet in sign area and shall not weigh more than fifty (50) pounds. 
b.  Temporary signs that are ground mounted shall be no greater than six feet in height. Temporary signs that are affixed to a building shall be no higher than thirty (30) feet. 
c.  Temporary signs shall not extend over or into any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public thoroughfare without a short term conditional use permit issued by the city council. 
d.  Each lot in a residential sign district shall be issued no more than three temporary sign permits per year. Each temporary sign permit shall be valid for no more than thirty (30) calendar days each. At the expiration of each permit, the permit holder shall immediately remove the temporary sign. 
D.  Standards Pertaining to All Temporary Signs. 
1.  Temporary signs shall not be erected over any wall openings, or in any manner that could prevent free ingress to or egress from doors, windows, fire escapes, and shall not be attached to any stand pipe or fire escape. 
2.  All temporary signs attached or secured to a wall with wire, steel cables, or other materials shall be safe and suitable as determined by the enforcement agency. 
3.  Temporary signs may not be roof-mounted. 
4.  Temporary signs shall not be used for off-premise commercial signs. 
5.  Any temporary sign that is in disrepair due to damage, deterioration, or other condition that detracts from the message or purpose of the sign shall be removed. 
(Ord. No. 8935, § 4, 8-16-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8935, § 4, adopted Aug. 16, 2016, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
15.44.300 - Standards applicable to all signs. 
    The following standards are applicable to all signs in addition to the sign allowance requirements of each sign district. 
A.  General Health, Safety and Welfare Standards. All signs shall be located, designed, constructed, and maintained in a manner that meets all applicable building codes or other public health and safety standards. In addition, no person shall display upon any sign or other advertising structure any obscene, indecent or immoral matter. 
B.  Traffic Safety. 
1.  No sign or associated structure shall be erected at the intersections of any street in such a manner as to obstruct free and clear vision as determined by the codes official considering the type of intersection or access, the control of traffic movements, the topography or other natural features, and the speed of on-coming traffic. 
2.  No sign or associated structure shall be erected where, by reason of the position, shape or color, it may interfere with, obstruct the view of or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device. 
3.  No signs may be illuminated in a manner that interferes with (including glaring or blinding), misleads or confuses traffic. 
4.  No sign may be erected using words and symbols that mimic traffic control symbols, emergency vehicle lights or otherwise interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
C.  Illumination. 
1.  Any illumination shall be designed to eliminate negative impacts on surrounding rights-of-way and properties. The light from an illuminated sign shall not create a negative impact on residential uses in direct line-of-sight to the sign. 
2.  External light sources shall be directed and shielded to limit direct illumination of any object other than the sign. 
3.  Signs permitted in residential districts shall not be illuminated, except for signs permitted for institutional uses such as schools of churches. 
4.  Illumination of signs not exceed 20.0 footcandles when measured at the sign surface. Illumination of any sign on lots abutting residential property shall not exceed 0.5 footcandles measured at the residential property boundary. 
5.  Except as otherwise specifically permitted for digital signs in subsection (D), flashing, blinking, oscillating, scintillating, rotating or intermittent turning on and off of any illuminating device is prohibited. 
D.  Digital Signs. 
1.  Digital signs are allowed in all sign districts except the residential sign district. In residential sign districts, digital signs are only allowed for permitted institutional uses (i.e., church or school). 
2.  No lot may have more than one digital sign in addition to any digital reader board signs. 
3.  Digital signs shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the total sign area allowance for the selected sign type (i.e., twenty-five (25) percent of the total allowance for wall signs, or ground signs), with the exception of off-premise signs in the manufacturing sign district, that may allocate up to six hundred seventy-two (672) square feet for digital signs, and reader board signs. 
4.  Sign messages shall remain static for at least eight seconds and take no longer than two seconds to change to a new display. 
5.  Signs shall not include: 
a.  Audio messages, tones or music. 
b.  Display animated messages, including flashing, blinking, fading, scrolling, shading, dissolving, or any other effect that gives the appearance of movement. 
c.  Exception. Any digital sign less than twelve (12) square feet may be used for single color scrolling messages. 
6.  Brightness. Signs shall utilize automatic dimming technology to adjust the brightness of the sign relative to ambient light so that at no time shall a sign exceed a brightness level of three-tenths footcandle above ambient light, as measured using a footcandle (lux) meter. An ambient light measurement shall be taken using a footcandle meter at some point between the period of time between thirty (30) minutes past sunset and thirty (30) minutes before sunrise with the sign turned off to a black screen. An operating sign light measurement shall be taken with the sign turned on to full white copy. The difference between the ambient light measurement and the operating sign light measurement is three-tenths footcandle or less. 
7.  Default Mechanism. Signs shall contain a default mechanism that will cause the sign to turn off or display a black screen if the sign malfunctions. 
E.  Limitations on Public Property. No sign shall be erected on or above any public property except: 
1.  A sign erected by a public officer or public employee in the performance of a public duty. 
2.  Where a building is authorized to be built at or near a right-of-way line, projecting wall signs or pedestrian signs permitted according to standards of a specific sign district may be placed on building appurtenances that extend over the right-of-way. Examples include signs mounted to canopies, awnings, marquees or signs projecting from a building built to the property line. 
3.  A portable reader board subject to the limitations in the exempt signs section. 
F.  Mobile Signs Prohibited. Mobile signs are prohibited in all districts due to the instability and other potential hazards to the public. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012; Ord. No. 8656, § 12, 11-20-2012; Ord. No. 9158, § 7, 1-2-2019) 
Article III. - Awnings and Canopies 

15.44.310 - Materials required for construction. 
A.  Awnings shall be constructed of a fire resistant material or metal; provided, however, all frames and supports shall be of metal. 
B.  Canopies shall be constructed of fire resistant material or metal hood; provided, however, all frames and supports shall be of metal. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.320 - Height above sidewalk-Proximity to curb line. 
A.  All awnings shall be constructed and erected so that the lowest portion thereof shall be not less than eight feet above the level of the sidewalk or public thoroughfare. 
B.  All canopies shall be constructed and erected so that the lowest portion thereof shall be not less than nine feet above the level of the sidewalk or public thoroughfare. 
C.  No awning or canopy shall be permitted to extend beyond a point two feet inside the curb line. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.330 - Width limitations. 
    No limitation on width of awnings; provided, however, full compliance with Section 15.44.300(A) is required. No canopy shall be permitted to exceed eight feet in width. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.340 - Support-Attachment to buildings. 
A.  Every awning shall be securely attached to and supported by the building. Posts or columns beyond the building line shall not be permitted for awnings. No awning shall be attached to the wood jambs, frames or other wood members of a building (frame buildings accepted) when such building is less than ten (10) feet from public property. 
B.  The framework of all canopies shall be designed by a structural engineer and approved by the building inspector as in compliance with the building code or other laws of the city. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.350 - Advertising. 
    No advertising shall be placed on any awning or canopy, except that the name of the owner and business, industry or pursuit conducted within the premises may be painted in a space not exceeding eight inches in height on the front and side portions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.360 - Permits and inspection. 
    Permits for awnings and canopies shall be required as provided in Article V of this chapter. Awnings and canopies shall be subject to annual inspection as required in Article III of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.370-15.44.400 - Reserved. 
Article IV. - Street Clocks 

15.44.410 - Construction generally-Materials required. 
A.  All street clocks as defined in this chapter shall be constructed of incombustible material, including the frames, braces and supports thereof. 
B.  The dial of all street clocks shall be not less than thirty (30) inches nor more than forty (40) inches in diameter. 
C.  Any glass forming a part of a clock or the sign thereon shall be safety glass or plate glass at least one-fourth inch thick and in case any single piece or pane of glass has an area exceeding three square feet, it shall be constructed of wired glass, securely held in place. 
D.  Any movable part of a street clock, that is, cover or service opening shall be securely fastened by metal hinges. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.420 - Location. 
A.  Clocks supported on the corner of any building or structure at the intersection of two streets, shall not be less than fifteen (15) nor more than twenty (20) feet above ground surface, and shall not project from the face or wall of the building or structure, in any direction, more than five feet. 
B.  Every clock erected shall be supported upon a post of ornamental design, the total height of which shall be not less than fifteen (15) feet. 
C.  No street clock shall project over public property. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.430 - Erection on exterior of buildings or other structures. 
A.  All clocks erected on the exterior of any building or structure shall comply with the applicable requirements set forth in Section 15.44.280 regulating signs in all respects concerning erection. 
B.  All street clocks erected on exterior walls shall comply with the building codes pertaining to wind pressure and dead load requirements. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.440 - Erection limited to one clock for each place of business. 
    No person shall be permitted to erect more than one street clock as defined in this chapter for any place of business, at any one location. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.450 - Advertising. 
    Only the name of the owner, proprietor or manager of the place of business erecting and maintaining such clock shall be permitted as advertising matter on such clock. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.460 - Clocks to keep accurate time. 
    Every street clock shall keep accurate time, and if this condition is not complied with, the clock shall be promptly repaired or removed. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.470-15.44.500 - Reserved. 
Article V. - Administration and Enforcement 

15.44.510 - Existing signs, removal and abandonment. 
A.  Every sign or other advertising structure lawfully in existence on March 13, 1979, shall not be repaired, altered or moved unless it is made to comply with the provisions of this chapter. Furthermore no alteration of existing signs or advertising structures shall be undertaken without the issuance of a permit. No fee will be charged for the permit, so long as such alterations do not substantially alter the basic design or concept of the sign. The application for said permit shall be completed in sufficient detail for the enforcement agency to review the desired changes and determine whether such changes are appropriate under this chapter. 
B.  All signs, billboards or other advertising structures, lettered or pictorial material which do not conform to the provisions of this chapter but which were constructed in compliance with previous regulations are declared nonconforming and shall comply with provisions of this chapter in the manner and in accordance with the provisions of this section: 
1.  For the purpose of this section, a nonconforming sign shall be such a sign which does not conform to the provisions or which does not comply with the zoning ordinance. 
2.  Should any nonconforming sign be damaged by any means to an extent of more than fifty (50) percent of its replacement cost at the time of damage, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
C.  Any sign including the structural framing now or hereafter existing which no longer advertises a bona fide business conducted, or a product sold, shall be taken down and removed by the owner, agent or person having the beneficial use of the building or structure upon which such sign may be found within ten (10) days after written notification from the enforcement agency, and, upon failure to comply with such notice within the time specified in such order, the enforcement agency is hereby authorized to cause removal of such sign, and any expense incident thereto shall be paid by the owner of the building or structure to which such sign is attached. 
D.  If the enforcement agency shall find that any sign or other advertising structure is unsafe or insecure, or is a menace to the public, or has been constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter, it shall give written notice to the permittee or property owner. If the permittee or owner fails to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the standards of this chapter within ten (10) days after such notice, such sign or other advertising structure may be removed or altered to comply by the enforcement agency at the expense of the permittee or owner of the property. The enforcement agency shall refuse to approve a permit to any permittee or owner who refuses to pay costs so assessed. The enforcement agency may cause any sign or other advertising structure which is an immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily and without notice. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.520 - Maintenance. 
A.  All signs within the city shall be maintained in a safe condition and in such a manner that they shall not become a visual detriment to the community at large. The designated official shall be charged with the responsibility and authority to inspect all signs within the city and direct the maintenance of said signs. Maintenance of signs is defined as keeping sign structures in a safe condition, free of rust, with broken glass or plastic replaced, electrical lights and other electrical operations in operable condition, letters and other sign components in the equivalent condition as on the sign permit or as approved. 
B.  All such signs and the premises surrounding the same shall be maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish and weeds. 
C.  The owner of any sign as defined and regulated by this chapter shall be required to have properly painted at least once every two years all parts and supports of the sign, unless the same are galvanized or otherwise treated to prevent rust. 
D.  Should the enforcement agency find a non-maintained sign as defined above, it shall cause the owner of said sign to be notified as to the deficiency and the corrective action that needs to be taken. 
E.  Should the owner fail to exhibit satisfactory evidence of compliance within thirty (30) days after the mailing of the letter of notification, the enforcement agency shall cause the owner to be cited for violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.530 - Permits. 
A.  Permit Required. No person shall erect, repair, structurally alter, relocate or maintain within the city any sign or other advertising structure as defined in this chapter without first obtaining an erection permit from the enforcement agency and making payment of the fee required by this section, except: 
1.  Signs exempt from the permit procedures in Article 2, Section 15.44.270; and 
2.  Repairs and changes in the painted or printed copy is permitted on conforming and nonconforming signs, as long as such repairs and changes do not alter the structure. Structural alterations involving minor extensions shall require an erection permit based on the square footage of the extension. 
B.  Application. Application for erection permits shall be made upon blanks provided by the enforcement agency, and shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
1.  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant; 
2.  Location of building, structure or lot to which or upon which the sign or other advertising structure is to be attached or erected; 
3.  Position of the sign or other advertising structure in relation to nearby buildings or structures; 
4.  Two blueprints or ink drawings of the plans and specifications and method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground; 
5.  Copy of stress sheets and calculations showing the structure is designed for dead load and wind pressure in any direction in the amount required by this and all other laws of the city; 
6.  Name of person erecting structure; 
7.  Written consent of the owner of the building, structure or land to which or on which the structure is to be erected; 
8.  Any electrical permit required and issued for the sign; 
9.  Insurance policy or bond as required; 
10.  Such other information as the enforcement agency shall require to show full compliance with this and all other laws of the city. 
C.  Temporary Sign Permits. 
1.  Permits for temporary signs erected allowed in the sign districts according to Article II shall be authorized for a period not to exceed thirty (30) consecutive days, with further restrictions of three temporary permits issued per calendar year. 
2.  Permits for temporary signs erected to provide identification of construction projects or new building, in addition to any exempt from permits by Article II, Section 15.44.270, may be authorized for a six-month period and upon application to the enforcement agency may be renewed for successive six-month periods; provided, that no additional fee shall be required for renewal of such permits. 
D.  Issuance-Term. The enforcement agency shall, upon filing of an application for an erection permit, examine such plans and specifications and other data and the premises upon which it is proposed to erect the sign or other advertising structure, and if it shall appear that the proposed structure is in compliance with all of the requirements of this chapter and all other laws of the city, the enforcement agency shall issue the permit. The applicant must commence work authorized under an erection permit within sixty (60) days of the date of issuance, or the permit shall become null and void. Work authorized under the permit shall proceed in a diligent and workmanlike manner until work authorized under the permit is completed. 
E.  Revocation. 
1.  All rights and privileges acquired under the provisions of this chapter or any amendment thereto are mere licenses revocable for cause at any time by the city council, and all such permits shall contain this provision. 
2.  The enforcement agency is authorized to recommend the revocation of any permit upon failure of the holder thereof to comply with any provision of this chapter. 
F.  Sign Permit Fee. Sign permit applications shall be accompanied by a permit fee of one dollar ($1.00) per square foot of sign area, with a minimum sign permit fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and a maximum sign permit fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Temporary sign permit applications shall be accompanied by a permit fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
G.  Permit Number. Every sign or other advertising structure hereafter erected shall have painted in a conspicuous place thereon, in letters not less than one inch in height, the date of erection, the permit number and the voltage of any electrical apparatus used in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012; Ord. No. 8935, § 5, 8-16-2016) 
15.44.540 - Penalties. 
A.  Any person erecting, constructing or altering any sign structure without obtaining a permit or paying the permit fee as required in this chapter shall in addition to the payment of such permit fee pay an additional penalty fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
B.  Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall upon conviction be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
15.44.550 - Variances. 
A.  The board of zoning adjustment may consider variances from the provisions of this chapter and criteria established in this section. 
B.  The variance procedures established herein shall be available only for the erection of signs subsequent to the effective date of this chapter and such variance shall not be issued for nonconforming signs in existence on the effective date of this chapter. 
C.  Such variances may be granted only to those regulations of this chapter which designate number of signs, sign area, sign height limits or sign setback. In no event shall a variance be granted for the erection of a sign in a district wherein such proposed sign is prohibited. 
D.  Variance from the sign ordinance may be granted when all of the following criteria are found: 
1.  There exist special circumstances involving size, shape, topography, location or surroundings which do not apply generally to other properties in the same district. 
2.  Any variance granted shall not constitute a grant of special privilege inconsistent with the limitations upon other properties in the vicinity and district in which such property is situated. 
3.  Granting the variance furthers one or more of the purposes in this chapter as well as or better than applying the standard, and does not undermine any of the purposes when considering the special circumstances. 
E.  It shall be the obligation and burden of the applicant to establish the compliance with the criteria and guidelines established herein. 
F.  Applications for variances shall be made in writing and shall contain such information as shall from time to time be prescribed by this section. 
G.  A uniform fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be paid to the city upon the filing of each application for variance for the purpose of defraying expenses resulting from the proceedings. 
H.  The application for variance shall contain the legal description of the property involved and the property use, along with the complete plans of all proposed signs and the location of existing signs. Such application shall contain a reference to the specific provisions of this chapter from which such sign is sought to be exempted. 
I.  The board of zoning adjustment shall cause such investigation of facts bearing on the application to be made as will provide necessary information to assure that the action on each application is consistent with the intent and purpose of this chapter. 
J.  Upon referral to the board of zoning adjustment of an application for variance, the board shall fix a time and place of hearing and give notice thereof to the applicant and any other interested parties. Such notice shall include a notice of such hearing published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, such publication to be at least fifteen (15) days; the board shall also notify by ordinary mail at their last known address all persons owning property within one hundred eighty-five (185) feet of the location of the proposed sign variance; provided however, that the failure of such persons to actually receive such notice shall not invalidate any decision by the board on such application for variance. 
K.  In the event the board determines that the variance should be granted, it may grant the variance either with or without conditions. 
L.  Approval of a variance shall be by a motion of the board of adjustment with a concurring vote of at least four members. 
M.  In the event the application is denied, the applicant may within thirty (30) days of the date of the order appeal the order to the Circuit Court of Clay County pursuant to R.S.Mo. Chapter 536. 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
Chapter 15.48 - FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT[12] 
Sections: 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8788, § 1, adopted Dec. 2, 2014, repealed former Ch. 15.48, §§ 15.48.010-15.48.120, and enacted a new Ch. 15.48 as set out herein. The former chapter pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

Article I. - Statutory Authority, Findings of Fact, and Purposes 

15.48.010 - Statutory authority. 
    The Legislature of the State of Missouri has in R.S.Mo. § 77.260, delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt floodplain management regulations designed to protect the health, safety, and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 8788, § 2, 12-2-2014) 
15.48.020 - Findings of fact. 
A.  Flood Losses Resulting from Periodic Inundation. The special flood hazard areas of the City of North Kansas City, Missouri are subject to inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base; all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
B.  General Causes of the Flood Losses. These flood losses are caused by (1) the cumulative effect of development in any delineated floodplain causing increases in flood heights and velocities; and (2) the occupancy of flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods, hazardous to others, inadequately elevated, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages. 
C.  Methods Used to Analyze Flood Hazards. The Flood Insurance Study (FIS) that is the basis of this chapter use standard engineering method of analyzing flood hazards which consist of a series of interrelated steps. 
1.  Selection of a base flood that is based upon engineering calculations which permit a consideration of such flood factors as its expected frequency of occurrence, the area inundated, and the depth of inundation. The base flood selected for this section is representative of large floods which are characteristic of what can be expected to occur on the particular streams subject to this section. It is in the general order of a flood which could be expected to have a one percent chance of occurrence in any one year as delineated on the Federal Insurance Administrator's FIS, and illustrative materials for Clay County dated August 3, 2015, as amended, and any future revisions thereto. 
2.  Calculation of water surface profiles are based on a standard hydraulic engineering analysis of the capacity of the stream channel and overbank areas to convey the regulatory flood. 
3.  Computation of a floodway required to convey this flood without increasing flood heights more than one foot at any point. 
4.  Delineation of floodway encroachment lines within which no development is permitted that would cause any increase in flood height. 
5.  Delineation of flood fringe, i.e., that area outside the floodway encroachment lines, but still subject to inundation by the base flood. 
(Ord. No. 8788, § 2, 12-2-2014; Ord. No. 8841, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
15.48.030 - Statement of purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare; to minimize those losses described in Section 15.48.020(A); to establish or maintain the city's eligibility for participation in the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) as defined in 44 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 59.22(a)(3); and to meet the requirements of 44 CFR 60.3(d) by applying the provisions of this chapter to: 
A.  Restrict or prohibit uses that are dangerous to health, safety, or property in times of flooding or cause undue increases in flood heights or velocities; 
B.  Require uses vulnerable to floods, including public facilities that serve such uses, be provided with flood protection at the time of initial construction; and 
C.  Protect individuals from buying lands that are unsuited for the intended development purposes due to the flood hazard. 
(Ord. No. 8788, § 2, 12-2-2014) 
Article II. - Definitions 

15.48.040 - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this chapter shall be interpreted so as to give them the same meaning they have in common usage and to give this chapter its most reasonable application. 
    "100-year flood." See "base flood." 
    "Accessory structure" means the same as "appurtenant structure." 
    "Actuarial rates." See "risk premium rates." 
    "Administrator" means the Federal Insurance Administrator. 
    "Agency" means the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). 
    "Agricultural commodities" means agricultural products and livestock. 
    "Agricultural structure" means any structure used exclusively in connection with the production, harvesting, storage, drying, or raising of agricultural commodities. 
    "Appeal" means a request for review of the floodplain administrator's interpretation of any provision of this chapter or a request for a variance. 
    "Appurtenant structure" means a structure that is on the same parcel of property as the principle structure to be insured and the use of which is incidental to the use of the principal structure. 
    "Area of special flood hazard" is the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. 
    "Base flood" means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    "Basement" means any area of the structure having its floor subgrade (below ground level) on all sides. 
    "Building." See "structure." 
    "Chief executive officer" or "chief elected official" means the mayor of the city who is charged with the authority to implement and administer laws, chapters, and regulations for that community. 
    "Community" means any state or area or political subdivision thereof, which has authority to adopt and enforce floodplain management regulations for the areas within its jurisdiction. 
    "Development" means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, levees, levee systems, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations, or storage of equipment or materials. 
    "Elevated building" means for insurance purposes, a non-basement building which has its lowest elevated floor raised above ground level by foundation walls, shear walls, posts, piers, pilings, or columns. 
    "Eligible community" or "participating community" means a community for which the administrator has authorized the sale of flood insurance under the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP). 
    "Existing construction" means for the purposes of determining rates, structures for which the "start of construction" commenced before the effective date of the FIRM or before January 1, 1975, for FIRMs effective before that date. "Existing construction" may also be referred to as "existing structures." 
    "Existing manufactured home park or subdivision" means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed before the effective date of the floodplain management regulations adopted by a community. 
    "Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision" means the preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads). 
    "Flood" or "flooding" means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from (1) the overflow of inland and/or (2) the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    "Flood boundary and floodway map (FBFM)" means an official map of a community on which the administrator has delineated both special flood hazard areas and the designated regulatory floodway. 
    "Flood elevation determination" means a determination by the administrator of the water surface elevations of the base flood, that is, the flood level that has a one percent or greater chance of occurrence in any given year. 
    "Flood elevation study" means an examination, evaluation and determination of flood hazards. 
    "Flood fringe" means the area outside the floodway encroachment lines, but still subject to inundation by the regulatory flood. 
    "Flood hazard boundary map (FHBM)" means an official map of a community, issued by the administrator, where the boundaries of the flood areas having special flood hazards have been designated as (unnumbered or numbered) A zones. 
    "Flood insurance rate map (FIRM)" means an official map of a community, on which the administrator has delineated both the special flood hazard areas and the risk premium zones applicable to the community. 
    "Flood insurance study (FIS)" means an examination, evaluation and determination of flood hazards and, if appropriate, corresponding water surface elevations. 
    "Floodplain" or "floodprone area" means any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source (see "flooding"). 
    "Floodplain management" means the operation of an overall program of corrective and preventive measures for reducing flood damage, including, but not limited to, emergency preparedness plans, flood control works, and floodplain management regulations. 
    "Floodplain management regulations" means zoning ordinances, subdivision regulations, building codes, health regulations, special purpose ordinances (such as floodplain and grading ordinances) and other applications of police power. The term describes such state or local regulations, in any combination thereof, that provide standards for the purpose of flood damage prevention and reduction.
