Chapter 16.02 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

16.02.020 - Authority. 
    These regulations are adopted and enacted under authority of R.S.Mo. Chapter 89 and amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.02.040 - When platting required. 
    No portion of an existing parcel may be sold or transferred to another party without first legally subdividing the property according to this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.02.060 - Statement of purpose. 
    The purpose of this title is to provide for the orderly arrangement of land intended for subdividing. Specifically, the subdivision of land shall provide for: 
A.  The orderly growth and development of the city through a logical pattern of lots, blocks, that are appropriately sized and shaped for the range of uses for which they are zoned, before such land is made available for sale, 
B.  An efficient pattern of streets which provide safe and convenient access to each lot and reasonable connections beyond the boundaries of the subdivision, 
C.  Appropriate easements, 
D.  The implementation of the Master Plan, zoning ordinance, and other associated regulations, 
E.  The creation of an accurate public record of lot, tract and easement boundaries, and 
F.  The protection of the health, safety and welfare of the general public. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.02.080 - Exceptions. 
    When topography, property configuration or other issues justify deviation from one or more of the standards set out in this title and when such deviations are consistent with the statement of purpose of this title, and will not impair the ability to achieve these purposes on property in the vicinity, the planning commission along with city council may at their sole discretion grant an exception to that requirement. The reasons for the exception shall be clearly set out by resolution of the planning commission and by resolution or ordinance of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.02.100 - Violation and penalty. 
    In addition to any other remedy allowed by law, the city may impose the following penalties for violation of this ordinance: 
    A. No owner, or agent of the owner, of any land located within the corporate limits of North Kansas City, knowingly or with intent to defraud, may transfer, sell, agree to sell, or negotiate to sell land by reference to or by other use of a plat of any purported subdivision of the land before the plat has been approved by the city council and recorded in the records of the Clay County recorder of deeds, unless the owner or agent shall disclose in writing that such plat has not been approved by the city council and that the sale is contingent upon the approval of such plat by the city council. 
B.  Any person violating the provisions of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall forfeit and pay to the city a penalty not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each lot transferred or sold or agreed or negotiated to be sold; and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring shall not exempt the transaction from this penalty. The city may enjoin or vacate the transfer or sale or agreement by legal actions and may recover the penalty in such action. 
C.  Any person committing any other violation of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction is subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day, or confinement of not more than ninety (90) days, or both fine and confinement. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
Chapter 16.04 - DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

16.04.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words or phrases, when used in this title, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context indicates a different meaning. Where a word or term is not defined herein and does not have meaning readily ascertainable in common usage, the zoning administrator may reference the most recent version of Harvey S. Moskowitz and Carl G. Lindbloom, The New Illustrated Book of Development Definitions (Center for Urban Policy Research, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey). 
    "Alley" means a minor way, dedicated to public use, which is used primarily for vehicular access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
    "Block" means a piece or parcel of land surrounded by public highways, streets, streams, railroad rights-of-way, parks, etc., or a combination thereof. 
    "Certified survey map" means a map of lot lines based upon a survey prepared and certified by a registered surveyor of the State of Missouri. 
    "Chief building official" means the individual staff member designated by the city council as the chief building official or his/her designee. 
    "City" means the City of North Kansas City, Missouri. 
    "Commission" or "planning commission" means the city planning and zoning commission. 
    "Council" means the city council and the City of North Kansas City, Missouri. 
    "Cul-de-sac" means a street having one end open to traffic and being terminated by a vehicle turnaround. 
    "Easement" means a grant by the property owner to the public, a corporation or persons, of the use of a described strip or area of land for specific purposes, including utility lines, drainageways, walkways. 
    "Director" means the director of the Department of Public Works of North Kansas City or his or her duly authorized representative. 
    "Improvements" means street pavement, curbs, sanitary and storm sewers, permanent street markers, sidewalks, water mains or other appropriate items. 
    "Lot" means a designated unit of land established by a plat or otherwise as permitted by law and to be separately owned, used, developed, or built upon. 
    "Lot line adjustment" means the application which, by certified survey map, revises one or more lot lines of previously platted lots resulting in a change in area, shape or legal boundaries to no more than four lots. A lot line adjustment is a type of minor subdivision that must also satisfy all conditions of a minor subdivision. 
    "Master or comprehensive plan" means the comprehensive plan made and adopted by the city indicating the general locations recommended for major thoroughfares, streets, parks, public buildings, zoning districts, and other elements, including special studies supplemental thereto. 
    "Minor plat" means the application which results in division of a lot or parcel of land into no more than five new legal lots. A minor plat is a type of minor subdivision that must also satisfy all conditions of a minor subdivision. 
    "Minor subdivision" means a platting process whereby legal lots can be established by an expedited review process as provided in this chapter. 
    "Parcel" means a contiguous unit of land owned and recorded as the property of the same persons or controlled by a single entity. 
    "Parcel, remnant" or "remnant parcel" means that portion of an existing parcel that is not made a part of a subdivision. 
    "Pedestrian way" means a right-of-way, dedicated or otherwise assigned to public use, which cuts across a block to facilitate pedestrian access to adjacent streets and properties. 
    "Setback lines" or "building lines" means a line on a plat generally parallel to the street right-of-way, indicating the limit beyond which buildings or structures may not be erected. 
    "Survey plat" means the application which, by the certified survey map, formally establishes the exact lot lines for any future lots noted on an approved final plat, but the approval of which is subject to actual physical construction and development on the proposed lot. A survey plat is a type of minor subdivision. 
    Plat, Final. "Final plat" means a complete and exact subdivision drawing, prepared for official recording as required by statute, to define property boundaries, easements, streets and other improvements, and dedication of property for public use where required. 
    Plat, Preliminary. "Preliminary plat" means a preliminary plat for a subdivision shall be a plan, drawn to scale, indicating prominent existing features of a tract and its surroundings and the general street and lot layout of the proposed subdivision and its relationship to the surrounding area. 
    "Right-of-way" means the land opened, reserved or dedicated for a street, highway, walk, drainage or other public purpose. 
    Street, Public. "Public street" means a strip of land, including the entire right-of-way, intended primarily as a means of vehicular and pedestrian travel which may also be used to provide space for sewers, public utilities, trees and sidewalks, and which is dedicated or deeded to the public for the above uses. 
    Street, Major or Thoroughfare. "Major or thoroughfare street" means a street or road of considerable continuity which serves or is intended to serve as the principal vehicular way between separated areas or districts. 
    Street, Collector. "Collector street" means a street which, in addition to serving abutting properties, intercepts minor streets, connects with community facilities and carries neighborhood traffic to the major street system. 
    Street, Commercial. "Commercial street" means a street used to provide access to abutting commercial properties. 
    Street, Residential. "Residential street" means a street used primarily to provide access to abutting residential properties. 
    "Subdivider" means a person, firm or corporation undertaking the subdividing or the re-subdividing of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, or other divisions of land for the purpose of transfer of ownership or development, whether immediate or future, including all changes in street or lot lines. 
    "Subdivision" means a division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots or other tracts of land, for the purpose of transfers of ownership or development, whether immediate or future, including all changes in street or lot lines. 
    "Tract" means a unit of land designated for limited or no development as part of a subdivision plat with a legitimate public purpose and designated for public or common ownership. 
    "Zoning administrator" means the individual staff member directed by the city council to administer the zoning ordinance or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
Chapter 16.06 - PLATTING PROCEDURE 
Sections: 

16.06.020 - Filing fees and additional costs. 
    A. Filing Fees. 
1.  The following schedule of fees is adopted, which fees are to be paid to the city by all persons or corporations submitting plats for approval by the city and shall be computed to the nearest dollar. The fee for any preliminary or final plat application submitted shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus: 
Number of lots 

in subdivision Per lot 10 or less $6.00 11 to 50 $3.00 51 or more $1.00  
  
2.  The minimum total fee for any preliminary or final plat shall be one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). This fee shall be paid at the time that any preliminary or final plat is submitted. If the final plat is submitted in segments, then the above fee schedule shall apply to each submittal. 
3.  The filing fee for a survey plat shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
B.  Additional Costs. 
1.  Published Notice. Applicants shall reimburse the city for the cost of publishing public notice for required public hearings. Reimbursement is required prior to the recording of the final plat by the city. 
2.  Recording Costs. Applicants shall pay to the city a sum of money equal to the cost of recording the ordinance and the plat, which are based upon the fees set by the Clay County Recorder of Deeds. Such payment may be made after the council approves the plat, but is due before the city submits the plat and ordinance for recording. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.040 - Pre-application conference. 
    Prior to the submittal of any subdivision application materials, the subdivider shall meet with the director of public works, zoning administrator, and chief building official so as to acquaint the city with the proposed plat. The conference shall determine which approval process, the standard or abbreviated platting process, under which the proposed subdivision would be able to be considered. In addition, the city will consider what, if any, infrastructure and utility improvements may be required in order to adequately serve the proposed subdivision. Upon completion of the conference, the subdivider may proceed with the appropriate subdivision application as determined by the conference. 
Platting Process Selection Table (Sections 16.06.060 and 16.06.080) Less than or equal to 5 lots Greater than 5 lots No new streets, nor change in layout of existing streets Abbreviated process Standard process New streets, or change in layout of existing streets Standard process Standard process  
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.060 - Standard platting process. 
    The standard platting process requires the preparation of a preliminary plat to go before the planning commission at a duly advertised public hearing. The preparation of a preliminary plat is required when there are more than five lots to be created with the subdivision and/or, when there are additions to or changes in the layout of city streets, or when new streets are to be dedicated. 
A.  Preliminary Plat. 
1.  Purpose. The purpose of the preliminary plat is to determine whether the proposed subdivision will comply with the comprehensive plan, development policies of the city, and meet the design standards herein contained and other applicable laws. 
2.  Submission. The subdivider or his or her duly authorized agent shall, at least thirty (30) days prior to the regularly scheduled planning commission meeting, file such preliminary plat, application and associated materials according to procedures specified in the preliminary plat application. The time of filing of a preliminary plat shall be construed to be the time at which the same, together with required data, is received in the office of the zoning administrator who shall indicate the date of submission upon the application and shall schedule a date on which the plat shall be considered by the commission. 
3.  Review. 
a.  Staff Review. Within five working days of the filing of the preliminary plat, the zoning administrator shall transmit copies of the plat to all involved city departments. Any findings and recommendations from city departments will be forwarded to the planning commission along with the preliminary plat. 
b.  Planning Commission Review. The planning commission shall approve, conditionally approve or disapprove the preliminary plat at a public hearing to be held not later than sixty (60) days after the preliminary plat is received and acknowledged as herein set forth. 
c.  Approval. In the event of planning commission approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider may proceed with the preparation and submittal of the final plat as required under these regulations. 
d.  Disapproval. In case of disapproval by the planning commission of the preliminary plat, a statement, in writing, of the reasons for such disapproval, shall be made to the subdivider. One or more subsequent hearings before the commission may be scheduled upon receipt of an amended preliminary plat which meets all applicable requirements. Any action by the planning commission may be taken to the city council on appeal. 
e.  Duration of Approval. Approval of the preliminary plat by the commission expires at the end of one year, unless a final plat covering all or a portion thereof has been submitted, and the preliminary plat shall be declared void one year after the date of original approval. 
f.  Effect of Approval. Approval of the preliminary plat does not constitute acceptance of the subdivision, but is merely an authorization to proceed towards the preparation of the final plat for record. 
i.  No grading of streets, or construction shall be done on the subdivision before the final plat is approved except by special permission of the city council. 
ii.  No site grading or site clearance may take place before final infrastructure plans are approved, without the express permission of the city council, who may grant such permission at their sole discretion. A separate site grading and/or site clearance plan must be approved by the director and/the chief building official in order to receive the permit. Such plans shall be compliance with all appropriate sediment and erosion control standards, including but not limited to the specifications set forth in APWA Section 5100. 
4.  Form. The subdivider shall cause the preliminary plat of the land proposed to be subdivided to be prepared by a registered land surveyor or professional engineer. Such preliminary plat shall be in full compliance with the requirements of these regulations. 
5.  Information Required. The following information shall be shown on the preliminary plat: 
a.  The name of the proposed subdivision which shall be different from that of any existing subdivision previously recorded in Clay County, Missouri, and the names of adjacent subdivisions and the owners of record of all adjacent unplatted land; 
b.  The name, address and telephone number of the record owner, or owners, subdivider and the person or firm preparing the preliminary plat; 
c.  The location of boundary lines of the subdivision and their relation to established section lines or fractional section lines; 
d.  A legal description of the land contained within the proposed subdivision, including gross acreage involved; 
e.  The date of preparation, and north point; 
f.  The scale of the map shall be no less than one inch to one hundred (100) feet and shall be clearly and legibly drafted and reproduced; 
g.  Zoning on and adjacent to the tract; 
h.  Topography of the tract shall be shown on the preliminary plat by means of contours of one- or two-foot intervals if the predominant ground slope within the tract is between level and ten (10) percent grade and five-foot intervals for predominant ground slopes within the tract over ten (10) percent grade, all at city datum; 
i.  The general alignment and pattern of all proposed streets, alleys, lots (approximate dimensions), and other features or areas of the proposed subdivision; 
j.  The location of all lot lines, property lines, streets, highways or easements on adjacent property to a distance of two hundred (200) feet from all boundaries of the subdivision or to a greater distance if the planning commission deems it necessary for adequate review and coordination with existing conditions. Center line profiles of proposed streets may be required by the director of public works in locations where extremely level or very steep natural slopes prevail; 
k.  Approximate gradients of streets; 
l.  The outline of any existing buildings to remain on the property and their locations in relation to existing or proposed street and lot lines or any other feature of importance to lot and street layout; 
m.  Notation of proposed use or uses of the property, as well as any proposed zoning change; and 
n.  Other preliminary information as may be required by the city in order to assure that the subdivision is capable of being constructed without an adverse effect upon the surrounding area or the community at large. 
B.  Preliminary Infrastructure Plans. Prior to the submittal of a final plat, the subdivider must provide preliminary infrastructure plans if such was determined by the director to be required. 
1.  Submission. 
a.  Determination of Need for Infrastructure Improvements. The subdivider shall consult with the director of public works at the pre-application conference or other opportunities to determine the infrastructure facilities necessary to serve the subdivision. The subdivider must provide sufficient information to the director so the director may determine whether or not existing infrastructure is sufficient to serve the requirements of the subdivision, or whether improvements are necessary to any facilities. If the director determines that existing facilities are sufficient, no further information need be provided. 
b.  Preliminary Plan Standards. If any new facilities, or improvements to existing facilities are needed, the subdivider shall prepare and submit to the director any or all of the following as may apply to the proposed subdivision according to the latest edition of APWA standards for the Kansas City region: preliminary plans and profiles of public streets, sanitary sewers, preliminary storm water plans, and a preliminary water supply and distribution plan. 
2.  Upsizing. Wherever any portion of the required infrastructure improvements are part of a planned future city improvement the city may require that the applicant enter into an agreement to build the facility to its planned size or capacity. The city and the applicant shall negotiate an agreement to share the cost of the additional construction, with the applicant responsible for all costs that would otherwise be paid in building the facility to serve the specific application absent any upsizing, and with the city responsible for any actual costs due to incremental upsizing of the facility. 
C.  Utility Review. Upon approval of the preliminary plat, or before approval of any final plat, at minimum, utility easements will be shown on the final plat according to the design standards of this title. At the city's discretion, the city may elect to transmit copies of the proposed final plat with proposed utility easements to any or all involved utilities for their review and comment. Each of the agencies may within fifteen (15) days after receipt of the plat, forward to the city any written comments. The city may, upon receipt of a request from a utility company, allow reasonable additional time for review. If no reply is received within said period of time, such plat shall be deemed acceptable to the utility. 
D.  Final Plat. 
1.  Purpose. The purpose of the final plat is to create an accurate public record for the sale of lots and to ensure all lots are buildable lots prior to recording. 
2.  Submission. After approval of the preliminary plat and preliminary infrastructure plans, the subdivider or his or her duly authorized agent shall, at least fifteen (15) days prior to the regularly scheduled planning commission meeting, file such final plat, application and associated materials according to procedures specified in the final plat application. Such plat shall be signed and sealed by a land surveyor, registered in Missouri, in a form suitable for recording according to the Clay County recorder of deeds. The time of filing of a final plat shall be construed to be the time at which the same, together with required data, is received in the office of the zoning administrator who shall indicate the date of submission upon the application and shall schedule a date on which the plat shall be considered by the commission. 
3.  Review. 
a.  Staff Review. Within five working days of the filing of the final plat, the zoning administrator shall transmit copies of the plat to all involved city departments. Any findings and recommendations from city departments will be forwarded to the planning commission along with the final plat. 
b.  Planning Commission Review. Upon receipt of the final plat from the zoning administrator, the planning commission shall give due attention to compliance with the preliminary plat, any comments or requirements from utilities, the public works review report of preliminary infrastructure plans, and technical recommendations of the staff and consultants. 
c.  City Council Review. Upon recommendation of approval by the commission, the zoning administrator shall submit the final plat to the council for their action. The council may approve, reject, or specify changes or modifications therein which it deems necessary and may make its approval subject to such alterations. Upon approval by the council by ordinance duly passed, such approval shall be endorsed on three paper copies under the hand of the city clerk and the seal of the city. 
d.  Recording. The zoning administrator shall record the approved plat within thirty (30) days of approval. For any final plat, where approval is conditioned upon the fulfillment of a specific act by the subdivider, then the approval date for the purpose of this section shall be the date that the condition is fulfilled to the city's satisfaction. 
4.  Form. The final plat shall be consistent with all submittal requirements of the Recorder of Deeds of Clay County, Missouri for the recording of plats. If more than two sheets are required, an index map showing the entire development shall be shown on each sheet. 
5.  Information Required. The final plat shall show and contain the following information: 
a.  Name of subdivision; 
b.  Location by section, township, range, county and state, and including descriptive boundaries of the subdivision, based on an accurate traverse, giving angular and linear dimensions of third order surveying accuracy. All calculations shall be furnished showing bearings and distances of all boundary lines and lot lines and the square foot area of each lot; 
c.  Location of boundaries shall be shown in reference to existing official monuments including true angles and distances to such reference points or monuments; 
d.  Location of lots, streets, public highways, alleys, parks and other features with accurate dimensions in feet and decimals of feet, with the length and radii of arcs of all curves, and with all other information necessary to reproduce the plat on the ground. Dimensions shall be shown from all angle points and points of curve to lot lines; 
e.  Lot shall be numbered clearly. If blocks are to be numbered or lettered, these shall be shown clearly in the center of the block; 
f.  The exact locations, widths and names of all streets to be dedicated; 
g.  Location and width of all easements to be dedicated and their designated purpose; 
h.  Boundary lines and description of boundary lines of any areas other than streets and alleys which are to be dedicated or reserved for public use; 
i.  Building setback lines on front and side streets in residential areas, including dimensions; 
j.  Name and address of developer and surveyor making the plat; 
k.  The scale of the plat shall be no less than one inch to one hundred (100) feet and shall include, date and north point; and 
l.  Statement of Dedication. See Appendix A. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.080 - Abbreviated platting process. 
A.  Intent, Applicability, and Eligibility. Abbreviated platting requirements are intended to provide expedited review and approval of minor adjustments to legal boundaries and title of property for proper recording with the county. The standards and procedures in this section are only allowed when: 
1.  The adjustments will not involve changes to the layout of city streets, or the dedication of any new street or roads unless previously approved through the city platting process; 
2.  Will not conflict with the master plan; and 
3.  Will not adversely impact any adjacent property or public facility. 
B.  All processes for infrastructure review, construction, and guarantees noted as part of the standard platting process remain applicable to this abbreviated platting procedure. 
C.  Types of Minor Subdivisions. The following applications are minor subdivisions-subject to the eligibility requirements listed in paragraph A of this section. 
1.  Minor Plat. The division of a lot or parcel of land into no more than five lots. 
2.  Lot Line Adjustment. The movement of lot lines that affects the size and shape of no more than four lots and results in no additional lots. 
3.  Survey Plat. The identification of surveyed lots for individual ownership based upon actual construction of buildings, site design and other facilities. The survey plat shall be in conformance with an approved plan, a recorded final plat, and result in no additional units, lots, or tracts as indicated on the approved plan or plat, including a note on the approved final plat indicating the maximum number of future lots to be created by a survey plat. 
D.  Submission Requirements. 
1.  Minor Plat. A minor plat shall submit all applicable information contained in Section 16.06.060.D for final plats. The planning commission or city council may refer a minor plat back through the standard platting procedures if it is determined to not meet the eligibility requirements of this section. 
2.  Certified Survey Map. An application for a lot line adjustment or survey plat shall be submitted with a certified survey map. The certified survey map shall be prepared by a registered surveyor and including: 
a.  A title indicating that the certified survey map is in reference to an approved and recorded final plat, and the name of that plat; 
b.  North arrow and scale; 
c.  Lot lines from the approved final plat for the portion the plat covered by the certified survey map; 
d.  New lot lines to be created by the survey map, clearly indicating any adjustments to the lot lines on the previously approved final plat; 
e.  Identification of all new lots, not duplicating the name of any existing or previously approved lot identifications; 
f.  The exact location of all buildings, structures, or other physical improvements; 
g.  Names and exact location of all abutting streets, lots, and parcels; 
h.  Exact location and dimension of all existing easements and utility facilities; 
i.  A statement by the applicant that the certified survey map is in conformance with all zoning requirements, all conditions of previous plan or plat approvals, subdivision regulation requirements, or other applicable city ordinances; and 
j.  A signature block containing the following signatures: 
i.  Signature of the owner or owners, including name and address; 
ii.  Signature of a notary public; and 
iii.  Certification of the registered land surveyor who prepared the survey map, including name and address. 
E.  Review Procedure. 
1.  Minor Plat. The review procedure for a minor plat shall be the same as for a final plat, except that no preliminary plat procedure is required. The planning commission or city council may refer a minor plat back through the standard platting procedures if it is determined to not meet the eligibility requirements of this section. 
2.  Certified Survey Map. The zoning administrator, or his or her designee, may approve a certified survey map, provided that the applicant presents clear and convincing evidence that the certified survey map: 
a.  Is in conformance with requirements of the zoning ordinance and zoning for the subject property; 
b.  Is in conformance with the subdivision regulations; 
c.  Is in conformance with all approved plans and plats for the subject property, including any proposed future lots indicated on the final plat in the case of a survey plat; 
d.  Satisfies all conditions on the approved plan and plat; 
e.  Satisfies all eligibility and approval standards for a minor subdivision; 
f.  Results in no additional lots than are existing or than are indicated through notes on an approved final plat; and 
g.  Meets the standards for property boundary surveys as established by the Missouri board for Architects, Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors, and the Missouri Department of Natural Resources. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.100 - Criteria for review. 
    In achieving the purposes of this ordinance in Section 16.02.060, the planning commission and city council shall consider the following criteria when reviewing any preliminary plat, final plat, or minor plat application: 
A.  Each resulting lot results in a buildable lot capable of meeting all existing zoning ordinance requirements, demonstrated by a sketch plan of proposed or possible buildings on the site. Consideration shall also be given to buildable lots for reasonably anticipated development should the proposed sketch plan not be built. 
B.  No plat shall result in adjacent properties becoming un-buildable. 
C.  Each resulting lot or tract will conform to the goals, strategies, and design concepts in the master plan, or any official area plan adopted by the city under the master plan, regarding the physical layout of blocks, lots, open spaces, or utilities, and regarding the design of the public right-of-way and other public spaces. 
D.  The proposed plat places no burdens or impacts on existing public facilities, without plans for addressing such impacts which are acceptable to the city. 
E.  The proposed plat: 
1.  Does not create any new zoning non-conformances; 
2.  Corrects, or does not unnecessarily extend the life of, an existing zoning nonconformance; and 
3.  Does not increase the degree of any existing zoning non-conformance that may exist. 
F.  The size and pattern of ownership for the proposed application meets the following thresholds, or demonstrates that by not meeting these thresholds that the proposed plat furthers the goals and strategies of the master plan, or any official area plan adopted by the city under the master plan: 
1.  All applications shall conform to the Design Standards in Chapter 16.08. 
2.  Where there is no zoning requirement for lot area, no lot shall be less than one thousand (1,000) square feet. 
3.  Where there is no zoning requirement for lot frontage, no lot shall have less than twenty-five (25) feet of frontage on a public street. 
4.  Irregular or non-rectangular lot patterns should only be justified through exceptional circumstances and conditions affecting the overall parcel and demonstration that proposed irregular or non-rectangular lot patterns that will not harm long-term viability and marketability of the lot and other lots in the area, when considering use, re-use, or redevelopment of buildings and sites. 
G.  The proposed plat will result in all lots or tracts being in compliance with all sections of the municipal code, or any specific procedures and criteria for relief from compliance under those codes. 
H.  The planning commission or city council may condition approval of any application based on site or building designs that further these criteria. Any ongoing conditions may be required to be covenants recorded with approval of the proposed application. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.120 - Plat approval or disapproval. 
A.  Within sixty (60) days after the submission of a plat to the commission, the commission shall recommend approval or disapproval of the plat; otherwise the plat is deemed to have been acted upon by the commission, except that the commission, with the consent of the applicant for the approval, may extend the sixty-day period. 
B.  The grounds for recommending disapproval of any plat by the commission shall be made a matter of record. 
C.  A recommendation of approval of a plat by the commission does not constitute or affect an acceptance by the city or public of the dedication to use of any street or other ground shown upon the plat. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.140 - Fulfillment of conditions prior to recording of final plat. 
    Upon city council approval of the final plat, the subdivider must satisfy, as applicable to a given subdivision, the following conditions prior to the recording of the plat. 
A.  Dedication of Lands. If the subdivision intends to have dedicated certain land for streets, alleys, or other public purposes, tax certificates from both the city and county shall be submitted, stating that all taxes and encumbrances have been satisfied; 
B.  Restrictive Covenants. One copy of any private restrictions affecting the subdivision or any part thereof for future reference by the city, shall be submitted; 
C.  Final Infrastructure Plans. If any new facilities, or improvements to existing facilities are required, the subdivider shall prepare and submit to the director, as applicable, final infrastructure plans and profiles of public streets, sanitary sewers, final storm water plans, and a final water supply and distribution plan according to latest edition of APWA standards for the Kansas City region. 
D.  Guarantee of Infrastructure Installation. Prior to the recording of any plat: 
1.  The subdivider may choose to complete the installation of required infrastructure according to the approved final infrastructure plans, or 
2.  The subdivider must provide surety to the city in the form of a performance bond, certified check, or letter of credit, enforceable by or payable to the city or its agent in a sum equal to the cost of constructing the improvements subject to the approval of the director and city attorney, and according to the approved final infrastructure plans. 
E.  Phasing. It is understood that for some developments, it may be more practicable to be developed in a phased manner. Provided there is an approved preliminary plat, subdividers may proceed with final platting in phases. Installation of infrastructure and guarantees for such installation may also proceed on the same phased basis as the final plat. However, the city retains the right to require sufficient plans so as to assure the viability of the infrastructure improvements. Surety may be provided in an amount equivalent to the infrastructure to be installed for each phase. 
F.  Failure to Fulfill Conditions. If the required conditions have not been fulfilled in order for the city to record a final plat within one year, the approval of the final plat is null and void. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.160 - Infrastructure maintenance bonds. 
    Upon completion and approval of construction, a two-year maintenance bond shall be required for all streets, curbs, sidewalks, and storm sewers. A one-year maintenance bond shall be required for water and sanitary sewer lines. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.06.180 - Building construction. 
    After a plat has been duly recorded, construction may begin on buildings within the subdivision upon issuance of building permit. However, no building permit shall be issued for a building within such subdivision, until such public infrastructure has been installed, or installation guaranteed, covering the installation of said improvements in the block upon which said lot fronts. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
Chapter 16.08 - DESIGN STANDARDS 
Section: 

16.08.020 - Lots. 
A.  All lots shall have direct access to public right-of-way. 
B.  All rectangular lots and all other lots, so far as practicable, shall have the side lines at right angles to the street on which the lot faces, or radial to curved street lines and cul-de-sac turnarounds. 
C.  Where there is no zoning requirement for lot frontage, no lot shall have less than twenty-five (25) feet of frontage on a public street. 
D.  For residential subdivisions, corner lots shall be at least fifteen (15) feet wider than the average lot in the subdivision. The minimum average depth of a lot shall be one hundred ten (110) feet. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.08.040 - Undeveloped or limited development tracts. 
    "Remnant parcels" are prohibited. However, the creation of undeveloped or limited development tracts may be made a legitimate part of a subdivision when: 
A.  Such units of land are designated as a tracts to be included as part of the plat, with their purpose made a part of the dedication within the plat, and 
B.  Such tracts serve a legitimate public purpose such as open space, recreation, environmental protection, or achieves other regulatory requirements, and/or 
C.  Such tracts may be designated for common or public ownership. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.08.060 - Building lines. 
    Building lines shall be shown on all lots, and shall provide at least the setback required by the zoning regulations. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.08.080. - Blocks. 
A.  In general, intersecting streets, which determine block lengths, shall be provided at such intervals as to serve cross traffic adequately and to meet existing streets or customary subdivision practices of the surrounding area. 
B.  For residential subdivisions, where no existing plats control, the blocks in residential districts shall not exceed one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) feet in length. Pedestrian ways and/or easements through the block may be required to serve nearby public facilities. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.08.100 - Streets and alleys. 
A.  Arrangement of major streets in the subdivision shall conform as nearly as possible to the comprehensive plan as adopted by the city, and provision shall be made for the extension of major and secondary thoroughfares. Except for courts and cul-de-sacs, streets normally shall connect with streets already dedicated in adjoining or adjacent subdivisions, or provide for future connections to adjoining unsubdivided tracts, or shall be reasonable projection of streets in the nearest subdivided tracts. 
B.  Residential streets shall be so planned as to discourage their use by non-local traffic and provisions shall be made for adequate traffic circulation. 
C.  Culs-de-sac may be permitted where topography or other conditions justify their use. A turnaround shall be provided at all closed ends with a right-of-way radius of not less than fifty (50) feet. Such cul-de-sac street shall not be longer than five hundred (500) feet. 
D.  When a tract is subdivided into larger than normal building lots, such lots shall be so arranged as to permit the continuous location and opening of future streets and appropriate re-subdivision, with provision for adequate utility connections for such re-subdivision. 
E.  Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles, except where topography or other conditions justify variations. The minimum angle of intersection of streets generally shall be sixty (60) degrees. 
F.  Street intersections shall either be directly across from each other or offset by at least one hundred fifty (150) feet from center line to center line. 
G.  Streets with reverse curves shall have a tangent between curves. 
H.  A frontage or service street may be required where frontage along a controlled access street or highway is to be subdivided. 
I.  Alleys. Except in unusual cases, alleys or loading courts must be provided in business blocks. Alleys are not required in residential districts. In case of intersecting alleys, a cutoff shall be required of at least five feet measured from the point of intersection of the alley lines, the resultant connecting lot line to be at least five feet in length. 
J.  Dedication of half streets will not be approved except where such dedication will serve the public interest and the improvement of the entire street is assured through irrevocable and timely agreements. 
K.  For all public ways hereafter dedicated and accepted, the minimum right-of-way widths for streets, alleys, or pedestrian ways included in any subdivision shall not be less than the minimum dimensions for each classification as follows and shall be in accordance with the master plan for streets: 
Classification R.O.W. Roadway Width, Back to Back of Curb Major Streets:  Primary-dual roadway 120 ft. 2-28' lanes  Arterial 80 ft. 52  Collector 60 to 80 ft. 36 to 52 Minor streets:  Residential, single-family 60 ft. 36 ft.  Residential, multifamily and other higher density 60 ft. 36 ft.  Commercial 66 ft. 42 ft.  Industrial 66 ft. 42 ft.  Frontage or service streets (abutting major street right-of-way) 40 ft. 28 ft.  Cul-de-sac Same as other minor streets above Outside curb radius 10 feet less than R.O.W. radius Alleys 20 ft. 20 ft. Pedestrian ways 6 ft. 6 ft. Sidewalks 5 ft. 5 ft.  
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.08.120 - Sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks shall be installed on both sides of all streets. They shall be located in the platted street, and abut the property line. Sidewalks shall conform to APWA specifications. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.08.140 - Utility easements. 
    Where alleys will not accommodate utilities, easements of not less than ten (10) feet shall be provided on each side of rear or side lot lines, or where necessary for the proper location or relocation of public utilities. If necessary for the extension of water or sewer lines, or similar utilities, or for surface drainage, easements of greater width may be required along lot lines or across lots. Easements shall connect with any established easements in adjoining property. Easements for sewer, water and gas lines shall be approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
16.08.160 - Drainage. 
A.  Grading. Grading shall be designed so that all surface water shall be conducted to a street, storm sewer or to a natural watercourse. No watercourse shall be altered so as to divert surface drainage from one watershed to another. No obstruction shall be permitted in natural watercourses, unless such obstruction meets with the approval of the director of public works. The development of areas subject to periodic flooding, poor drainage or other unsuitable physical conditions is prohibited unless rendered suitable by satisfactory improvements. 
B.  Impact of Proposed Streets. Proposed streets must conform to existing topography as nearly as possible, in order that drainage problems may be reduced. Streets shall, wherever possible, follow valleys so as to form a collection system for surface water. Surface drainage across lots or along the side or rear lot lines shall be avoided wherever possible. Where such drainage on lots is necessary, easements shall be provided and the director of public works may require installation of pipe, masonry or rip-rap flumes, or such other protective devices in order that adjacent or surrounding property or the welfare of the public shall not be endangered and maintenance will be kept at a minimum. 
(Ord. No. 8383, § 2, 3-24-2009) 
Appendix A

Streets shown on this plat and not heretofore dedicated to public use are hereby so dedicated. 
Building lines or setback lines are hereby established as shown on this plat and no building or portion thereof shall be built or otherwise located between this line and the lot or street line.

Title 17 - ZONING 
Chapters: 
Chapter 17.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

17.04.010 - Title. 
    The ordinance codified in this Title 17 shall be known, cited, and referred to as: "The North Kansas City Zoning Ordinance." 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.04.020 - Purpose and intent. 
A.  This Title 17 is adopted for the purpose: 
1.  Promoting the public health, safety, comfort, morals, convenience and general welfare; 
2.  Securing adequate light, pure air and safety from fire and other dangers; and 
3.  Conserving the taxable value of land and buildings throughout the city. 
B.  To these ends the ordinance codified in this Title 17 is designed to set up and accomplish certain standards and objectives by: 
1.  Dividing the entire city into districts and restricting and regulating therein the location, construction, reconstruction, alteration and use of buildings, structures and land, whether for residence, business, manufacturing or other specified uses; 
2.  Avoiding or lessening congestion in the public streets; 
3.  Preventing the overcrowding of land through regulating and limiting the height and bulk of buildings hereafter erected as related to land area; 
4.  Establishing, regulating and limiting the building or setback lines on or along streets, alleys or property lines; 
5.  Regulating and limiting the intensity of the use of lot area, and regulating and determining the area of open spaces within and surrounding such buildings; 
6.  Establishing standards to which buildings or structures therein shall conform; 
7.  Prohibiting uses, buildings or structures incompatible with the character of the residence, business or manufacturing districts; 
8.  Preventing additions to, and alterations or remodeling of, existing buildings or structures in such a way as to avoid the restrictions and limitations imposed hereunder; 
9.  Providing for the gradual elimination of those uses, buildings and structures which are incompatible with the character of the districts in which they are made or located, including, without being limited thereto: 
a.  Elimination of such uses of unimproved lands or lot areas when existing rights of the persons in possession thereof are terminated, or when the uses to which they are devoted are discontinued, 
b.  Elimination of uses to which such buildings and structures are devoted, if they are adaptable for permitted uses, and 
c.  Elimination of such buildings and structures when they are destroyed or damaged in major part; 
10.  Defining and limiting the powers and duties of the administrative officers and bodies as provided hereinafter; 
11.  Prescribing penalties for the violation of the provisions of this Title 17, or of any amendment thereto. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.04.030 - Authority. 
    The ordinance codified in this title is enacted pursuant to the powers granted and limitations imposed by the Constitution and laws of the state of Missouri, including the statutory authority granted in Chapter 89 RSMo., as amended. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.04.040 - Applicability and jurisdiction. 
    The provisions of this title shall apply to the development of all structures and land within the incorporated area of the City of North Kansas City. It shall be unlawful to conduct any development or construct any structure until: 
A.  All applicable development review and approval processes have been followed; 
B.  All applicable approvals have been obtained; and 
C.  All required permits or authorizations to proceed have been issued. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.04.050 - Interpretation. 
A.  In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this Title 17 shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals and welfare of the citizens of North Kansas City. 
B.  Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this title upon the (a) use of land or buildings, (b) the bulk of buildings, (c) floor area requirements, (d) lot area requirements and (e) yard requirements are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other provision of this tile or of any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
C.  This title is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or other private agreement; provided, that where the regulations of this title are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than such easements, covenants or other private agreements, the requirements of this title shall govern. 
D.  No building, structure or use not lawfully existing at the time of the adoption of this title shall become or be made lawful solely by reason of the adoption of this title; and to the extent that, and in any manner that, such unlawful building, structure or use is in conflict with the requirements of this title, such building, structure or use remains unlawful hereunder. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.04.060 - Rules of construction. 
    The language set forth in the text of this title will be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction: 
A.  The singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular; 
B.  The present tense includes the past and the future tenses, and the future the present; 
C.  The word "shall" is mandatory while the word "may" is permissive; 
D.  The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter; 
E.  All measured distances shall be to the nearest integral foot; if a fraction is one-half foot or more, the integral foot next above shall be taken; 
F.  The time within which an act is to be completed shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day. If the last day is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, that day shall be excluded and the act shall be completed on the next business day. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.04.070 - Separability. 
    It is declared to be the intention of the city council of the City of North Kansas City, Missouri, that the several provisions of the ordinance codified in this Title 17 are separable, in accordance with the following: 
A.  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any provisions of this title to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect any other provision of this title not specifically included in said judgment. 
B.  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge invalid the application of any provision of this title to a particular property, building or other structure, such judgment shall not affect the application of said provision to any other property, building or structure not specifically included in said judgment. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.04.080 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8418, § 1, adopted August 25, 2009, repealed § 17.04.080, which pertained to regulation of uses. See also the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
Chapter 17.08 - DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

17.08.010 - Definitions. 
A.  The following words and terms, wherever they occur in this title, shall be construed as defined in this section. Where a word or term is not defined herein and does not have meaning readily ascertainable in common usage, reference may be made to the most recent version of Harvey S. Moskowitz & Carl G. Lindbloom, The New Illustrated Book of Development Definitions (Center for Urban Policy Research, Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey). 
    "Antenna" means a device used to transmit and/or receive radio, electromagnetic waves or similar communication technology between terrestrially and/or orbitally based structures. 
    "Aircraft" means any contrivance now known or hereafter invented for use in or designed for navigation of or flight in air. 
    "Airport" means any premises which are used, or intended for use, for the landing and take off of aircraft; and any appurtenant areas which are used, or intended for use for airport buildings or other airport structures or right-of-way, together with all airport buildings and structures located thereon. 
    "Alley" means a right-of-way with a width not exceeding twenty-four (24) feet which affords a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Alteration" means any addition, removal, extension or change in the location of any exterior wall of a building. 
    "Animal hospital" means any building, or portion thereof, designed or used for the care, observation or treatment of domestic animals. 
    "Apartment" means a room or suite of rooms within an apartment house arranged, intended or designed as a place of residence for a family. 
    "Automatic car wash" means any building, or portion thereof, where automobiles are washed using a conveyor, blower, steam-cleaning equipment or other mechanical device of production-line nature. 
    "Automobile service station" means any building, or portion thereof, or premises used for dispensing or offering for sale at retail any automotive fuels or oils, having pumps and storage tanks thereon; or where battery, tire and other similar services are rendered, but only if rendered wholly within lot lines. When dispensing, sale or offering for sale is incidental to the conduct of a repair garage, the premises are classified as a repair garage. Automobile service stations do not include open sales lots as defined herein. 
    "Automobile salvage" or "wrecking yard" means any area of land where three or more motor vehicles not in running condition, or the parts thereof, are stored in the open and are not being restored to operation, or any land, building or structure used for the stripping, wrecking or storing of such automobiles, or parts thereof, and which may include sale of parts of vehicles. 
    "Basement" means a portion of a building located partly underground, but having less than half its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    "Bed and breakfast" means overnight accommodations and a morning meal in a dwelling unit provided to transients for compensation. 
    "Block" means a tract of land bounded by streets or by a combination of one or more streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, or shorelines of waterways or corporate boundary lines. 
    "Building" means anything constructed for shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind and which is permanently affixed to the land. 
    "Board of zoning adjustment" means an officially constituted body whose principal duties are to hear appeals and, where appropriate, grant variances from the strict application of the zoning ordinance. 
    Building, Accessory. "Accessory building" means a subordinate building located on the same lot or portion of a principal building, the use of which is incidental to that of the principal building and customary in connection with that use. 
    Building, Completely Enclosed. "Completely enclosed building" means a building separated on all sides from the adjacent open space or from other buildings or structures by a permanent roof, and by exterior walls having only windows and normal entrance or exit doors, or by party walls. 
    Building, Detached. "Detached building" means a principal building surrounded by open space on the same lot. 
    "Building height" means the vertical distance from grade plane to the average height of the highest roof surface. For purposes of this definition, "grade plane" is the reference plane representing the average of finished ground level adjoining the building at exterior walls. Where the finished ground level slopes away from the exterior walls, the reference plane shall be established by the lowest points within the area between the building and the lot line or, where the lot line is more than six feet from the building and a point six feet from the building. 
    "Building permit" means written permission issued by the proper municipal authority for the construction, repair, alteration, or addition to a structure. 
    Building, Principal. "Principal building" means a nonaccessory building in which is conducted the principal use of the lot on which it is located. 
    Building, Residential. "Residential building" means a building arranged, designed, used or intended to be used for a residential occupancy by one or more families. 
    Building, Temporary. "Temporary building" means any building not designed to be permanently located, placed or affixed in the place where it is. 
    "Bulk" means a composite characteristic of a given building as located upon a given lot, not definable as a single quantity, but involving all of the following characteristics: 
1.  Size and height of building; 
2.  Location of exterior walls at all levels in relation to lot lines, streets or to other buildings; 
3.  Gross floor area of the building in relation to lot area (floor area ratio); 
4.  All open spaces allocated to the building; and 
5.  Amount of lot area provided per dwelling unit. 
    "Business" means an occupation, employment or enterprise which occupies time, attention, labor and materials, or wherein merchandise is exhibited or sold or where services are offered. 
    "Campground" means an area of land, including supporting sanitary and other facilities, for the overnight or temporary parking of recreational vehicles and other modes of camping while traveling by auto. 
    "Car title lenders, check cashing lenders, or pay day lenders" means establishments primarily engaged in the business of providing non-depository credit for short-term loans typically secured by car titles, paychecks, post-dated checks, or personal property other than personal property affixed to real estate. 
    "Cellar" means the portion of a building located partly or wholly underground and having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    "Check cashing lenders," see car title lenders. 
    "Child care facility" means a house or other place conducted or maintained by any person who advertises or holds himself or herself out as providing care for more than four children, during the daytime, for compensation or otherwise, except those operated by a school system or in connection with a business establishment as a convenience for its customers, but a child care facility shall not include any private or religious organization elementary or secondary school, a religious organization academic preschool or kindergarten for four- and five-year-old children, a home school, as defined in Section 167.031, Revised Statutes of Missouri, a weekly Sunday or Sabbath school, a vacation Bible school or child care made available while the parents or guardians are attending worship services or other meetings and activities conducted or sponsored by a religious organization. 
    "Child day care center," whether known or incorporated under another title or name, means a child care program conducted in a location other than the provider's permanent residence, or separate from the provider's living quarters, where care is provided for children not related to the child care provider for any part of the twenty-four (24) hour day. This definition also includes employer operated or contracted day care for employee families. 
    "Church(es)/place(s) of worship" means a building(s) primarily used for public religious worship and associated religious functions (education, fellowship, etc.), including synagogues and temples. 
    Club or Lodge, Private. "Private club or lodge" means an association of persons who are bona fide members, paying dues, and being generally restricted to members and their guest. 
    "Cluster housing" means the site planning technique of grouping dwelling units around courts, parking areas, common open spaces and private drives as opposed to fronting all on a public street. 
    "Comprehensive master plan" (a.k.a. "master plan") means the comprehensive master plan of North Kansas City, Missouri, and any other adopted plan, program, or regulation for the physical development of the city. 
    "Conditional use" means a use permitted in a particular zoning district by the city's discretion only upon showing that the location, design and operation of the use will comply with conditions and standards established in the zoning ordinance and set by the approving agency for the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare. 
    "Condominium" means a type of ownership whereby portions of a building are separately owned under the condominium statutes of the state of Missouri. 
    "Court" means an open, unoccupied space, other than a yard, bounded on three or more sides by exterior walls of a building, or by exterior walls and lot lines on which walls are allowable. 
    "Curb level" means the level of the established curb in front of a building or structure measured at the center of such front. Where no curb level has been established, it shall be deemed to be the established level of the center line of the street surface in front of a building or structure measured at the center line of such front. 
    "Decibel" means a unit of measurement of the intensity (loudness) of sound. As used in this title, decibel levels shall be measured on the "A scale" and referred to as "dB(A)." 
    "Dedication" means the transfer of property by the owner to another property. 
    "Density" means the number of families, individuals, dwelling units, households or housing structures per unit of land. 
    "Development" means the division of a parcel of land into two or more parcels; the construction, reconstruction, conversion, structural alteration, relocation or enlargement of any structure; any mining, excavation, landfill or land disturbance; or any use or extension of the use of land. 
    "Development permit" means the written governmental permission issued by an authorized official, empowering the holder thereof to do some act not forbidden by law but not allowed without such authorization. 
    "Development phases" means development undertaken in a logical time and geographical sequence. 
    "Drainage courses" means any natural or artificial water course, trench, ditch, swale or similar depression into which surface water flows. 
    "Drive" means a right-of-way which affords a means of vehicular access to or through an area and which is owned and maintained by the owner of the property it serves. 
    "Drive-in establishment" means any restaurant, financial institution or product-vending enterprise where the patron does not enter and remain within the building during the transaction of his business. Food-vending establishments where the food is not normally consumed within a building or where facilities are provided for eating outside a building shall be deemed a drive-in for purposes of this title. 
    "Dog kennel" means any premises where three or more dogs are owned, boarded, bred and/or offered for sale. 
    "Dwelling" means a building or portion thereof intended for occupancy for residential purposes but not including hotels, motels, rooming houses, nursing homes, tourist homes or trailers. 
    Dwelling, Multiple-family. "Multiple-family dwelling" means a dwelling, or portion thereof, containing three or more dwelling units. 
    Dwelling, Single-family. "Single-family dwelling" means a dwelling containing one dwelling unit. 
    Dwelling, Two-family (Duplex). "Two-family dwelling (duplex)" means a dwelling containing two dwelling units. 
    "Dwelling unit" means one or more rooms constituting all or part of a dwelling and which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use exclusively as a single housekeeping unit for one family, and which include cooking, living, sanitation and sleeping facilities. 
    "Efficiency dwelling unit" means a dwelling unit consisting of one principal room together with bathroom, kitchen, hallway, closets and/or dining alcove directly off the principal room. 
    "Easement" means a grant of one or more of the property rights by the property owner to and/or for use by the public, a corporation, or another person or entity. 
    "Family" means one or more persons, each related to the other by blood, marriage or legal adoption, or group of not more than four persons not so related, and maintaining a common household and using one set of kitchen facilities in a dwelling unit. A family may include not more than two roomers, boarders or permanent guests not a part of a common household, whether or not gratuitous. 
    Fence, Solid. "Solid fence" means a fence, including solid entrance and exit gates, which effectively conceals from viewers in or on adjoining properties, streets, alleys or public ways, materials stored and operations conducted behind it. 
    "Final Decision" means the last official action of the approving agency taken on a development plan that has been given preliminary approval, after all conditions and requirements of preliminary approval have been met and the required improvements have either been installed or guarantees properly posted for their installation, or approval conditioned upon the posting of such guarantees. 
    "Finished Elevations" means a fully dimensioned drawing of the front, rear, or side of a building showing features such as windows, doors and relationship of grade to floor level. 
    "Finished Grade" means the elevation of the ground level after development. 
    "Floor area for the purpose of determining off-street parking requirements" means the total floor area of the building, expressed in square feet, measured from the exterior surface of outside walls, and including mezzanines, upper floors, whether finished or not, from which is subtracted the floor area of washrooms, elevator shafts, stairways, mechanical rooms and any permanent shopping center malls. 
    "Floor area ratio" means the numerical value obtained through dividing the floor area of a building or buildings by the area of the lot on which such building or buildings are located. 
    Floor Area, Total. "Total floor area" means the sum of the gross horizontal areas of the several floors measured in square feet, including the cellar floor of the building; measured from the exterior faces of the exterior walls or from the center line of walls separating two buildings. The floor area of a building shall also include elevator shafts and stairwells at each floor; floor space used for mechanical equipment; penthouses; attic space having headroom of seven feet ten inches or more; interior balconies and mezzanines; enclosed porches; and floor devoted to accessory uses; provided, that any space devoted to off-street parking or loading shall not be included in floor area. 
    Garage, Private. "Private garage" means an accessory building or an accessory portion of the principal building, including a carport, which is intended for and used for storing the private passenger vehicles of the persons, family or families using the premises. 
    Garage, Storage. "Storage garage" means a building or premises used for housing of motor vehicles pursuant to previous arrangements and for duration greater than three days. 
    "Garden apartment" means an apartment building located on a lot, either singly or together with other similar apartment buildings, generally having a low density of population and having substantial landscaped open space adjacent to the dwelling units. 
    "Ground floor area" means the lot area covered by a building measured from the exterior faces of exterior walls, but excluding open terraces or open porches, garages or carports. 
    "Group home for adults" means a residential facility for five or more persons, eighteen (18) years of age or older, who have been institutionalized for various reasons and released, or who have had physical or social disabilities which make operation in society difficult and require the protection of a group setting to facilitate the transition to a functional member of society (for example former convicts, alcoholics, drug addicts, mental patients, etc.). 
    "Group home for minors" means a residential facility for five or more persons under eighteen (18) years of age who, for various reasons, cannot reside in their natural home and where twenty-four (24) hour adult care, supervision and consultation shall exist. 
    Guest, Permanent. "Permanent guest" means a person who occupies or has the right to occupy a residence or dwelling accommodation for a period of thirty (30) days or more. 
    "Height of structure other than a building" means the vertical distance from the average ground level at the base of the structure to the highest part thereof. 
    "Home occupation" means any gainful occupation or profession conducted in a dwelling by a member of the immediate family residing on the premises. 
    "Hotel" means a building containing lodging rooms, a common entrance and lobby, halls and stairways, and lodging rooms which do not have doorway openings directly to the outdoors except for emergencies; and where more than fifty (50) percent of the lodging rooms are for rent, with or without meals, to transient guests for a continuous period of less than thirty (30) days. 
    Hotel, Apartment. "Apartment hotel" means a hotel, except more than fifty (50) percent of the lodging rooms are available for permanent guests. 
    "Junkyard" means an open area where waste, used or secondhand materials are bought, sold, exchanged, stored, baled, packed, disassembled or handled, including, but not limited to, scrap iron and other metals, paper, rags, rubber tires and bottles. A "junkyard" includes an auto wrecking yard, but does not include uses carried on entirely within enclosed buildings, nor does it include an establishment engaged only in the processing of scrap metal to be sold for the manufacture of steel. 
    "Laboratory" means a building, or group of buildings, in which are located facilities for scientific research, investigation, testing or experimentation, but not facilities for the manufacture or sale of products, except as incidental to the main purpose of the laboratory. 
    "Infrastructure" means public facilities and services needed to sustain industry, residential, commercial and all other land use activities. 
    "Landscaping" means the bringing of the soil surface to a smooth finished grade, installing sufficient trees, shrubs, ground cover and grass to soften building lines, provide shade and generally produce a pleasing visual effect of the premises. 
    "Loading areas" means an off-street space or berth used for the loading or unloading or cargo, products or materials from vehicles. 
    "Lodging room" means a room rented as sleeping and living quarters, but without cooking facilities, and with or without an individual bathroom. In a suite of rooms, each room shall be counted as one lodging room. 
    "Lot" means a parcel of land with boundaries designated by plat, subdivision, or otherwise permitted by law, to be separately owned, used, developed, or built upon. 
    "Lot area" means the area of a horizontal plane bounded by the vertical planes through front, side and rear lot lines. 
    Lot, Corner. "Corner lot" means a lot situated at the junction of, and abutting on two or more intersecting streets. A corner lot shall be deemed to front on that street on which it has its least dimension unless otherwise specified by the building inspector. 
    "Lot depth" means the average horizontal distance between the front lot line and the rear lot line of a lot measured within the lot boundaries. 
    "Lot line" means a property boundary line of any lot. 
    Lot Line, Front. "Front lot line" means the boundary line between a lot and the street that provides primary access to the lot. 
    Lot Line, Rear. "Rear lot line" means any lot line that is not a front or side lot line. 
    Lot Line, Side. "Side lot line" means any boundary of a lot which intersects with a front lot line. 
    Lot, Reversed Corner. "Reversed corner lot" means a corner lot where the side lot line adjoining a street is substantially a continuation of the front lot line of the first lot to its rear. 
    Lot, Through. "Through lot" means an interior lot having frontage on two streets. 
    "Lot width" means the horizontal distance between side lot lines, measured at the front building line. 
    "Medical marijuana cultivation facility" means a facility licensed by the State of Missouri to acquire, cultivate, process, store, transport, and sell marijuana to a medical marijuana dispensary facility, medical marijuana testing facility, or a medical marijuana infused products manufacturing facility. 
    "Medical marijuana dispensary facility" means a facility licensed by the State of Missouri to acquire, store, sell, transport, and deliver marijuana, marijuana-infused products, and drug paraphernalia used to administer marijuana to a qualifying patient, a primary caregiver, another licensed dispensary facility, a licensed testing facility, or a licensed manufacturing facility. 
    "Medical marijuana infused products manufacturing facility" means a facility licensed by the State of Missouri to acquire, store, manufacture, transport, and sell marijuana-infused products to a medical marijuana dispensary facility, a medical marijuana testing facility, or to another medical marijuana-infused products manufacturing facility. 
    "Medical marijuana testing facility" means a facility certified by the State of Missouri to acquire, test, certify, and transport marijuana. 
    "Mobile home" means a residential structure, assembled in total or in not more than three sections at a factory, and transported over the road on its own wheel carriage to a destination, and which may be moved from one destination to another. 
    "Mobile home park" means a tract of land having a system of utilities including water supply, sanitary sewers, power and telephone, which utilities are available to mobile homes which may be placed on the property on a temporary or permanent basis for residential purposes. 
    "Motel" or "motor hotel" means a building containing lodging rooms having adjoining individual bathrooms, and used primarily by transient guests traveling by automobile. 
    "Motor freight terminal" means a building or premises in which freight is received or dispatched by motor vehicle. 
    "Motor vehicle" means any self-propelled vehicle designed primarily for transportation of persons or goods along public streets or alleys, or other public ways. 
    "Nameplate" means a sign indicating the name and address of a building, or the name of an occupant thereof and/or the practice of a permitted occupation therein. 
    "Noxious matter" means material which is capable of causing injury or physical discomfort to living organisms by chemical reaction or is capable of causing detrimental effects upon the health or the psychological, social or economic well-being of human beings. 
    "Nursing home" means a residential establishment for the care of persons requiring a moderate level of health care. 
    "Open sales lots" means any land used or occupied for the purpose of displaying, buying or selling merchandise, passenger cars, trucks, motor scooters, motorcycles, boats and monuments, or for the storing of same prior to sale. 
    "Off-street parking" means a temporary storage area for a motor vehicle that is directly accessible to an access aisle and that is not located on a dedicated street right-of-way. 
    "Parcel" means a contiguous lot or tract of land owned and recorded as the property of the same persons or controlled by a single entity. 
    "Particulate matter" means material which is suspended in or discharged into the atmosphere in finely divided form as a liquid or solid at atmospheric temperature and pressure. 
    "Party wall" means a wall which is common to but divides contiguous buildings; such a wall contains no openings and extends from its footing below the finished ground grade to the height of the exterior surface of the roof. 
    "Pay day lenders," see car title lenders. 
    "Pawn Shop" means an establishment engaged in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or the purchase of tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased for a fixed price within a fixed period of time. 
    "Performance standard" means a criterion to control noise, odor, smoke, toxic or noxious matter, vibration, fire and explosive hazards or glare, heat or other effects generated by or inherent in uses of land or buildings. 
    "Permit" means written governmental permission issued by an authorized official, empowering the holder thereof to do some act not forbidden by law but not allowed without such authorization.
