    "Permitted use" means any use allowed in a zoning district and subject to the restrictions applicable to that zoning district. 
    "Permittee" means any person to whom a permit is issued. 
    "Planned unit development (PUD)" means a zoning district that is based on a comprehensive design plan that addresses the entire complex of land and uses on a site as a single project; and functions as a substitute for the property development regulations of the underlying zoning. 
    "Planning and zoning commission" or "planning commission" means the duly appointed advisory board having duties and jurisdiction in the City of North Kansas City as set out in Missouri Statutes and local ordinances, and which board may be referred to in this title as "planning commission" or "commission." 
    "Refuse" means all waste products resulting from human habitation or the conduct of business or industry, except sewage. 
    "Rights-of-way" means a strip of land acquired by reservation, dedication, forced dedication, prescription, or condemnation and intended to be occupied by a road, crosswalk, railroad, electric transmission lines, oil or gas pipeline, water line, sanitary storm sewer, and other similar uses or the right to pass over the property of another. 
    "Right-of-way line" means the lines that forms the boundaries of a right-of-way. 
    "Ringelmann chart" means a chart which is described in the U.S. Bureau of Mines Information Circular 6888, and on which are illustrated graduated shades of gray for use in estimating the light-obscuring capacity of smoke. 
    "Rooming house" means a building, or portion thereof, containing lodging rooms which accommodate persons who are not members of the keeper's family, and where lodging rooms or meals, or both, are provided for compensation. 
    "Satellite dish" means a parabolic or dish-shaped antenna or any other apparatus or device that is designed for the purpose of receiving radio waves. 
    "Screening" means a structure erected or vegetation planted as a screen designed to conceal materials and operations conducted behind it. 
    "Setback line" means a line parallel to the respective lot line and internal to the lot at a distance specified in the zoning district regulations, within such area no building or structure may be constructed, except as specifically provided by this title. 
    Setback Line, Front. "Front setback line" means the setback line parallel to the front lot line and extending from side lot line to side lot line. 
    Setback Line, Rear. "Rear setback line" means the setback line parallel to the rear lot line and extending from side lot line to side lot line. 
    Setback Line, Side. "Side setback line" means the setback line parallel to any side lot line and extending from front setback line to rear setback line. 
    "Site plan" means the development plan for one or more lots on which is shown the existing and proposed conditions of the lot, including the topography, vegetation, drainage, flood plains, wetlands and waterways; landscaping and open spaces; walkways; means of ingress and egress; circulation; utility services; structures and buildings; signs and lighting; berms, buffers, and screening devices; surrounding development; and any other information that reasonably may be required in order that an informed decision can be made by the approving authority. 
    Smoke Units, Number of. "Number of smoke units" means the number obtained by multiplying the smoke density in Ringelmann numbers by the time of emission in minutes. For the purpose of this calculation, a Ringelmann density reading is made at least once every minute during the period of observation; each reading is then multiplied by the time in minutes during which it is observed; the various products are then added together to give the total number of smoke units observed during the total period under observation. 
    "Sound level meter" means an instrument standardized by the American Standards Association for measurement of the intensity of sound. 
    "Storage." The word "storage," "stored" or "store" when used in this title means the keeping of any goods, junk, material, merchandise, products, vehicles or equipment in the same place for more than twenty-four (24) hours. 
    "Story" means that portion of a building included between the surface of any floor and the floor or the ceiling next above. A basement shall be counted as a story and a cellar shall not be counted as a story. 
    Story, Half. "Half story" means a space under a sloping roof which has the line of intersection of roof decking and wall not more than three feet above the top floor level and in which space not more than sixty (60) percent of the floor area is completed for principal or accessory use. 
    "Street" means a right-of-way which affords a primary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Structural alteration" means any change, other than incidental repairs, in the supporting members of a building or structure such as bearing walls or partitions, columns, beams or girders. 
    "Structure" means anything erected, the use of which requires more or less permanent location on, above or below the ground, or attached to something having permanent location on the ground. 
    "Toxic material" means a substance (liquid, solid or gaseous) which by reason of an inherent deleterious property when emitted in any amount is injurious to living organisms of plants, animals and human beings. 
    "Trailer" means a vehicle, other than a mobile home, equipped with wheels and normally towed over the road behind a motor vehicle. 
    Trailer, Advertising. "Advertising trailer" means a trailer, as defined in this section, but carrying, or having attached thereto, a sign, billboard or other media for advertising being the prime purpose and use of the trailer. 
    Trailer, Hauling. "Hauling trailer" means a trailer, as defined in this section, and designed and normally used for over-the-road transportation of belongings, equipment, merchandise, livestock and other objects, but not equipped for human habitation. 
    Travel Trailer or Recreation Vehicle. "Travel trailer" or "recreation vehicle" means a portable structure mounted on wheels or on a motorized chassis, including converted buses, and which is normally used as sleeping quarters and shelter while traveling but not as a dwelling. 
    "Treatment facility for drug and alcohol abuse" means any facility which is certified by the state of Missouri Division of Alcohol and Drug Abuse of the Department of Mental Health for such treatment. 
    "Use" means the purpose or activity for which the land or building thereon is designed, arranged or intended, or for which it is occupied or maintained. 
    Use, Accessory. "Accessory use" means a subordinate use which is clearly and customarily incidental to the principal use of a building or premises, and which is located on the same lot as the principal building or use. 
    Use, Conditional. "Conditional use" means a building, structure or use, the location and operation of which is established or allowed by procedures set out in Chapter 17.84. 
    Use, Nonconforming. "Nonconforming use" means any use of a building or premises which on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Title 17 does not, even though lawfully established, comply with all the applicable use regulations as set forth in this title for the zoning district in which such building or premises is located. 
    Use, Permitted. "Permitted use" means any building, structure or use which, on the effective date of this title, complies with the applicable regulations governing permitted uses of the zoning district in which such building, structure or use is located. 
    Use, Principal. "Principal use" means the main use of land or building as distinguished from a subordinate or accessory use. 
    "Variance" means a variation or relief from a specific requirement in this title as applied to a specific property and as approved by the board of adjustment. 
    "Yard" means an open space on a lot which is generally unoccupied and unobstructed from ground level to the sky, except as otherwise permitted in this title. A yard extends along a lot line and at right angles to such line to a depth or width specified in the yard regulations for the district in which such lot is located. 
    Yard, Front. "Front yard" means a yard across the full width of the lot and extending back from the front lot line to the front line of the main building. 
    Yard, Rear. "Rear yard" means the portion of the yard on the same lot with the principal building and located between the rear line of the building and the rear lot line and extending for the full width of the lot; provided, that in those locations where an alley or a railroad lead track right-of-way is platted in the rear of the lots, one-half of the width of the platted alley or such right-of-way may be included in the rear yard requirements. 
    Yard, Side. "Side yard" means a yard extending along a side lot line between the front and rear yards. 
    "Zero lot line home" means a single family attached dwelling located on a lot in such a manner that one or more of the building's sides rest directly on the lot line. 
    "Zoning administrator" means the individual staff member directed by the city council to administer the zoning ordinance or his/her designee. 
    "Zoning district map" means the map or maps that are part of the zoning ordinance and delineate the boundaries of zone districts. 
(Ord. 7908 § 1, 2004; Ord. 7621 § 1, 2002; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8418, § 2, 8-25-2009; Ord. No. 8447, § 1, 2-23-2010; Ord. No. 9183, § 1, 3-19-2019) 
Chapter 17.12 - ZONING DISTRICTS DESIGNATED AND REGULATION OF USES[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8419, § 3, adopted August 25, 2009, amended the title of Chapter 17.12 to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Ch. 17.12 was entitled, "Zoning Districts Designated." See also the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 

17.12.010 - Establishment of districts. 
    In order to carry out the purposes and provisions of this title, the City of North Kansas City, Missouri, is divided into the following districts: 
A.  District P-C public/civic district; 
B.  District R-1A low density single-family residential district; 
C.  District R-1B high density single-family residential district; 
D.  District R-2 two-family residential district; 
E.  District R-3 cluster or garden-type residential district; 
F.  District R-4 medium density apartment district; 
G.  District R-5 high density apartment district; 
H.  District C-0 non-retail business district; 
I.  District C-1 local business district; 
J.  District C-2 retail business district; 
K.  District C-3 service business district; 
L.  District M-1 limited industrial district: 
M.  District M-2 general industrial district; 
N.  District G-1 gaming and amusement district; 
O.  Planned unit development. 
(Ord. 8015 § 2, 2005; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
17.12.020 - Map. 
    The location and boundaries of the districts established by the ordinance codified in this title are set forth on the "zoning district map," which is made a part of this title. The said map, together with everything shown thereon and all amendments thereto, shall be as much a part of this title as though fully set forth and described herein. The map shall be filed with the office of the city clerk and copies thereof in the office of the building inspector, and shall be open to public reference at all times during which those offices are open. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.12.030 - Boundaries of districts. 
    When uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of the various districts as shown on the zoning district map, the following rules shall apply: 
A.  District boundary lines are either the center lines of railroads, or the right-of-way lines of highways, streets, alleys, tract or lot lines, or such lines extended, unless otherwise indicated. 
B.  In areas not subdivided into lots and blocks, wherever a district is indicated as a strip adjacent to and paralleling a street, highway or railroad, the depth of such strips shall be in accordance with dimensions shown on the maps measured at right angles from the property line of a street, highway or railroad, and the length of frontage shall be in accordance with dimensions shown on the map from the property lines of streets, highways or railroad rights-of-way unless otherwise indicated. 
C.  Where a district boundary line divides a lot in single ownership, the regulations for either portion of the lot may, in the owner's discretion, extend over the entire lot, but not more than twenty-five (25) feet beyond the mapped boundary line of the district. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.12.040 - Customary utility uses; exceptions. 
    The following public utility uses are permitted in any district if customarily located and compatible in such district: poles, wires, cables, conduits, vaults, laterals, pipes, mains, valves or any other similar distributing equipment, provided that any wireless communication facilities shall be permitted only as provided in Section 17.84.030 of this Code. Installation, location and design shall conform with applicable federal, state and local government rules and regulations. Wireless facilities shall be governed by Section 17.84.030 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 8944, § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8944, § 2, adopted Sept. 20, 2016, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
17.12.050 - Regulation of uses. 
A.  Building on Lot. In single-family residence districts, every single family dwelling hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be located on a lot, and there shall not be more than one principal building on one lot except as may be approved in the planned zoning process. In any nonresidential district, any business must have a building or structure from which to conduct business, except as may be otherwise authorized by other procedures within this title. 
B.  Allowable Use of Land or Buildings. When a use is not specifically listed as a permitted use, or cannot be readily classified, the director of community development shall determine the appropriate district or districts where such use shall be allowed based on a comparison of other uses that most closely resemble the use in question. The following uses of land or buildings are allowed in the districts indicated on the zoning district map and under the conditions specified in this Title 17. 
1.  Uses lawfully established on the effective date of this title: 
2.  Permitted uses as designated in Chapters 17.16 through 17.88, inclusive. 
C.  Prohibited Use of Land or Buildings. No building or tract of land shall be devoted to any use other than one which is specified as a permitted use, accessory use or conditional use in Chapters 17.16 through 17.88, inclusive. However, where a building permit for a building or structure has been issued in accordance with law, prior to the effective date of this title, and where construction has been begun within six months of such effective date, and is being diligently prosecuted to completion, said building or structure may be completed in accordance with approved plans on the basis of which the building permit was issued; and further may, upon completion, be occupied under a certificate of occupancy by the use originally designated, subject to the provisions of this title. 
D.  Prohibited Uses: 
1.  No lot, parcel or tract of land shall be used, and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or remodeled for any of the following uses: abattoirs; animal crematories; composting, in fertilizer manufacture; dumping, reduction or incineration of garbage, dead animals, offal or refuse; storage, curing or tanning of raw hides or skins; refining of petroleum or coal oil; salt works, stockyards or slaughter of animals or fowl; asphalt manufacture or refining, creosote manufacture or treatment; tar distillation; distillation of bones, fat rendering, glue manufacture. 
2.  No activities involving the storage, utilization or manufacture of materials or products which decompose by detonation shall be permitted, except such as are specifically licensed by the city. Such materials shall include but shall not be confined to all primary explosives such as lead oxide, lead styphnate, fulminates and tetracene; all high explosives such as TNT, RDX, HMX, PETN and picric acid, propellants and components thereof such as cellulose nitrate of a nitrogen content of twelve and one-half (121/2) percent or greater, black powder, boron hydrides, hydrazine and its derivatives; pyrotechnics and fireworks such as magnesium powder, potassium chlorate, and potassium nitrate; blasting explosives such as dynamite and nitroglycerine, unstable organic compounds such as acetylides, tetrazoles, perchloric acid; perchlorates, chlorates, hyrdrogen peroxide in concentrations greater than thirty-five (35) percent; and nuclear fuels, fissionable materials and products and reactor elements such as uranium 235 and plutonium 239. 
(Ord. No. 8418, § 4, 8-25-2009; Ord. No. 8720, § 1, 11-19-2013) 
Chapter 17.14 - P-C, PUBLIC/CIVIC DISTRICT 

17.14.005 - Statement of purpose. 
    The P-C public/civic district is established for the purposes of supporting civic and institutional uses that serve as centers of community activity. These civic and institutional uses provide public amenities and are the focus of significant public investment. 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
17.14.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district P-C, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Churches/places of worship; 
B.  Publicly owned and operated community buildings, public museums, public libraries; 
C.  Government offices; 
D.  Parks and playgrounds, including recreation or services buildings and swimming pools, which are owned or operated by a governmental agency; 
E.  Public schools, elementary and high, and private schools with curriculum equivalent to that of a public elementary or high school and institutions of higher learning, including stadiums and dormitories in conjunction, if located on the campus; 
F.  Golf courses and clubhouses appurtenant thereto (except miniature golf courses, driving ranges and other similar activities operated as a business); 
G.  Railroad rights-of-way, not including railroad yards; 
H.  Public and private utility facilities; 
I.  Passive open space. 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
17.14.020 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district P-C, the height of buildings and the minimum dimension of lots and yards shall be as designated in Sections 17.14.030 through 17.14.040. See Chapter 17.72 for exceptions. 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
17.14.030 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed three stories in height. 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
17.14.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yards. No front yard is required. 
B.  Side Yards. No side yard is required, except that where a side line of a lot in this district abuts the side line of a lot in a district R-1A to C-0, inclusive, a side yard shall then be provided the same as required in the abutting district. 
C.  Rear Yards. No rear yard is required, except that where the rear line of a lot in this district abuts land in a district R-1A to C-0, inclusive, a rear yard of not less than ten (10) feet shall then be provided in this district. 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
17.14.050 - Design guidelines. 
    All applications for building or land use permits in the P-C district shall be evaluated to determine that it conforms to or enhances the character of the district and the community at large. When reviewing a plan, the planning commission shall determine the compatibility of the proposed development with adjacent buildings, uses, and neighborhoods. The following criteria shall be used to determine if the development is appropriate for the site on which it is proposed: 
A.  Exterior public spaces, such as courtyards or plazas, are encouraged to enhance pedestrian activity. 
B.  The dominant materials for new construction or additions within the public/civic district shall be brick and/or stone. 
C.  Buildings shall maintain a pedestrian orientation at the street level. Buildings shall be located to front toward public streets. Buildings should not be oriented toward a parking lot. 
D.  Parking lots serving buildings should be located in the rear or on the sides of buildings. 
E.  Building entrances shall be defined and articulated by architectural elements such as lintels, pediments, pilasters, columns, overhangs, or other elements as appropriate. 
F.  Where sites are located at the termination of a street, improvements should be designed so that significant architectural features, public art, or landscaping features are located at the termination of the street. 
    In the review and approval process, the design guidelines listed above will be considered as requirements unless an acceptable alternative design can be shown by the applicant to better meet the intent of the guidelines as interpreted by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
17.14.060 - Approval of development. 
    Before beginning any project requiring a building or land use permit in the P-C district, an applicant shall schedule a pre-application meeting with city staff to discuss the proposed project and the requirements for review and approval. 
    Prior to the commencement of exterior structural alteration or construction of any structure within the district for any of the uses provided for above, a site plan shall be submitted to and approved by the planning commission. The site plan shall conform with the standards of the site plan review section (Section 17.96.010) of the zoning chapter. 
    In addition to the requirements of Section 17.96.010, the site plan shall also include the following information: 
A.  Location and use of all existing and proposed buildings which are the subject of the application, including public areas and open spaces. 
B.  Building elevation drawings and all dimensions of height and floor area, showing the location of all exterior entrances. 
C.  Design details (materials and colors) to make new construction compatible with existing structures. 
(Ord. No. 8737, § 2, 2-18-2014) 
Chapter 17.16 - R-1A, LOW DENSITY SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.16.010 - Permitted use. 
    In district R-1A, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Dwellings, one-family; 
B.  Churches/places of worship and schools and publicly owned and operated community buildings, public museums, public libraries; provided preliminary development plans and final plans shall be approved by the planning commission prior to the issuance of building permits. Preliminary plans submitted shall include a site plan, building floor plan and elevation sketches. Final plans submitted shall include complete working drawings. Approval or disapproval by the planning commission shall be based upon the following: 
1.  The capability of the site to accommodate the building parking and drives per Chapter 17.76, with reasonable open space and safe and easy ingress and egress, 
2.  A reasonable degree of harmony will prevail between the architectural quality of the proposed public building or church and the surrounding neighborhood; 
C.  Parks and playgrounds, including recreation or service buildings and swimming pools, which are owned or operated by a governmental agency; 
D.  Public schools, elementary and high, and private schools with curriculum equivalent to that of a public elementary or high school and institutions of higher learning, including stadiums and dormitories in conjunction, if located on the campus; 
E.  Golf courses and clubhouses appurtenant thereto (except miniature golf courses, driving ranges and other similar activities operated as a business); 
F.  Railroad rights-of-way, not including railroad yards; 
G.  Child care facility as an accessory use to residential dwellings, churches and schools subject to the performance standards and requirements outlined in this chapter for accessory uses and home occupations, and pursuant to meeting the applicable regulations for such uses as provided in Chapter 210 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri and/or Title 19, CSR, Division 40, Chapter 61, rules of the Department of Health. Child care facilities for seven or more children shall be regulated by Chapter 17.84 of this code. 
(Ord. 8293 § 6, 2008; Ord. 8198 § 1, 2006: Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.16.020 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district R-IA the height of buildings, the minimum dimension of lots and yards, and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as designated in Sections 17.16.030 through 17.16.070. 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 2, 11-19-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8720, § 2, adopted Nov. 19, 2013, repealed former § 17.16.020, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 7500, § 1, 2002. 
17.16.030 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed two and one-half stories or thirty-five (35) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.16.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yards. Any building hereafter constructed shall provide for a front yard, the minimum depth of which shall be thirty (30) feet. 
B.  Side Yards. There shall be a side yard on each side of the dwelling the total of which side yards shall be not less than twenty (20) percent of the width of the lot, and no side yard shall be less than seven feet and need not be more than fifteen (15) feet. Buildings on corner lots shall provide a side yard on the street side of not less than fifteen (15) feet. 
C.  Rear Yards. The depth of the rear yard shall be at least twenty-five (25) feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.16.050 - Lot area per family. 
    Every dwelling hereafter erected, moved or altered shall provide a lot area of not less than eight thousand (8,000) square feet per family; provided, that where a lot has less area than herein required in separate ownership at the time of the passage of this title, this regulation shall not prohibit the erection of a one-family dwelling. Where a public or community sewer is not available and in use for the disposal of all sanitary sewage, only a single-family dwelling may be constructed and the minimum lot area therefore shall be fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.16.060 - Floor area and lot size. 
    No single-family dwelling shall be constructed, reconstructed, altered or moved unless it contains a total floor area, finished for living purposes, of not less than one thousand (1,000) square feet. The minimum lot width in this district shall be seventy (70) feet; provided, that where a lot has less width than herein required in separate ownership at the time of the passage of this title, this regulation shall not prohibit the erection of a single-family dwelling. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.20 - R-1B, HIGH DENSITY SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.20.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district R-1B, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district R-1A. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.20.020 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district R-1B the height of buildings, the minimum dimension of lots and yards and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.20.030 through 17.20.070. For exceptions, see Chapter 17.72. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.20.030 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed two and one-half stories or thirty-five (35) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.20.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yards. Any building hereafter constructed shall provide a front yard the minimum depth of which shall be twenty (20) feet. 
B.  Side Yards and Distance Between Buildings. There shall be a side yard on each side of the residential building the total of which side yards shall be not less than nine feet and no side yard shall be less than three feet. Buildings on corner lots shall provide a side yard on the street side of not less than eight feet. In no case shall a residential building be constructed closer than six feet to a building on an adjoining lot. 
C.  Rear Yards. The depth of a rear yard shall be at least twenty (20) feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.20.050 - Lot area per family. 
    Every dwelling hereafter constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered shall provide a lot area of not less than three thousand eight hundred fifty (3,850) square feet per family. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.20.060 - Floor area and lot size. 
    Every dwelling hereafter constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered shall contain a total floor area, finished for living purposes, of not less than one thousand (1,000) square feet. The minimum lot width in this district shall be thirty-five (35) feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.24 - R-2, TWO-FAMILY AND ROOMING HOUSE RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.24.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district R-2, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district R-1B; 
B.  Dwellings, two-family, commonly referred to as duplexes. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.24.020 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district R-2 the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.24.030 through 17.24.070. For exceptions, see Chapter 17.72. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.24.030 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed two and one-half stories or thirty-five (35) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.24.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yards. Any building hereafter constructed shall provide for a front yard, the minimum depth of which shall be at least thirty (30) feet. 
B.  Side Yards. There shall be a side yard on each side of the building, the total of which side yards shall be not less than twelve (12) feet and no side yard shall be less than four feet. Buildings on corner lots shall provide a side yard on the street side of not less than ten (10) feet. 
C.  Rear Yards. The depth of the rear yard shall be at least twenty (20) feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.24.050 - Lot area per family. 
    Every dwelling hereafter erected, moved or altered shall provide a lot area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet per family for each one-family dwelling, or three thousand (3,000) feet per family per two-family dwelling. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.24.060 - Lot size. 
    The width of the lot shall be at least fifty (50) feet. 
(Ord. 8252 § 1 (part), 2007) 
17.24.065 - Conversion of two-family dwellings to individually owned units 
    Two-family dwellings which otherwise comply with the codes and ordinances of the city may be divided at the party wall as to ownership and owned as separate dwelling units by separate owners and such ownership shall not constitute violation of the lot and yard requirements of this title. However, for such conversions of two-family dwellings to individually owned units it is required that: 
A.  All utilities must be modified as needed to individually serve each lot without needing access from an adjoining lot. 
B.  Driveways intended to be shared by adjoining lots must provide for shared access easements. 
C.  Common attics and crawl spaces will be divided at the party wall consistent with all building code requirements. 
D.  Subdivision plats required for the authorization of the division of such a lot must include plat notes stating: 
1.  That exterior siding and roofing materials will be maintained as a single building with the same material, style and color scheme; and 
2.  The owners must each obtain written permission from the other before commencing any exterior alterations or improvements to the siding or roofing materials. 
(Ord. 8252 § 1 (part), 2007) 
Chapter 17.28 - R-3, CLUSTER OR GARDEN-TYPE RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.28.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district R-3, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district R-1A; 
B.  Garden apartment buildings and townhouses; 
C.  Innovative housing techniques such as patio houses, zero lot line homes and mixed housing systems. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.28.020 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district R-3 the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards, the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.28.040 through 17.28.060. For exceptions, see Chapter 17.72. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.28.030 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed three stories in height; except, that on land having a natural slope of seven feet or more vertical change in one hundred (100) feet horizontal distance, buildings containing four stories to be occupied for residential purposes in the downhill portion may be approved by the planning commission upon submittal of preliminary site and building plans. Such approval shall be given only after the commission satisfies itself that adequate natural light and air will be available to all dwelling units and that no occupant shall be required to traverse more than one and one-half stories of stairs from the building entrance to the highest or lowest occupied story. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.28.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yards. No building shall be located closer than thirty (30) feet to a public street. 
B.  Side and Rear Yards. No building shall be located closer than fifteen (15) feet to a project property line, other than a street line. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.28.050 - Lot area per family. 
    The minimum lot area shall be three thousand five hundred (3,500) square feet per family. Cluster housing may not be constructed where adequate sanitary sewers are not available for connection thereto. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.28.070 - Planned zoning required. 
    No residential building or group of buildings shall be constructed in this district until said property is zoned under the planned zoning procedures set out in Chapters 17.70 and 17.96. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8418, § 5, 8-25-2009) 
Chapter 17.32 - R-4, MEDIUM DENSITY APARTMENT DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.32.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district R-4, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed or altered except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Single-family dwellings under the regulations of district R-1 A; 
B.  Two-family dwellings under the regulations of district R-2; 
C.  Medium-density apartment buildings; 
D.  Housing of a single or multifamily type for senior citizens; 
E.  Rooming houses; 
F.  Churches/places of worship. 
(Ord. 8015 § 3, 2005; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.32.020 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district R-4, the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards, and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.32.030 through 17.32.060. See Chapter 17.72 for exceptions. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.32.030 - Height. 
    Buildings and structures shall not exceed four stories; provided, all buildings exceeding two and one-half stories shall be equipped with elevators. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.32.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yard. Any building hereafter constructed shall provide for a front yard the minimum depth of which shall be at least twenty (20) feet. 
B.  Side Yards. There shall be a side yard on each side of the building of not less than eight feet. Not less than fifteen (15) feet shall be provided on the street side of a comer lot. 
C.  Rear Yard. The depth of the rear yard shall be not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.32.050 - Lot area per family. 
    Every medium density apartment house and every senior citizens' dwelling hereafter constructed shall provide a lot area per unit of not less than the following: 
4-bedroom unit 2,000 square feet 3-bedroom unit 1,700 square feet 2-bedroom unit 1,400 square feet 1-bedroom unit 1,100 square feet  
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.32.060 - Regulations for rooming houses. 
    Rooming houses shall be subject to the following: 
A.  Not less than two hundred (200) square feet of living floor area for each occupant; 
B.  Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant shall have a minimum floor area of eighty (80) square feet; every room occupied for sleeping purposes by two occupants shall have a minimum floor area of one hundred (100) square feet, and every room occupied for sleeping by three occupants, which shall be maximum, shall have a minimum floor area of one hundred fifty (150) square feet; 
C.  Full compliance with Ordinance 4013 of the City of North Kansas City, that being the minimum structures and standards ordinance; 
D.  No building except the principal residence on the lot shall be used for human occupancy; 
E.  Each rooming house shall be inspected by the building inspector not less than once annually and certified as to compliance with all applicable regulations. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.36 - R-5, HIGH DENSITY APARTMENT DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.36.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district R-5, no building, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed or altered except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Single-family dwellings under the regulations of district R-1 A; 
B.  Two-family dwellings under the regulations of district R-2; 
C.  Medium rise apartment buildings under the regulations of district R-4; 
D.  High density apartment buildings; 
E.  Churches/places of worship. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.36.020 - Height and area regulations generally. 
    In district R-5, the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.36.030 through 17.36.050. See Chapter 17.72 exceptions. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.36.030 - Height. 
    No maximum or minimum height required except as governed by yard requirements provided all buildings exceeding two and one-half stories shall have elevators. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.36.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yard. Any building hereafter constructed shall provide for a front yard the minimum depth of which shall be thirty (30) feet plus three feet for each story in excess of four. 
B.  Side Yards. There shall be a side yard on each side of a building of not less than ten (10) feet for one-, two-, three- and four-story buildings and ten (10) feet plus three feet for each story in excess of four. Not less than fifteen (15) feet shall be provided on the street side of a corner lot. 
C.  Rear Yard. The depth of the rear yard shall be at least thirty (30) feet for buildings up to four stories and at least the height of the building for buildings in excess of four stories. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.36.050 - Lot area per family. 
    Every high density apartment house hereafter constructed shall provide a lot area of not less than eight hundred (800) square feet per dwelling unit. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.40 - C-0, NON-RETAIL BUSINESS DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.40.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district C-0, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district R-3; 
B.  Office buildings to be used only for the administrative functions of companies, corporations, social or philanthropic organizations or societies; 
C.  Other offices limited to the following: 
1.  Accountants, 
2.  Architects, 
3.  Brokers and accountants, 
4.  Engineers, 
5.  Dentists, 
6.  Lawyers, 
7.  Physicians, osteopaths, chiropractors, 
8.  Real estate and insurance. 
D.  Mortuaries; 
E.  Hospitals, clinics, laboratories and other treatment and diagnostic facilities for the medical arts for humans only; 
F.  Child day care center pursuant to meeting the applicable performance standards and requirements of Chapter 210 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri and/or Title 19, CSR, Division 40, Chapter 61 rules of the Department of Health. 
G.  Reserved. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 3, 11-19-2013) 
17.40.015 - Performance standards. 
    No merchandise shall be handled or displayed except inside buildings and no equipment or vehicles other than motor messenger cars shall be stored outside a building in this district for more than twenty-four hours in a thirty-day period. 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 4, 11-19-2013) 
17.40.020 - Height and area regulations generally. 
    In district C-0, the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards, and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows; provided, residential uses in this district shall be subject to those regulations of the district in which the specific residential use is enumerated. For exception see Chapter 17.72. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.40.030 - Height. 
    No building or structure shall exceed three stories in height for property less than five acres. No building or structure shall exceed one hundred eighty (180) feet in height for property greater than or equal to five acres. 
(Ord. 7690 § 1, 2003: Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.40.040 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yard. A front yard of not less than thirty (30) feet shall be provided. 
B.  Side Yards. There shall be a side yard on each side of a building of not less than seven feet for one-story buildings, ten (10) feet for two-story buildings and twenty (20) feet for two-and-one-half and three-story buildings. Not less than fifteen (15) feet shall be provided on the street side of a comer lot. 
C.  Rear Yard. The depth of the rear yard shall be at least thirty (30) feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.40.050 - Requirements for dwelling. 
    See corresponding district where use is enumerated. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.44 - C-1, LOCAL BUSINESS DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.44.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district C-1, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district C-0; 
B.  Shops and stores for sale at retail of foods and beverages for human consumption; soft goods such as clothing and shoes, drugs and cosmetics; furniture and appliances; printed materials; notions; hardware and paint; kitchenware; toys and sporting goods; jewelry, gifts and novelties, flowers; tobacco products; photographic equipment; antiques; artist and hobby supplies; music supplies and medical supplies; bicycles; 
C.  Services such as professional offices, banks and savings and loan associations, insurance, barber and beauty shops, schools, optical shops, seamstress and tailoring, dry cleaning and laundry pickup or coin-operated and dry cleaning operations classed as low hazard in the applicable codes, eating establishments, interior decorators, photographers, shoe repairs, clinics, small animal hospitals; 
D.  Offices of all types, including post offices, public or privately owned utilities offices. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.44.020 - Performance standards. 
    The following standards shall not be exceeded by any use in this district: 
A.  No wholesale sales shall be conducted. 
B.  No merchandise or equipment shall be stored or displayed outside a building. 
C.  All products shall be sold and all services rendered inside a building, except that banks and savings and loans establishments may have drive-in or walkup service. 
D.  No noise, smoke, radiation, vibration or concussion, heat or glare shall be produced that is perceptible outside a building and no dust, fly ash or gas that is toxic, caustic or obviously injurious to humans or property shall be produced. 
E.  Alcoholic beverages shall not be sold for consumption on the premises. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.44.030 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district C-1, the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.44.040 and 17.44.050. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.44.040 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed two stories; except, that in a district CP-1, no building or structure shall exceed one hundred forty-four (144) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.44.050 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yard. A front yard of not less than fifteen (15) feet shall be provided for one- and two-story buildings, and a front yard of not less than fifteen (15) feet plus three feet for each story over two shall be provided for buildings in excess of two stories in district CP-1. 
B.  Side Yards. For one and two story buildings no side yard is required; except, that where a side line of a lot in this district abuts the side line of a lot in a district R-1A to C-0 inclusive, a side yard shall then be provided the same as required in the district it abuts. A side yard of fifteen (15) feet shall also be provided on the street side of a comer lot containing a one or two story building. Buildings in district CP-1 in excess of two stories shall provide a side yard on the street side of a comer lot at least fifteen (15) feet plus three feet for each story over two. 
C.  Rear Yard. No rear yard is required; except, that where a rear line of a lot in this district abuts upon land in a district R-1A to C-0 inclusive a rear yard of not less than ten (10) feet shall then be provided in this district 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.44.060 - Requirements for dwellings. 
    See corresponding district where use is enumerated. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.44.080 - Conversion of buildings. 
    No building that was designed and constructed as a residential building shall be converted for use as an office building or other business purpose unless the following conditions are met: 
A.  Setbacks comply with those required in this district; 
B.  All off-street parking required by this title or by the proposed use of the premises can be accommodated in the side or rear yard and the yards have access and dimensions to permit the full and safe use thereof; 
C.  The building is made to comply with all building and other code requirements; 
D.  A site plan depicting the above requirements plus any changes to the exterior of the building shall be prepared by a professional architect, registered in the state, and submitted for review and approval by the planning commission prior to issuance of permits. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.48 - C-2, RETAIL BUSINESS DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.48.005 - Statement of purpose. 
    The C-2 retail business district serves as the primary environment for commercial activity. It is the intent of this district to maintain a "main street" quality that balances a variety of retail and service businesses with a large volume of automobile and pedestrian traffic. Increased diversification of uses and expansion of businesses is desired, however, these activities should incorporate the character as expressed by the scale, materials and orientation of existing buildings. 
(Ord. 7770 § 1, 2003) 
17.48.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district C-2, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district C-1 (unless specifically prohibited in Section 17.48.015 of this chapter), except that dwellings shall not be permitted unless located on the second floor or higher of a permitted use; 
B.  Shops and stores for the sale at retail or wholesale of department store merchandise, furniture and appliances, petroleum products (bulk plants not permitted), newspapers, pets, books, stationery, handcraft, office and hotel supplies; 
C.  Services such as clubs, hotels and motels, automobile maintenance and repair, dry cleaning and laundries, appliance and small equipment repair, printing and publishing, custom maintenance, on-site handcrafting, delivery services, radio and television broadcasting studios, public or private entertainment and recreation, places where alcoholic beverages are served, charity and welfare. 
(Ord. 7851 § 1, 2004) 
17.48.015 - Prohibited uses. 
    In District C-2, the following uses shall be prohibited: 
A.  Mortuaries; 
B.  Hospitals; 
C.  Sale of new automobiles and trucks; 
D.  Used car lots; 
E.  Automobile bodywork or automobile painting; 
F.  Motorcycle sales; 
G.  Residential dwellings as a principal use. 
(Ord. 8230 § 1, 2007; Ord. 7851 § 2, 2004) 
17.48.020 - Performance standards. 
A.  Drive-up or drive-in service may be provided, except where ready-to-eat food, including beverages, or where cereal malt beverages in any form are served, dispensed or otherwise change hands. 
B.  No noise, smoke, radiation, vibration or concussion, heat or glare shall be produced that is perceptible outside a building and no dust, fly ash or gas that is toxic, caustic or obviously injurious to humans or property shall be produced. 
C.  Merchandise which may appropriately be displayed or stored outside a building shall be kept off the public sidewalks and streets, shall not reduce the capacity of a parking lot below that required by this title and shall not occupy an area greater than twenty (20) percent of the ground floor area of the building. 
(Ord. 7851 § 3, 2004: Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.48.030 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district C-2, the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards and the minimum lot area per family permitted upon any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.48.040 and 17.48.050. For exceptions, see Chapter 17.72. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.48.040 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed three stories in height, except that in a district CP-2 buildings and structures shall not exceed one hundred forty-four (144) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.48.050 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yards. No front yard is required. 
B.  Side Yards. No side yard is required, except that where a side line of a lot in this district abuts the side line of a lot in a district R-1A to C-0 inclusive, a side yard shall then be provided the same as required in the district it abuts. 
C.  Rear Yards. No rear yard is required, except that where a rear line of a lot in this district abuts upon land in a district R-1 to C-0 inclusive, a rear yard of not less than ten (10) feet shall then be provided in this district. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.48.080 - Design guidelines. 
    All applications for building or land use permits in the C-2 retail business district shall be evaluated to determine that it conforms to or enhances the character of the district. When reviewing a plan, the planning commission shall determine the compatibility of the proposed development with adjacent buildings, structures and uses. The following criteria shall be used to determine if the development is appropriate for the site on which it is proposed: 
A.  Buildings shall define the streetscape by maintaining a zero setback from the front building line. 
B.  Exterior public spaces, such as courtyards or plazas, are encouraged to enhance pedestrian activity. 
C.  Buildings shall be considered in terms of their relationship to the height, massing, materials and colors of adjacent buildings. The dominant materials for new construction or additions within the C-2 retail business district shall be brick and/or stone, similar to the materials used on the majority of buildings within the district. 
D.  Buildings shall maintain a pedestrian orientation at the street level, including large show windows and hanging or wall mounted signs oriented to pedestrians. 
E.  Buildings shall be located to front towards public streets. Buildings should not be oriented to front toward a parking lot. Parking lots shall be located in the rear or on the sides of buildings. When located adjacent to a street, parking lots shall be separated from the right-of-way by a wall, made of materials compatible with the adjacent buildings (i.e., brick), with a minimum height of three feet. 
F.  Paving materials shall be appropriate to their location and intended purpose. 
G.  Walls and fences shall be architecturally compatible with the style, materials, and colors of the principal building on the same lot. 
H.  Buildings shall avoid long, monotonous, uninterrupted walls or roof planes. Building wall offsets, including projections and recesses shall be used to add architectural interest and variety. 
I.  Façades visible from the public right-of-way shall be architecturally emphasized through fenestration, entrance treatment, and details. 
J.  Building entrances shall be defined and articulated by architectural elements such as lintels, pediments, pilasters, columns, overhangs, or other elements as appropriate. 
K.  Light fixtures attached to the exterior of buildings shall be compatible with the style, materials, colors, and details of the building. 
L.  Buildings shall contain a minimum of two stories. Upper floors of buildings may be made available for office or accessory residential uses, but are not required to be functional. 
M.  All mechanical equipment shall be thoroughly screened from view from the public right-of-way and adjacent properties. 
N.  Buildings shall contain a footprint of no more than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet per user. 
    In the review and approval process, the design guidelines listed above will be considered as requirements unless an acceptable alternative design can be shown by the applicant to better meet the intent of the guidelines as interpreted by the planning commission. 
(Ord. 7770 § 2, 2003) 
17.48.085 - Approval of design guidelines. 
    Before beginning any project in the C-2 retail business district, an applicant shall schedule a pre-application meeting with city staff to discuss the proposed project and the requirements for review and approval. 
    Prior to the commencement of exterior structural alteration or construction of any structure within the district for any of the uses provided for above, a plan shall have been submitted to and approved by the planning commission. The plan shall conform with the standards of the site plan review section (Section 17.96.010) of the zoning chapter. 
    In addition to the requirements of Section 17.96.010, the site plan shall also include the following information: 
A.  Location and use of all existing and proposed buildings which are the subject of the application, including public areas and open spaces. 
B.  Building elevation drawings and all dimensions of height and floor area. Show the location of all exterior entrances. 
C.  Design details (materials and colors) to make new construction compatible with existing structures. 
(Ord. 7770 § 3, 2003) 
17.48.090 - Residential standards. 
    In district C-2, residential uses are permitted on the second floor or higher of new mixed-use buildings subject to the following conditions: 
A.  A separate entrance shall be provided to the residential portions of the building. 
B.  Each residential unit shall include a minimum of thirty-six (36) square feet of exterior patio or balcony space. 
C.  All residential units shall meet all life safety requirements of the city's building codes and all other applicable city codes and ordinances. 
(Ord. 8199 § 1, 2006) 
Chapter 17.52 - C-3, SERVICE BUSINESS DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.52.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district C-3, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district C-2; 
B.  Shops, stores and yards for the sale at retail or wholesale, or the rental of such items as new automobiles and trucks, used car lots, automobile supplies, motorcycles, automotive equipment, trucks, trailers, boats, camping accessories, tools, farm machinery supplies, building supplies, ice, lawn accessories; 
C.  Services such as assembly and meeting halls, automobile repair and washing, farm machinery repair, pop bottling, miniature golf and commercial recreation parks, drive-in theaters, general repair and fix-it shops, frozen foods, including lockers, swimming pools, trade schools, lending establishments; 
D.  Nurseries and greenhouses, bakeries; 
E.  Manufacture or assembly of products to be sold only at retail on the premises. 
F.  Mortuaries and hospitals. 
G.  Medical marijuana dispensary. 
(Ord. 7851 § 6, 2004: Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 9183, § 2, 3-19-2019) 
17.52.015 - Prohibited uses. 
    In district C-3, the following uses shall be prohibited: 
A.  Residential dwellings. 
(Ord. 8199 § 2, 2006) 
17.52.020 - Performance standards. 
A.  Drive-up or drive-in service may be provided at any establishment. 
B.  Any manufacturing or assembly of products as permitted above. shall be entirely within a totally enclosed building. 
C.  No noise, smoke, radiation, vibration or concussion, heat or glare shall be produced that is perceptible outside a building and no dust, fly ash or gas that is toxic, caustic or obviously injurious to humans or property shall be produced. 
D.  Automobiles, trucks, boats and trailers for sale may be stored or displayed outside a building but not within ten (10) feet of a street line. Other merchandise which may appropriately be displayed or stored outside a building shall be kept off the public sidewalks and streets and shall not reduce the capacity of a parking lot below that required by this title. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.52.030 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district C-3, the height of buildings, the minimum dimensions of lots and yards, and the minimum lot area per family permitted on any lot shall be as follows in Sections 17.52.040 and 17.52.050. For exceptions, see Chapter 17.72. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.52.040 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed three stories, except that in a district CP-3 buildings and structures shall not exceed one hundred forty-four (144) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.52.050 - Yards. 
A.  Front Yard. No front yard is required. 
B.  Side Yards. No side yard is required, except that where a side line of a lot in this district abuts upon the side line of a lot in a district R- I A to C-0 inclusive, a side yard shall then be provided the same as, required in the district it abuts. 
C.  Rear Yard. No rear yard required, except that when a rear lot line abuts a lot in a district R-IA to C-0 inclusive, a rear yard of not less than twenty (20) feet shall be provided. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.52.070 - Conversion of buildings. 
    No building that was designed and constructed as a residential building shall be converted to or hereafter used for nonresidential purposes enumerated in this district. Those buildings and premises being used in violation of this regulation on the date of the adoption of this title may continue as nonconforming uses under Chapter 17.80. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.52.080 - Standards for medical marijuana dispensaries. 
    No building shall be constructed, altered, or used for a medical marijuana dispensary without complying with the following regulations. 
A.  Buffer Requirement. No medical marijuana dispensary shall be located within three hundred (300) feet of an existing elementary or secondary school, licensed child day care center, or church. Measurements shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the nearest point on the exterior building wall of the school, child care center, or church, to the nearest point on the property line containing the medical marijuana business. 
B.  Outdoor Operations or Storage Prohibited. All operations and all storage of materials, products, or equipment shall be within a fully enclosed building. No outdoor operations or storage shall be permitted. 
C.  Onsite Usage Prohibited. No marijuana may be smoked, ingested, or otherwise consumed on the premises of a medical marijuana dispensary. 
D.  Hours of Operation. All medical marijuana dispensaries shall be closed to the public, no persons not employed by the business shall be on the premises, and no sales or distribution of marijuana shall occur upon the premises or by delivery from the premises between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
E.  Display of Licenses Required. The medical marijuana license issued by the State of Missouri shall be displayed in an open and conspicuous place on the premises. 
F.  Residential Dwelling Units Prohibited. No medical marijuana dispensary shall be located in a building that contains a residence. 
G.  Ventilation Required. All medical marijuana businesses shall install and operate a ventilation system that will prevent any odor of marijuana from leaving the premises of the business. No odors shall be detectable by a person with a normal sense of smell outside the boundary of the parcel on which the facility is located. 
H.  Site Plan Review Required. A site plan meeting the requirements of this title shall be submitted for review and approval subject to the procedures of Section 17.96.010. The site plan shall include a description of the ventilation system to be used to contain odors within the building. 
(Ord. No. 9183, § 4, 3-19-2019) 
Chapter 17.56 - M-1, LIMITED INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.56.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district M-1, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district C-3 except child day care centers or child care facilities, unless operated on-site as an accessory use to the primary employment function of the property and for use by employee families only. Such centers or facilities are subject to the appropriate standards and requirements of Chapter 210 Revised Statutes of Missouri and/or Title 16, CSR, Division 40, Chapter 61 rules of the Department of Health; 
B.  Manufacturing, processing, fabrication, assembling, disassembling, packaging, repairing, cleaning, servicing or testing of any commodity except junk or salvage; 
C.  Warehousing, wholesaling and storage of any commodity except junk or salvage; 
D.  Nurseries and greenhouses limited to the propagation and cultivation of plants; 
E.  Public and private utility facilities. 
F.  Medical marijuana cultivation facility, infused products manufacturing facility, or testing facility. 
(Ord. 8198 § 2, 2006; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 9183, § 3, 3-19-2019) 
17.56.020 - Performance standards. 
A.  All operations shall be conducted within a fully enclosed building. 
B.  All storage of materials, products or equipment shall be within a fully enclosed building or in an open yard so screened that the materials, products or equipment are not visible at eye level from adjacent property. 
C.  No use shall be permitted or so operated as to produce or emit: 
1.  Smoke or particulate matter of a number 1 or darker on the Ringelmann chart; 
2.  Dust, fly ash, radiation, gases, heat, glare or other effects which are obviously injurious to humans at the property line; 
3.  Vibration or concussion perceptible without instruments at the property line; 
4.  The noise level shall not exceed seventy-five (75) dB(A) at any point along the property line; 
5.  Industrial processes and wastes shall be of such a quantity and nature as not to overburden the public sewage disposal facilities or to cause odor and unsanitary effects beyond the property line. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 5, 11-19-2013) 
17.56.030 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district M-1, the height of buildings, and the minimum dimension of lots and yards shall be as follows in Sections 17.56.040 and 17.56.050. See Chapter 17.72 for exceptions. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.56.040 - Height. 
    No building or structure shall exceed three stories or fifty (50) feet in height except that in a district MP-1 buildings and structures shall not exceed one hundred forty-four (144) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.56.050 - Yards. 
A.  A side yard of not less than five feet shall be provided between a side lot line and any free-standing buildings and structures, and shall be at least ten (10) feet from any other building or structure on the same or adjacent lot; except that no yard is required where any two buildings are joined by a party wall meeting all fire rating requirements for all allowed uses within the district on each lot. 
B.  A yard of not less than ten (10) feet shall be provided between a building and any abutting street line. 
C.  A rear yard shall be provided of not less than ten (10) feet. 
D.  Lots adjacent to any lot zoned as R1-A to C-3 shall have the same side and rear yard requirement, where that district's required setback is greater than what is required for this district. 
E.  Side and rear yard setbacks may be eliminated or reduced from minimum requirements, provided such lesser setbacks facilitate the creation of a common parking area serving the subject property and some or all of the properties adjacent to such parking area. 
(Ord. 8064 § 1, 2005) 
(Ord. No. 8418, § 6, 8-25-2009) 
17.56.060 - Landscaping. 
    All yards abutting a public street shall be landscaped. See Chapter 17.78 for landscaping standards. 
(Ord. 8015 § 4, 2005) 
17.56.070 - Standards for medical marijuana uses. 
A.  Buffer Requirement. No medical marijuana business shall be located within three hundred (300) feet of an existing elementary or secondary school, licensed child day care center, or church. Measurements shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the nearest point on the exterior building wall of the school, child care center, or church, to the nearest point on the property line containing the medical marijuana business. 
B.  Outdoor Operations or Storage Prohibited. All operations and all storage of materials, products, or equipment shall be within a fully enclosed building. No outdoor operations or storage shall be permitted. 
C.  Onsite Usage Prohibited. No marijuana may be smoked, ingested, or otherwise consumed on the premises of a medical marijuana business. 
D.  Hours of Operation. All medical marijuana businesses shall be closed to the public, no persons not employed by the business shall be on the premises, and no sales or distribution of marijuana shall occur upon the premises or by delivery from the premises between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
E.  Display of Licenses Required. The medical marijuana license issued by the State of Missouri shall be displayed in an open and conspicuous place on the premises. 
F.  Residential Dwelling Units Prohibited. No medical marijuana business shall be located in a building that contains a residence. 
G.  Ventilation Required. All medical marijuana businesses shall install and operate a ventilation system that will prevent any odor of marijuana from leaving the premises of the business. No odors shall be detectable by a person with a normal sense of smell outside the boundary of the parcel on which the facility is located. 
H.  Site Plan Review Required. A site plan meeting the requirements of this title shall be submitted for review and approval subject to the procedures of Section 17.96.010. The site plan shall include a description of the ventilation system to be used to contain odors within the building. 
(Ord. No. 9183, § 5, 3-19-2019) 
Chapter 17.60 - M-2, GENERAL INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.60.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district M-2, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure shall be hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Any use permitted in district M- 1; 
B.  Bus barns or lots; 
C.  Cleaning, pressing and dyeing plants including laundries; 
D.  Cold storage plants; 
E.  Dog pounds and kennels if within an enclosed building; 
F.  Machine shop; 
G.  Plumbing and sheet metal shops; 
H.  Railroad yards; 
I.  Railroad repair shops; 
J.  River freight terminals, docks, loading and unloading equipment; 
K.  Handling, storage and processing of salvage and scrap metals. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.60.020 - Performance standards. 
A.  Operations may be conducted within a building or in an open yard, except that no operations shall be conducted within ten (10) feet of a property line. 
B.  All storage of materials, products or equipment shall be within a fully enclosed building or in a partially enclosed building or in an open yard having a solid screen fence not less than six feet high giving total or partial screening from neighboring property and adjacent streets. In the case of salvage or junk operations, all storage and processing areas shall be screened by a solid screen fence not less than ten (10) feet and not exceeding fifteen (15) feet in height, the materials and setback of which shall be approved by the planning commission. 
C.  No use shall be permitted or so operated as to produce or emit: 
1.  Smoke or particulate matter of a number I or darker on the Ringelmann chart; 
2.  Dust, fly ash, radiation, gases, heat, glare or other effects which are obviously injurious or damaging to humans or property beyond the property line; 
3.  Vibration or concussion perceptible without instruments at the property line; 
4.  Noise that exceeds eighty (80) dB(A) at any point along the property line; 
5.  Industrial wastes of a quantity or nature that they may overburden the public sewage disposal facilities or cause odors or unsanitary effects beyond the property line. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.60.030 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district M-2, the height of buildings, the minimum dimension of lots and yards shall be as follows in Sections 17.60.040 and 17.60.050. See Chapter 17.72 for exceptions. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.60.040 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.60.050 - Yards. 
    Same as district M-1. 
(Ord. 8064 § 2, 2005) 
17.60.060 - Standards for medical marijuana uses. 
A.  Buffer Requirement. No medical marijuana business shall be located within three hundred (300) feet of an existing elementary or secondary school, licensed child day care center, or church. Measurements shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the nearest point on the exterior building wall of the school, child care center, or church, to the nearest point on the property line containing the medical marijuana business. 
B.  Outdoor Operations or Storage Prohibited. All operations and all storage of materials, products, or equipment shall be within a fully enclosed building. No outdoor operations or storage shall be permitted. 
C.  Onsite Usage Prohibited. No marijuana may be smoked, ingested, or otherwise consumed on the premises of a medical marijuana business. 
D.  Hours of Operation. All medical marijuana businesses shall be closed to the public, no persons not employed by the business shall be on the premises, and no sales or distribution of marijuana shall occur upon the premises or by delivery from the premises between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
E.  Display of Licenses Required. The medical marijuana license issued by the State of Missouri shall be displayed in an open and conspicuous place on the premises. 
F.  Residential Dwelling Units Prohibited. No medical marijuana business shall be located in a building that contains a residence. 
G.  Ventilation Required. All medical marijuana businesses shall install and operate a ventilation system that will prevent any odor of marijuana from leaving the premises of the business. No odors shall be detectable by a person with a normal sense of smell outside the boundary of the parcel on which the facility is located. 
H.  Site Plan Review Required. A site plan meeting the requirements of this title shall be submitted for review and approval subject to the procedures of Section 17.96.010. The site plan shall include a description of the ventilation system to be used to contain odors within the building. 
(Ord. No. 9183, § 6, 3-19-2019) 
Chapter 17.64 - G-1, GAMING AND AMUSEMENT DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.64.010 - Permitted uses. 
    In district G-1, no building, structure, land or premises shall be used and no building or structure hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or altered, except for one or more of the following uses: 
A.  Gambling boats and accessory uses and equipment; 
B.  Hotels; 
C.  Motels; 
D.  Campgrounds; 
E.  Family theme entertainment parks; 
F.  Establishments for eating and dispensation of alcoholic beverages; 
G.  Shops and stores for sale at retail of soft goods such as clothing, jewelry, and gifts and novelties; 
H.  Churches/places of worship. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.64.020 - Performance standards. 
A.  No noise, smoke, radiation, vibration or concussion, heat or glare shall be produced that is perceptible outside a building and no dust, fly ash or gas that is toxic, caustic or obviously injurious to humans or property shall be produced. 
B.  All storage of materials, products, or equipment shall be within a fully enclosed building or in an open yard so screened that the materials, products or equipment are not visible at eye level. 
C.  All products shall be sold and all services rendered inside a building, except camping sites within campgrounds and family theme entertainment parks. 
D.  Alcoholic beverages shall be dispensed only within eating establishments, eating establishments within hotels and motels, or boats. 
E.  Drive-up or drive-in services shall not be permitted. 
F.  Signage within this zoning district shall comply with the requirements of the general business district. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.64.030 - Height and area regulations. 
    In district G-1, the height of buildings and the minimum dimension of lots and yards shall be as follows in Sections 17.64.040 and 17.64.050. See Chapter 17.72 for exceptions. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.64.040 - Height. 
    Buildings or structures shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) feet in height. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.64.050 - Yards. 
    No yard shall be required, except that a yard of not less than ten (10) feet shall be provided between a building or other structure and any abutting street line. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.64.060 - Landscaping. 
    All yards or areas abutting a public street or abutting adjacent property shall be landscaped according to the standards in Chapter 17.78. 
(Ord. 8015 § 5, 2005) 
17.64.070 - Requirements for dwellings. 
    Single-family, two-family, multiple-family, or apartment buildings are not permitted. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.66 - BURLINGTON CORRIDOR OVERLAY DISTRICT 
Sections: 

17.66.010 - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the intent of this district to: 
A.  Implement the Vision and Principles of the Burlington Corridor Study (June 2009) and the Master Plan of the City. 
B.  Coordinate regulations impacting the land use, development pattern and transportation system concepts in the Study. 
C.  Promote a blend of land uses that strengthen the corridor and its relationship to surrounding areas. 
D.  Anticipate the potential for multiple transportation modes, including vehicles, pedestrians, bicycles, and transit throughout the corridor so that no one single mode of transportation thrives at the expense of safe and convenient access of the others. 
E.  Strengthen unifying urban design themes along the Burlington Corridor. 
F.  Promote efficient site and building design patterns for new construction and existing building rehabilitation. 
G.  Allow flexibility to accommodate varying conditions on the corridor, provided it directly advances the Vision and Principles of the Burlington Corridor Study and promotes the intent and concepts of the regulations and design guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010) 
17.66.020 - District boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the Burlington Corridor Overlay District shall be all property within the city limits of North Kansas City, excluding the Northgate Planned Unit Development District which meets any of the following: 
A.  All lots with any portion of property within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the right-of-way of Burlington 
B.  The district shall be further divided into the following three (3) sub-areas: 
1.  North area: shall extend from 32nd Avenue on the north, to 23rd Avenue 
2.  Central area: shall extend from 23rd Avenue to 16th Avenue 
3.  South area: shall extend from 16th Avenue to 10th Avenue 
(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010)

    The uses of the underlying zoning districts remain applicable unless specified to the contrary by the uses listed below.
