(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010; Ord. No. 9089, § 1, 5-15-2018) 
17.66.040 - Applicability of site, building and design standards. 
A.  The site standards in Section 17.66.050 and the Building Standards in Section 17.66.060 shall apply to the following: 
1.  Any application for new development which is submitted after the effective date of this ordinance. 
2.  Any application for expansion of an existing principal structure which represents an increase of more than fifteen percent (15%) of the floor area of an existing principal structure. 
3.  All site improvements that impact any areas between existing buildings and the corridor right-of-way, or at a minimum, site areas within fifty (50) feet of the right-of-way. 
B.  The Design Guidelines in Section 17.66.070 shall apply to the following: 
1.  Any application requiring the interpretation of the site and/or building standards of this chapter. 
2.  When conditional approvals are considered. 
3.  Any exterior structural alteration of a building. 
C.  Any site, building and/or design standards applicable within the Overlay District shall supersede any conflicting standards of any underlying zoning district. 
(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010) 
17.66.050 - Site standards. 
A.  Vehicle access and circulation. 
1.  Curb-cuts shall be limited to balance pedestrian, transit, and vehicle interests along the corridor. In general, lot access shall be by alley, side streets, or shared access easements. 
2.  Limited curb-cut site access may be permitted: 

Illustration #1
a.  (North) Up to twenty percent (20%) of the frontage width and separated by at least one hundred fifty (150) feet from other access points or side streets. Maximum width: Thirty (30) feet ( Illustration #1 ) 
  

Illustration #2
  
b.  (Central) Up to ten percent (10%) of the frontage width and separated by at least two hundred fifty (250) feet from other access points or side streets. Maximum width: Twenty (20) feet ( Illustration #2 ) 
  

Illustration #3
c.  (South) up to fifteen percent (15%) of the frontage width and separated by at least two hundred (200) feet from other access points, or side streets. Maximum width: Thirty (30) feet ( Illustration #3 ) 
3.  In addition to these standards, all access on Burlington shall also be coordinated with the Missouri Department of Transportation. 
4.  Any lot existing prior to the date of these regulations and not permitted access by these standards, and which cannot achieve adequate access to the site by other feasible means, may be permitted limited access through a planning commission review, provided the site is otherwise designed in accordance with these standards and the design guidelines. 
B.  Parking. 
1.  In general, parking shall meet the requirements of Chapter 17.76, except the following additional site design standards apply. In cases where an application cannot meet both the required parking and these site design standards, the conflict shall be reconciled through a conditional use process, and design and approval of the application shall prioritize the parking guidelines in Section 17.66.070. 
2.  In general, parking shall be located behind the building. An exception may be granted for sites where a block scale master plan has been prepared for all lots on the block, coordinating access, parking, and streetscape design according to the Design Guidelines. ( Illustration #1 ): 
3.  Limited on-site parking may be permitted to the side of the building: 
a.  (North) Parking may be permitted on the side of a building provided ( Illustration #1 ): 
i.  It occupies no more than fifty percent (50%) of the lot frontage. 
ii.  It is setback at least thirty (30) feet from the front building line; and 
iii.  It is screened by a fence, wall or civic open space at the extension of the front building line. 
b.  (Central) A single-loaded aisle may be permitted on the side of a building provided ( Illustration #2 ): 
i.  It occupies no more than twenty percent (20%) of the lot frontage; 
ii.  It is set back at least five (5) feet behind the front building line; and 
iii.  It is screened by a fence or wall at the extension of the front building line. 
c.  (South) A single or double-loaded aisle may be permitted on the side of a building provided ( Illustration #3 ): 
i.  It occupies no more than thirty-five percent (35%) of the lot frontage 
ii.  It is setback at least twenty (20) feet from the front building line; and 
iii.  It is screened by a fence, wall or civic open space at the extension of the front building line. 

Illustration #4
C.  Landscape design. All landscape design in the corridor shall serve each of the following purposes. Landscape materials and locations shall occur according to the design guidelines in Section 17.66.070. 
1.  To support the design and function of any civic open space on the site, such as a court yard, or pocket park. 
2.  To define the streetscape edge for any non-building frontage on the site. 
3.  To provide low-maintenance, four-season planting areas that screen the more intense elements of the site, such as, but not limited to trash dumpsters, loading docks, and mechanical equipment from the streetscape and adjacent property. 
D.  Lot standards. 
1.  Minimum lot width (measured along lot frontage): Twenty-five (25) feet ( Illustration #4 ) 
2.  Side setbacks shall be: 
a.  Zero (0) feet if the building has a party wall meeting all building code requirements. 
b.  Five (5) feet if not a party wall and the building is two (2) stories or less; 
c.  Ten (10) feet if not a party wall and the building is three (3) stories or more; and 
d.  Lots abutting the R-1A through C-O shall have the same side setback as the abutting district. 
3.  No rear building shall be built within twenty (20) feet of a rear lot line, except that building sites located on a rear alley may be setback only ten (10) feet from the rear lot line. 
E.  Loading docks. 
1.  (Central) All loading areas shall be located on the rear of the building, or located on the interior of a site and screened by the building from the street. 
2.  (North and South) All loading areas shall be set back at least fifty (50) feet from the lot frontage: 
a.  Loading areas within fifty (50) feet to one hundred (100) feet of the lot frontage shall be oriented to the side of the building; 
b.  Loading areas beyond one hundred (100) feet of the lot frontage may be oriented towards the front, provided they are otherwise screened from the streetscape by an ornamental wall, fence or civic open space. 
(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010) 
17.66.060 - Building standards. 
A.  Front building line. 
1.  All buildings shall be built within zero (0) feet and ten (10) feet of the front lot line. 
2.  An exception may be granted to allow up to a thirty (30) feet setback along no more than forty percent (40%) of the building frontage for civic open space designed according to the design guidelines. 
3.  (North only) An exception may be granted up to one hundred twenty (120) feet setback for sites where a block scale master plan has been prepared for all lots on the block, coordinating access, parking, and streetscape design according to the design guidelines. 

Illustration #5
B.  Height (Illustration #5). 
1.  Height shall be measured in stories: 
a.  Ground level stories: Fourteen (14) feet min.; twenty (20) feet max, 
b.  Ground level stories shall start between one (1) foot below or up to two (2) feet above the front sidewalk grade. 
c.  Upper stories: Nine (9) feet min.; fourteen (14) feet max. 
2.  Building height shall be: 
a.  Two (2) story min.; four (4) story max. (Central) 
b.  One (1) story min.; four (4) story max. (South and North) 
c.  Additional stories may be permitted in the Central and North by special review and subject to the Design Guidelines. 

Illustration #6
3.  (South only) Light industrial or flex buildings may have a first story up to fifty (50) feet provided that the building frontage includes a lobby, office or show room that otherwise meets the height standards to a depth of at least thirty (30) feet from the Front Building Line. ( Illustration #6 ) 
C.  Entrance feature (Illustration #7). 

Illustration #7
1.  All buildings shall have a primary entrance directly connecting to the Burlington Streetscape: 
a.  One (1) for every one hundred fifty (150) feet of building frontage (North). 
b.  One (1) for every seventy-five (75) feet of building frontage (Central). 
c.  One (1) for every building site (South). 
D.  Transparency (Illustration #8). 
1.  Ground story front façades shall have the following minimum amounts of transparency between two (2) feet and eight (8) feet above the street level: 
a.  Seventy-five percent (75%) (Central); 
b.  Fifty percent (50%) (north and south); 
c.  Fifty percent (50%) within thirty (30) feet of either side of the entrance for light industry buildings (south). ( Illustration #9 ) 
2.  Upper level front façades shall have a minimum transparency between three (3) feet and nine (9) feet above the finished floor level: 
a.  Twenty-five percent (25%) to seventy percent (70%) for all buildings except light industrial buildings. 
b.  No requirement for light industrial buildings, except that the front façades of these buildings shall meet this requirement with architectural ornamentation specified in the Design Guidelines. 

Illustration #8

Illustration #9
E.  Other. 
1.  Permitted projections: Awnings, balconies, eaves or other projections associated with the design of the building may project up to five (5) feet in front of the Front Building Line, provided a minimum eight-foot clearance above the sidewalk is maintained. 
2.  Any building with less than eighty-five percent (85%) frontage at the front building line shall use the same materials and design styles on the side façades. Any building with less than seventy percent (70%) frontage at the front building line, or which has any portion of a building and site that backs onto a public street, shall use the same materials and design styles on the side and rear façades. 
3.  All buildings shall be designed according to the Design Guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010) 
17.66.070 - Design guidelines. 
    These design guidelines are consistent with the vision and principles of the Burlington Corridor Study. They may be used to help interpret the site and building standards of the district. They must be used when considering any conditional approvals or exceptions to the standards. 

Illustration #10
A.  Building form and design. The outer form and design of a building establishes the scale of public spaces and shape the public streetscape. Façade designs with greater "permeability" can support a more active and interesting streetscape. 
1.  Frontage design: ( Illustration #10 ) 
a.  All buildings shall be placed on the lot to shape positive public space in the Burlington Corridor, including planned and anticipated streetscape arrangements. Consult the Street Design concepts in the Burlington Corridor Study for potential street sections on particular segments of the corridor. 
b.  Buildings constructed at the "build to" should form a more consistent street wall along Burlington. 
c.  Rehabilitation of existing buildings should aim to bring sites more in conformance with the setbacks and orientation concepts in the Corridor Study. 
d.  Where portions of a lot are not fronted by building façades, such as an open space or parking area, the disruption in the street wall should be minimized to the greatest extent practical by a continuation of the substitute street wall extended from the façade. Examples of substitute street walls include small "courtyard walls" constructed of the same material as the principal building, ornamental fencing, or year-round evergreen landscape materials forming a vertical wall-like element. 
2.  Height and massing: 
Illustration #11

a.  The height of buildings should establish a ratio of building height to distance between street walls on opposite sides of the block between 1:1 or 1:3 ( Illustration #11 ), with the ideal goal being a 1:2 ( Illustration #12 ) relationship. This will typically require between 2-story and 4-story buildings. Where larger heights are permitted, upper portions of buildings should step back to maintain these proportions. ( Illustration #13 ) 
b.  Building heights should be consistent along a single block face. Minor deviations in building heights between five percent (5%) to fifteen percent (15%) along a single block face are acceptable to add depth and texture to the street wall. ( Illustration #14 ) 
c.  Significant deviations in height are acceptable at limited locations on a block provided they are at key intersections to emphasize a focal point within the streetscape. 
d.  Larger buildings of four (4) or more stories or occupying more than one-third ( 1/3 ) of the block face should use more complex massing to break up the form of the building and create a more pedestrian scale. 
e.  Such complex massing should still maintain a consistent street wall at the front building line. Deviations of more than two (2) feet along a front façade at street level should only be permitted to shape positive and useable outdoor space which improves the relationship and transitions between the streetscape and activities within the building. 
3.  Orientation: 

Illustration #15
a.  All buildings should have its primary façade and primary entrance oriented towards the street. 
b.  Pedestrian activity should be directed towards Burlington. 
c.  Vehicle activity should be directed towards side streets and rear alley systems, or limited in extent when it is necessary for them to be oriented towards Burlington. 
d.  For retail use, building entrances should be located more frequently along the streetscape to generate more activity and complimentary pedestrian traffic for nearby uses. 
e.  Areas of the façade immediately associated with the entrance should be reserved for the most ornamental or dynamic elements of the building design. 
f.  Entrance features should be designed at a pedestrian scale - primarily single story and no wider than the smallest architectural bay of the building. ( Illustration # 15 & 17 ) 
4.  Articulation/Modulation: ( Illustration #15 ). 

Illustration #16
a.  Façades that extend more than one hundred (100) feet along the block face should be broken down into architectural bays. Bays should be a consistent dimension on any single building. They may be formed by gangs of windows, groupings of architectural ornamentation, or pilasters associated with structural and massing elements of a building. ( Illustration #16 ) 
  
b.  Retail uses should use architectural bays of twenty-five (25) feet to fifty (50) feet that coordinate with differentiated storefronts on the street level. 

Illustration #17
c.  Expansive areas of blank façades on Burlington should be broken up by windows, building entrances, or ornamental features. No more than thirty (30) feet of horizontal blank wall space should exist along Burlington without creating greater transparency and articulation through a combination of these elements. 
5.  Transparency: 
a.  Street level façades for retail areas should include significant proportions of transparent display windows. No window starting at a level of greater than three and one-half (3.5) feet above the street level should be included in the calculation. 
b.  Where the internal operations of the use are such that there is no practical way for the transparency guidelines to be met, a limited alternate of boxed display windows or enhanced building ornamentation may be used. Boxed display windows should meet all other transparency guidelines, but may be closed off at a depth of no less than two (2) to three (3) feet. 
c.  Where permitted, industrial buildings should use architectural elements and enhanced building ornamentation that complements the building materials and style to break up any blank wall space permitted by the standards. Fake windows that imitate transparency are not recommended for buildings where lack of transparency may otherwise be acceptable. 
d.  Glazing or heavy tints, reflective treatment, simulated windows, banded windows or glass curtains disrupt the scale and permeability of a building and should not be used. 
6.  Building materials: 
a.  All buildings should be constructed according to the following material standards. Percentage requirements for materials exclude windows or other openings. 
i.  Primary Materials. All buildings should have one (1) primary material covering at least sixty-five percent (65%) of the building façades. 
ii.  Secondary Materials. Buildings may have a secondary material covering up to thirty percent (30%) of the façades. 
iii.  Accent Materials. Buildings should have at least one (1), and may have up to two (2) accent or trim materials covering between five percent (5%) and ten percent (10%) of the building façades. 
iv.  Permitted Materials. Exterior materials should be permitted in accordance with the following table: 
Primary Materials Secondary Materials Accent/Trim Materials Brick, unpainted. 
  
Stone, unpainted. 
  
Stucco 
  
Or equal or better simulated materials Any of the Primary Materials may be used as Secondary Materials 
  
Glass 
  
Standing Seam Metal 
  
Color Concrete Any of the Primary or Secondary Materials may be used as an accent material 
  
Wood trim (or equal or better simulated material) 
  
Precast stone, or wood moldings or similar architectural details (or equal or better simulated material)  
b.  Where "equal or better" simulated materials should only be used as follows: 
i.  If the proposed material has an identical physical appearance as the material it intended to simulate, including color and texture, as perceived from any public spaces surrounding the property; 
ii.  If the material presents benefits in addition to cost savings, such as reduced maintenance, or enhanced durability and performance; 
iii.  If the material has a demonstrated track record of successful application and use that will result in equally long-lasting and sustainable appeal of the neighborhood as that of the permitted materials; and 
iv.  The use of equal or better materials is applied in compliance with all manufacturer specifications. 
c.  Each distinct building material should be of uniform color. The compilation of building materials should form a compatible color pallet. Primary and any secondary materials should use muted or earth tone colors. Accent and trim materials may use bold or vibrant colors. 
B.  Site design. The design of individual sites impacts streetscapes, site access and circulation, and the function and aesthetics for the entire corridor. Site designs must account for vehicle traffic in a manner that least disrupts pedestrian activity to and immediately surrounding a building. 
1.  Streetscapes: 
a.  All development should be reviewed in relation to the impact on the long-range street design scenarios in the Burlington Corridor Study. Refer to the study for the three (3) primary street design scenarios - North Area; Central Area; and South Area. 
b.  Individual projects should preserve the potential for these concepts to be done, and include site designs that reinforce these concepts with proper building placement and orientation. 
c.  Larger or block-scale projects should implement these concepts on critical segments of the streetscape in association with new development. 
d.  Projects that conflict with these concepts should only be approved on a finding by the City that they will not pursue long-term capital projects for that segment of the street, and that incremental implementation through a series of private projects is not possible. 
2.  Curb cuts: 
a.  Curb cuts should be limited on Burlington. Sites that have access by side streets or rear alley systems should use these access points for vehicles. 
b.  Curb cuts on Burlington should be consolidated within blocks. A single central curb cut that provides access to a shared easement circulation system is preferred. 
c.  Curb cuts on Burlington should be as narrow as possible to avoid disruption of the streetscape and pedestrian flow. In areas planned for higher pedestrian traffic slower turning movements off Burlington are desired and narrower curb cuts should be sued. Single-lane, one-way entry ways with access to more remote portions of the site are preferred over wide access to prominent portions of the site. 
d.  Curb cuts should be designed to provide the least disruption to pedestrian facilities along the corridor, and wherever possible the grade and surface shall be maintained over vehicle access points. 
3.  Parking location: 
a.  On-street parking should be prioritized and permitted to contribute to on-site parking requirements. 
b.  For any area where a Parking Management District is established, parking requirements should be waived. 
c.  Sites with access to frequent transit service, and where the nature of the use of the building is frequented by transit patrons, should consider a reduced parking count. 

Illustration #18
d.  Parking should be located on remote portions of the site, ideally to the rear of the building and accessible to the streetscape from pedestrian passages. 
e.  Where parking is permitted to the side or front of the building, it should be screened from the streetscape at the extension of the street wall. This screen may be a small "courtyard wall" constructed of the same material as the principal building, ornamental fencing, or year-round evergreen landscape materials. ( Illustration #18 ). 
f.  Parking areas should be designed as shared space wherever possible. For example parking that can serve as a courtyard or similar outdoor space when not in use or for special events are encouraged. 
g.  Parking over the minimum required parking should be discouraged unless it is part of a shared parking program or if it is otherwise mitigated by some improved design features beyond the standards of these guidelines. 
4.  Civic open spaces ( Illustration #19 ). 

Illustration #19
a.  Areas of the street edge that are not occupied by buildings should be designed as active spaces, either as extensions of the public streetscape ("shared use zones" in the Burlington Corridor Study) or as civic open spaces associated with the use of the building. 
  
b.  Civic open spaces should provide space for people to congregate, transition from the public streetscape, and emphasize important elements of the building or site ( Illustration #20 ). 

Illustration #20
c.  A balance of landscape and hardscape elements for more formal open spaces should be used for these areas. 
  

Illustration #21
d.  Larger buildings with continuous street walls along the streetscape should provide pedestrian passages between the streetscape and any rear parking areas. ( Illustration #21 ) 
e.  Where a series of buildings are setback from the street wall for any reason, they should be oriented around a common civic space that contains direct pedestrian paths from the streetscape. 
5.  Landscape and screening: 
a.  Landscape materials should be used to define the edge of unbuilt portions of sites along the streetscape (i.e. areas without direct building frontages or civic open spaces): 
i.  Landscape materials should form a low edge on all non-building frontages, and in particular on any permitted on-site parking areas. Materials should provide a four-season screen and should be a minimum thirty-six (36) inches high. 
ii.  Longer expanses of non-building frontages should include vertical elements to reinforce the street wall along the block. Gaps larger than fifty (50) linear feet should have one (1) two and one-half-inch caliper tree for every thirty (30) feet of frontage. Species should reach a height of more than thirty (30) feet high at maturity. Street trees should be consistent with requirements of Chapter 12.40. 
iii.  Screen any other high-intensity site elements (mechanical equipment, vehicle service bays or loading areas, etc.) from view of the right-of-way with landscape elements. 
iv.  Provide ornamental foundation plantings along any building frontages setback from the right-of-way by more than ten (10) feet. Foundation planting beds should be at least eight (8) feet deep. 
v.  On narrow blocks where two (2) tiers of lots are not possible, additional screening techniques and buffer areas should be used adjacent to the public street. 
b.  Develop low-maintenance landscapes. 
i.  Use low-water species. 
ii.  Incorporate native plants, or use other species that adapt well to the climate, seasonal variations, and soils of this region 
c.  Create high-performance landscapes where possible. 
i.  Find opportunities to "disconnect" paved surfaces from the storm water system and streets through intervening landscape areas. 
ii.  Plant species that provide potential to infiltrate storm water where soils and conditions allow. 
iii.  Incorporate landscape designs that enhance the environmental performance and energy programs for the site and building. 
C.  Block scale master plans and "Shared use Area". A key component of the Burlington Corridor Study is the "shared use area" of the streetscape concepts, and supporting more pedestrian and urban-scaled development supported by the streetscape concepts. The study recognizes that this approach may need to be phased in over time, particularly in the North area. The easiest way to accomplish this is block-scale master plans, where streetscape designs, access, parking and site design of various owners can be coordinated, and where redevelopment of sites can then occur under each landowner's individual time frame according to the block-scale master plan. 
    The standards and design guidelines support the vision of the Burlington Corridor Study. However, where sites propose development that deviates from the standards and guidelines, it should only be done according to block-scale master plans that support the broader corridor interests beyond the individual site. Particularly in the North area, these plans should advance the following concepts: 
1.  Each block shall incorporate additional right-of-way, or cross access easements that replicate the shared use area of the street design concepts and links to similar pedestrian and shared use areas on adjacent blocks on the corridor. 
2.  Cross-access areas shall replicate the shared use areas or boulevard "slip streets" for urban areas in a continuous manner along the block, including narrow vehicle lanes, "on-street" parking on one (1) or both sides of the vehicle lane, street trees, pedestrian areas, and "street-front" buildings. 
3.  Buildings may be set back greater than ten (10) feet from current right-of-way provided that all buildings still frame positive shared, common or public space along the block, similar to the Building Form and Design Guidelines. 
4.  Additional setback areas may be used for the following, provided it is coordinated along the entire lengths of the block: 
a.  Landscape areas including a trail corridor along the Burlington Corridor ( Illustration #22 & #23 ); 
b.  Parking "blocks" providing front parking; provided a "slip street" is located along all lot and building frontages, an enhanced pedestrian area is shifted off Burlington and provided at the building frontage along the "slip street", and parking is buffered from the corridor ( Illustration #23, Option 2 ); or 
c.  Single or double bays of front parking provided that the parking is buffered from the corridor and a continuous pedestrian easement is provided along all building frontages which directly connects to pedestrian routes on adjacent blocks, and the parking areas include connections between pedestrian facilities along Burlington and the building frontage areas. ( Illustration #22, Option 1 ). 
5.  Any front parking shall include frequent and direct dedicated pedestrian connections between pedestrian routes on Burlington and building frontages set back from Burlington. 

Illustration #22

Illustration #23
(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010) 
17.66.080 - Administrative procedures. 
A.  Site Plan Requirement. Any development in the Burlington Corridor District shall submit a site plan according to Section 17.96.010. 
B.  Site plans not meeting a dimensional requirement of the Site Standards or Building Standards may be approved as a conditional use, according to the conditional use procedures in Section 17.96.020, and all of the following specific criteria: 
1.  The proposed deviation from the dimensional requirement is necessary for the project to fulfill a specific goal from the Burlington Corridor Study. 
2.  The proposed site plan uses an alternative design that meets the intent of the Design Guidelines in Section 17.66.070. 
3.  The deviation from the dimensional requirement is the least necessary to facilitate the proposed site plan, and in no case is more than fifteen percent (15%) from the requirement. 
4.  Any conditions necessary to fulfill additional goals from the Burlington Corridor Study may be required in addition to the standards. 
C.  Applications for conditional use authorization as described above must include an analysis of the proposed construction or development, based upon the standards and guidelines of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8508, § 1, 12-14-2010; Ord. No. 8605, § 4, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 8720, § 6, 11-19-2013) 
Chapter 17.68 - MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS 
Sections: 

17.68.010 - Mobile homes-Where permitted. 
A.  Except as provided in subsections B and C of this section, a mobile home may be permitted in the city only in an approved mobile home park by conditional use permit. (See Chapter 17.84) 
B.  A mobile home may be permitted elsewhere in the city by the city council, for the purpose of providing temporary housing following a disaster, such as fire, windstorm or flood; provided, such mobile home is removed from its location within six months of its original placement. 
C.  One or more mobile homes may be used as a temporary office or other nonresidential structure on the site of a construction project; provided, such structure is removed upon completion of the project. 
(Ord. 8015 § 6, 2005; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.68.030 - Minimum standards for mobile home parks. 
    No mobile home park shall have a site smaller than twenty (20) acres. The density for mobile home parks shall be not more than five mobile homes per acre. 
A.  Stands and Skirts. Each mobile home space shall contain a level and stable stand upon which the mobile home will be situated, and each home shall be equipped with skirts on all sides, such skirts to be of material harmonious to the mobile home structure. 
B.  Streets and Drives. All public streets within the park shall be improved to city standards for residential streets. There shall be at least two street or drive openings into the park providing ingress and egress. All private drives shall be not less than twenty-four (24) feet in width, having Portland cement curbs, and be surfaced with at least six inches of compacted stone base with two inches of hot mix bituminous concrete as the surface course, or equal, as determined by the director of public works. 
C.  Parking. At least two parking spaces for each mobile home shall be provided within sixty (60) feet of the mobile home. Such parking spaces shall be off the public street or private drive, and each shall be not less than nine feet by twenty (20) feet in size, and shall be surfaced to at least the standard set out above for drives. 
D.  Park and Playground Space. Park and playground space shall be provided for occupants of the mobile home park on the basis of three hundred (300) square feet for each space in the park. Such playground space shall be separate and in addition to the open space required for each mobile home space, and shall be equipped and maintained for the use of the residents of the park. 
E.  Open Space. Each mobile home shall be located on the mobile home space so that no part of one mobile home structure, including canopies, awnings, carports and other protrusions, is closer than twelve (12) feet to another mobile home, or to the edge of the surface of a drive. No mobile home shall be located closer than thirty (30) feet to the boundary line of the mobile home park or to a public street. Each mobile home space shall have not less than two live trees planted and in place at least six feet in height after planting. 
F.  Utilities. All liquid waste shall be disposed of through a sanitary sewer system and treatment facility, the plans of which shall be approved by the director of public works prior to construction. All solid wastes shall be disposed of by accumulation in tight containers, and removed at regular intervals by methods to be approved by the director of public works. All power and telephone lines shall be underground, and shall be in compliance with standards of the utility corporation involved. The site of the park shall be graded so that surface water will not accumulate, but will run off in a manner that will not adversely affect the residential character of the park or adjacent property. The proposed drainage system shall be approved by the director of public works prior to construction of streets or other portions of the park. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.68.040 - Mobile home park plan approval. 
A.  Construction of a mobile home park within the city shall begin only after a conditional use permit has been granted by the city council, in compliance with the zoning ordinance. No such permit shall be granted, however, until a development plan for the proposed mobile homes park has been prepared and submitted by the developer to the planning commission, and found satisfactory by the commission, and further submitted to the city council and approved by that body. Such plans shall be accurately drawn, at a scale acceptable to the director of community development, and shall show the following: 
1.  Proposed street and drive pattern; 
2.  Proposed mobile homes spaces and their approximate dimensions; 
3.  Any existing streets in or abutting the property; 
4.  Location and size of parking spaces; 
5.  Location and size of park and playground area; 
6.  Screening and landscaping; 
7.  Legal description of the tract; 
8.  Name of the landowner, developer and the firm preparing the plan; 
9.  North point, scale and date. 
B.  The planning commission shall, upon submission of three copies of the plan and an application for a conditional use permit, publish notice and hold a hearing on the proposal, in conformance with the zoning ordinance. The decision of the commission to recommend approval or denial of the proposed mobile homes park shall be based upon the following criteria: 
1.  The proposed property will be in harmony, in general, with the comprehensive plan of the city; 
2.  Two or more routes of safe and efficient ingress and egress of vehicular and pedestrian traffic and an adequate level of utility and other services are assured; 
3.  A safe and healthful living environment will exist for the occupants of the park; 
4.  The plans for the park indicate that neighboring property will not be adversely affected to an unreasonable extent. 
C.  Upon hearing and consideration of the project, the commission shall, within reasonable time, submit its recommendation and an endorsed copy of the plans to the city council for final action. 
D.  All final plans, including detailed landscaping plans, and signs to be allowed shall be reviewed by the planning commission and be approved by that body prior to the beginning of grading or other construction of the mobile homes park. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 7, 11-19-2013) 
17.68.050 - Mobile home subdivisions prohibited. 
    A subdivision for the purpose of selling individual lots in fee for the purpose of mobile home sites shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.68.060 - Management of mobile home park. 
    Each mobile home park shall be operated in a sanitary, orderly and efficient manner, and shall maintain a neat appearance at all times. No damaged or deteriorated mobile home shall be permitted to remain; and suitable and effective rules for regulating the outside storage of equipment, the removal of wheels and installation of skirtings, the collection of trash and garbage, and the attachment of appurtenances to the mobile homes shall be continually enforced. A map shall be placed at the main entrance to the park, clearly showing the location of each space, and the name and address of the occupant. Such map shall be illuminated at all times and be enclosed in a weatherproof case within full view of persons entering the park. All drives, playground areas and equipment, lawn and trees, and any recreation or accessory buildings shall be maintained at a level at least equal to the average residential neighborhood in the city. All portions of the mobile home park shall be open and accessible to fire, police and other emergency and protective vehicles and personnel, including city, county and state inspectors. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.68.070 - Violation. 
    The owner and/or operator of the mobile homes park shall be responsible for the conformance to all plans, codes and ordinances and any conditions set out in the conditional use permit, and any deviation or nonperformance or the occurrence of any nuisance or unsanitary condition, or the termination of a park operation for one year or more shall constitute grounds for the cancellation of a conditional use permit. In addition, the city shall have all remedial and corrective powers conveyed by city ordinances and statutes of the state of Missouri. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.70 - PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT 
Sections: 

17.70.010 - Purposes. 
    The planned unit development (PUD) provides for project variety and diversity in any zoning district through the process established in this chapter. Development flexibility is provided in exchange for on-going community benefits that achieve the following purposes: 
A.  To encourage a mix of different land uses which results in: 
1.  Commercial, office, recreational and educational facilities conveniently located to residential uses; 
2.  Economic benefits to the public due to efficient use of land and of public and private services; 
3.  Lessen the burden of traffic on streets, roads, and highways; 
4.  Commercial, institutional and employment based land uses, accessible to residential land uses by multiple modes of transportation, including walking, biking, transit or automobiles; or 
5.  Increased public open spaces in higher density residential and mixed-use settings. 
B.  To encourage innovations in residential, commercial, recreational and industrial development and redevelopment which: 
1.  Results in better management of or reduction in the environmental impacts of development on the surrounding community; or 
2.  Relates the type, design, and layout of residential, commercial, recreational, and industrial development to the particular site, thereby encouraging preservation of important natural and environmental characteristics of the site. 
C.  To allow flexibility in the application of the zoning requirements regarding bulk, setbacks, lot sizes, and open space, due to unique physical conditions of a particular site, while ensuring that such flexibility will not be used in a manner that distorts the objectives of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 8, 11-19-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8720, § 8, adopted Nov. 19, 2013, repealed former § 17.70.010, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 7500, § 1, 2002. 
17.70.020 - Applicability. 
A.  Minimum District Size. A site proposed for a planned unit development shall contain a contiguous area of five acres or more, unless the planning commission and city council find that a smaller district is appropriate due to special and unusual circumstances. In no case shall the contiguous site area be less than two acres. Property is contiguous if all parts are under unified control and abut or are separated only by a road, easement or right-of-way. 
B.  Additions. Additions to existing planned unit developments shall have no minimum size provided that: 
1.  The addition is contiguous with the original planned unit development; 
2.  The addition can be fully integrated in function, operation, and aesthetics, into the original planned unit development; and 
3.  The addition is subject to all approval standards of the original planned unit development. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.70.030 - Establishment of allowed and conditional uses. 
A.  Allowed Uses. Any use specifically authorized in a zoning district may become part of a planned unit development, provided the council finds the use compatible with the existing and planned uses in the development and on adjacent properties. 
B.  Conditional Uses. All uses allowed by conditional use permit pursuant to Section 17.84 may become part of a planned unit development, provided that all of the procedures and requirements for that conditional use are met. 
C.  Adoption and Modification of Authorized Uses. The council, at the time of adoption of an ordinance establishing a PUD shall list the uses that are authorized by right and by conditional use permit. All authorized uses shall be subject to applicable permit and approval processes established in these regulations. Modification of the authorized use lists for any PUD shall be processed pursuant to a rezoning application as established in 17.96. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.70.040 - Development standards. 
A.  Generally. Planned unit developments shall comply with the standards for the zoning district most closely associated with each proposed use, except where the city finds that public or private amenities provided by the proposed development exceed those that would be achieved through development that strictly complies with the minimum standards of the zoning districts. 
B.  Modification of Standards. 
1.  Mixed Use PUDs. A mixed-use PUD shall include at least two land uses which are not allowed together in any single zoning district, and each use must account for at least twenty-five (25) percent of the land area. The remaining fifty (50) percent of the land area may be used for any use approved through the plan. Any mixed-use PUD may modify the zoning district standards as follows: 
a.  Residential Density and Nonresidential intensity. Residential density and nonresidential floor area ratios may, in the discretion of the planning commission and city council, be increased by up to ten (10) percent of the regular district standards if the PUD contains: 
i.  A mix of housing types including single-family, two-family, and multi-family, integrated throughout the PUD; 
ii.  Uses, designed within convenient walking distance of the majority of residences, that commonly and customarily support the residential neighborhoods, such as a neighborhood grocery store, a neighborhood hardware store, personal services, recreational facilities, and public institutions; 
iii.  Increased open space and parks, accessible throughout the PUD, for active or passive recreation; 
iv.  Transportation amenities, including walking trails, bicycle trails or lanes, and transit facilities; 
v.  A street layout that provides multiple connections and access points for all of the various uses and provides multiple route options between the various uses; 
vi.  Architectural standards that assure the compatibility of the different types of residential uses, and of the residential and nonresidential uses; or 
vii.  Any other provisions in excess of the minimum standards that the planning commission and city council determines necessary to add to the public benefit and offset the increase in density. 
b.  Dimensional Standards. Dimensional standards such as setbacks, building height, lot area may be modified if the applicant can demonstrate that: 
i.  Buildings can be designed safely and compatibly with lesser setbacks; 
ii.  Modification of the dimensional standards is offset by readily accessible public, private, or common open space; and 
iii.  All buildings are provided with adequate emergency access for fire protection, emergency management technicians, or other public safety concern. 
c.  Parking and landscape requirements are subject to the provisions of Chapters 17.76 and 17.78, respectively. 
d.  The adopted building code of the City of North Kansas City shall not be varied or modified in any manner by the adoption of a PUD. Any modification of the building code shall be by the procedures set forth in that code. 
2.  Single-Use PUDs. A PUD which contains only uses which could be authorized in a single zoning district or any plan not meeting the requirements of a mixed-use PUD in 17.70.040 (B)(1) may modify the zoning district standards subject to the following: 
a.  The modification will only be allowed for: 
i.  Innovations in site development which result in less or better management of the environmental impacts of development on the surrounding community, or which allow preservation of important natural and environmental characteristics of the site by incorporating them into the site design; or 
ii.  To allow flexibility in the application of the zoning requirements due to unique physical conditions of a particular site, while ensuring that such flexibility will not be used in a manner that distorts the objectives of these regulations. 
b.  Dimensional standards. Dimensional standards such as setbacks, building height, lot area may be modified if the applicant can demonstrate that: 
i.  Buildings can be designed safely and compatibly with lesser setbacks; 
ii.  Modification of the dimensional standards is offset by readily accessible public, private, or common open space; 
iii.  All buildings are provided with adequate emergency access for fire protection, emergency management technicians, or other public safety concern; and 
iv.  The purpose of 17.70.040(B)(2)(a) above, could only be achieved by the modification of the standards. 
c.  Residential Density and Nonresidential intensity. Residential density and floor area ratios for non residential uses shall not be modified for single-use PUDs. 
d.  Parking and landscape requirements are subject to the provisions of Chapters 17.76 and 17.78, respectively. 
e.  The adopted building code of the City of North Kansas City shall not be varied or modified in any manner by the adoption of a PUD. Any modification of the building code shall be by the procedures set forth in that code. 
C.  Approved Plan. No use of the parcel, nor construction, modification or alteration of any use or structure within a PUD shall be permitted unless such construction or use complies with the terms and conditions of the approved plan. 
    Each subsequent owner and/or entity created by the development, such as a property owner's association or an architectural review committee, shall comply with the terms and conditions of the approved plan. A seller of a property that is zoned PUD or which is in the process of receiving such approval shall notify the buyer of the terms and conditions of PUD approval. The City bears no liability for misrepresentation of terms and conditions of an existing approval. 
    The developer shall set forth the conditions of approval within covenants that shall be recorded with the final approved map and plan. 
D.  Surrounding Land Use. The PUD shall be designed and arranged so that all uses on the perimeter of the PUD are compatible with surrounding land uses, such that the PUD may be integrated into the existing surrounding land uses rather than separated with buffers. 
(Ord. 8015 § 7, 2005; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8418, §§ 7, 8, 8-25-2009) 
17.70.050 - Application, procedures, and review criteria. 
    A planned unit development shall be reviewed according to the following procedures and criteria. 
A.  Sketch Plan and Rezoning Application. Applicants for a planned unit development shall submit a rezoning request pursuant to the procedures established in Section 17.96. In addition to the requirements of Section 17.96, an application for a planned unit development shall include a sketch plan including the following: 
1.  All information required by the City subdivision regulations for preliminary subdivision approval; 
2.  All the various existing and proposed land uses, depicting their relationship to each other and to surrounding uses; 
3.  All information required for a site plan for any non-single-family uses; 
4.  A list of all proposed uses and all proposed conditional uses; 
5.  The approximate number of acres in each proposed use category; 
6.  The density being requested for each type of residential use proposed; 
7.  The intensity (floor area ratio) for each non residential use proposes; 
8.  The legal description for the entire area of the plan; 
9.  If the project will be phased, a phasing plan establishing what order the plan will be built, demonstrating how each individual phase meets the requirements of this section, and specifying how all streets and utilities will constructed in conjunction with the proposed phases; 
10.  Names and addresses of property owners within one hundred eighty-five (185) feet of all boundaries of the property. 
11.  A written narrative report for the plan explaining how the elements of the plan function together, justifying all modifications of zoning district standards according to these regulations, and establishing the proposed architectural character of dwellings, structures, or uses on each portion of the property; 
12.  A preliminary plan submitted in accordance with the city's sign regulations concerning PUDs as they relate to applicable sign districts (see Section 15.44.270). 
B.  Application Process. The rezoning application and sketch plan for the planned unit development shall be processed according to the procedures established in Section 17.96 for a rezoning request. 
C.  Review Criteria. In addition to the review criteria established in Section 17.96 for a rezoning request, the planning commission and city council shall consider the following additional criteria when reviewing a planned unit development: 
1.  The PUD is consistent with the purposes and standards established in this Section 17.70; 
2.  No land use in the PUD, and no modification requested as part of a PUD, is detrimental to any surrounding land use, or any proposed land use within the plan area; 
3.  Any request for modification of the zoning district standards meet the requirements of this Section 17.70 and results in ongoing community benefits beyond what would be required in any single zoning district; 
4.  The extent that the proposed mixture of uses is at a ratio of residential to non residential use which allow the uses to mutually support each other; 
5.  The purpose, location and amount of common open space in the planned unit development relative to the proposed density and type of residential development, and the reliability of proposals for maintenance and conservation of common open space; 
6.  The physical design of the plan and the extent that adequate provision for public facilities, services, and traffic control; and 
7.  In the case of a multiphased plan, the sufficiency of the terms and conditions intended to protect the interests of the public, residents and owners of the planned unit development and the integrity of the plan. 
D.  Approved Action. If the city council approves an application, it shall adopt an ordinance establishing the rezoning and specifying that development of the property is subject to the terms of an approved final plan. No permit shall be issued concerning the subject property until the ordinance becomes effective and a final plan has been adopted. 
1.  Duration of Approval. Sketch plan approval shall be valid for one year, unless otherwise established at the time of approval. One extension of time for a maximum of one year may be granted by the city council. 
2.  Revocation of Approval. Sketch plan approval shall be revoked automatically at the time of expiration through no action by the city. Subsequent to sketch plan approval revocation, the city may initiate a rezoning action to rezone the property to an appropriate classification. 
E.  Final Plan. 
1.  Application. A final plan shall be adopted prior to expiration of a sketch plan and prior to any construction or permits being issued for the planned unit development. A final plan shall include: 
a.  All information required by the city subdivision regulations for final subdivision approval; 
b.  All information in the proposed sketch plan; 
c.  Final plans for all road grading, surfacing, signing and lighting, and curbs and gutters; 
d.  Final location of all sidewalks, pedestrian walks, trails and associated structures; 
e.  A final engineering plan for all sanitary sewers, water lines, fire hydrants, and drainage structures and improvements; 
f.  Location and design of all open space improvements, facilities and landscaping; 
g.  Final location and size all structures and parking areas; 
h.  Building elevations for all commercial and multi-family residential structures; and 
i.  A final written narrative of the plan establishing all architectural controls, covenants, and restrictions on the future use of land within the plan. If a homeowners association or similar organization is proposed by the applicant, for the purposes of maintaining and administering the development's lands, streets and/or facilities, the applicant shall provide restrictive covenants. These documents shall be recorded at or prior to the recording of the final map. 
j.  A final sign plan in accordance with the city's sign regulations concerning PUDs as they relate to applicable sign districts (see Section 15.44.240). 
2.  Submission and Determination of Complete Application. 
a.  Final plans shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for a determination of completeness. The zoning administrator shall make this determination within ten (10) business days of submission. 
b.  Applications will be considered complete when all items required for submissions by these regulations and the appropriate fee have been submitted to the zoning administrator. 
c.  Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with a written explanation of deficiencies. The city shall take no further action on incomplete applications. 
d.  Complete applications shall be processed in accordance with this section. The zoning administrator shall notify the applicant that the application was determined to be complete. 
e.  If the zoning administrator fails to act within ten (10) business days, the application shall be deemed complete and the applicant shall request the zoning administrator to issue a notice of completeness. 
f.  Modification of the application by the applicant without specific instruction to do so from the zoning administrator, the planning commission, or city council following a determination of completeness shall void the determination and trigger a new ten (10) day review period. 
g.  A determination of completeness shall not constitute a determination of compliance with the substantive requirements of these regulations. 
3.  Processing of Application and Scheduled Review. Following the determination that a final plan is complete or is deemed complete, the zoning administrator shall prepare a report and forward the plan for review to the planning commission. Upon receipt of the application and report, the planning commission shall schedule review of the plan at its next regular meeting, or at such other time as the applicant and zoning administrator agree. 
4.  Plan Commission Review and Criteria. The planning commission shall review the final plan at a public meeting and consider whether the final plan is in substantial compliance with the sketch plan based on the following criteria; 
a.  The final plan does not vary the proposed gross residential density by more than five percent and in no case may it be increased more than the maximum modification allowed by Section 17.70.040; 
b.  The final plan does not increase the floor area or intensity proposed for nonresidential use by more than five percent and in no case may it be increased more than the maximum modification allowed by Section 17.70.040; 
c.  The final plan does not vary the proposed ratio of residential to nonresidential use, or the ratio of any different types of residential uses by more than five percent. 
d.  The final plan does not involve a reduction of the area set aside for common open space, or the substantial relocation of such area; 
e.  The final plan does not substantially increase the total ground areas covered by buildings or involve a substantial change in the height of buildings; 
f.  Any staff recommendations. 
5.  Planning Commission Decision. The planning commission may approve, deny or conditionally approve the application, or take such other action as it deems appropriate. 
6.  Approved Action. If the planning commission approves an application, it shall adopt a resolution reflecting such action. 
7.  Duration of Approval. Final plan approval shall be valid for two years, unless otherwise established at the time of approval. One extension of time for a maximum of two years may be granted by the planning commission. 
8.  Revocation. If no action has been taken in furtherance of development, the final plan approval shall be revoked automatically at the time of expiration through no action by the city. Subsequent to sketch plan approval revocation, the city may initiate a rezoning action to rezone the property to an appropriate classification. 
9.  Amendments and Revisions. 
a.  The zoning administrator may approve minor revisions to a final plan approved as part of a PUD. Minor revisions must be authorized in writing by the zoning administrator and limited to those that are necessary in light of technical considerations due to natural features on the property discovered by the applicant or zoning administrator after the decision on the final plan. Minor revisions may include those that: 
i.  Will not have the affect of changing the nonresidential floor area ratio or residential density from that of the approved final plan; 
ii.  Will not result in any parking area, vehicle circulation, pedestrian connections being moved significantly in any direction; 
iii.  Will not have the affect of changing any dimensional standard such as setbacks, building height, lot area by more than five percent from that of the approved final; 
iv.  Will not result in any change in uses, or change in the percent of land area used for any particular use; 
v.  Will not increase or create any new adverse impacts or undesirable affects on the surrounding neighborhood or any property within the plan. 
b.  Planning Commission Revisions. If a revision exceeds requirements of a minor revision, but would still comply with the requirements specified in the ordinance authorizing the PUD, the planning commission may approve an amendment to the final plan, in the same manner as the original authorization, and by resolution. 
c.  If the applicant requests a revision that the zoning administrator determines is not a minor revision nor a planning commission revision, approval of the revision is required in accordance with the procedures established for the original approval, and shall be considered an amendment to the ordinance approving the rezoning and resolution approving the final plan. 
(Ord. 8015 §§ 8-13, 2005; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8603, § 1, 2-7-2012) 
Chapter 17.72 - HEIGHT AND AREA REQUIREMENTS 
Sections: 

17.72.010 - Generally. 
    The regulations and requirements as to height of buildings and area of lots which may be occupied by buildings, front yards, side yards, rear yards and other regulations and requirements as follows in the foregoing sections of this title shall be subject to the following exceptions and additional regulations. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.020 - Height. 
A.  In any district, public or semipublic buildings, such as hospitals, churches, sanitariums or schools, either public or private, where permitted, may be erected to a height not exceeding one hundred (100) feet; provided, that such buildings shall have yards which shall be increased one foot on all sides for each additional foot that such buildings exceed the specified height limit as established by the regulations of the district in which such buildings are situated. 
B.  Parapet walls and false mansards may extend not more than six feet above the height limit. Flagpoles, chimneys, cooling towers, elevator bulkheads, penthouses, finials, tanks, grain elevators, stacks, storage towers, radio transmitter towers, ornamental towers, monuments, cupolas, domes, spires, standpipes and other necessary mechanical appurtenances may be erected as to height in accordance with other local regulations and in conformance with air space regulations relative to the Kansas City Municipal Airport. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.030 - Yard exceptions. 
A.  Residential Districts. In districts R-1A, R-1B, R-2, R-3, R-4, and R-5 where lots comprising forty (40) percent or more of the frontage, on the same side of a street between two intersecting streets, (excluding reverse comer lots) are developed with buildings having front yards with a variation of not more than ten (10) feet in depth, the average of such front yards shall establish the minimum front yard depth for the entire frontage; provided, that the board of adjustment may establish a reasonable setback in case of hardship or where the configuration of the ground and buildings is such as to make conformity with the front yard requirements impractical. 
B.  C-0 to M-2 Districts. In districts C-0 to M-2 inclusive, where buildings located in the same block on the same side of a street have provided front yards of greater or less depth than herein required, the board of adjustment may establish setbacks for buildings or structures constructed hereafter. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.040 - Official line for future widening or opening of street. 
    Where an official line has been established by the city council or state highway commission for future widening or opening of a street upon which a lot abuts, then the depth or width of a yard shall be measured from such official line to the nearest line of the building. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.050 - Required yard or court to be open-Exceptions. 
    Every part of a required yard shall be open from its lowest point to the sky, unobstructed except for the ordinary projection of sills, belt courses, cornices, chimneys, buttresses, ornamental features and eaves; provided, however, that none of the above projections shall extend into a minimum yard more than twenty-four (24) inches; and provided further, that canopies or open porches having a roof area not exceeding sixty (60) square feet may project a maximum of six feet into the required front or rear yard and existing open porches extending into the required yard shall not be enclosed. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.060 - Fire escapes and stairways. 
    An open fire escape may project into a required side yard not more than half the width of such yard, but not more than four feet from the building. Fire escapes, solid floored balconies and enclosed outside stairways may project not more than four feet into a required rear yard. A below grade exterior stairway shall have a rail not less than three feet in height surrounding the below grade area. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.080 - Sight distance on corner lots. 
    All corner lots shall provide sight distance triangles, the short leg of which shall be twenty (20) feet, and the long leg of which shall be one hundred forty (140) feet measured along the curb line or edge of the pavement. Such area shall be and remain free of shrubbery, fences or other obstruction to vision more than two feet in height measured from the roadway. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.090 - Rear yards in C-1 to M-2 districts. 
    No rear yard shall be required in districts C-1 and M-2 inclusive on any lot used for business or industrial purposes, the rear line of which adjoins a railway right-of-way or which has a rear railway track connection. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.72.100 - Through lot with one end abutting a limited access highway. 
    A through lot having one end abutting a limited access highway, or thoroughfare with no access permitted to that lot from said highway shall be deemed to front upon the street which gives access to that lot. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.76 - PARKING AND LOADING REQUIREMENTS 
Sections: 

17.76.010 - Statement of purpose. 
    The goals of the parking requirements, in order of priority, are as follows: 
A.  To provide sufficient parking to support the intended land use; 
B.  To design off-street parking in such a way so as to promote safe access to and from, and circulation within, the parking area; 
C.  To ensure that parking areas are located and designed to reduce visual impacts on adjacent properties and streetscapes; 
D.  To promote mass transit and bicycle usage. 
(Ord. 8293 § 3 (part), 2008) 
17.76.030 - Parking spaces required. 
A.  All new buildings or structures hereafter constructed shall provide off-street parking according to the requirements specified within this chapter. 
B.  Use of Required Off-Street Parking Areas. Off-street parking spaces shall be used solely for the parking of motor vehicles in operating condition and shall not be used for the sale, repair, dismantling, or service of any vehicle, nor for the sale, display, or storage of equipment, goods, materials, or supplies; unless otherwise permitted within this title. (See also property maintenance code) 
C.  Spaces Required. 
1.  Spaces Required by Use. 
By Use Requirement Churches, Theatres, Athletic Fields, Assembly Halls and Other Seating Facilities 1 space per three seats, unless in the C-2 district where no off-street parking is required. Libraries 1 space per two employees and 1 space per 200 square feet of floor area Fraternity or sorority houses, or dormitories 1 space per two employees and 1 space per resident room or two beds Hotels and apartment Hotels 1 space per two employees and 1 space per guest room or two guest beds Hospital/Clinic, Institutional Living, Assisted Living, Transitional Living Center Planning Commission determination based on parking study provided by applicant Gymnasiums, tennis courts, and similar recreation facilities not owned by the city Planning Commission determination based on parking study provided by applicant  
2.  Spaces Required by Zoning District. Except for the uses specifically listed above or elsewhere in this title, parking spaces shall be provided by the zoning district as noted below. 
Residential Districts Requirement R-1A and R-1B Two off-street parking spaces shall be provided for each single-family dwelling, at least one of which shall be a garage or carport. R-2 Two off-street parking spaces shall be provided for each single-family dwelling unit. R-3 Two off-street parking spaces shall be provided for each dwelling unit. R-4 One off-street parking space shall be provided for each one bedroom unit. 
Two off-street parking spaces shall be provided for every two or more bedroom units. 
For rooming houses, one off-street parking space shall be provided for each occupant or permanent guest, either on the premises or within two hundred (200) feet of walking distance therefrom. R-5 Either on the premises, or within two hundred (200) feet of the entrance to the building: 
One off-street parking space shall be provided for each one bedroom unit. 
Two off-street parking spaces shall be provided for every two or more bedroom units.  
Commercial Districts Requirement C-0, C-1, & C-3 Restaurants, including fast food establishments, shall provide one parking space for every two and one-half (2.5) seats based on the maximum designed seating capacity. All other uses in these districts shall provide four and one-half (4.5) off-street parking spaces for each one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor area. For the conforming commercial uses of this district, if the location of such commercial property is located within three hundred (300) feet of a city owned public parking facility, such parking will be considered as an acceptable alternative to the off-street parking requirement of this district. C-2 No off-street parking for commercial users required in this district. For residential uses, one off-street parking space shall be provided per bedroom, not to exceed a maximum of two parking spaces. Required parking spaces for residential uses shall be located within three hundred (300) feet of the entrance to the residential portions of the building.  
Gaming District Requirement G-1 Four and one-half off-street parking spaces shall be provided for each one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor area.  
Industrial Districts Requirement M-1 and M-2 Each industrial establishment shall provide one space per one thousand (1,000) square feet of total floor area. 
Any office or commercial use as enumerated in any of the commercial districts of this chapter, shall provide four and one-half parking spaces per one thousand (1,000) square feet of total floor area. Further, any warehouse or industrial spaces converting to commercial uses, shall provide four and one-half parking spaces per one thousand (1,000) square feet of total floor area.  
3.  Maximum Number of Parking Spaces. The maximum number of off-street parking spaces that may be permitted shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) percent of the minimum number of spaces required. 
4.  Accessible Parking Spaces. In each off-street parking lot, a portion of the total number of required parking spaces shall be specifically designated, located and reserved for use by persons with disabilities. The standards governing provision of parking spaces for persons with disabilities shall be according to the most recent adopted provisions of the International Commercial Code. One in every four accessible spaces shall be designed and designated for lift van accessibility in accordance with the requirements of Mo. Rev. Stat. § 301.143. 
5.  When measurements of the number of required spaces result in fractions, any fraction shall be disregarded to determine the required whole number. 
6.  Shared Parking. By conditional use permit, the city may authorize a reduction in the number of parking spaces for multiple use developments or for uses that are located near one another and which have different peak parking demands and operating hours. The city may consider such shared parking, but shall be subject to the following standards: 
a.  As a part of the application materials required for a conditional use permit, the applicant seeking shared parking shall submit a study to the zoning administrator which: (1) clearly establishes that uses will make use of the shared spaces at different times of the day, week, month or year; (2) addresses the size and types of activities, composition of tenants, rate of turnover for parking spaces, and anticipated peak parking and traffic loads; (3) that such a study is based upon the Urban Land Institute's "shared parking" table provided below, or other industry standards as the city determines to be acceptable for the types of uses proposed. 
b.  Shared Parking Table. Parking requirements shall be the cumulative requirements of the uses sharing the parking, except where different categories of uses (retail or service, employment, civic, or dwellings) are participating in the sharing agreement and are likely to generate distinctly different times of peak parking demand. The following table is a base guide for shared parking. Each use should provide a percentage of parking required by these regulations according to the shared parking table below. Whichever time period column requires the highest total parking spaces among the various uses should be the amount of parking provided subject to the shared parking agreement. Alternative parking allocations may be approved as a function of the conditional use permit based on industry data or other sufficient evidence and analysis of peak parking demands for specific uses.

c.  If proposed for multiple parcels or lots, the shared parking plan shall be enforced through a written agreement signed by the property owner(s), to be reviewed and approved by the zoning administrator and city counselor, and which shall be recorded with the recorder of deeds. 
d.  Should any of the shared parking uses be changed, or the zoning administrator find that any of the conditions described in the parking study no longer exist, the zoning administrator may require a revised shared parking study and an amended shared parking agreement. 
e.  Failure to comply with the shared parking requirements of this subsection shall constitute a violation of these regulations and shall be a cause for revocation of the conditional use permit. 
7.  Deferral of Required Spaces. A portion of the parking area required by this title may remain unimproved until such time as the site plan review committee deems it must be improved to adequately serve current parking demand. A permit for construction of such delayed improvement may be issued only after the site plan review committee is satisfied that the initial occupancy of the premises will be adequately served by the lesser number of spaces and only after approval of a final development plan indicating clearly the location, pattern and circulation to and from the initial and the delayed parking spaces. The land area so delineated for future parking shall be brought to finished grade, be landscaped, and shall not be used for building, storage, loading or other purposes. Appeals to the decisions of the site plan review committee may be made to the planning commission. 
8.  Parking Space Reduction Under the Minimum Required. 
a.  Minor reductions (ten (10) percent or less) from the required number of parking spaces may be approved by the staff site plan review committee: 
i.  Upon consideration of the proposed use as well as potential future uses of the site; 
ii.  When the evidence presented, indicates the lesser number of spaces will be sufficient for the needs of the specified use on the site; and 
iii.  When such a reduction better promotes the goals stated in the statement of purpose section of this chapter. 
b.  Significant reductions greater than ten (10) percent may be approved by the planning commission: 
i.  Upon consideration of the proposed use as well as potential future uses of the site; 
ii.  When the requested reduction is based on upon such credible sources as the most recent versions of either the APA Parking Standards PAS Report, or the ITE Parking Generation report; 
iii.  When the evidence presented, indicates the lesser number of spaces will be sufficient for the needs of the specified use on the site; and 
iv.  When such a reduction better promotes the goals stated in the statement of purpose section of this chapter. 
c.  Reductions (twenty (20) percent or less) from the required number of parking spaces shall be approved if: 
i.  Any portion of the property is within five hundred (500) feet of a heavy passenger rail, light rail, streetcar, or trolley station; 
ii.  Any portion of the property is within two hundred fifty (250) feet of a bus rapid transit stop (a bus route with stops no more than every one-quarter mile); or 
iii.  If any portion of the property is within one hundred (100) feet from a standard bus stop or a city-provided bicycle rack capable of holding at least two bicycles. 
9.  Parking Space Increase Over the Maximum Permitted. 
a.  Minor increases (ten (10) percent or less) above the maximum number of parking spaces may be approved by the staff site plan review committee: 
i.  Upon consideration of the proposed use as well as potential future uses of the site; and 
ii.  When the evidence presented, indicates the greater number of spaces will be sufficient for the needs of the specified use on the site. 
b.  Significant increases greater than ten (10) percent may be approved by the planning commission: 
i.  Upon consideration of the proposed use as well as potential future uses of the site; 
ii.  When the requested increase is based on upon such credible sources as the most recent versions of either the APA Parking Standards PAS Report, or the ITE Parking Generation report; and 
iii.  When the evidence presented, indicates the greater number of spaces will be sufficient for the needs of the specified use on the site. 
(Ord. 8293 § 3 (part), 2008) 
(Ord. No. 8418, § 9, 8-25-2009; Ord. No. 8509, § 3, 12-14-2010; Ord. No. 8720, § 9, 11-19-2013; Ord. No. 9012, § 1, 7-18-2017) 
17.76.050 - Loading requirements. 
    All nonresidential uses shall provide adequate loading space within a building or on the premises in such a way that all storage, standing and maneuvering of trucks and other service vehicles shall be off the public right-of-way, and shall not obstruct the movements of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. 8293 § 3 (part), 2008) 
17.76.070 - Design standards and improvements. 
A.  Location of parking area. 
1.  "Head-In" Parking. With the exception of customary driveways for single-family and two-family dwellings, head-in" parking spaces on private property where each space is directly and individually accessible to public right-of-way is prohibited. Except, such "head-in" parking may be permitted by conditional use permit provided that it meets the following criteria: 
a.  Such "head in" parking is perceived as, and functions the same as on-street parking along a block face; 
b.  Adequate and continuous pedestrian access exists along the front of all "head-in" parking spaces, and connects to the overall pedestrian circulation system of surrounding areas; and 
c.  Perpendicular or angled spaces may be considered provided that adequate sight and backing distance exists for the safe movement of vehicles, relative to the traffic volumes and speeds along the street.

NOT THIS 

2.  Districts R-1A to R-5. No parking shall be permitted in the required front yard or within thirty (30) feet of a public street; except, that parking of motor passenger cars shall be permitted in customary driveways of single-family and two-family dwellings. 
3.  District C-0. 
a.  No parking area in a front yard shall extend closer than fifteen (15) feet to the street; 
b.  No parking area shall extend closer than four feet to an adjacent property line or an adjacent right-of-way line; 
c.  No parking spaces shall be located within six feet of an adjoining residential lot, in a residential district. 
4.  District C-1. 
a.  Parking shall be located in the side or rear yard;
