Notice shall be sent by the zoning administrator, by U.S. mail at least fifteen (15) business days before the hearing to each current owner of real property, as listed in the official records of the Clay County Recorder of Deeds, located within one hundred eighty-five (185) feet of the exterior boundary of the property in question unless otherwise specified by the zoning administrator. 
2.  The failure of a property owner to receive notice by mail shall not be grounds for invalidating any action taken by the planning commission or city council. 
C.  Posted Notice. The zoning administrator shall cause to be posted at least one sign on the subject property at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. The sign(s) shall remain posted on the property until after the close of the public hearing. The sign shall give notice of the date, time and place of the hearing and the action requested. The zoning administrator shall prescribe the size, format, and location of the sign(s). The sign shall be the property of the City of North Kansas City and it shall be a public offense for any person to remove, deface, conceal or destroy any such sign. The placement of signs is for the convenience and information of the public and the absence of such signs during all or part of the specified period of time shall in no way impair or nullify proceedings on the action being considered. 
D.  Substantial Compliance Required. Minor technical deviations in the language of published, personal or posted notice shall not be deemed to impair the notice where actual notice has been given. Where there is a question raised at the hearing regarding the adequacy of notice, the planning commission shall make a formal finding as to whether there was substantial compliance with the notice requirement of these regulations. 
E.  Review and Recommendation by Planning Commission. The planning commission shall hold a public hearing to receive evidence and consider the application. Evidence may be submitted with the application or thereafter, or presented during the public hearing by the applicant or others. The commission's written recommendations, together with the application, staff report, any exhibits or evidence made a part of the record at the hearing, and a transcript or recording of the public hearing shall constitute the "official record" which shall be forwarded to city council for its decision. 
F.  Public Hearing. Unless a hearing or the requirements herein are waived by applicant, each hearing shall provide a record of the proceedings (by audio, video, stenographic, or other reliable means of recording capable of transcription) and shall permit the parties to introduce evidence under oath, and shall provide for cross-examination, when requested. The formal hearing requirements herein shall be deemed waived if not affirmatively requested by applicant in its petition. 
G.  Scope of Action. The planning commission may make a recommendation to the city council that is consistent with the notice given, including approval of the application, conditional approval of the application or denial of the application. The planning commission may allow amendments or recommend conditions to the application if the effect is to allow a lesser change than that requested on the original application or to reduce the impact of the application or to reduce the amount of land involved from that indicated in the notices of the hearing. The planning commission may not, in any case, recommend a greater amount of development, or a use falling in a different general use category, or a larger land area than indicated in the original application and notice. 
H.  Review Criteria. In determining whether any proposed conditional use permit shall be approved, the planning commission and city council shall consider the following factors: 
1.  Whether the proposed use at the specified location is consistent with the policies embodied in the adopted master plan; 
2.  Whether the proposed use is consistent with the general purpose and intent of the applicable zoning district regulations and complies with the requirements of the zoning ordinance; 
3.  Whether the proposed conditional use may be materially detrimental to the public health, safety, convenience and welfare, or may result in material damage or prejudice to other property in the vicinity; 
4.  Whether the proposed use is compatible with and preserves the character and integrity of adjacent development and neighborhoods and includes improvements or modifications either on-site or within the public rights-of-way to mitigate any adverse impacts which may result from the development, such as traffic, noise, odors, visual nuisances, or other similar adverse effects; 
I.  Decision by City Council. Following the planning commission's public hearing and receipt of the planning commission's official record, the city council shall consider only the official record and decide whether to approve, conditionally approve or deny the conditional use permit application. The city council may hold its own hearing to take additional evidence or hear additional public comment if it reasonably determines additional evidence or comment is necessary or appropriate and shall supplement the official record accordingly and make its decision thereon. 
J.  Findings Required. The city council's decision shall be contemporaneously accompanied by substantial evidence supporting the decision, which shall be made a part of the written record of the meeting at which a final decision on the application is rendered. 
1.  No conditional use permit shall be approved by the city council unless findings in the affirmative are made that the following conditions exist: 
a.  That the applicant has clearly demonstrated by substantial evidence that placement of wireless facilities permitted as a permitted use or through an administrative permit pursuant to this section is not technologically or economically feasible. The city may consider current or emerging industry standards and practices, among other information, in determining feasibility; 
b.  That the review criteria with or without conditions imposed are generally met; 
c.  If a disguised support structure is proposed, the structure fully satisfies the disguised element requirements, provided that requirement for disguise may be waived if the support structure is otherwise in compliance with this section and the city council finds on a showing by applicant that (1) no disguised support structure(s) could be proposed that are economically and technically feasible to substantially address the need for the tower or (2) if, located in an industrial district, the location and appearance proposed is such that the application still meet the criteria of this section; 
d.  That the design of the wireless facilities, including ground layout, maximally reduces visual degradation and otherwise complies with the provisions and intent of this section; 
e.  That the proposed height, location, design, and appearance of the wireless facility is of a type and nature commonly found in the area and shall not materially detrimentally impact the view of the surrounding area, safety, or the surrounding property values or uses. The city council may impose location, appearance, safety or other conditions as may be appropriate to address the nature of the use and conform to the purposes of this code; 
f.  That the proposal fully complies with applicable law including all requirements of this section, provided that an exception to the requirements, other than building or safety code compliance, may be approved upon substantial evidence that compliance is not feasible or is shown to be unreasonable under the specific circumstances shown; 
K.  Scope of Action. The city council may take any action on the application that is consistent with the notice given, conditional approval of the application or denial of the application. The city council may impose conditions as are reasonably necessary to assure compliance with applicable general or specific standards stated in these regulations. Any conditions recommended by the zoning administrator or planning commission may be modified by the city council based on the official record. 
L.  Continuances of Proceedings. Given the various time restrictions applicable to approvals under this section, unless otherwise required by law or agreed upon by the applicant and the city, there shall be no continuance granted for the scheduled public hearing, unless the meeting is cancelled for reasons beyond the city's control. 
M.  Amendments and Revisions. The zoning administrator may approve minor revisions to a site plan approved as part of a conditional use permit when authorized in writing by the zoning administrator and limited to those that are necessary in light of technical considerations discovered by the applicant or zoning administrator after the decision on the conditional use permit. 
N.  Revocation of a Conditional Use Permit. Unless otherwise required by law, any conditional use permit granted under the authority of these regulations is subject to revocation pursuant to and in accordance with the procedures in Section 17.96.020.K.3-4 and applicable law. 
O.  Transferability. Unless otherwise required by law, a conditional use permit shall not be transferred without the prior written consent of the city. The transfer of a permit where these conditions have not been satisfied shall be invalid. 
4.  Appeals. The administrative review procedures set forth in Chapter 2.46 shall govern appeals by any aggrieved person of a final action of any city officer, employee, board, commission, or the city council that are claimed by an aggrieved person to be unlawful or an unconstitutional taking of property without compensation. To the fullest extent permitted by law, the review procedures of Chapter 2.46 shall be exhausted before any action may be filed in any court against the city or its officers, employees, boards, officials or commissions. Nothing herein shall be deemed to unlawfully limit any remedy that is required to be available as a matter of law. 
(Ord. No. 8944, § 3, 9-20-2016; Ord. No. 9024, §§ 1, 2, 9-19-2017; Ord. No. 9154, § 1, 12-18-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8944, § 3, adopted Sept. 20, 2016, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
17.84.040 - Additional requirements. 
    In granting a conditional use, the city may impose such conditions, safeguards and restrictions upon the premises to reduce or minimize any potential injurious effect of such conditional uses upon other property in the neighborhood, and to carry out the general purpose and intend of these regulations. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.84.050 - Short-term conditional uses. 
A.  The city council may authorize the issuance of a short-term conditional use permit for the use of a specific tract, parcel or section of the city for such temporary short term uses as: 
1.  Trade shows; 
2.  Street fairs; 
3.  Expositions such as art fairs, boat shows, etc.; 
4.  Promotional ventures; 
5.  Entertainment and recreation including carnivals and circuses; 
6.  Sidewalk, truckload and warehouse sales. 
B.  Such activities may be of a nonprofit, profit-making, civic br public agency nature and may be on private or public property. A short term conditional use permit may be approved by the city council without referral to the planning commission provided the following conditions are met: 
1.  The applicant shall submit in written form a complete description of the proposed activity, including estimates of traffic generation over and above normal flows, accumulation of vehicles including parking needs, accumulation of persons, hours of operation, ability to accommodate fire and police services and access, need for special protection and other characteristics that may affect the public safety, convenience and welfare. 
2.  In the case of use of a public street or sidewalk, a plan shall be submitted showing the location and type of any equipment, fixtures or other appurtenances that will be involved. Care shall be exercised in maintaining safe and convenient circulation for both vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
3.  It is required that the complete plans pertaining to an event requiring a conditional use permit shall be filed with the code enforcement division before the permit is presented to the council for consideration and that all conditions upon which the permit approval is granted shall be satisfied at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the scheduled commencement date of the event or the permit may be denied. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 17.88 - ACCESSORY USES 
Sections: 

17.88.010 - General regulations. 
    Buildings and structures may be erected and land may be used for purposes which are clearly incidental to, and customarily and commonly associated with the main permitted use of the premises. Such accessory buildings and uses shall be so constructed, maintained and conducted as to not produce noise, vibration, concussion, dust, dirt, fly ash, odor, noxious gases, heat or glare which is injurious, unhealthful or disturbing to adjacent property or the users thereof and shall be on the premises of the main use. 
A.  Generally. The following uses shall be permitted as accessory to main uses permitted in this Title 17. 
B.  Eligibility for Accessory Use. The determination of the eligibility of a proposed use as an accessory use shall be made by the zoning administrator and appeal can be made from his decision as set out in Chapter 17.92. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.88.020 - Home-based business standards for all residential zoning districts. 
A.  A home occupation shall employ only those who are permanent residents of the dwelling. 
B.  A home occupation shall be conducted only within an enclosed living area of the dwelling unit or the garage and shall be clearly incidental and secondary to the residential use of the structure. Home occupations shall not be permitted out-of-doors or in any trailer or in any accessory structure other than a garage, detached or integral to the house. The conduct of any home occupation shall not reduce the number of parking spaces below what is required by ordinance. 
C.  There shall be no storage of equipment or supplies associated with the home occupation outside of the dwelling or garage. 
D.  There shall be no change in the residential appearance of the dwelling or premises or any visible evidence of the conduct of a home occupation. On-site advertising of any nature is prohibited. 
E.  The use of commercial vehicles in conjunction with a home occupation shall be strictly limited to one vehicle not to exceed one ton, owned by a resident of the dwelling, which must be parked in a garage or a hard surfaced residential drive on site if available. Parking shall be handled in such a manner as to not impede or hinder traffic on any public right-of-way. Vehicles parked on public streets shall comply with all requirements of Section 10.48.040, "Parking not to obstruct traffic," and Section 10.48.190, "Oversize vehicles," of this code. 
F.  No equipment, machinery or operation shall be used in such activities that is perceptible off the premises by reason of noise, smoke, odor, dust, radiation, electrical interference or vibration. 
G.  Visitors, customers or deliveries shall not exceed that normally and reasonably occurring in a residential neighborhood, including not more than two commercial deliveries (other than mail or parcel services) of products or materials per week. Delivery vehicles shall be limited to those that are single-unit vehicles and have only two axles. Any need for parking generated by the conduct of a home occupation shall be met off the street and other than in a required front yard. 
1.  If the home occupation is the type in which customers or clients visit the premises, they shall be limited to eight business visitors a day per dwelling unit. Vehicular traffic associated with business visitors shall be limited to two vehicles at a time during allowable business hours stated below. 
2.  If the home occupation is the type in which classes are held or instruction is given, they shall be limited to twelve (12) students or pupils a day and not more than four at the same time. Classes of three or more pupils must be scheduled at least thirty (30) minutes apart to reduce traffic congestion. 
H.  In no case shall a home occupation be open to customers, clients or students at a time earlier than eight a.m. or later than nine p.m. with the exception of care providers for children or adults. 
I.  No highly flammable, combustible or explosive material shall be used or stored on the premises in conjunction with a home occupation. No activity shall be allowed that would interfere with radio or television transmission in the area, nor shall there be any offensive noise, vibration, smoke, dust, odors, heat or glare noticeable outside the structure. 
J.  Accumulation of inventories for public sale on premises and/or sale of any merchandise or products on display within or outside the residence are strictly prohibited, except that orders placed by private clients or at a sales party may be filled on premises. 
K.  No newspaper, radio, television or telephone listing shall be used to advertise the location of a home occupation to the general public. 
L.  Care facilities shall be limited to two adults or four children with not more than two children under two years of age or six children with none under two years, including the operator's own children. Care facilities for seven or more children or three adults shall be regulated by Chapter 17.84. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.88.030 - Districts R-1A, R-1B and R-2. 
A.  Garages and Carports. 
1.  In District R-1A for any dwelling unit, there may be permitted one private garage and one covered carport with space for not less than one automobile. A detached garage shall not be located less than sixty (60) feet from the front lot line, nor less than three feet from any side or rear lot line, nor less than three feet from any alley line. 
2.  In Districts R-1B and R-2 for any dwelling unit, there may be permitted one private garage and one covered carport with space for not less than one automobile. A detached garage shall not be located less than sixty (60) feet from the front lot line nor less than one foot from any side or rear lot line, nor less than one foot from any alley line. 
3.  No covered carport shall encroach upon any easement, nor shall any portion extend beyond the existing front building line, nor extend beyond the front yard setback. 
4.  No garage shall encroach on any easement. A garage constructed on a corner lot shall maintain the same setback from the street line adjoining the side yard as is required for the main building. A detached garage shall be limited to a single story with the roof peak not being higher than sixteen (16) feet above finished grade. The roof of a detached garage must have a pitch of at least 4:12 (four units rise per twelve (12) units run). The wall height of a detached garage shall not exceed nine feet above the finished floor. Detached garages constructed on lots with an area of four thousand five hundred (4,500) square feet or less, shall not occupy an area greater than four hundred (400) square feet, on lots greater than four thousand five hundred (4,500) square feet a detached garage shall not occupy an area greater than seven hundred fifty (750) square feet. The design and construction of a detached garage shall be similar to or compatible with the design and construction of the main building and surrounding structures. A garage constructed as an integral part of the main building shall be subject to the regulations affecting the main building and shall not exceed the height of the main building, nor set closer than eighteen (18) feet from the rear lot line, nor occupy more than thirty (30) percent of the required rear yard. All garages must be constructed on a frost depth footing designed for the structure. 
B.  Hobby Activity-Additional Uses. A hobby activity may be operated as an accessory use by the occupant of the premises purely for personal enjoyment, amusement or recreation; provided, that the articles produced or constructed are not sold either on or off the premises. Such additional uses as private swimming pools, gardens, customary pets, television and radio receiving antennae not exceeding sixty (60) feet in height, signs as permitted by ordinance, parking areas, accessory buildings, play equipment, the overnight parking of a truck of one ton rating or less and other similar uses shall be allowed. Any accessory use which exceeds ten (10) feet in height shall be located a distance inside the property line at least equal to one-third its height. 
C.  Vehicles for Personal Transportation. Motor passenger vehicles used for personal transportation of residents are a permitted accessory use provided such vehicles may only be stored in garages or parked on paved driveways of asphalt or Portland cement. 
D.  Recreational Vehicles, Watercraft and Trailers. 
1.  Long-Term Storage 
a.  Only one recreational vehicle, or one watercraft, or one trailer, or watercraft on a trailer is allowed for outside storage per lot; 
b.  Such items may be stored in garages, in the rear yard, in the side yard entirely behind the front building line; and for corner lots, shall also be stored behind the side building line facing the street; 

c.  Any storage occurring on the side or rear yard must be stored or parked upon a single pad of pavement constructed of asphalt or Portland cement; 
d.  Public right-of-way may not be used to store such items; 
e.  None may be used for residential purposes. 
2.  Temporary Parking 
a.  The resident, or temporary guests of the residence, may park a recreational vehicle, or watercraft on a trailer, on the resident's premises on a temporary basis not to exceed seven consecutive days two times per calendar year. 
b.  An extended period, not to exceed fourteen (14) additional consecutive days per calendar year, may be approved at the discretion of the code compliance official. 
c.  In instances of extraordinary circumstances, an additional period of time may be considered by the city council, at their sole discretion, via authorization as a short-term conditional use as noted in this title. 
d.  Temporary guests of the residence may reside in a recreational vehicle during the authorized time period. 
e.  The recreational vehicle, watercraft or trailer must be parked upon the driveway, or upon a single pad of pavement constructed of asphalt or Portland cement. 
E.  Any other Equipment, Material or Vehicles Not Used for Daily Transportation. Except as may be consistent with appropriate building permit: 
1.  No such item shall be stored for more than seventy-two (72) hours in a thirty (30) day period; 
2.  With the approval of the codes enforcement division, such equipment, material or vehicle may be stored up to one hundred twenty (120) hours; 
3.  Such excess storage shall not occur more than once in any calendar year; 
4.  Such vehicles and equipment may only be parked or stored on paved areas of asphalt or Portland cement. 
F.  Temporary Portable Storage Containers. For any single-family dwelling unit, there may be permitted one temporary portable storage container per lot. Such containers may only be used for the temporary storage of furniture, clothing or other personal belongings customarily associated with a household; except that in no way shall such containers be utilized for human occupancy, or the storage of live animals or hazardous materials. Such containers shall be placed on a paved surface on site; and shall not be placed on any right-of-way or easement and shall not create a site obstruction for any vehicular or pedestrian traffic. The maximum time such containers are permitted to remain on the lot is fourteen (14) consecutive days within one calendar year. The department of public works is authorized to administratively permit such containers within these prescribed limits. The above regulations shall not apply to trash receptacles that are placed for construction purposes in connection with a valid building permit, or during any period of declared emergency by federal, state or local official action. 
G.  Residential Sidewalks. Private residential sidewalks shall be limited to four feet in width. 
(Ord. 8294 § 1, 2008; Ord. 8015 § 19, 2005; Ord. 7967 § 3, 2004; Ord. 7833 § 2, 2004; Ord. 7830 § 1, 2004; Ord. 7604 § 1, 2002; Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8447, §§ 2-4, 2-23-2010; Ord. No. 8605, § 5, 2-21-2012) 
17.88.040 - Districts R-3, R-4 and R-5. 
A.  In the R-3, R-4 and R-5 districts, permitted accessory uses are as follows: parking areas, signs as permitted by ordinance, recreation areas including tenant-used swimming pools and minor recreation buildings, trash collection enclosures, power generators, vending machines for tenant use and other similar uses. 
B.  Any Other Equipment, Material or Vehicles Not Used for Daily Transportation. Except as may be consistent with an appropriate building permit: 
1.  No such item shall be stored for more than seventy-two (72) hours in a thirty-day period; 
2.  With the approval of the codes enforcement division, such equipment, material or vehicle may be stored up to one hundred twenty (120) hours; 
3.  Such excess storage shall not occur more than once in any calendar year; 
4.  Such vehicles and equipment may only be parked or stored on paved area of asphalt or Portland cement. 
(Ord 7967 § 4, 2004) 
(Ord. No. 8447, § 5, 2-23-2010) 
17.88.050 - Districts C-0 and C-1. 
    In the C-0 and C-1 districts, accessory uses are as follows: parking areas, signs as permitted by ordinance, vending machines, private garages for motor vehicles, apartment for maintenance personnel, low level exterior lighting, radio, television or microwave antennae not exceeding sixty (60) feet in height, flagpoles, cooling towers and other similar uses. A pharmacy where there is retail sale only of prescription medicines, drugs, pharmaceuticals and orthopedic devices, customarily incident to the practice of medicine, shall be allowed as an accessory use in an office building; provided, not less than five physicians occupy offices within the building. No direct exterior entrance to the pharmacy and no exterior sign or advertising relative to the pharmacy shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 12, 11-19-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8720, § 12, adopted Nov. 19, 2013, repealed former § 17.88.050, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 7500, § 1, 2002. 
17.88.060 - Districts C-2 and C-3. 
    In the C-2 and C-3 districts, permitted accessory uses are as follows: parking areas, signs as permitted by ordinance, floodlighting and other similar uses. Washing and other passenger car cleaning shall be permitted as an accessory use in service stations; provided, such washing and cleaning shall not utilize more than two car stalls or more than thirty (30) percent of the floor area in any one station, shall be a part of the main building, and shall not be open for use during hours when the service station is closed. Such washing and cleaning operation shall utilize the same entrance drives as the service station and may use coin-operated or attendant-operated equipment, but not continuous line or conveyor-type washing equipment. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.88.070 - Districts M-1 and M-2. 
    In the M-1 and M-2 districts, permitted accessory uses are as follows: parking and loading areas, signs as permitted by ordinance, security and screen fencing, radio and microwave towers to heights as set out in this title, gate house, loading equipment, employee recreation and other similar uses. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.88.080 - Motor hotels. 
    The following are accessory uses within a motor hotel: a restaurant, banquet rooms, liquor, notions and magazine counters, vending machines, beauty and barbershops, flower and gift shops; provided, all are within the main building and designed to serve primarily the occupants and patrons of the motor hotel. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.88.090 - Hospitals. 
    The following are accessory uses in connection with a hospital: residential quarters for staff and employees, nursing or convalescent quarters, storage and utility buildings, food service and vending machines, laundry and other similar services for hospital personnel, visitors and patients. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.88.100 - Utility buildings. 
    Outside storage of materials and equipment is an accessory use in connection with utility buildings; provided, all outside storage is screened from view from off the premises. Any of the accessory uses listed in this chapter may be specifically prohibited or further controlled by restrictions written into the conditional use permit prior to its being approved. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.88.110 - Detached accessory buildings. 
    In any nonresidential district, a detached accessory building not exceeding twenty-four (24) feet or two stories in height, or in any case not higher than the main building, may occupy not more than thirty (30) percent of a required rear yard. In residential districts, one detached accessory building per lot not exceeding three hundred (300) square feet in area and not greater than thirty (30) percent of the required rear yard and no portion of the accessory building shall exceed the eave height of the principal building nor shall the average height exceed nine feet. 
(Ord. 7831 § 1, 2004) 
17.88.120 - Construction trailers. 
    One or more trailers may be used for a temporary office or other nonresidential structure on the site of a construction project; provided, such trailer is removed upon completion of the project. 
(Ord. 7967 § 5, 2004) 
17.88.130 - Solar panels. 
A.  Solar panels are permitted as an accessory use in all zoning districts subject to the following standards: 
1.  Such panels must be located on the premises. 
2.  Such panels may be mounted on roofs or walls subject to: 
a.  Such panels may be installed at any angle, provided they are not visible from the public right-of-way or other public places immediately adjacent to the lot. If they are visible from such locations, they must be installed with an equivalent pitch angle as the roof itself. 
b.  Such panels may not project beyond any wall, roof edge or roof ridge. 
3.  No solar panel may cause a reflection onto other property. 
4.  Free standing panels may only be authorized by conditional use permit if roof or wall mounted panels are shown to be infeasible. 
B.  Solar panels may be mounted on light poles as a source of power for the light fixtures if they are designed as part of the fixtures. 
C.  Exceptions to these standards may be considered for approval through conditional use permit, if the city, at its' sole discretion determines that sufficient evidence exists demonstrating there will be no ill effects detrimental to the public health, safety, welfare, or public interest. 
(Ord. No. 8418, § 14, 8-25-2009) 
17.88.140 - Wind energy conversion systems. 
A.  Wind energy conversion systems are permitted as an accessory use in all zoning districts, subject to the following standards: 
1.  Such systems must be located on the premises. 
2.  In residential and commercial districts, such facilities must be mounted on an existing structure; free standing systems are not permitted. 
3.  In industrial districts, such facilities may be mounted on existing structures or may be free standing, provided such free standing systems must be of monopole construction. 
4.  Height, as measured from the top of the system, is limited to the maximum height allowed in the applicable zoning district, but may not be taller than one hundred (100) feet. 
5.  Such systems shall be sited in a manner that prevents shadowing or flicker impacts beyond the property line. 
6.  Noise at the property line shall not exceed forty-five (45) decibels. 
7.  No lighting is permitted unless to comply with other regulations. 
8.  Such systems shall be painted a neutral non-reflective color. 
9.  If such systems have been unused or inoperable for twelve (12) months, they will be considered abandoned, and therefore must be removed within ninety (90) days. 
B.  Exceptions to these standards may be considered for approval through conditional use permit, if the city, at its' sole discretion determines that sufficient evidence exists demonstrating there will be no ill effects detrimental to the public health, safety, welfare, or public interest. 
(Ord. No. 8418, § 14, 8-25-2009)
