17.96.010 - Site plan review. 

A.  Purpose. The purpose of requiring site plan review is to ensure that proposed development conforms with these regulations and proposes a compatible arrangement of buildings, off-street parking, lighting, signage, landscaping, vehicle and pedestrian circulation, site drainage and open spaces. Site plan review shall consider the siting of proposed construction and its impact on the existing topography and natural vegetation, and the relationship of proposed construction to existing public and private improvements in the immediate area and its conformance to the policies and standards of the master plan. The design shall encourage the elimination of unnecessary grading and retention of the natural character of the site including the preservation of trees and other natural features. 
B.  Applicability. A site plan shall be required for all new construction, exterior additions or, any exterior structural or site alterations resulting from changes in use of any structure used for multi-family, commercial, industrial or public use, whether such use is a permitted use in the district, authorized by a conditional use permit or allowed as a planned development. The requirement for a site plan may be waived when it is determined by the site plan review committee that the minimum required information on a site plan will not be useful in evaluating compliance with the zoning ordinance or assessing any impact on adjacent property. No building permit shall be issued for a development subject to site plan review until such site plan has been approved in accordance with these regulations. Site plans approved as part of a conditional use permit, variance, or rezoning are subject to the procedures of 17.96.020, 17.96.030 and 17.96.040, respectively. 
C.  Pre-application Meeting. Before any application is made, the applicant is encouraged to meet with the chief building inspector to discuss, in general, the procedures and requirements for site plan approval pursuant to these regulations. 
D.  Information Required. 
1.  Minimum Required Information. An applicant for site plan review shall submit five sets of plans containing the following minimum required information: 
a.  Name and address of record of landowner, applicant and any engineer, surveyor, planner, or contractor that participated in preparing the site plan; 
b.  Date, north arrow and scale; 
c.  A scale of not less than 1? = 20' if the site is less than three acres and 1? = 100' if the site is greater than or equal to three acres; 
d.  A vicinity map of sufficient and accurate scale to clearly show the property location; 
e.  Size, use and location of existing and proposed structures and drives on the subject property, and existing structures and drives within one hundred (100) feet of the property; 
f.  The existing zoning of the property; 
g.  The existing zoning of adjacent property; 
h.  The existing land use of adjacent property; 
i.  A legal description and accompanying map exhibit of the property, showing the location and type of boundary; 
j.  The height, number of floors and proposed square footage of all buildings, both above and below or partially below the finished grade; 
k.  The yard dimensions from the development boundaries and adjacent streets and alleys; 
l.  Off-street parking and loading areas, including dimensions of proposed drives and parking spaces, and structures and landscaping for parking areas; 
m.  A plan or statement showing the location and design of all screening measures required by ordinance; and 
n.  A landscape plan demonstrating compliance with any landscape elements required by ordinance; 
2.  Additional Information. In addition to all information required in Section 1 above, the site plan review committee may require any of the following information based on circumstances specific to the site: 
a.  Location of existing and proposed rights-of-way, easements and infrastructure (streets, sewers, water lines, etc.); 
b.  A table which sets forth the following data: (i) Total number of dwelling units; (ii) Residential density and units per acre; (iii) Total floor area (in square feet) and floor area ratio for each type of use; (iv) Total area in open space; (v) Total area in developed recreational open space; (vi) total number of off-street parking spaces, required and provided; and (vii) total off-street loading spaces, required and provided; 
c.  Existing topography with maximum contour interval of two feet, except where existing ground is on a slope of less than two percent then either one foot contours or spot elevations shall be provided where necessary; 
d.  Location of floodplain areas subject to flooding, centerlines of drainage courses and finished floor elevations of proposed buildings; 
e.  The traffic and the pedestrian circulation system, including the location and width of all streets, driveways, entrances to parking areas and parking structures, walkways and bicycle paths; 
f.  Greenbelt and other active recreation space areas, together with proposed private recreational areas, specifying the proposed improvement of all such areas, and delineating those areas proposed for specific types of recreational facilities; 
g.  Architectural elevations of proposed structures and a detailed list of proposed building materials; 
h.  A master sign plan, detailing all proposed signage for the site; 
i.  When the development is to be constructed in stages or units, a final sequence of development schedule showing the order of construction of such stages or units, and approximate completion date for the construction of each stage or unit; 
j.  A copy of all covenants, restrictions and conditions pertaining to the use, maintenance and operation of private open space areas; 
k.  Drainage information sufficient to meet City requirements; and 
l.  Any other information required by the site plan review committee. 
E.  Application Process. 
1.  Standard Forms. Requests for any site plan review shall be made on applications provided by the city. The city may promulgate submittal requirements, instructions for completing applications and other forms, internal procedures for acceptance and filing of applications, and provisions for waiver of information and/or submittal requirements, by establishing administrative guidelines. 
2.  Determination by the Site Plan review Committee. The site plan review committee shall consist of the chief building inspector, acting as the chair, the zoning administrator, the fire marshall, and the director of public works, or their designated representatives. The site plan review committee shall review the complete site plan application and determine whether it complies with the terms of this code and any other applicable codes or regulations of the City of North Kansas City. The site plan review committee may ask other staff members, consultants or professionals to attend a site plan review to assist the site plan review committee in its determination. 
a.  If the application is in compliance with applicable codes and regulations, it shall be approved. 
b.  If the application is not in compliance, the site plan review committee shall deny the application and provide the applicant a written response identifying areas of non-compliance. 
c.  Revisions to site plans approved as part of a conditional use permit, variance, or rezoning may only be approved according to the procedures in section 17.96.020, 17.96.030 and 17.96.040, respectively. 
3.  Appeals to Board of Zoning Adjustment. In any instance where the site plan review committee exercises the final decision on the development application, and there is an alleged error in the determination of the site plan review committee, appeals may be made to the board of zoning adjustment according to the procedures in Section 17.96.030. However, in the case of any such appeal, the standard for review shall be whether the site plan review committee's decision was clearly in error. 
F.  Expiration of a Site Plan Approval. 
1.  If a site plan authorized or granted under the provisions of this section is not acted upon or the actual construction commenced on the buildings or structures involved within one year from the date of the site plan approval, the approval shall be deemed to be revoked and any further activity on the site shall be treated as a violation of these regulations. 
2.  If construction is started, it must be diligently prosecuted to completion. A lapse of work for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days will be sufficient to cause the revocation of the site plan approval. 
3.  Extensions of Time. Unless otherwise prohibited by Missouri law or these regulations, the site plan review committee may extend the time for expiration of a site plan approval for a period not to exceed one year from the date of the original expiration, and if the application for extension is made in writing within the original period of validity. An extension for a period in excess of one year shall be granted only by the planning commission or city council in accordance with the site plan appeal procedures set forth in the these regulations. No extension may be granted by the site plan review committee planning commission, or city council for a period exceeding any applicable time limits established by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.96.020 - Conditional use permits. 

A.  Purpose. Conditional uses are those uses which generally are compatible with the permitted land uses in a given zoning district, but which require individual review of their location, design and configuration and the imposition of conditions in order to ensure the appropriateness of the use at a particular location within a given zoning district, as specified in a conditional use permit. 
B.  Restrictions. 
1.  The designation of a use in a zoning district as a conditional use does not constitute an authorization or assurance that such use or permit will be approved. 
2.  Approval of a conditional use permit shall authorize only the particular use for which the permit is issued. 
3.  No use authorized by a conditional use permit shall be enlarged, extended, increased in intensity or relocated unless an application is made for a new conditional use permit in accordance with the procedures set forth in these regulations. 
4.  Development of the conditional use shall not be carried out until the applicant has secured all the permits and approvals required by these regulations, other appropriate provisions of the North Kansas City Code or any permits required by county, regional, state or federal agencies. 
C.  Pre-application Meeting. Before any application is made, the applicant is encouraged to meet with the zoning administrator to discuss, in general, the procedures and requirements for a conditional use permit request pursuant to these regulations. 
D.  Information Required. Conditional use permit applications shall include a site plan meeting the requirements in Section 17.96.010.D. Applications shall also include the appropriate application fee. 
E.  Application Process. 
1.  Standard Forms. Requests for any conditional use permit shall be made on applications provided by the city. The city may promulgate submittal requirements, instructions for completing applications and other forms, internal procedures for acceptance and filing of applications, and provisions for waiver of information and/or submittal requirements, by establishing administrative guidelines. 
2.  Application Fee. Application fees for conditional use permits shall be charged as set forth in the application fee schedule adopted by the city council. 
3.  Submission and Determination of Complete Application. 
a.  Conditional use permit applications shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for a determination of completeness. The zoning administrator shall make this determination within ten (10) business days of submission. 
b.  Applications will be considered complete when all items required for submissions by these regulations and the appropriate fee have been submitted to the zoning administrator. 
c.  Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with a written explanation of deficiencies. The city shall take no further action on incomplete applications. 
d.  Complete applications shall be processed in accordance with this chapter. The zoning administrator shall notify the applicant that the application was determined to be complete. 
e.  If the zoning administrator fails to act within ten (10) business days, the application shall be deemed complete and the applicant shall request the zoning administrator to issue a notice of completeness. 
f.  Modification of the application by the applicant without specific instruction to do so from the zoning administrator, the planning commission, or city council following a determination of completeness shall void the determination and trigger a new ten (10) day review period. 
g.  A determination of completeness shall not constitute a determination of compliance with the substantive requirements of these regulations. 
h.  A deterinination that the application is incomplete may be appealed by the applicant to the board of zoning adjustment. 
4.  Processing of Application and Scheduled Hearing. Following the determination that a conditional use permit application is complete or is deemed complete, the zoning administrator shall forward the application for review to the planning commission. Upon receipt of the application, the planning commission shall schedule a public hearing on the application at its next reg.ular meeting, or at such other time as the applicant and zoning administrator agree. 
5.  Report. Following the determination that a conditional use permit application is complete or is deemed complete, the zoning administrator shall review the substance of the application, prepare a report to the planning commission and city council. The report shall be made available to the applicant at least two business days prior to the hearing on the application. 
6.  Examination of and Copying of Documents. At any time, upon reasonable request, any person may examine the application and the materials submitted in support of or in opposition to a conditional use permit application. Copies of such material shall be made available at cost. 
F.  Notice Provisions. 
1.  Published Notice. 
a.  Notice setting forth the date, time, place and purpose of the public hearing, the name of the applicant, and identification of the subject property must be published once at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation throughout the city. 
b.  Not less than twenty (20) days prior to the public hearing, the applicant shall provide the information required for the notice to the zoning administrator. 
2.  Personal Notice of Public Hearing. 
a.  Notice shall be sent by the zoning administrator, by U.S. mail at least fifteen (15) business days before the hearing to each current owner of real property, as listed in the official records of the Clay County Recorder of Deeds, located within one hundred eighty-five (185) feet of the exterior boundary of the property in question unless otherwise specified by these regulations. 
b.  The failure of a property owner to receive notice by mail, if timely sent and properly addressed to the current owner of record, shall not be grounds for invalidating any action taken by the planning commission or city council. 
3.  Posted Notice. The zoning administrator shall cause to be posted at least one sign on the subject property at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. The sign(s) shall remain posted on the property until after the close of the public hearing. The sign shall give notice of the date, time and place of the hearing and the action requested. The zoning administrator shall prescribe the size, format and location of the sign(s). The sign shall be the property of the City of North Kansas City and it shall be a public offense for any person to remove, deface, conceal or destroy any such sign. The placement of signs is for the convenience and information of the public and the absence of such signs during all or part of the specified period of time shall in no way impair or nullify proceedings on the action being considered. 
4.  Substantial Compliance Required. Minor technical deviations in the language of published, personal or posted notice shall not be deemed to impair the notice where actual notice has been given. Where there is a question raised at the hearing regarding the adequacy of notice, the planning commission shall make a formal finding as to whether there was substantial compliance with the notice requirement of these regulations. 
G.  Review and Recommendation by Planning Commission. The planning commission shall hold a public hearing to receive evidence and consider the application. The commission's written recommendations, together with the staff report and recommendation shall be transmitted to the city clerk within ten (10) days of the commission's decision. 
1.  Scope of Action. The planning commission may take any action on the application that is consistent with the notice given, including approval of the application, conditional approval of the application or denial of the application. The planning commission may allow amendments to the application if the effect of the amendments is to allow a lesser change than that requested on the original application or to reduce the impact of the development or to reduce the amount of land involved from that indicated in the notices of the hearing. The planning commission may not, in any case, permit a greater amount of development, or a use falling in a different general use category, or a larger land area than indicated in the original application and notice. 
2.  Review Criteria. In determining whether any proposed conditional use permit shall be approved, the planning commission shall consider, in addition to the factors described in Section 17.84 with each particular conditional use, the following factors: 
a.  Whether the proposed use at the specified location is consistent with the policies embodied in the adopted master plan; 
b.  Whether the proposed use is consistent with the general purpose and intent of the applicable zoning district regulations and complies with the requirements of the zoning ordinance; 
c.  Whether the proposed conditional use, may be materially detrimental to the public health, safety, convenience and welfare, or may result in material damage or prejudice to other property in the vicinity; 
d.  Whether the proposed use is compatible with and preserves the character and integrity of adjacent development and neighborhoods and includes improvements or modifications either on-site or within the public rights-of-way to mitigate any adverse impacts which may result from the development, such as traffic, noise, odors, visual nuisances, or other similar adverse effects; 
e.  Whether the proposed use will generate pedestrian and vehicular traffic which will be hazardous to the existing and anticipated traffic in the neighborhood; 
f.  Whether the proposed use will comply with all other regulations of the district in which it is located. 
H.  Decision by City Council. Following the planning commission's public hearing and receipt of the planning commission's recommendation, the city council shall decide whether to approve, conditionally approve or deny the conditional use permit application. 
1.  Scope of Action. The city council may take any action on the application that is consistent with the notice given, conditional approval of the application or denial of the application. The city council may allow amendments to the application if the effect of the amendments is to allow a lesser change than that requested on the original application or to reduce the impact of the development or to reduce the amount of land involved from that indicated in the notices of the hearing. The city council may not, in any case, permit a greater amount of development, or a use falling in a different general use category, or a larger land area than indicated in the original application and notice. 
2.  Conditional Approval. After review of the application, the recommendation of the zoning administrator and/or the planning commission, and other pertinent documents and any evidence made part of the public record, the city council may impose conditions as are reasonably necessary to assure compliance with applicable general or specific standards stated in these regulations. Any conditions recommended by the zoning administrator or planning commission may be modified by the city council. 
3.  Denial of Application. If the city council denies the application, it shall establish on the record the basis for the decision. Within ten (10) business days of decision, the zoning administrator shall mail a notice of the decision and a statement setting forth the basis for the decision to the applicant and file a copy of the notice and statement with the city clerk. 
I.  Continuances of Proceedings. 
1.  Any applicant or authorized agent of an applicant shall have the right to one continuance before the scheduled planning commission or city council meeting, provided that a written request is filed with the zoning administrator at least two (2) business days prior to the date of the scheduled hearing unless unusual circumstances exist. 
2.  The planning commission or city council may grant a continuance at any time for good cause shown. All motions to grant a continuance shall state the new date on which the matter is to be heard, otherwise the hearing will require re-notification at the applicant's expense. A majority vote of those members in attendance shall be required to grant a continuance. 
3.  The record shall indicate the reason such continuance was made and any stipulations or conditions placed upon the continuance. 
J.  Expiration of Application Acted Upon. A conditional use permit application may be deemed expired and/or withdrawn where it is not acted upon by the planning commission or city council due to: 
1.  The failure of the applicant to appear or to be represented at a scheduled public hearing on such application; or 
2.  The request or consent of the applicant to withhold action on any application, and such application remains in an inactive status for more than one hundred eighty (180) days without a request by the applicant for a rehearing of the application. 
K.  Post Decision Proceedings. 
1.  Amendments and Revisions. The zoning administrator may approve minor revisions to a site plan approved as part of a conditional use permit, subject to the following: 
a.  Minor revisions must be authorized in writing by the zoning administrator and limited to those that are necessary in light of technical considerations discovered by the applicant or zoning administrator after the decision on the conditional use permit; 
b.  If the holder of an approved conditional use permit requests a revision that the zoning administrator determines is not a minor revision, approval of the revision is required in accordance with the procedures established for the original approval and shall be considered amendments to the conditional use permit; 
c.  The determination of the zoning administrator on a minor revision is subject to appeal to the board of zoning adjustment. 
2.  Appeals. Appeals of a final decision on a conditional use permit application may be made to the Circuit Court Clay County. 
3.  Revocation of a conditional use permit. Any conditional use permit granted under the authority of these regulations is subject to revocation pursuant to the procedures below for any or all of the following reasons: 
a.  Noncompliance with any special conditions imposed on the conditional use permit by the city council or these regulations at the time of approval of the conditional use. 
b.  Violation of any provisions of these regulations pertaining to the use of land, the construction or use of buildings or structures or activities conducted on the premises by the pennittee of agents of the permittee; 
c.  Violation of any other applicable zoning regulation or North Kansas City Code provision or any county, state or federal law or regulation by the permittee or agents of the permittee, provided that such violations relate to the conduct or activity authorized by the conditional use permit or the qualifications of the permittee or its agents to engage in such conduct or activity. 
4.  Revocation Procedures. 
a.  Duties of Zoning Administrator. If the zoning administrator determines, based upon an inspection by city staff, that there are reasonable grounds for revocation of a conditional use permit, the zoning administrator shall set a hearing before the city council. The city council may refer the proposed revocation to the planning commission for its report and recommendation prior to the city council hearing. However, the zoning administrator may summarily revoke any conditional use permit in violation of these regulations or conditions of the permit which poses an immediate danger or threat to the health, safety, or welfare or property values of the public or adjacent property owners, and schedule a subsequent hearing on the action as soon as practicable. 
b.  Notice and Public Hearing. Notice of the conditional use permit revocation hearing shall be given in the same manner as provided for the initial application. At the hearing, the city council shall reconsider the criteria governing the permit approval, the evidence submitted at the public hearing and the circumstances of the permit. 
c.  Decision and Notice. Following the public hearing, the city council shall render a decision to revoke the permit, to allow the applicant to retain the permit or to reconsider the permit, and shall notify the holder of the permit and any other person who has filed a written request for such notice. 
d.  Effect and Appeals. A decision to revoke a conditional use permit shall become effective immediately upon the decision or at some other effective date specified in the decision. After such effective date of revocation, any activities continuing pursuant to such permit shall be deemed to be in violation of these regulations. A decision to revoke a conditional permit may be appealed in the same manner provided for an original decision on a conditional use permit. 
5.  Transferability. A conditional use permit may be conveyed with the land only if the transferor has obtained a building permit for one or more structures authorized by the conditional use permit and is at least ten (10) percent completed in terms of total expected cost of the project. The transfer of a permit where these conditions have not been satisfied shall be invalid. 
6.  Expiration of a Conditional Use Permit. 
a.  If a conditional use authorized or granted under the provisions of this section is not actually established or the actual construction commenced on the buildings or structures involved within one year from the date of the conditional use permit approval, the approval shall be deemed to be revoked and any further activity on the site shall be treated as a violation of these regulations. 
b.  If construction is started, it must be diligently prosecuted to completion. A lapse of work for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days will be sufficient to cause the revocation of the conditional use approval. 
c.  If any use of land, building, structure or premises established under the provisions of this section has been discontinued for a period of one year, it is unlawful to again use such land, building or premises for such discontinued use until a subsequent conditional use permit is granted. 
d.  Extensions of Time. Unless otherwise prohibited by Missouri law or these regulations, the zoning administrator may extend the time for expiration of a conditional use permit for a period not to exceed one year from the date of the original expiration, and if the application for extension is made in writing within the original period of validity. An extension for a period in excess of one year shall be granted only by the city council in accordance with the procedures set forth in these regulations for the original approval. No extension may be granted by the zoning administrator or by the city council for a period exceeding any applicable time limits established by the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
7.  Term. Any conditional use permit that has a specified term as one of its conditions shall not be valid upon expiration of the term, without an approved renewal of the permit. Renewal of the permit shall be subject to all procedures and regulations in this chapter. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8605, § 1, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 8820, § 1, 4-7-2015) 
17.96.030 - Variances. 

A.  Purpose. The board of zoning adjustment may authorize a variance from the strict application of these regulations where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of these provisions will, in an individual case, result in practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship. 
B.  Applicability. A variance may be granted where, by reason of exceptional narrowness, shallowness or shape of a specific piece of property at the time of the enactment of these regulations, or by reason of exceptional topographic conditions or other extraordinary and exceptional situation or condition of the piece of property, the strict application of these regulations would result in practical difficulties to, or unnecessary hardships upon, the property owner. 
C.  Pre-application Conference. Before an application is made, the applicant is encouraged to confer with the zoning administrator to discuss, in general, the procedures and requirements for a variance request pursuant to these regulations. 
D.  Information Required. A variance application shall include: 
1.  A site plan, as described in Section 17.96.010D. The site plan shall include floor plans and an elevation and shall indicate clearly the nature and location of the requested variance. Specific requirements of site plan preparation may be waived by the zoning administrator and/or additional information may be required if circumstances so require. 
2.  Evidence that the property was acquired in good faith and that because of the exceptional narrowness, shallowness or shape of the parcel at the time of the effective date of these regulations, or by reason of exceptional topographic conditions or other extraordinary or exceptional circumstances, the strict application of the terms of these regulations the property meets the criteria for a variance established in this section. 
3.  Evidence of the ability and intention of the applicant to proceed with actual construction in accordance with the submitted site plan after issuance of the variance. 
E.  Application Process. 
1.  Standard Forms. Requests for any variance shall be made on applications provided by the city. The city may promulgate submittal requirements, instructions for completing applications and other forms, internal procedures for acceptance and filing of applications, and provisions for waiver of information and/or submittal information, by establishing administrative guidelines. Additional information may be required for particular applications at the discretion of the zoning administrator. 
2.  Application Fee. The application fee for a variance shall be set forth in the application fee schedule adopted by the city council. 
3.  Submission and Determination of Complete Application. 
a.  Variance applications shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for a determination of completeness. The zoning administrator shall make this determination within ten (10) business days of submission. 
b.  Applications will be considered complete when all items required for submissions by these regulations and the appropriate fee have been submitted to the zoning administrator. 
c.  Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with a written explanation of deficiencies. The city shall take no further action on incomplete applications. 
d.  Complete applications shall be processed in accordance with this chapter. The zoning administrator shall notify the applicant that the application was determined to be complete. 
e.  If the zoning administrator fails to act within ten (10) business days, the application shall be deemed complete and the applicant shall request the zoning administrator to issue a notice of completeness. 
f.  Modification of the application by the applicant without specific instruction to do so from the zoning administrator or the board of zoning adjustment following a determination of completeness shall void the determination and trigger a new ten (10) day review period. 
g.  A determination of completeness shall not constitute a determination of compliance with the substantive requirements of these regulations. 
h.  A determination that the application is incomplete may be appealed by the applicant to the board of zoning adjustment. 
4.  Processing of Application and Scheduled Hearing. Following the determination that a variance application is complete or is deemed complete, the zoning administrator shall forward the application for review to the board of zoning adjustment. Upon receipt of the application, the board of zoning adjustment shall schedule a public hearing on the application at its next regular meeting, or at such other time as the applicant and zoning administrator agree. 
5.  Report. Following the determination that a rezoning application is complete or is deemed complete, the zoning administrator shall review the substance of the application, prepare a report to the board of zoning adjustment. The report shall be made available to the applicant at least two business days prior to the hearing on the application. 
6.  Examination of and Copying of Documents. At any time, upon reasonable request, any person may examine the application and the materials submitted in support of or in opposition to a variance application. Copies of such material shall be made available at cost. 
F.  Notice Provisions. 
1.  Published Notice. 
a.  Notice setting forth the date, time, place and purpose of the public hearing, the name of the applicant, and identification of the subject property must be published once at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation throughout the city. 
b.  Not less than twenty (20) days prior to the public hearing, the applicant shall provide the information required for the notice to the zoning administrator. 
2.  Personal Notice of Public Hearing. 
a.  Notice shall be sent by the zoning administrator, by U.S. mail at least fifteen (15) business days before the hearing to each current owner of real property, as listed in the official records of the Clay County Recorder of Deeds, located within one hundred eighty-five (185) feet of the exterior boundary of the property in question unless otherwise specified by these regulations. 
b.  The failure of a property owner to receive notice by mail, if timely sent and properly addressed to the current owner of record, shall not be grounds for invalidating any action taken by the planning commission or city council. 
3.  Posted Notice. The zoning administrator shall cause to be posted at least one sign on the subject property at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. The sign(s) shall remain posted on the property until after the close of the public hearing. The sign shall give notice of the date, time and place of the hearing and the action requested. The zoning administrator shall prescribe the size, format and location of the sign(s). The sign shall be the property of the City of North Kansas City and it shall be a public offense for any person to remove, deface, conceal or destroy any such sign. The placement of signs is for the convenience and information of the public and the absence of such signs during all or part of the specified period of time shall in no way impair or nullify proceedings on the action being considered. 
4.  Substantial Compliance Required. Minor technical deviations in the language of published, personal or posted notice shall not be deemed to impair the notice where actual notice has been given. Where there is a question raised at the hearing regarding the adequacy of notice, the board of zoning adjustment shall make a formal finding as to whether there was substantial compliance with the notice requirement of these regulations. 
G.  Review and Decision by Board of Zoning Adjustment. The board of zoning adjustment shall hold a public hearing to receive evidence and consider the application. 
1.  Decision by Board of Adjustment. Following the public hearing the board of zoning adjustment shall approve, conditionally approve or deny the application and establish on the record the basis for its decision. 
a.  Approval of Variance. Approval of a variance shall be by a motion of the board of adjustment with a concurring vote of at least four members. Any variance approved by the board of adjustment must: 
1.  Commence construction within one year and completion within eighteen (18) months from approval; and 
2.  Conform to plans approved as a part of the variance permit. 
b.  Conditional Approval. The board of zoning adjustment may require such conditions and restrictions upon the premises to be benefited by a variance as may be necessary to comply with the standards set forth in this section to reduce or minimize the injurious effect of such variance upon other property in the neighborhood and to implement the general purpose and intent of this ordinance. Failure to maintain such conditions or restrictions as may have been imposed shall constitute grounds for revocation of such variance. 
c.  Denial of Application. If the board of adjustment denies the variance, within ten (10) business days of decision, the zoning administrator shall mail a notice of the decision and the written statement to the applicant and file a copy of the notice and statement with the city clerk. 
2.  Review Criteria. In determining whether the proposed variance shall be approved, the board of zoning adjustment shall make findings based upon evidence presented to it that the application meets all of the following standards: 
a.  The particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the specific property involved create practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship upon the owner, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, such that the property in question cannot yield a reasonable return or use under strict application of the ordinance; 
b.  The conditions upon which the petition for variance is based is due to unique circumstances not applicable generally to other property within the same neighborhood or zoning classification, and has not been created by any person having an interest in the property. 
c.  The granting of the variance will not adversely affect the rights of adjacent property owners, tenants, or residents; 
d.  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare such that it will substantially increase the danger of fire or otherwise endanger the public safety; and 
e.  The granting of the variance will not alter the essential character of the locality, and will not be opposed to the general intent and spirit of the ordinance from which the variance is sought. 
3.  Additional Rules. The board of zoning adjustment may adopt rules of procedure to limit the number of applications for development approval, which may be considered per meeting, and to limit the time for each presentation or speaker. 
H.  Expiration ofApplication Acted Upon. A variance application may be deemed expired and/or withdrawn where it is not acted upon by the board of zoning adjustment due to: 
1.  The failure of the applicant to appear or to be represented at a scheduled public hearing on such application; or 
2.  The request or consent of the applicant to withhold action on any application; and such application remains in an inactive status for more than one hundred eighty (180) days without a request by the applicant for a rehearing of the application. 
I.  Post Decision Proceedings. 
1.  Appeals. Appeals of a final decision on a variance application may be made to the Circuit Court of Clay County in accordance with Chapter 89 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
2.  Expiration of a Variance. 
a.  If a variance authorized and granted under the provisions of this section is not actually established or the actual construction commenced on the buildings or structures involved within one year from the date of the variance approval, the approval shall expire and any activity authorized by the variance shall no longer be valid. 
b.  If construction is started, it must be diligently prosecuted to completion. A lapse of work for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days cause the expiration of the variance approval. 
c.  If any use of land, building, structure or premises established under the provisions of this section has been discontinued for a period of one year, it is unlawful to again use such land, building or premises for such discontinued use until subsequent variance application is approved according to this chapter. 
d.  Extensions of Time. Unless otherwise prohibited by Missouri law or these regulations, the zoning administrator may extend the time for expiration of a variance permit for a period not to exceed one year from the date of the original expiration, and if the application for extension is made in writing within the original period of validity. An extension for a period in excess of one year shall be granted only by the board of zoning adjustment in accordance with the procedures set forth in the these regulations for the original approval. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8605, § 2, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 8820, § 2, 4-7-2015) 
17.96.040 - Zoning Amendments. 

A.  Purpose. It may be necessary or advisable, from time to time, to amend the zoning classification of property as indicated on the zoning district map ("Rezoning"). 
B.  Pre-application Meeting. Before any appli-cation is made, the applicant is encouraged to meet with the zoning administrator to discuss, in general, the procedures and requirements for a zoning amendment request pursuant to these regulations. 
C.  Information Required. Zoning amendment applications shall include a site plan meeting the requirements in Section 17.96.010(D). Applications shall also include the appropriate application fee. 
D.  Application Process. 
1.  Standard Forms. Requests for any rezoning shall be made on applications provided by the city. The city may promulgate submittal requirements, instructions for completing applications and other forms, internal procedures for acceptance and filing of applications, and provisions for waiver of information and/or submittal requirements, by establishing administrative guidelines. 
2.  Application Fee. Application fees for zoning amendments shall be charged as set forth in the application fee schedule adopted by the city council. 
3.  Submission and Determination of Complete Application. 
a.  Rezoning applications shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for a determination of completeness. The zoning administrator shall make this determination within ten (10) business days of submission. 
b.  Applications will be considered complete when all items required for submissions by these regulations and the appropriate fee have been submitted to the zoning administrator. 
c.  Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with a written explanation of deficiencies. The city shall take no further action on incomplete applications. 
d.  Complete applications shall be processed in accordance with this chapter. The zoning administrator shall notify the applicant that the application was determined to be complete. 
e.  If the zoning administrator falls to act within ten (10) business days, the application shall be deemed complete and the applicant shall request the zoning administrator to issue a notice of completeness. 
f.  Modification of the application by the applicant without specific instruction to do so from the zoning administrator the planning commission, or city council following a determination of completeness shall void the determination and trigger a new ten (10) day review period. 
g.  A determination of completeness shall not constitute a determination of compliance with the substantive requirements of these regulations. 
h.  A determination that the application is incomplete may be appealed by the applicant to the board of zoning adjustment. 
4.  Processing of Application and Scheduled Hearing. Following the determination that a rezoning application is complete or is deemed complete, the zoning administrator shall forward the application for review to the planning commission. Upon receipt of the application, the planning commission shall schedule a public hearing on the application at its next regular meeting, or at such other time as the applicant and zoning administrator agree. 
5.  Report. Following the determination that a rezoning application is complete or is deemed complete, the zoning administrator shall review the substance of the application, prepare a report to the planning commission and city council. The report shall be made available to the applicant at least two business days prior to the hearing on the application. 
6.  Examination of and Copying of Documents. At any time, upon reasonable request, any person may examine the application and the materials submitted in support of or in opposition to a rezoning application. Copies of such material shall be made available at cost. 
E.  Notice Provisions. 
1.  Published Notice. 
a.  Notice setting forth the date, time, place and purpose of the public hearing, the name of the applicant, and identification of the subject property must be published once at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation throughout the city. 
b.  Not less than twenty (20) days prior to the public hearing, the applicant shall provide the information required for the notice to the zoning administrator. 
2.  Personal Notice of Public Hearing. 
a.  Notice shall be sent by the zoning administrator, by U.S. mail at least fifteen (15) business days before the hearing to each current owner of real property, as listed in the official records of the Clay County Recorder of Deeds, located within one hundred eighty-five (185) feet of the exterior boundary of the property in question unless otherwise specified by these regulations. 
b.  The failure of a property owner to receive notice by mail, if timely sent and properly addressed to the current owner of record, shall not be grounds for invalidating any action taken by the planning commission or city council. 
3.  Posted Notice. The zoning administrator shall cause to be posted at least one sign on the subject property at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. The sign(s) shall remain posted on the property until after the close of the public hearing. The sign shall give notice of the date, time and place of the hearing and the action requested. The zoning administrator shall prescribe the size, format and location of the sign(s). The sign shall be the property of the City of North Kansas City and it shall be a public offense for any person to remove, deface, conceal or destroy any such sign. The placement of signs is for the convenience and information of the public and the absence of such signs during all or part of the specified period of time shall in no way impair or nullify proceedings on the action being considered. 
4.  Substantial Compliance Required. Minor technical deviations in the language of published, personal or posted notice shall not be deemed to impair the notice where actual notice has been given. Where there is a question raised at the hearing regarding the adequacy of notice, the planning commission shall make a formal finding as to whether there was substantial compliance with the notice requirement of these regulations. 
F.  Review and Recommendation by planning commission. The planning commission shall hold a public hearing to receive evidence and consider the rezoning application. The commission's written recommendations, together with the staff report and recommendation shall be transmitted to the city clerk within ten (10) days of the commission's decision. 
1.  Scope of Action. The planning commission may take any action on the application that is consistent with the notice given, including approval of the application, The planning commission may allow amendments to the application if the effect of the amendments is to allow a lesser change than that requested on the original application or to reduce the impact of the development or to reduce the amount of land involved from that indicated in the notices of the hearing. The planning commission may not, in any case, permit a greater amount of development, or a use falling in a different general use category, or a larger land area than indicated in the original application and notice. 
2.  Review Criteria. The planning commission shall consider the following criteria when reviewing a rezoning application: 
a.  The character of the neighborhood includeing the zoning and uses of property nearby; 
b.  The suitability of the subject property for the uses to which it has been restricted under the existing zoning classification. 
c.  The extent to which the proposed use will detrimentally affect nearby property. 
d.  The length of time the subject property has remained vacant or underutilized as zoned; 
e.  Conformance of the requested change with the adopted master plan; 
f.  The availability and adequacy of required public and community facilities, utilities and services to serve the proposed use. These may include, but are not limited to, sanitary and storm sewers, water, electrical service, police and fire protection, schools, parks and recreation facilities, roads, libraries, solid waste collection and disposal and others, as applicable; 
g.  The extent to which the proposed use would adversely affect the capacity or safety of that portion of the street network influenced by the use, or present parking problems in the vicinity of the property; 
h.  The environmental impacts that the proposed use could generate (i.e. stormwater runoff, water pollution, air pollution, noise pollution, excessive night time lighting, etc.); 
i.  The precedents and possible effects of such precedents that might result from approval or denial; 
j.  The ability of the applicant to satisfy any requirements applicable to the specific use imposed pursuant to these regulations and other applicable city ordinances; 
k.  Recommendations of the city's professional staff. 
G.  Decision by city council. Following the planning commission's public hearing and receipt of the planning commission's recommendation, the city council shall decide whether to approve, conditionally approve or deny the rezoning application. 
1.  Scope of Action. The city council may take any action on the application that is consistent with the notice given, including approval of the application, conditional approval of the application or denial of the application. The city council may allow amendments to the application if the effect of the amendments is to allow a lesser change than that requested on the original application or to reduce the impact of the development or to reduce the amount of land involved from that indicated in the notices of the notices of the hearing. The city council may not, in any case, permit a greater amount of development, or a use falling in a different general use category, or a larger land area than indicated in the original application and notice. 
2.  Approval of Application. Unless otherwise required by law, approval of the application shall be by an ordinance approved by a majority of the city council. 
3.  Conditional Approval. After review of the application, other pertinent documents and any evidence made part of the public record, and the recommendations of the zoning administrator and/or the planning commission, the city council may impose conditions as are reasonably necessary to assure compliance with applicable general or specific standards stated in these cegulations. Any conditions recommended by the zoning administrator or planning commission may be modified by the city council. 
4.  Denial of Application. If the city council denies the application, it shall establish on the record the basis for the decision. Within ten (10) business days of decision, the zoning administrator shall mail a notice of the decision and a statement setting forth the basis for the decision to the applicant and file a copy of the notice and statement with the city clerk. 
5.  Protest. In case of a protest against a rezoning duly signed and acknowledged by the owners of thirty (30) percent or more, either of the areas of the land (exclusive of streets and alleys) included in such proposed change or within an area determined by lines drawn parallel to and one hundred and eighty-five feet (185) distant from the boundaries of the district proposed to be changed, such amendment shall not become effective except by the favorable vote of two-thirds of all the members of the legislative body of such municipality. A valid protest petition must be submitted to the city clerk at least five business days prior to the city council proceeding in order to affect the city council determination 
H.  Continuances of Proceedings. 
1.  Any applicant or authorized agent of an applicant shall have the right to one continuance before the scheduled planning commission or city council meeting, provided that a written request is filed with the zoning administrator at least two business days prior to the date of the scheduled hearing unless unusual circumstances exist. 
2.  The planning commission or city council may grant a continuance at any time for good cause shown. All motions to grant a continuance shall state the new date on which the matter is to be heard, otherwise the hearing will require renotification at the applicants expense. A majority vote of those members in attendance shall be required to grant a continuance. 
3.  The record shall indicate the reason such continuance was made and any stipulations or conditions placed upon the continuance. 
I.  Expiration of Application Acted Upon. A rezoning application may be deemed expired and/or withdrawn where it is not acted upon by the planning commission or city council due to: 
1.  The failure of the applicant to appear or to be represented at a scheduled public hearing on such application; or 
2.  The request or consent of the applicant to withhold action on any application; and such application remains in an inactive status for more than one hundred eighty (180) days without a request by the applicant for a rehearing of the application. 
J.  Post Decision Proceedings. 
1.  Reapplication Following Denial. Whenever any rezoning application is denied for failure to meet the substantive requirements of these regulations, an application for a rezoning of all or a part of the same property shall not be considered for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of denial unless the subsequent application involves a proposal that is materially different from the previously denied proposal or unless a majority of the members of the planning commission determines that the prior denial was based upon a material mistake of fact. The planning commission shall address and resolve any questions concerning the similarity of the second application, material differences, mistakes of fact, or other related issues. Denial of a second application following the one hundred eighty (180) day period shall result in a prohibition on the submission of another application for a period of one year from the second date of denial. 
2.  Appeals. Appeals of a final decision on a rezoning application may be made to the Circuit Court of Clay County. 
3.  Amendinents and Revisions. The zoning administrator may approve minor revisions to a site plan approved as part of a rezoning, subject to the following: 
a.  Minor revisions must be authorized in writing by the zoning administrator and limited to those that are necessary in light of technical considerations discovered by the applicant or zoning administrator after the decision on the rezoning. 
b.  If the applicant requests a revision that the zoning administrator determines is not a minor revision, approval of the revision is required in accordance with the procedures established for the original approval, and shall be considered an amendment to the ordinance approving the rezoning. 
c.  The determination of the zoning administrator on a minor revision is subject to appeal to the board of zoning adjustment. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8605, § 3, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 8820, § 3, 4-7-2015) 
Chapter 17.100 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

17.100.010 - Application for building or land use permit. 
    The director of community development or his or her duly authorized representative shall be empowered to act within the provisions of this Title 17 upon all applications for permits. In the event of refusal to issue a permit upon an application, as herein provided, the applicant shall have the right to appeal to the board of adjustment as set forth in Chapter 17.96. 
(Ord. No. 8720, § 13, 11-19-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8720, § 13, adopted Nov. 19, 2013, repealed former § 17.100.010, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 7500, § 1, 2002. 
17.100.020 - Building permit. 
A.  No building or structure shall be erected, added to or altered until a permit therefore has been issued by the director of community development. Except upon a written order of the board of adjustment, no such building permit shall be issued for any building where said construction, addition or alteration or use thereof would be in violation of any of the provisions of this Title 17 or other ordinances. 
B.  There shall be submitted with all applications for building permits three copies of a layout or site plan, drawn to scale, showing actual dimensions of the lot to be built upon, the exact size and location on the lot of the building and any accessory buildings to be erected, parking and any loading areas including access thereto, landscaping, and such other information as may be necessary to determine and provide for the enforcement of this title. In the case of any application requiring a site plan in accordance with Section 17.96, the approved site plan shall meet the requirements of this section. In the case of building permits in a planned unit development, the zoning administrator shall determine that all aspects of the proposed construction conform to the final development plan duly approved and endorsed by the planning commission. 
C.  One copy of such layout or plot plan shall be returned with approval by the director of community development, together with such permit to the applicant. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8720, §§ 14, 15, 11-19-2013) 
17.100.030 - Land use permit. 
    No open, vacant or unimproved land shall be used for any purpose other than agricultural without first obtaining a land use permit. Land use permits shall be required for, but not limited to the following uses: 
A.  Parking lots not included in a building permit; 
B.  Used car or auto storage lots; 
C.  Machinery, equipment or materials storage yards not included in a building permit; 
D.  Skeet shoots or target ranges; 
E.  Commercial, public or semipublic recreation areas, such as ball parks, golf courses, race tracks, fairs and similar temporary or permanent uses; 
F.  Refuse dumps or landfills; 
G.  Picnic groves; 
H.  Cemeteries; 
I.  Nurseries. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.100.040 - Certificate of occupancy. 
A.  After completion of a building or structure for which a building permit has been issued and all requirements of all codes and ordinances of the city have been met, a certificate of occupancy shall be issued stating that the building or proposed use thereof complies with the provisions of this title. 
B.  No nonconforming use shall be maintained, renewed or changed without a certificate of occupancy having first been issued by the director of community development. 
C.  All certificates of occupancy shall be applied for coincident with the application for a permit. The certificate shall be issued within ten (10) days after the erection or alteration has been approved as complying with the provisions of this title and other codes of the city. 
D.  The director of community development shall maintain a record of all certificates and copies shall be furnished upon request to any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in the building affected. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 8720, §§ 16, 17, 11-19-2013) 
17.100.050 - Fees for land use permit. 
    The fee for a land use permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) plus one dollar ($1.00) for each one hundred dollars ($100.00) of cost of improvements to the property other than buildings or structures for which building permits are issued; provided, the cost of grading or grubbing and clearing shall not be included in this fee calculation. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.100.060 - Minimum rights-of-way. 
    When a building or land use permit is requested on a lot or tract abutting a public street, the director of public works shall determine that an adequate right-of-way exists on that portion of the public street abutting the property. The minimum right-of-way, measured from the center line of the street to the property line of the lot or tract, shall be as follows: 
A.  Single-family area: twenty-five (25) feet. 
B.  Multifamily and industrial areas: thirty (30) feet. 
C.  Secondary thoroughfares (including collectors): thirty (30) feet. 
D.  Primary thoroughfares: forty (40) feet. 
E.  Commercial streets: thirty (30) feet. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.100.070 - Noncompliance with right-of-way. 
    In any case where the abutting right-of-way does not clearly comply with the above dimensions, a building or land use permit shall not be issued for the lot or tract until title for the required additional right-of-way has been conveyed to the city in keeping with established procedures. 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002) 
17.100.080 - Violation-Penalty-Enforcement. 
A.  In case any building or structure is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building, structure or land is used in violation of this Title 17 or other regulation made under authority conferred thereby, the city, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance or use, to restrain, correct or abate such violation, or to prevent the occupancy of such building, structure or land, or to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business or use in or about such premises. 
B.  The owner or general agent of a building or premises where a violation of any provision of said regulations has been committed or shall exist, or the lessee or tenant of an entire building or entire premises where such violation has been committed or shall exist, or the owner, general agent, lessee or tenant of any part of the building or premises in which such violation has been committed or shall exist, or the general agent, architect, builder, contractor or any other person who commits, takes part or assists in any such violation or who maintains any building or premises in which any such violation shall exist shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each and every day that such violation continues or by imprisonment for ten (10) days for each and every day such violation shall continue or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 82.300, RSMo, however, for the second and subsequent offenses involving the same violation at the same building or premises, the punishment shall be a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each and every day that such violation shall continue or by imprisonment for ten (10) days for each and every day such violation shall continue or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. 
C.  Any such person who having been served with an order to remove any such violation shall fall to comply with such order within ten days after such service or shall continue to violate any provision of Title 17 in the respect named in such order shall also be subject to a civil penalty of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. 7500 § 1 (part), 2002)
